description: Apple Certified Support Professional (ACSP) certification confirms the candidate's understanding of macOS's core functionality as well as having the ability to configure key services, perform basic troubleshooting, and support multiple users with essential macOS capabilities. Candidates for this course may be in a role of help desk professional, technical coordinator, or power user who supports macOS users, manages networks, or provides technical support for the Mac.

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:03.847
[SOUND] In this segment,
we're gonna take a look at

2
00:00:03.847 --> 00:00:09.219
the Apple Certified Support Professional
training here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:09.219 --> 00:00:10.826
Now the ACSP's been around a while, and

4
00:00:10.826 --> 00:00:12.580
this is not the first
time we've filmed it.

5
00:00:12.580 --> 00:00:17.305
This is actually the updated version for
MacOS Sierra or OS 10.12.

6
00:00:17.305 --> 00:00:20.820
Now the ACSP, if you've never heard of it,
is the certification that is designed

7
00:00:20.820 --> 00:00:25.710
really for anybody who has to support
Apple computers in the workplace.

8
00:00:25.710 --> 00:00:28.680
We are seeing Apples market
share grow year after year.

9
00:00:28.680 --> 00:00:32.858
More and more people are using
MacBook Pros, iMacs, Mac Minis and

10
00:00:32.858 --> 00:00:37.276
we're seeing them not just at home but
in the workplace environment.

11
00:00:37.276 --> 00:00:41.370
And so what the Apple certifies for
professional design to do is to help, you,

12
00:00:41.370 --> 00:00:45.587
any system administrator that's out there
who's gotta be able to support these

13
00:00:45.587 --> 00:00:47.218
devices in a corporate world.

14
00:00:47.218 --> 00:00:50.205
Now, I keep saying that in
the business like corporate side.

15
00:00:50.205 --> 00:00:53.930
The reason I mention that is a lot
of what we learn applies home users

16
00:00:53.930 --> 00:00:55.720
as well as business users but

17
00:00:55.720 --> 00:00:58.830
there are certain things that are really
our focus on the business site.

18
00:00:58.830 --> 00:01:02.180
Like doing streamline
deployments of applications or

19
00:01:02.180 --> 00:01:06.510
managing, restricting when applications
can either run on a particular device.

20
00:01:06.510 --> 00:01:09.940
Being able to control that type of
functionality is really important

21
00:01:09.940 --> 00:01:12.870
to successfully managing
Macs in the workplace.

22
00:01:12.870 --> 00:01:16.130
But even for home use, there's a lot of
advanced features, like multiple user

23
00:01:16.130 --> 00:01:20.210
accounts, and disk encryption that a lot
of people just don't take advantage of.

24
00:01:20.210 --> 00:01:23.710
And they're a check mark away from
actually enabling some great feature to

25
00:01:23.710 --> 00:01:27.410
protect their information,
if they only know it's there.

26
00:01:27.410 --> 00:01:30.120
So if you find yourself in that position
where you're now responsible for

27
00:01:30.120 --> 00:01:32.180
supporting Apple computers
in the workplace or

28
00:01:32.180 --> 00:01:36.000
at home, the ACSP is really
a great certification for you.

29
00:01:36.000 --> 00:01:37.710
Lets take a look in
the certification itself.

30
00:01:37.710 --> 00:01:40.726
I've got an Apple's web page pulled
up here and on their Training and

31
00:01:40.726 --> 00:01:44.377
Certification web page you'll see what
they got a few different certifications.

32
00:01:44.377 --> 00:01:47.595
The ACSP falls on the IT
professional certifications, so

33
00:01:47.595 --> 00:01:48.990
if we browse into there.

34
00:01:48.990 --> 00:01:52.250
You'll see that they've only got two
certifications that have been updated for

35
00:01:52.250 --> 00:01:53.910
MacOS Sierra, so far.

36
00:01:53.910 --> 00:01:57.130
They haven't announced any plans to
update some of their other ones.

37
00:01:57.130 --> 00:01:59.730
There's Mac Management Basics,
is another one, and

38
00:01:59.730 --> 00:02:02.390
the Apple-Certified Technical Coordinator.

39
00:02:02.390 --> 00:02:04.055
Those haven't been updated to Sierra yet.

40
00:02:04.055 --> 00:02:05.795
I'm not sure if those
are coming in the future.

41
00:02:05.795 --> 00:02:07.675
They haven't announced any plans on it.

42
00:02:07.675 --> 00:02:10.975
But right now,
we've got the Mac Integration Basics,

43
00:02:10.975 --> 00:02:14.195
which we've already filmed as
a separate series, and the ACSP,

44
00:02:14.195 --> 00:02:17.102
which is what we're focusing
on here in this series.

45
00:02:17.102 --> 00:02:18.762
Now, the certification is the ACSP.

46
00:02:18.762 --> 00:02:21.172
They have an exam that's tied to it.

47
00:02:21.172 --> 00:02:23.412
You pass the exam,
you get the certification.

48
00:02:23.412 --> 00:02:28.167
The exam itself is called
MacOS Support Essentials 10.12.

49
00:02:28.167 --> 00:02:32.332
You'll hear people refer to this
certification in the exam by both names.

50
00:02:32.332 --> 00:02:35.392
So it gets a little bit confusing but
they're both referring to the same thing.

51
00:02:35.392 --> 00:02:38.552
The exam has one name,
the certification has a different name.

52
00:02:38.552 --> 00:02:42.640
And the reason for that Is there's
a second course that hasn't been updated

53
00:02:42.640 --> 00:02:44.380
yet, that also grants the ACSP.

54
00:02:44.380 --> 00:02:47.130
There's two different
exams that get the ACSP.

55
00:02:47.130 --> 00:02:49.660
That's why we have these different names.

56
00:02:49.660 --> 00:02:53.950
Now the exam itself is a computer-based,
proctored exam.

57
00:02:53.950 --> 00:02:57.400
You do have to take it at
an Apple-authorized training provider.

58
00:02:57.400 --> 00:02:58.400
They've got a link right here,

59
00:02:58.400 --> 00:03:01.160
to find an Apple-authorized
training provider near you.

60
00:03:01.160 --> 00:03:04.510
Anybody can take the course, anybody can
learn the material, it's really useful

61
00:03:04.510 --> 00:03:07.910
information to learn and it'll help you
manage those devices in your environment.

62
00:03:07.910 --> 00:03:09.410
But if you wanna take the exam,

63
00:03:09.410 --> 00:03:12.470
you do have to go down to
an authorized training provider.

64
00:03:12.470 --> 00:03:13.450
Then the exam itself,

65
00:03:13.450 --> 00:03:17.115
if you click on the Exam Preparation Guide
it'll tell you about it.

66
00:03:17.115 --> 00:03:21.755
Basically, what it boils down to
is a pretty straightforward exam.

67
00:03:21.755 --> 00:03:25.915
It has 80 technical questions that
you have to two hours to complete.

68
00:03:25.915 --> 00:03:27.832
So you've got plenty
of time to go through.

69
00:03:27.832 --> 00:03:30.002
The majority of the questions
are multiple choice.

70
00:03:30.002 --> 00:03:33.712
So you read the question, you choose the
best answer, you move onto the next one.

71
00:03:33.712 --> 00:03:36.552
A passing score is 75% or higher.

72
00:03:36.552 --> 00:03:39.600
So it's actually not really that hard.

73
00:03:39.600 --> 00:03:42.140
As long as you've studied,
you've learned the material, and

74
00:03:42.140 --> 00:03:45.610
you understand the concepts, you'll find
that the exam is not that challenging.

75
00:03:45.610 --> 00:03:47.700
Well, what are the concepts?

76
00:03:47.700 --> 00:03:48.390
There's a lot.

77
00:03:48.390 --> 00:03:50.780
That's really the biggest
challenge with the certification,

78
00:03:50.780 --> 00:03:54.040
is there is a ton of information
buried inside of it.

79
00:03:54.040 --> 00:03:56.340
For example, we start with
installation and configuration.

80
00:03:56.340 --> 00:03:59.450
Just getting MacOS Sierra up and
running on a system.

81
00:03:59.450 --> 00:04:05.080
From there, you move on to the next
area which is User Accounts, right.

82
00:04:05.080 --> 00:04:06.870
Actually getting user accounts
set up in the system,

83
00:04:06.870 --> 00:04:09.800
managing more than one user account
on an individual Individual system.

84
00:04:09.800 --> 00:04:11.810
We go on to talk about printer sharing.

85
00:04:11.810 --> 00:04:14.930
We talk about joining directories,
managing security.

86
00:04:14.930 --> 00:04:16.370
Then you'll see if I scroll to this,

87
00:04:16.370 --> 00:04:18.860
it just goes on and on and
on all the different areas.

88
00:04:18.860 --> 00:04:20.520
And I say like it's a bad thing.

89
00:04:20.520 --> 00:04:21.550
It goes on and on and on.

90
00:04:21.550 --> 00:04:22.580
It's not a bad thing.

91
00:04:22.580 --> 00:04:26.800
It's just that there is a lot that you
can do inside of MacOS especially in

92
00:04:26.800 --> 00:04:30.130
a business environment that if you take
advantage of all these features, you can

93
00:04:30.130 --> 00:04:34.860
really have a very powerful system and
make it very easy to manage and support.

94
00:04:34.860 --> 00:04:39.440
And that's really the key thing here to
remember is the target audience for this.

95
00:04:39.440 --> 00:04:41.770
The target audience for
this is not the end-user, right?

96
00:04:41.770 --> 00:04:44.340
A lot of this is information an end user
is not going to have to deal with on any

97
00:04:44.340 --> 00:04:45.350
regular basis.

98
00:04:45.350 --> 00:04:49.160
This is desktop support engineers and
system administrators who are responsible

99
00:04:49.160 --> 00:04:52.230
for managing Apple
devices in the workplace.

100
00:04:52.230 --> 00:04:55.950
And really it's focused on
the OS X devices, not iOS,

101
00:04:55.950 --> 00:04:57.650
we talk about iOS in another series.

102
00:04:57.650 --> 00:05:02.501
But in the OS X world, we're talking
about MacBooks, MacBook Pros,

103
00:05:02.501 --> 00:05:05.910
MacBook Air, iMacs, Mac Pros, Mac Minis.

104
00:05:05.910 --> 00:05:08.630
All of those devices run OS X and

105
00:05:08.630 --> 00:05:11.890
Mac OS Sierra has introduced some new
features that are pretty exciting.

106
00:05:11.890 --> 00:05:14.470
And we need to make sure we
understand how to manage those, and

107
00:05:14.470 --> 00:05:16.710
how to control the devices
in our environment.

108
00:05:16.710 --> 00:05:22.080
Now, if you are just getting started with
MacOS, this is actually a great place.

109
00:05:22.080 --> 00:05:23.800
We run through it really
from the beginning and

110
00:05:23.800 --> 00:05:25.390
move into the advanced features.

111
00:05:25.390 --> 00:05:26.450
If you're an expert,

112
00:05:26.450 --> 00:05:29.210
you've been working with it a long time,
it's still a great series to run

113
00:05:29.210 --> 00:05:31.720
through cuz you're gonna learn about some
of the new features found in Sierra.

114
00:05:31.720 --> 00:05:34.930
And you'll find that there's a lot of
the old features that are still the same,

115
00:05:34.930 --> 00:05:37.270
that you kinda maintain
the same skill set and

116
00:05:37.270 --> 00:05:39.450
are able to continue
to support the system.

117
00:05:39.450 --> 00:05:41.920
Now there is another course that we have
in our course library I wanna make you

118
00:05:41.920 --> 00:05:44.120
aware of, which is Mac Integration Basics.

119
00:05:44.120 --> 00:05:46.690
Mac Integration Basics focuses on

120
00:05:46.690 --> 00:05:50.500
connecting Macs to
a Microsoft Windows network.

121
00:05:50.500 --> 00:05:51.510
In the business world,

122
00:05:51.510 --> 00:05:54.430
you'll find that Microsoft Windows
has the dominant market share.

123
00:05:54.430 --> 00:05:56.990
So normally when we deploy Macs
in a business environment,

124
00:05:56.990 --> 00:05:59.200
we gotta get them talking
to a Windows network.

125
00:05:59.200 --> 00:06:01.340
And that's what Mac
integration basics tackles.

126
00:06:01.340 --> 00:06:03.960
So if you're the person that's out there
in the field that's actually trying to

127
00:06:03.960 --> 00:06:06.970
make these Macs work in a business,
you'll find that other course,

128
00:06:06.970 --> 00:06:09.740
Mac Integration Basics is
pretty beneficial too.

129
00:06:09.740 --> 00:06:12.390
But I would recommend
completing this one first.

130
00:06:12.390 --> 00:06:14.810
This course is gonna show
you how to manage MacOS,

131
00:06:14.810 --> 00:06:18.470
how to work with the operating system to
get it functioning right before we start

132
00:06:18.470 --> 00:06:20.940
integrated it into Windows,
which is a really handy thing to have.

133
00:06:20.940 --> 00:06:23.300
So this is a great place to start,
right here.

134
00:06:23.300 --> 00:06:26.050
If you already have this requisite
knowledge though, and you're just looking

135
00:06:26.050 --> 00:06:29.160
for that Windows compatibility side,
jump over to Mac Integration Basics.

136
00:06:29.160 --> 00:06:32.590
I think you'll find what you want there,
a little more in detail.

137
00:06:32.590 --> 00:06:34.540
All right,
well if this all sounds exciting to you,

138
00:06:34.540 --> 00:06:36.430
something you wanna learn,
you're in the right place.

139
00:06:36.430 --> 00:06:37.080
Stay tuned,

140
00:06:37.080 --> 00:06:40.730
cuz Mac Integration Basics is, or sorry,
I gotta get my certification right.

141
00:06:40.730 --> 00:06:43.570
Apple Certified Support Professional
is coming up right after this, but

142
00:06:43.570 --> 00:06:46.500
do remember Mac Integration Basics
is part of the course library and

143
00:06:46.500 --> 00:06:48.230
is part of your ITProTV subscription.

144
00:06:48.230 --> 00:06:50.350
So be sure to check that one out too.

145
00:06:50.350 --> 00:06:53.068
All right I hope you guys enjoyed it and
I'll see you in the episodes.

146
00:06:53.068 --> 00:06:53.568
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don take a look at prerequisites for getting Sierra installed. They will look at the requirements for hardware as well as the platforms that are supported by Sierra.
episodes.title: Getting Prepared
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:01.378
Welcome to ITProTV,

2
00:00:01.378 --> 00:00:05.343
I'm your host Don Pezet coming at you
live from San Francisco, California.

3
00:00:05.343 --> 00:00:10.600
[CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.150 --> 00:00:14.161
>> Hello and welcome to ITProTV,
thanks for joining us.

5
00:00:14.161 --> 00:00:17.503
I'm your host Wes Bryan and in today's
episode, we got a great show for

6
00:00:17.503 --> 00:00:18.070
you today.

7
00:00:18.070 --> 00:00:20.980
We're gonna be looking at
the Apple Certified Support Professional.

8
00:00:20.980 --> 00:00:25.210
And joining us in the studio is none
other than ITProTVs very own, Don Pizet.

9
00:00:25.210 --> 00:00:26.290
Don, how do you doing sir?

10
00:00:26.290 --> 00:00:27.268
>> I'm doing great Wes.

11
00:00:27.268 --> 00:00:31.420
Ready to kick off a new series and we're
jumping into well ACSP like Wes said and

12
00:00:31.420 --> 00:00:34.100
specifically taking
a look at macOS Sierra.

13
00:00:34.100 --> 00:00:37.690
That's right the ACSP has been updated
to cover our new certification then

14
00:00:37.690 --> 00:00:40.300
we need to be ready to get it
installed and up and going.

15
00:00:40.300 --> 00:00:43.303
So that's exactly where we're gonna
start right at the very beginning.

16
00:00:43.303 --> 00:00:46.037
We're gonna learn about macOS Sierra,
we need to get it installed,

17
00:00:46.037 --> 00:00:48.830
there's a few things that we need to
be aware of before we get started.

18
00:00:48.830 --> 00:00:53.176
Well the first I wanna talk about with
Sierra is understanding whether or

19
00:00:53.176 --> 00:00:55.890
not we can even run it in the first place.

20
00:00:55.890 --> 00:01:00.800
Apple is really, really good about
pushing updates out to Mac hardware

21
00:01:00.800 --> 00:01:03.565
even Mac hardware that's pretty dated,
right?

22
00:01:03.565 --> 00:01:07.789
A lot of times we'll get a MacBook or an
iMac, or a Mac Mini, and they'll run for

23
00:01:07.789 --> 00:01:09.694
years and years and years, right?

24
00:01:09.694 --> 00:01:12.794
When we buy one,
they might have a one-year warranty, but

25
00:01:12.794 --> 00:01:15.535
you can upgrade it to
a three-year with AppleCare.

26
00:01:15.535 --> 00:01:20.995
But you might find you get five, six,
seven years out of a laptop or a desktop.

27
00:01:20.995 --> 00:01:23.970
And it's not uncommon, because
the hardware's really high quality.

28
00:01:23.970 --> 00:01:27.870
Well one of the challenges other
vendors have is that after a few years

29
00:01:27.870 --> 00:01:30.670
the hardware's usually no longer
supported, you don't get updates.

30
00:01:30.670 --> 00:01:32.490
With Apple they do a good job of that, but

31
00:01:32.490 --> 00:01:35.610
it doesn't mean that we
can go all the way back.

32
00:01:35.610 --> 00:01:38.874
You're not gonna fire up
your Apple II [LAUGH] and

33
00:01:38.874 --> 00:01:40.390
install macOS Sierra on it, right?

34
00:01:40.390 --> 00:01:42.757
So there are some requirements we need
to understand whether our hardware

35
00:01:42.757 --> 00:01:43.489
is compatible or not.

36
00:01:43.489 --> 00:01:47.496
And so, I've got Apple's official tech
support page brought up here that has

37
00:01:47.496 --> 00:01:49.864
the general requirements for
macOS Sierra and

38
00:01:49.864 --> 00:01:52.870
you'll see it actually
does go back quite a ways.

39
00:01:52.870 --> 00:01:59.700
Basically the rule of thumb is if your
Mac Book came and I say Mac Book,

40
00:01:59.700 --> 00:02:05.030
it could be a Mac Pro or an iMac,
Mac Mini, any of the Mac OS devices.

41
00:02:05.030 --> 00:02:08.285
If it shipped with OS X 10.7.5 or later,

42
00:02:08.285 --> 00:02:12.133
then the odds are you'll be
able to upgrade to Sierra.

43
00:02:12.133 --> 00:02:15.007
If it shipped with 10.7.5.

44
00:02:15.007 --> 00:02:18.729
But even if it didn't ship with 10.7.5
there's a good chance you'll be able to

45
00:02:18.729 --> 00:02:21.580
upgrade, because the hardware
requirements are pretty small.

46
00:02:21.580 --> 00:02:26.630
2 gigs of memory 8.8 gigs of storage and

47
00:02:26.630 --> 00:02:29.320
just a couple of other, these are really
kind of software features, right?

48
00:02:29.320 --> 00:02:32.900
If you want to use things like iCloud
you're gonna have to have an Apple ID.

49
00:02:32.900 --> 00:02:35.270
If you want to have certain things,

50
00:02:35.270 --> 00:02:37.890
well again like iCloud,
you need internet access, right?

51
00:02:37.890 --> 00:02:40.780
So those aren't really hardware
requirements, that's just software.

52
00:02:40.780 --> 00:02:45.410
But on the hardware side, 2 gigs of
memory, 8.8 gigs of available storage.

53
00:02:45.410 --> 00:02:49.610
Now this has changed a little bit
from El Capitan which only required 8

54
00:02:49.610 --> 00:02:50.310
gigs of storage.

55
00:02:50.310 --> 00:02:53.830
It's grown a bit and
really largely you can thank Siri and

56
00:02:53.830 --> 00:02:55.370
a few other new features for that.

57
00:02:55.370 --> 00:02:57.040
They consume a little more disk space.

58
00:02:57.040 --> 00:03:01.530
But in today's day and age 8.8 gigs
is a laughable amount of storage so

59
00:03:01.530 --> 00:03:04.360
it's not a huge amount that
we need to have there.

60
00:03:04.360 --> 00:03:07.880
Another thing that they don't list
anymore is that you do need to have

61
00:03:07.880 --> 00:03:09.290
an Intel processor.

62
00:03:09.290 --> 00:03:12.320
They don't make a macOS Sierra for
PowerPC.

63
00:03:12.320 --> 00:03:14.600
PowerPC systems are no longer supported.

64
00:03:14.600 --> 00:03:17.220
In fact, not even all the Intel
systems are supported.

65
00:03:17.220 --> 00:03:20.640
If I scroll down a little bit here,
you'll see the minimum requirements, and

66
00:03:20.640 --> 00:03:23.700
the cut-off date is really 2009.

67
00:03:23.700 --> 00:03:28.440
Anything manufactured before 2009
is not supported for macOS Sierra.

68
00:03:28.440 --> 00:03:31.350
But you'll see if you have
a MacBook late 2009 or

69
00:03:31.350 --> 00:03:35.760
newer, an iMac late 2009 or
newer you're gonna be good to go.

but I'm gonna say --application path.

513
00:26:20.020 --> 00:26:28.959
And then I'm gonna point it to
/applications/installMacOsSierra.app.

514
00:26:28.959 --> 00:26:32.670
All right, this time I'm not going to
point to anything inside of it, though.

515
00:26:32.670 --> 00:26:36.030
I'm just pointing to
the actual application.

516
00:26:36.030 --> 00:26:39.225
And then, last I'm gonna add one
more thing here to the end which is

517
00:26:39.225 --> 00:26:42.250
--nointeraction.

518
00:26:42.250 --> 00:26:45.890
There's actually a couple of questions
that can pop up when you build a media,

519
00:26:45.890 --> 00:26:48.110
like it asks you to accept license and
all that.

520
00:26:48.110 --> 00:26:51.550
And by saying no interaction, I'm
telling it, hey, don't ask me questions.

521
00:26:51.550 --> 00:26:55.930
Just build the media and
get it done, so --nointeraction.

522
00:26:55.930 --> 00:27:00.370
And when I run that, it's going to ask
me for my password, because I use SUDO,

523
00:27:00.370 --> 00:27:03.230
because I'm running this
as an administrator.

524
00:27:03.230 --> 00:27:06.110
I've gotta give it that permission,
and here it goes.

525
00:27:06.110 --> 00:27:07.810
Now, it's erasing the disk.

526
00:27:07.810 --> 00:27:08.590
And you might ask yourself,

527
00:27:08.590 --> 00:27:12.220
well Don, didn't we waste our time
erasing the disk a minute ago?

528
00:27:12.220 --> 00:27:13.830
And the short answer here is no.

529
00:27:13.830 --> 00:27:16.550
It's erasing the disk,
it's not repartitioning it, right?

530
00:27:16.550 --> 00:27:19.860
So if there were extra partitions,
what we did would've wiped those out.

531
00:27:19.860 --> 00:27:21.884
This is just kind of erasing
what's already there, so

532
00:27:21.884 --> 00:27:23.560
it's making sure it's in the right format.

533
00:27:23.560 --> 00:27:27.684
It's gonna change it's name so
won't be called untitled anymore right,

534
00:27:27.684 --> 00:27:30.370
now it's gonna be called something else.

535
00:27:30.370 --> 00:27:33.330
And now it's copying
the files to the disk.

536
00:27:33.330 --> 00:27:37.251
Now this copy operation it can take
a while right, I've got a USB3

537
00:27:37.251 --> 00:27:41.609
thumb drive here and it's plugging in
one of the USB3 ports on my laptop.

538
00:27:41.609 --> 00:27:44.770
So, it shouldn't take too long,
maybe four or five minutes.

539
00:27:44.770 --> 00:27:47.890
But, if you're on USB 2.0,
this can take half an hour.

540
00:27:47.890 --> 00:27:50.800
It could take a long time, so, be patient.

541
00:27:50.800 --> 00:27:55.035
Kickback, relax, twiddle your thumbs, take
up a hobby, or whatever it is that you do.

542
00:27:55.035 --> 00:27:59.900
And when it's done, you'll now have a USB
key that you can use to boot up, really,

543
00:27:59.900 --> 00:28:02.850
any Mac, and
start the MacOS Sierra install.

544
00:28:02.850 --> 00:28:06.340
You can do upgrades and
clean installs from this USB key.

545
00:28:06.340 --> 00:28:08.460
It's a great idea to have
one of these on hand,

546
00:28:08.460 --> 00:28:14.350
because Apple doesn't ship install media
with any device anymore, no device, right?

547
00:28:14.350 --> 00:28:16.140
So it doesn't matter whether
you're buying a laptop,

548
00:28:16.140 --> 00:28:20.200
a desktop, any of them, they don't
come with the DVDs like they used to.

549
00:28:20.200 --> 00:28:23.510
So this is the only way that we
can get media to do the install.

550
00:28:23.510 --> 00:28:25.760
It's a good idea to have at
least one of these on hand.

551
00:28:25.760 --> 00:28:28.632
And we'll even talk about it in later
episodes about how truly useful to

552
00:28:28.632 --> 00:28:29.800
troubleshooting too.

553
00:28:29.800 --> 00:28:32.330
If you think you have a failed hard drive,

554
00:28:32.330 --> 00:28:34.430
how are you gonna boot your system up and
check?

555
00:28:34.430 --> 00:28:38.710
Well, you could boot off of a USB key and
then access the diagnostic utilities and

556
00:28:38.710 --> 00:28:41.460
test the hard drive, erase the hard drive,
see if that fixes it.

557
00:28:41.460 --> 00:28:44.790
But if you don't have that media to boot
from, you're gonna be out of luck, right.

558
00:28:44.790 --> 00:28:48.790
So definitely something that
you want to have handy.

559
00:28:48.790 --> 00:28:50.060
>> Lot of great information there Don.

560
00:28:50.060 --> 00:28:52.594
We're gonna have to have an operating
system if we're gonna support it, so

561
00:28:52.594 --> 00:28:53.791
thanks for helping us get started.

562
00:28:53.791 --> 00:28:55.069
But looking at the time clock,

563
00:28:55.069 --> 00:28:57.932
it does look like we've come to
the end of another great episode Don.

564
00:28:57.932 --> 00:29:00.669
But before we do when it
comes to getting started for

565
00:29:00.669 --> 00:29:04.760
the first time in our Mac Sierra
here do you got any parting words?

566
00:29:04.760 --> 00:29:06.480
>> All right well, you know,
remember what we saw in this episode.

567
00:29:06.480 --> 00:29:09.616
We got a chance to see figuring out
whether our equipment could even support

568
00:29:09.616 --> 00:29:12.168
Mac OS Sierra and then we built
the install media for Sierra.

569
00:29:12.168 --> 00:29:14.620
It's still running here in
the background it'll be done eventually.

570
00:29:14.620 --> 00:29:17.720
What we're gonna do in the next
episode is we're gonna pick up right

571
00:29:17.720 --> 00:29:18.580
here where we left off.

572
00:29:18.580 --> 00:29:20.090
We're gonna take this install media and

573
00:29:20.090 --> 00:29:22.560
we're actually gonna install
Mac OS Sierra on a system.

574
00:29:22.560 --> 00:29:25.400
So I know we're kind of leaving you
hanging here in this episode but

575
00:29:25.400 --> 00:29:26.720
it all falls in place, right?

576
00:29:26.720 --> 00:29:28.750
These are all the early setup steps.

577
00:29:28.750 --> 00:29:31.780
In the next episode we'll
actually get to the true install.

578
00:29:31.780 --> 00:29:33.890
>> All right, well that's a great
place to call this one a wrap.

579
00:29:33.890 --> 00:29:36.040
We appreciate it as always,
Don, you being with us.

580
00:29:36.040 --> 00:29:37.990
And we appreciate you,
the viewer, watching.

581
00:29:37.990 --> 00:29:40.330
Signing out for
ITPro.TV I've been your host Wes Bryan.

582
00:29:40.330 --> 00:29:41.470
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

583
00:29:41.470 --> 00:29:42.733
>> And we'll see you next time.

584
00:29:42.733 --> 00:29:49.325
[MUSIC]

585
00:29:49.325 --> 00:29:52.452
Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don walk the viewer through the process of installing Sierra on a Mac supported device. They talk about some of the considerations as well as the various options that are available when installing the operating system.
episodes.title: Installing macOS Sierra
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.940 --> 00:00:05.988
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:05.988 --> 00:00:07.261
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.261 --> 00:00:10.590
[MUSIC]
>> You are watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.200 --> 00:00:13.945
>> Hello and welcome to ITProTV.

5
00:00:13.945 --> 00:00:15.393
I'm your host Wes Bryan thanks for
tuning in.

6
00:00:15.393 --> 00:00:17.060
We gotta great show for you today.

7
00:00:17.060 --> 00:00:20.104
We're gonna be looking at the Apple
certified support professional.

8
00:00:20.104 --> 00:00:23.035
And joining us back in the studio is
none other than is mister Don Pezet.

9
00:00:23.035 --> 00:00:24.465
Don, how are we doing to day, sir?

10
00:00:24.465 --> 00:00:25.415
>> I'm doing great Wes.

11
00:00:25.415 --> 00:00:27.115
Ready to dive back in and

12
00:00:27.115 --> 00:00:31.410
resolve the cliff hanger on the ending
that we left on that last episode, right?

13
00:00:31.410 --> 00:00:32.500
>> If you didn't watch last episode,

14
00:00:32.500 --> 00:00:37.100
we talked about how to make sure that
our hardware supported MacOS Sierra.

15
00:00:37.100 --> 00:00:40.517
And all the steps we needed to go through
to get ready to do the MacOS Sierra

16
00:00:40.517 --> 00:00:41.199
deployment.

17
00:00:41.199 --> 00:00:46.455
And we ended the episode by building
a USB installer for MacOS Sierra.

18
00:00:46.455 --> 00:00:48.930
So I left that running right
there at the end of the episode.

19
00:00:48.930 --> 00:00:50.790
And it took about 10 minutes.

20
00:00:50.790 --> 00:00:54.219
And once it was done I now
have this USB key, right?

21
00:00:54.219 --> 00:00:56.420
All I did was pop it out of my laptop and
that's it.

22
00:00:56.420 --> 00:01:00.470
So now we're gonna take this USB key and
we're actually gonna use it, right?

23
00:01:00.470 --> 00:01:03.750
We're gonna stick it into a machine and
perform the Sierra update.

24
00:01:03.750 --> 00:01:07.379
All right, now I've got a Mac Mini sitting
on the table here in front of me and

25
00:01:07.379 --> 00:01:10.573
I pulled this from one of our back
closets before the show started.

26
00:01:10.573 --> 00:01:14.210
I actually don't know much about
this Mac Mini really at all.

27
00:01:14.210 --> 00:01:18.710
So I don't trust a machine
that I didn't set up myself so

28
00:01:18.710 --> 00:01:22.590
I want to erase it and get a good,
clean installation on there.

29
00:01:22.590 --> 00:01:25.911
Well if it was running El Capitan,
or Yosemite, or whatever,

30
00:01:25.911 --> 00:01:28.992
I could fire up the app store and
do the in-place upgrade.

31
00:01:28.992 --> 00:01:30.079
No big deal, right?

32
00:01:30.079 --> 00:01:33.230
You go into the app store,
you click install and you upgrade.

33
00:01:33.230 --> 00:01:35.900
But because I don't trust this machine,
I want to erase it.

34
00:01:35.900 --> 00:01:41.080
I want it to be good and clean and a nice
fresh start, and I want it to be Sierra.

35
00:01:41.080 --> 00:01:43.890
And that's why I need this USB installer,
right?

36
00:01:43.890 --> 00:01:45.342
So, if you didn't watch the last episode,

37
00:01:45.342 --> 00:01:47.399
I show you how to build that USB
installer in the last episode.

38
00:01:47.399 --> 00:01:50.571
But in this episode,
we're gonna take this USB installer and

39
00:01:50.571 --> 00:01:53.450
we're actually gonna put it to use,
put it to work.

40
00:01:53.450 --> 00:01:55.340
So that's what we're starting
off here in this episode.

41
00:01:55.340 --> 00:01:58.181
So I'm gonna take this USB installer and
just install it into my Mac mini here.

42
00:01:58.181 --> 00:02:03.350
And if we watch, the Mac mini is gonna
recognize that and it's gonna mount it.

43
00:02:03.350 --> 00:02:06.469
Now, depending on how you're set up,
it may or may not show up on your desktop.

44
00:02:06.469 --> 00:02:09.705
And I'll see mine's prompting me
about doing some updates here so

45
00:02:09.705 --> 00:02:11.920
I'm gonna ignore that for right now.

46
00:02:11.920 --> 00:02:16.020
But if we take a look at it I can see
I've got this install Mac OS Sierra.

47
00:02:16.020 --> 00:02:19.104
That's what it renamed my USB key
to at the end of the last episode.

48
00:02:19.104 --> 00:02:21.501
So that install disk if we browse into it,

49
00:02:21.501 --> 00:02:25.539
it's basically got the installation file,
and it looks like, hey,

50
00:02:25.539 --> 00:02:29.920
we just drag-and-dropped the installer
right here onto the media.

51
00:02:29.920 --> 00:02:32.564
But it actually made it
a bootable partition also, so

52
00:02:32.564 --> 00:02:34.694
it's ready to boot right off of this disk.

53
00:02:34.694 --> 00:02:38.865
Now, in order to do a nice fresh and
clean install,

54
00:02:38.865 --> 00:02:41.590
I need to boot off of this USB key.

55
00:02:41.590 --> 00:02:43.729
And there's two ways to do that.

56
00:02:43.729 --> 00:02:48.317
One way is, if I have access to
the system like I do right here,

57
00:02:48.317 --> 00:02:53.320
then what I can do is,
I can go into my system preferences.

58
00:02:53.320 --> 00:02:58.830
And in your system preference,
you'll see where you can pick a boot disk.

59
00:02:58.830 --> 00:03:01.359
When you look inside of your
system preferences in here,

60
00:03:01.359 --> 00:03:05.048
you've got an option where you can specify
by which disk you're going to boot off of

61
00:03:05.048 --> 00:03:06.328
when the computer comes up.

62
00:03:06.328 --> 00:03:10.686
So you've got start up disk right here,
and inside of start up disk,

63
00:03:10.686 --> 00:03:15.650
you'll see each of the devices that
are attached and you can choose it.

64
00:03:15.650 --> 00:03:18.365
Well, if you build your media
on a disk and is supported,

65
00:03:18.365 --> 00:03:20.470
it'll show up in here and
you can choose it.

66
00:03:20.470 --> 00:03:22.350
And mine's not showing up, all right?

67
00:03:22.350 --> 00:03:23.200
Why is that?

68
00:03:23.200 --> 00:03:28.700
Well, because it's not an official
Apple supported USB cable apparently.

69
00:03:28.700 --> 00:03:31.310
If it was,
it would show up here in the list and

70
00:03:31.310 --> 00:03:34.490
I could just click on my USB key and
I can hit Restart.

71
00:03:34.490 --> 00:03:36.537
Now, mine's not showing up,
so am I out of luck?

72
00:03:36.537 --> 00:03:37.700
No.

73
00:03:37.700 --> 00:03:39.820
I just have to go about it
a slightly different way.

74
00:03:39.820 --> 00:03:42.810
If your disk doesn't show up here,
then you can't do the easy,

75
00:03:42.810 --> 00:03:44.460
automated way to tell it to restart.

76
00:03:44.460 --> 00:03:47.410
Instead, what you're gonna
have to do is shut down and

77
00:03:47.410 --> 00:03:53.470
when you boot up the Mac if you hold
the option key on your keyboard,

78
00:03:53.470 --> 00:03:56.860
while you're holding the option
key it'll display a boot menu.

79
00:03:56.860 --> 00:04:01.530
And it'll show your hard drive and
any removable media alongside it.

80
00:04:01.530 --> 00:04:03.835
Right here on this screen I'm
only seeing my hard drive but

81
00:04:03.835 --> 00:04:06.626
when I get to my options screen here
in a minute, we'll see a lot more.

82
00:04:06.626 --> 00:04:08.970
All right, so
that's what I'm gonna have to do.

83
00:04:08.970 --> 00:04:11.130
So what I'm gonna do is
I'm gonna turn my Mac off.

84
00:04:11.130 --> 00:04:14.071
Now when I do that, because of
the way I share my screen and stuff,

85
00:04:14.071 --> 00:04:17.408
it's gonna make the screen go blank,
which kind of makes sense, right?

86
00:04:17.408 --> 00:04:19.771
So, [LAUGH] I'm shutting it down.

87
00:04:19.771 --> 00:04:21.490
So we'll shut this one down.

88
00:04:21.490 --> 00:04:25.240
And after it's shut down,
my screen's gonna blank out, okay?

89
00:04:25.240 --> 00:04:27.900
So I'm gonna get a blank screen,
very exciting.

90
00:04:27.900 --> 00:04:30.490
And I'm gonna hold down
option on my keyboard.

91
00:04:30.490 --> 00:04:33.345
Now, one thing I do wanna point out is
I've got a wireless keyboard, right.

92
00:04:33.345 --> 00:04:37.440
But the fun part here
is it actually works.

93
00:04:37.440 --> 00:04:40.920
The wireless connectivity on
the wireless keyboard is Bluetooth but

94
00:04:40.920 --> 00:04:43.742
it connects even before
the operating system fires up.

95
00:04:43.742 --> 00:04:47.470
So I'm gonna hold down
the option key here.

96
00:04:47.470 --> 00:04:50.960
And I'm gonna push power
button on my Mac and

97
00:04:50.960 --> 00:04:54.130
I just heard the Mac tone, so
I know that it's starting up.

98
00:04:54.130 --> 00:04:57.445
I'm holding down the option key, so
it's gonna start the boot process and

99
00:04:57.445 --> 00:05:01.248
I'm not gonna see much on my screen right
away while it's starting the boot process.

100
00:05:01.248 --> 00:05:05.440
But then, I'm gonna get this.

101
00:05:05.440 --> 00:05:07.330
Normally when you boot,
you see the Apple logo,

102
00:05:07.330 --> 00:05:10.630
and there's a little status bar
that goes across the bottom, right?

103
00:05:10.630 --> 00:05:13.120
Well here,
it's not gotten to that point yet.

104
00:05:13.120 --> 00:05:14.290
When you see the Apple logo and

105
00:05:14.290 --> 00:05:17.990
the status bar moving, that means it's
already booting the operating system.

106
00:05:17.990 --> 00:05:21.318
Because I held the option button,
I see the boot options, so

107
00:05:21.318 --> 00:05:24.854
I can pick which drive I wanna boot from,
and I see three drives.

108
00:05:24.854 --> 00:05:29.260
Now that's interesting, because a minute
ago, I had the Macintosh hard drive.

109
00:05:29.260 --> 00:05:31.580
And I know I added my USB key.

110
00:05:31.580 --> 00:05:33.660
What the heck is the third option?

111
00:05:33.660 --> 00:05:36.740
Well, what you're gonna see is
your main hard drive, right?

112
00:05:36.740 --> 00:05:40.042
So Mac HD, whatever,
we expect to see that one, right?

113
00:05:40.042 --> 00:05:44.270
And then next to it is
a recovery partition.

114
00:05:44.270 --> 00:05:47.240
Now, you should have a recovery
partition on your Mac.

115
00:05:47.240 --> 00:05:50.509
There's really only one or two scenarios
where you might be missing it.

116
00:05:51.700 --> 00:05:56.430
Scenario one, is your hard drive failed,
and so you just put in a new hard drive.

117
00:05:56.430 --> 00:05:59.060
A brand new hard drive is
gonna be completely blank.

118
00:05:59.060 --> 00:06:02.050
It won't have a recovery partition on it,
and so it won't show up.

119
00:06:02.050 --> 00:06:05.390
But it also won't show up as a bootable
option, cuz it's completely blank.

120
00:06:05.390 --> 00:06:07.450
So both of these would be missing.

121
00:06:07.450 --> 00:06:12.148
The other option though, is where somebody
else may have erased the Mac, in the past.

122
00:06:12.148 --> 00:06:15.859
And when they erased it,
they may not have known to leave room for

123
00:06:15.859 --> 00:06:19.250
the recovery partition, and
so one didn't get created.

124
00:06:19.250 --> 00:06:24.070
And so you might just see Macintosh HD and
your USB drive, and that's it.

125
00:06:24.070 --> 00:06:25.164
You might not see a recovery partition.

126
00:06:25.164 --> 00:06:28.620
Now what is a recovery partition?

127
00:06:28.620 --> 00:06:32.170
Well, we're about to boot off this
USB key and when I boot off of it,

128
00:06:32.170 --> 00:06:36.710
it's gonna load a miniature version of MAC
OS, not the full blown version of MAC OS,

129
00:06:36.710 --> 00:06:38.590
just a small version of it, all right.

130
00:06:38.590 --> 00:06:40.557
And when it boots that
small version of it,

131
00:06:40.557 --> 00:06:44.550
I can then take actions like repairing the
MAC, diagnosing problems, formatting and

132
00:06:44.550 --> 00:06:46.754
installing MAC OS,
all those things, right.

133
00:06:46.754 --> 00:06:50.662
And that's great if I have a USB key but
what if I don't have a USB key?

134
00:06:50.662 --> 00:06:55.270
Well Apple creates a recovery partition
right there on the hard drive too.

135
00:06:55.270 --> 00:06:56.351
So I can always boot to that and

136
00:06:56.351 --> 00:06:58.614
use it right off of the hard drive
without a removal of a media.

137
00:06:58.614 --> 00:07:01.440
That doesn't help me if
the hard drive fails though.

138
00:07:01.440 --> 00:07:05.260
If the hard drive fails I
can't boot off of that, right?

139
00:07:05.260 --> 00:07:07.940
So it's always a good idea to have more
than one way to get to recovery and

140
00:07:07.940 --> 00:07:09.157
there's a few different ways.

141
00:07:09.157 --> 00:07:12.824
The USB Key method is the one that I
normally use cuz I know I can keep

142
00:07:12.824 --> 00:07:13.770
a USB Key handy.

143
00:07:13.770 --> 00:07:16.290
And even if the hard drive fails,
I know that'll work.

144
00:07:16.290 --> 00:07:19.016
But, pretty much every Mac
made in the last five years,

00:18:16.420 --> 00:18:20.870
The other thing is when I erase it,
it's only doing one partition, right or

375
00:18:20.870 --> 00:18:22.170
one that it's gonna show me, right?

376
00:18:22.170 --> 00:18:23.690
So it's gonna wipe that out, and

377
00:18:23.690 --> 00:18:27.150
then I'm just gonna have one nice
empty partition when this is done.

378
00:18:27.150 --> 00:18:30.330
So now i know that any files
that were on the disk are gone.

379
00:18:30.330 --> 00:18:33.440
If I'm worried about somebody putting
bad stuff on there, that's gone now, and

380
00:18:33.440 --> 00:18:35.010
I've got a nice empty disk.

381
00:18:35.010 --> 00:18:37.630
>> Don, when you're using the disk
utilities, are you doing this for

382
00:18:37.630 --> 00:18:41.430
security purposes and data remnants, or
are you doing it for spring cleaning, or

383
00:18:41.430 --> 00:18:45.510
is it just for customization, just so
you're controlling exactly how

384
00:18:45.510 --> 00:18:48.340
that disk gets formatted prior to
putting the operating system on it.

385
00:18:48.340 --> 00:18:50.100
>> That's really all of the above, tight?

386
00:18:50.100 --> 00:18:55.010
When you do an upgrade, remnant files,
files from the previous OS, stay there.

387
00:18:55.010 --> 00:18:57.190
And so if there were malicious files or
infected files,

388
00:18:57.190 --> 00:19:00.710
they stay there That's not all that
common on a Mac, but it can happen.

389
00:19:00.710 --> 00:19:05.100
Or just junked up file preferences, from
applications that you want to go away,

390
00:19:05.100 --> 00:19:07.020
that they would stay there on an upgrade.

391
00:19:07.020 --> 00:19:11.390
By erasing the drive,
I make sure that all that data is gone.

392
00:19:11.390 --> 00:19:16.220
And in fact, if I click on the disk,
I can see that it is empty.

393
00:19:16.220 --> 00:19:17.540
There's nothing in there.

394
00:19:17.540 --> 00:19:21.140
It's not named Macintosh HD anymore,
I should probably rename that.

395
00:19:21.140 --> 00:19:22.150
But otherwise, nice and empty.

396
00:19:22.150 --> 00:19:23.520
I know all of that is gone.

397
00:19:23.520 --> 00:19:27.830
So, for security, for spring cleaning,
for control, it's all there.

398
00:19:27.830 --> 00:19:30.820
The only thing I didn't do was
partitioning and you'll see up here I do

399
00:19:30.820 --> 00:19:35.110
have the option where I could partition
it out and divide it up into sub disks.

400
00:19:35.110 --> 00:19:38.160
But again I don't normally do that on
these disks cuz it's just not a ton of

401
00:19:38.160 --> 00:19:40.330
benefit as long as you're not
gonna run it out of space.

402
00:19:40.330 --> 00:19:42.160
>> Well Don you could
do the installer right?

403
00:19:42.160 --> 00:19:45.890
If I understand this right and you can let
the installer go ahead and do all this but

404
00:19:45.890 --> 00:19:48.870
you would lose all this that
flexibility and that control, right?

405
00:19:48.870 --> 00:19:51.450
>> Well Wes, you can use the installer,
but it doesn't give you a lot of options.

406
00:19:51.450 --> 00:19:54.220
So like if I wanted a partition, you
don't have that option in the installer.

407
00:19:54.220 --> 00:19:57.700
If you want a partition, you're going
to have to go to Disk Utility to do it.

408
00:19:57.700 --> 00:20:01.120
And as far as erasing the drive, when
you do the installer if you choose to do

409
00:20:01.120 --> 00:20:04.540
an upgrade, it doesn't give you the option
to erase cuz you're upgrading, right?

410
00:20:04.540 --> 00:20:05.960
So that's a problem there.

411
00:20:05.960 --> 00:20:08.200
So there are times you'll need
to drop to the Disk Utility.

412
00:20:08.200 --> 00:20:09.610
And some of this can get changed later.

413
00:20:09.610 --> 00:20:13.500
So for example, partitioning If
you decided to do Boot Camp later.

414
00:20:13.500 --> 00:20:17.300
Boot Camp will actually partition the
drive out to make room for Windows to run.

415
00:20:17.300 --> 00:20:18.670
If you don't know about Boot Camp,

416
00:20:18.670 --> 00:20:21.890
it lets you run Microsoft Windows
right on your Apple hardware.

417
00:20:21.890 --> 00:20:23.620
You obviously wanna keep
Mac OS too though, so

418
00:20:23.620 --> 00:20:26.180
it uses partitions to create
a Windows hard drive and

419
00:20:26.180 --> 00:20:30.750
a Mac OS hard drive, right, basically two
virtual hard drives on one physical disk.

420
00:20:30.750 --> 00:20:33.680
All right, so let's say that I
wanted to set up partitions, tight.

421
00:20:33.680 --> 00:20:37.590
Well, I would come in here
to my Disk Utility and

422
00:20:37.590 --> 00:20:40.050
notice the partition button at
the top is kinda grayed out.

423
00:20:40.050 --> 00:20:42.310
That's because I'm clicked on a partition.

424
00:20:42.310 --> 00:20:44.920
But if you click on
the physical disk itself,

425
00:20:44.920 --> 00:20:48.470
now the partition button lights up and
you can click on that and

426
00:20:48.470 --> 00:20:53.900
you can come in here and you can define
a partition and set the size, right.

427
00:20:53.900 --> 00:20:57.760
So right now, it's one big disk,
right, for this untitled partition.

428
00:20:57.760 --> 00:21:00.830
And so I'm gonna change that
to be called Macintosh HD,

429
00:21:00.830 --> 00:21:04.710
which is really just a really old name
that's been around for a long time.

430
00:21:04.710 --> 00:21:06.470
People are kinda used to
calling the disk that.

431
00:21:06.470 --> 00:21:11.700
But down here, I can hit the plus sign,
and I can start to create more partitions.

432
00:21:11.700 --> 00:21:16.210
So I might want to create
a partition called you know data or

433
00:21:16.210 --> 00:21:17.680
storage or whatever right.

434
00:21:17.680 --> 00:21:19.410
This is gonna be where I can
put my personal stuff and

435
00:21:19.410 --> 00:21:23.130
as you build it you'll see there's
this little white dot here and so

436
00:21:23.130 --> 00:21:27.140
you can resize and change things
based on what you want right?

437
00:21:27.140 --> 00:21:32.000
And it won't let you go too crazy on
these because you need room to install

438
00:21:32.000 --> 00:21:36.400
the operating system but maybe I want
75% of my data for storage And then, for

439
00:21:36.400 --> 00:21:38.650
my operating system,
a smaller drive, right?

440
00:21:38.650 --> 00:21:39.970
So you can kinda divide the drive up,

441
00:21:39.970 --> 00:21:43.010
based on what your needs are,
to get that put in place.

442
00:21:43.010 --> 00:21:45.840
That's the power we have when
we go through Disk Utility.

443
00:21:45.840 --> 00:21:51.180
You don't have these options when you go
through the regular installer, right?

444
00:21:51.180 --> 00:21:54.180
So that's gonna reach in there and
partition that out.

445
00:21:54.180 --> 00:21:55.980
And then we'll be ready to
continue with the install.

446
00:21:55.980 --> 00:21:58.240
We are going to go to
the installer eventually.

447
00:21:58.240 --> 00:22:00.400
The other thing is,
you can drop to terminal and

448
00:22:00.400 --> 00:22:02.360
do a lot of this stuff too, right.

449
00:22:02.360 --> 00:22:05.160
I'm doing it here through
the GUI because that's easy and

450
00:22:05.160 --> 00:22:07.030
that's the way that Apple
intends you to do it.

451
00:22:07.030 --> 00:22:09.760
But a lot of this stuff can
be done through the terminal.

452
00:22:09.760 --> 00:22:12.760
If I get out of Disk Utility and

453
00:22:12.760 --> 00:22:16.710
I go back here, It's easy to get
distracted by these four big giant options

454
00:22:16.710 --> 00:22:20.180
in the middle of the screen by up top
you've got the utilities menu and

455
00:22:20.180 --> 00:22:23.980
under utilities you'll find where
you can launch the terminal.

456
00:22:23.980 --> 00:22:29.460
And when you get into the terminal you're
down into the BSD kind of UNIX interface.

457
00:22:29.460 --> 00:22:30.700
Did I not click on it?

458
00:22:30.700 --> 00:22:31.390
There we go.

459
00:22:31.390 --> 00:22:35.580
It's just taking its time but
you can drop down to this interface And

460
00:22:35.580 --> 00:22:39.070
from here you can access
all sorts of things.

461
00:22:39.070 --> 00:22:44.710
So for example, I can run diskutil-l and,

462
00:22:44.710 --> 00:22:47.100
ops diskutil list, how about that?

463
00:22:47.100 --> 00:22:51.020
There we go and I can pull up a listing of
all of my disks and what's on the system.

464
00:22:51.020 --> 00:22:55.320
And I can use diskutil from the command
line and there is things that don't show

465
00:22:55.320 --> 00:23:02.240
up in here That if I run it from
the command line, I can see a lot more.

466
00:23:02.240 --> 00:23:06.142
For example, the recovery partition
which I think I've killed at this point.

467
00:23:06.142 --> 00:23:08.097
[LAUGH] We scroll back here.

468
00:23:08.097 --> 00:23:11.550
We start to see the disk and
Here it is, so

469
00:23:11.550 --> 00:23:16.910
I can see this 500 gig disk that I've got,
and now I can see the 125 gigs

470
00:23:16.910 --> 00:23:21.830
that I put for Macintosh HD,
and 374 gigs for storage.

471
00:23:21.830 --> 00:23:25.950
There's a 209 meg partition for the EFI.

472
00:23:25.950 --> 00:23:28.560
I didn't see that in Disk Utility,
but I see it here.

473
00:23:28.560 --> 00:23:29.690
So from the command line,

474
00:23:29.690 --> 00:23:33.180
there's even more that we can do,
that we don't normally see, right?

475
00:23:33.180 --> 00:23:36.490
So you might need to do that for
a really advanced configuration.

476
00:23:36.490 --> 00:23:38.030
Most of us aren't going
to have to do that.

477
00:23:38.030 --> 00:23:42.720
All right, so assuming that we
get our partitioning set up, or

478
00:23:42.720 --> 00:23:44.360
assuming that we just erased the disk and

479
00:23:44.360 --> 00:23:49.110
have one big partition, Then we're
ready to move on with our installation.

480
00:23:49.110 --> 00:23:51.543
And as far as moving on with
the installation is concerned,

481
00:23:51.543 --> 00:23:52.913
it's pretty straightforward.

482
00:23:52.913 --> 00:23:54.990
Let me quit out of
the terminal here real quick.

483
00:23:54.990 --> 00:23:56.641
And it'll return me back to my installer.

484
00:23:56.641 --> 00:24:00.721
Now I can choose to install macOS
Sierra We can continue, and now it's gonna

485
00:24:00.721 --> 00:24:05.760
come through and it'll actually ask me to
pick the drive that I'm installing on.

486
00:24:05.760 --> 00:24:09.200
If you have more than one hard drive,
or if you have more than one partition,

487
00:24:09.200 --> 00:24:12.410
it's gonna show you those partitions and
drives so that you can pick.

488
00:24:12.410 --> 00:24:15.900
So as I advance through the installer,
well I get my licensing agreement,

489
00:24:15.900 --> 00:24:19.790
we get through our 20 lawyer
speak pages here, and eventually,

490
00:24:19.790 --> 00:24:23.150
we get to the good stuff here, where
we pick where we're gonna install it.

491
00:24:23.150 --> 00:24:26.440
And I can see Macintosh HD,
I can see storage.

492
00:24:26.440 --> 00:24:30.370
If I had made it too small,
I wouldn't even be able to click on it.

493
00:24:30.370 --> 00:24:31.900
It would be grayed out.

494
00:24:31.900 --> 00:24:34.010
See how this USB drive is grayed out?

495
00:24:34.010 --> 00:24:37.958
Well, if I click on it, it's warning me
like, "hey that's my installation media".

496
00:24:37.958 --> 00:24:42.440
I can't install on the installation media,
it's gonna mess everything up.

497
00:24:42.440 --> 00:24:45.900
So I'm gonna choose the main partition
that we created, and I'll go ahead and

498
00:24:45.900 --> 00:24:49.540
move forward on that, and there we go,
now it's gonna start the installation.

499
00:24:49.540 --> 00:24:53.361
And when it's done, I'll have a fresh and
clean install of Sierra.

500
00:24:54.410 --> 00:24:58.250
If I had picked a partition
that already had Mac OS on it,

501
00:24:58.250 --> 00:25:02.570
maybe it had Yosemite or El Capitan
was already on it when I picked that,

502
00:25:02.570 --> 00:25:05.680
instead of doing a fresh and
clean install it would do an upgrade.

503
00:25:05.680 --> 00:25:10.340
It would actually upgrade it and
preserve all of my applications,

504
00:25:10.340 --> 00:25:12.800
all of my data, my documents and so on.

505
00:25:12.800 --> 00:25:15.370
So that is something I may not want.

506
00:25:15.370 --> 00:25:18.010
And that's why in this episode I was
showing you guys going into Disk Utility

507
00:25:18.010 --> 00:25:18.970
and erasing the disk.

508
00:25:18.970 --> 00:25:22.220
So now I know I'm gonna get a good,
clean copy of Sierra.

509
00:25:22.220 --> 00:25:25.780
And when it's up and running I've got
a computer that should be running nice and

510
00:25:25.780 --> 00:25:30.060
fast, nice and smooth and I know and
can trust everything that's on it.

511
00:25:30.060 --> 00:25:33.220
>> All right Don, lot of great information
getting that operating system installed.

512
00:25:33.220 --> 00:25:35.940
Looking forward to the episode yet to
come where we can actually lift the hood,

513
00:25:35.940 --> 00:25:37.590
get in there and
do a little peeking and tweaking.

514
00:25:37.590 --> 00:25:39.680
But we do not have
the time in this episode.

515
00:25:39.680 --> 00:25:41.380
So we're gonna go ahead and
wrap this one up.

516
00:25:41.380 --> 00:25:42.110
But before we do Don,

517
00:25:42.110 --> 00:25:45.290
you got any parting words about
getting your installation started?

518
00:25:45.290 --> 00:25:49.360
>> Well, key thing to remember here is if
you get your partition scheme wrong or

519
00:25:49.360 --> 00:25:50.530
you decide to change it later,

520
00:25:50.530 --> 00:25:52.900
just doesn't work out,
you actually can change it later.

521
00:25:52.900 --> 00:25:55.210
It's not a binding decision,
it's just harder.

522
00:25:55.210 --> 00:25:56.995
It's harder to go and change it later.

523
00:25:56.995 --> 00:26:01.020
Worst-case scenario, you can always back
up a time machine, erase the whole system,

524
00:26:01.020 --> 00:26:04.430
and then redo the installation and
restore your data.

525
00:26:04.430 --> 00:26:05.970
It's a lot of work.

526
00:26:05.970 --> 00:26:09.990
So you can change your partition
even without doing that.

527
00:26:09.990 --> 00:26:12.920
It just takes a lot of effort and
it's more challenging later on.

528
00:26:12.920 --> 00:26:15.660
So it's better to get the partition
schemes set up properly

529
00:26:15.660 --> 00:26:17.410
in the beginning if
you're even gonna use it.

530
00:26:17.410 --> 00:26:20.920
Remember what I said, I always just
do one partition and that's it.

531
00:26:20.920 --> 00:26:22.470
Unless I have more than one physical disk,

532
00:26:22.470 --> 00:26:24.400
cuz then each disk is
represented separately.

533
00:26:24.400 --> 00:26:26.910
It's still one partition per disk.

534
00:26:26.910 --> 00:26:28.620
So just keep that in mind.

535
00:26:28.620 --> 00:26:30.210
Everybody's needs
are a little bit different.

536
00:26:30.210 --> 00:26:32.030
So figure out what works for you.

537
00:26:32.030 --> 00:26:34.210
>> All right Don,
that's a great place to wrap this one up.

538
00:26:34.210 --> 00:26:37.470
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

539
00:26:37.470 --> 00:26:38.270
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

540
00:26:38.270 --> 00:26:40.129
>> We'll see you next time.

541
00:26:40.129 --> 00:26:45.774
[MUSIC]

542
00:26:45.774 --> 00:26:48.999
Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don dive into the world of recovering the Sierra operating system when failures arise. They discuss some of the common symptoms that might manifest themselves, the options available during the recovery process as well as demonstrating that process.
episodes.title: OS Recovery
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:02.771
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.771 --> 00:00:06.302
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.302 --> 00:00:08.171
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.171 --> 00:00:11.861
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.861 --> 00:00:15.170
>> Hello, and welcome to ITProTV,
we're glad you're joining us today.

6
00:00:15.170 --> 00:00:17.220
I'm your host Wes Bryan,
and in today's episode,

7
00:00:17.220 --> 00:00:20.440
we're continuing through our
Apple Certified Support Professional.

8
00:00:20.440 --> 00:00:23.460
And joining us back in the studios
is none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

9
00:00:23.460 --> 00:00:24.540
Don, how are you doing, sir?

10
00:00:24.540 --> 00:00:27.582
>> I'm doing great, Wes, ready to dive
right back into the world of ACSP.

11
00:00:27.582 --> 00:00:31.217
And in this episode we're gonna be
taking a look at OS Recover, or

12
00:00:31.217 --> 00:00:33.510
operating system recovery.

13
00:00:33.510 --> 00:00:37.440
There are times when Mac OS just doesn't
behave the way that it's supposed to.

14
00:00:37.440 --> 00:00:39.706
And we can't boot up,
can't get into our operating system and

15
00:00:39.706 --> 00:00:41.520
we need to do something to get back up and
running.

16
00:00:41.520 --> 00:00:44.076
So we're gonna look at some of
the potential causes of that and

17
00:00:44.076 --> 00:00:45.411
the ways that we can address it.

18
00:00:45.411 --> 00:00:48.639
And get our systems back up and
running right here in this episode.

19
00:00:48.639 --> 00:00:51.568
All right, well let's start off with
how we end up in this situation,

20
00:00:51.568 --> 00:00:52.592
in the first place.

21
00:00:52.592 --> 00:00:56.629
There are any number of things that
can cause Mac OS not to start up.

22
00:00:56.629 --> 00:01:02.329
Now, deep down under the hood, Mac OS is
actually a Unix-based operating system.

23
00:01:02.329 --> 00:01:05.986
Which means it's incredibly stable and
incredibly reliable.

24
00:01:05.986 --> 00:01:10.788
And the thing about Unix is it is reliable
and stable but it is insanely complex and

25
00:01:10.788 --> 00:01:11.575
hard to use.

26
00:01:11.575 --> 00:01:15.521
Unless you stick a very nice graphic user
interface on top of it that makes it super

27
00:01:15.521 --> 00:01:16.170
easy to use.

28
00:01:16.170 --> 00:01:18.380
Which is exactly what Apple did.

29
00:01:18.380 --> 00:01:22.630
So we get an easy to use OS
that's incredibly reliable and

30
00:01:22.630 --> 00:01:23.520
stable under the hood.

31
00:01:23.520 --> 00:01:25.620
So normally everything runs fine.

32
00:01:26.630 --> 00:01:29.009
The problem is it's not always normal,
right.

33
00:01:29.009 --> 00:01:31.529
Sometimes we can have disk failures and
other things.

34
00:01:31.529 --> 00:01:33.660
That make it where our
system does not boot up and

35
00:01:33.660 --> 00:01:35.500
operate the way that we expect.

36
00:01:35.500 --> 00:01:38.080
So, let me just kind of run
down a few scenarios for

37
00:01:38.080 --> 00:01:38.900
you to help you out with this.

38
00:01:40.130 --> 00:01:42.550
You can actually have hardware failing and

39
00:01:42.550 --> 00:01:45.800
one of the more common pieces
that fail is the power supply.

40
00:01:45.800 --> 00:01:48.260
If the power supply is failing in your
system, and you push the power button,

41
00:01:48.260 --> 00:01:49.480
guess what happens?

42
00:01:49.480 --> 00:01:51.130
Nothing, absolutely nothing.

43
00:01:51.130 --> 00:01:53.330
If you push the button and
nothing happens,

44
00:01:53.330 --> 00:01:55.900
you pretty much know you
have a bad power supply.

45
00:01:55.900 --> 00:01:58.430
You can try plugging it into a few
different outlets, see if that changes.

46
00:01:58.430 --> 00:02:01.618
A bad power supply always results
in needing to call Apple and

47
00:02:01.618 --> 00:02:03.568
getting a repair done on it, right.

48
00:02:03.568 --> 00:02:06.170
Taking it to an Apple Store, or whatever.

49
00:02:06.170 --> 00:02:07.502
But after that,

50
00:02:07.502 --> 00:02:10.650
there are a few other components
that can fail, things like memory.

51
00:02:10.650 --> 00:02:15.970
If memory starts to fail, you'll see
random freezes on the laptop or desktop.

52
00:02:15.970 --> 00:02:19.590
You'll see video artifacts on
the screen where video renders weird.

53
00:02:19.590 --> 00:02:24.710

Reinstalling is gonna

00:18:43.500 --> 00:18:45.170

00:18:45.170 --> 00:18:46.720

So slight variation in the terminology

00:18:50.610 --> 00:18:54.430
It's gonna put the operating system back

00:18:54.430 --> 00:18:55.620

00:19:19.220 --> 00:19:23.710
So I'll actually get the choice to pick

00:19:23.710 --> 00:19:27.230
finish in the first place, so it's

00:19:27.230 --> 00:19:31.132
But the nice part here is when it does

00:19:40.780 --> 00:19:42.950
If the operating system were older, right,

You can do both.

00:20:02.130 --> 00:20:04.580

Too many changes.

00:20:11.050 --> 00:20:14.110

00:20:17.820 --> 00:20:22.090

00:20:26.990 --> 00:20:32.630

00:20:39.590 --> 00:20:44.020

00:20:44.020 --> 00:20:47.210

00:20:49.310 --> 00:20:52.800
If you have the Sierra media

00:20:52.800 --> 00:20:55.610
And use that to recover,

00:20:55.610 --> 00:20:57.120
now your operating system is up.

00:20:57.120 --> 00:21:00.440
Your applications are there,

00:21:00.440 --> 00:21:03.600
Obviously if this was a hardware

00:21:03.600 --> 00:21:05.820
replace the disk first.

00:21:05.820 --> 00:21:09.010
Then we run through this process and if

00:21:12.230 --> 00:21:14.511

445
00:21:14.511 --> 00:21:21.321
All right, couple of other
things worth mentioning here.

446
00:21:21.321 --> 00:21:23.575
If it was memory that was the problem,

447
00:21:23.575 --> 00:21:26.966
memory can sometimes manifest
itself as a disk failure.

448
00:21:26.966 --> 00:21:29.761
You might think you have disk failure and
in actuality it's memory.

449
00:21:29.761 --> 00:21:33.712
So for example when you copy a file to
your hard drive you maybe you have a file

450
00:21:33.712 --> 00:21:34.940
on a USB disk.

451
00:21:34.940 --> 00:21:36.690
And you copy it over and
you copy it to the hard drive.

452
00:21:36.690 --> 00:21:39.700
And then you go open it on the hard
drive and it says the file's corrupt.

453
00:21:39.700 --> 00:21:42.350
Or you download a file from the Internet
and then you go to open it and

454
00:21:42.350 --> 00:21:43.020
it says it's corrupt.

455
00:21:43.020 --> 00:21:45.970
And you start thinking wow, maybe I
have some bad sectors on the hard drive.

456
00:21:45.970 --> 00:21:49.340
Well, what happens is anytime you
copy a file to the hard drive,

457
00:21:49.340 --> 00:21:51.410
it gets copied to RAM first.

458
00:21:51.410 --> 00:21:54.310
And then from RAM it gets
written to the hard drive.

459
00:21:54.310 --> 00:21:58.570
If your RAM is bad, the file that
gets copied to RAM is now corrupt and

460
00:21:58.570 --> 00:22:00.280
it gets written to the disk corrupt.

461
00:22:00.280 --> 00:22:03.395
And so it looks like it's corrupt on disk
when its actually the RAM that's causing

462
00:22:03.395 --> 00:22:03.948
the problem.

463
00:22:03.948 --> 00:22:08.645
If I do this reinstall and it completes
the Sierra install and I boot up and

464
00:22:08.645 --> 00:22:12.584
I still have the problem,
I might actually have bad memory.

465
00:22:12.584 --> 00:22:16.400
And so I might need to boot up into
the hardware diagnostics to check that.

466
00:22:16.400 --> 00:22:19.150
On most Macs, not all of them, but most.

467
00:22:19.150 --> 00:22:21.882
You can boot while holding Cmd+D.

468
00:22:21.882 --> 00:22:24.950
And Cmd+D will load into
a special diagnostic mode,

469
00:22:24.950 --> 00:22:27.290
where it runs a series of hardware checks.

470
00:22:27.290 --> 00:22:30.730
And it can diagnose some fine problems
that you can't otherwise find.

471
00:22:30.730 --> 00:22:33.210
So for example, my laptop.

472
00:22:33.210 --> 00:22:35.927
I would show you but
it's actually fixed now [LAUGH].

473
00:22:35.927 --> 00:22:39.310
My laptop, I noticed one day,
the headphone jack stopped working.

474
00:22:39.310 --> 00:22:42.045
I'd plug in my headphones and
I would just hear static, [SOUND].

475
00:22:42.045 --> 00:22:43.580
It was bad.

476
00:22:43.580 --> 00:22:48.470
And I noticed that I didn't even
see the volume slider on my Mac.

477
00:22:48.470 --> 00:22:52.150
And so the speakers on the Mac wouldn't
work, not just the headphone jack, but

478
00:22:52.150 --> 00:22:54.040
the speakers themselves wouldn't work.

479
00:22:54.040 --> 00:22:58.350
It was as if the sound
card wasn't even there.

480
00:22:58.350 --> 00:23:00.405
Well, I booted in the diagnostic mode.

481
00:23:00.405 --> 00:23:03.150
And in the diagnostic mode, it ran
through a series of hardware checks.

482
00:23:03.150 --> 00:23:06.810
And it said, you've got a problem
with your sound hardware.

483
00:23:06.810 --> 00:23:09.870
And it gave me a code, and so
when I called Apple for support,

484
00:23:09.870 --> 00:23:12.213
I said hey I ran diagnostics,
I got this code.

485
00:23:12.213 --> 00:23:14.566
I told them the code and they say,
yep that's the sound card,

486
00:23:14.566 --> 00:23:15.796
we'll replace it on warranty.

487
00:23:15.796 --> 00:23:17.560
They changed it and that was that.

488
00:23:17.560 --> 00:23:20.500
I was able to diagnose exactly
what that problem was.

489
00:23:20.500 --> 00:23:23.224
It diagnoses memory as well.

490
00:23:23.224 --> 00:23:27.540
So holding Cmd+D to boot into that
diagnostic mode, that is a great way to be

491
00:23:27.540 --> 00:23:30.270
able to jump in there and
check that hardware before you call Apple.

492
00:23:30.270 --> 00:23:32.920
So you actually have
the hardware code to give them.

493
00:23:32.920 --> 00:23:36.400
Otherwise if you take it to the Apple
store they don't like to say this but

494
00:23:36.400 --> 00:23:37.500
that's actually what they do.

495
00:23:37.500 --> 00:23:38.775
They just boot it holding Cmd+D.

496
00:23:38.775 --> 00:23:42.010
[LAUGH] That's the Apple
genius technique right there,

497
00:23:42.010 --> 00:23:43.450
I just ruined the whole secret.

498
00:23:43.450 --> 00:23:46.450
And then once they have the code
they know, yeah it's this hardware.

499
00:23:46.450 --> 00:23:47.970
They replace it and that's the end of it.

500
00:23:47.970 --> 00:23:52.340
So, pretty easy to recover from
a failed operating system.

501
00:23:52.340 --> 00:23:54.760
Your failed data is
a different story though,

502
00:23:54.760 --> 00:23:59.790
I can easily put the CRL OS back on here
as long as I have my recovery media.

503
00:23:59.790 --> 00:24:02.590
But if I lost some of my data,
that's where your Time Machine comes in.

504
00:24:02.590 --> 00:24:06.208
You really need to make sure you've got
good Time Machine backups or that you use

505
00:24:06.208 --> 00:24:09.778
cloud services like iCloud and Dropbox
to backup your data to a cloud service.

506
00:24:09.778 --> 00:24:12.484
And that way, if you ever have
to replace your hard drive,

507
00:24:12.484 --> 00:24:16.210
you just re-download your data from
the cloud, and you're back in business.

508
00:24:16.210 --> 00:24:19.000
All right, as far as OS recovery,
I think it's about it.

509
00:24:19.000 --> 00:24:21.710
I mention Mountain Lion,
how it has its different recovery.

510
00:24:21.710 --> 00:24:23.660
Hopefully, none of you are running
Mountain Lion anymore.

511
00:24:23.660 --> 00:24:26.230
But, you can just go to Apple's website,
download that recovery,

512
00:24:26.230 --> 00:24:28.240
that's easy enough.

513
00:24:28.240 --> 00:24:32.750
The other thing is when you're
in the recovery window,

514
00:24:32.750 --> 00:24:34.480
there's other utilities
that are available.

515
00:24:34.480 --> 00:24:36.380
I've talked a bit about some
of them in the last episode.

516
00:24:36.380 --> 00:24:37.880
But if you go to
the Utilities menu up top,

517
00:24:37.880 --> 00:24:41.890
you'll see things like your firmware
password utility and a few other things.

518
00:24:41.890 --> 00:24:43.860
But most importantly you'll see Terminal.

519
00:24:43.860 --> 00:24:46.660
You can drop to the Terminal and
do all sorts of stuff.

520
00:24:46.660 --> 00:24:49.900
For example, you could pop in
a USB hard drive and mount it.

521
00:24:49.900 --> 00:24:54.140
And from there, you might be able to copy
data from your hard drive to the USB drive

522
00:24:54.140 --> 00:24:58.510
to make a last minute, a last ditch back
up of your data before formatting it.

523
00:24:58.510 --> 00:25:01.190
Those are some of the things you
can do once you're in the Terminal.

524
00:25:01.190 --> 00:25:04.040
It's harder to work in the Terminal,
but at least it's there,

525
00:25:04.040 --> 00:25:06.690
at least you can get into it, and
it's right there as part of recovery.

526
00:25:06.690 --> 00:25:10.122
So just be aware there's all these
utilities that are out there for you.

527
00:25:10.122 --> 00:25:12.730
>> All right Don, a lot of great
information on how to get that operating

528
00:25:12.730 --> 00:25:14.770
system back up and
running through recovery but

529
00:25:14.770 --> 00:25:17.280
what we can't seem to recover here
is a few extra minutes on the clock.

530
00:25:17.280 --> 00:25:20.127
So it does look like we're going
to have to wrap this one up here.

531
00:25:20.127 --> 00:25:23.546
But before we do, when it comes to OS
recovery do you have any parting words you

532
00:25:23.546 --> 00:25:24.926
want to impart in our viewers?

533
00:25:24.926 --> 00:25:27.226
>> The main thing that
I would recommend is,

534
00:25:27.226 --> 00:25:31.378
while your system is healthy while
it's happy, create an install media.

535
00:25:31.378 --> 00:25:37.075
USB keys are cheap, they're $15 for
a 16 gig one, pretty easy anywhere.

536
00:25:37.075 --> 00:25:40.983
Buy one, make the recovery media and stick
in a drawer in your desk, have it handy.

537
00:25:40.983 --> 00:25:44.137
That way when there's a failure you
can easily just grab that media and

538
00:25:44.137 --> 00:25:44.842
boot off of it.

539
00:25:44.842 --> 00:25:48.629
If you only have one Mac that's really
important, cuz if I have two Macs, and

540
00:25:48.629 --> 00:25:52.780
mine fails, I can just go to Wes' laptop,
and make the recovery media from his.

541
00:25:52.780 --> 00:25:54.370
And now I can come over and fix mine.

542
00:25:54.370 --> 00:25:58.460
But if you've only got one Mac,
it takes a Mac to make the recovery media.

543
00:25:58.460 --> 00:26:00.730
You can't make it from a Windows or
a Linux machine.

544
00:26:00.730 --> 00:26:04.780
So make the recovery media while you
still have a functioning device.

545
00:26:04.780 --> 00:26:06.130
>> All right, Don, words of wisdom.

546
00:26:06.130 --> 00:26:06.710
Thank you there.

547
00:26:06.710 --> 00:26:08.890
And we appreciate you,
the viewer watching.

548
00:26:08.890 --> 00:26:10.040
Signing out for ITProTV.

549
00:26:10.040 --> 00:26:11.630
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

550
00:26:11.630 --> 00:26:12.450
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

551
00:26:12.450 --> 00:26:13.406
>> And we'll see you next time.

552
00:26:13.406 --> 00:26:20.075
[MUSIC]

553
00:26:20.075 --> 00:26:23.152
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don take you through the initial setup configuration for a new or recently installed Mac OS system. Here they will explain and demo the 5 basic setup steps which includes migrating existing data, configure networking, configure user accounts, adjust system preferences, and configure software updates.
episodes.title: Initial Configuration
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1

it's hard to pretend we're professional,

>> Speaking of legitimate film though,

18

Now if you've been watching all these

When you fire up a brand new Mac, or you

Now you'll find there's a number of

32

and talk about what they mean, when we use

and what we need to do to make sure

35

As quickly and painlessly as possible.

36
00:01:39.070 --> 00:01:40.540
So we can be out there in the field, and

37

actually being productive and
professional right?

38

Versus, we're standing around waiting
on a status bar to scroll across and

talking about total recall.

40

[LAUGH]
>> Well there's worst ways to spend that
