time, right everyone?

42
00:01:53.655 --> 00:01:57.620
[LAUGH] That being said Don, what
are these basic steps which Apple says,

43
00:01:57.620 --> 00:01:59.330
that we're gonna walk
ourselves through here?

44
00:01:59.330 --> 00:02:03.080
Okay, so they've got five steps, and
they don't necessarily have to be done in

45
00:02:03.080 --> 00:02:06.200
order, sometimes they
can't be done in order.

46
00:02:06.200 --> 00:02:08.960
But the first one is we need
to migrate data, right?

47
00:02:08.960 --> 00:02:11.940
If you just got a new Mac,
the odds are you had an old Mac.

48
00:02:11.940 --> 00:02:14.870
And you need to be able to get your data
from the old Mac over to the new Mac.

49
00:02:14.870 --> 00:02:18.430
Or, hey, maybe you're making the switch,
maybe you had a Windows machine.

50
00:02:18.430 --> 00:02:21.730
And you need to get your data off
the Windows machine and over to your Mac.

51
00:02:21.730 --> 00:02:24.670
It's very rare that you have
somebody who's starting out with

52
00:02:24.670 --> 00:02:28.250
their very first computer with absolutely
no historical data whatsoever.

53
00:02:28.250 --> 00:02:30.100
I'm just going to start out from scratch.

54
00:02:30.100 --> 00:02:33.270
I think we all did that at some point but.

55
00:02:33.270 --> 00:02:36.360
Kids these days get their first
computer when they're like

56
00:02:36.360 --> 00:02:37.732
eight years old and or even younger.

57
00:02:37.732 --> 00:02:38.232
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah.

58
00:02:38.232 --> 00:02:40.402
Just don't know a day without some sort of

59
00:02:40.402 --> 00:02:41.360
electronic history.

60
00:02:41.360 --> 00:02:42.360
>> Yeah, that screen.

61
00:02:42.360 --> 00:02:44.960
So, it's pretty rare that
you start out with nothing.

62
00:02:44.960 --> 00:02:46.570
So, you've got data we
you need to get over.

63
00:02:46.570 --> 00:02:47.260
So that's step one.

64
00:02:47.260 --> 00:02:48.690
Is just kinda migrating our data.

65
00:02:48.690 --> 00:02:52.000
Well I can't migrate my data to
this computer right now because

66
00:02:52.000 --> 00:02:53.480
it's sitting at its set-up screen.

67
00:02:53.480 --> 00:02:54.650
I've got to get through the set-up first.

68
00:02:54.650 --> 00:02:56.440
So that's why I say they aren't
necessarily going to be done

69
00:02:56.440 --> 00:02:58.090
in the order that Apple has them.

70
00:02:58.090 --> 00:03:00.130
The next thing is configuring networking.

71
00:03:00.130 --> 00:03:03.950
It's very rare these days that we use
a computer that's not networked and

72
00:03:03.950 --> 00:03:05.270
that didn't use to be true.

73
00:03:05.270 --> 00:03:08.400
I mean, I remember buying my
first network adaptor in,

74
00:03:08.400 --> 00:03:13.420
it was probably like 1996, but prior to
that my computers weren't network, right?

75
00:03:13.420 --> 00:03:15.460
They were stand-alone
independent machines.

76
00:03:15.460 --> 00:03:16.700
But in today's world,

77
00:03:16.700 --> 00:03:20.350
to encounter a machine that doesn't have
internet access is like a broken machine.

78
00:03:20.350 --> 00:03:21.500
What's wrong with this thing?

79
00:03:21.500 --> 00:03:22.540
I can't get on the internet.

80
00:03:22.540 --> 00:03:25.780
So, we need to get configured for
the network, right?

81
00:03:25.780 --> 00:03:30.680
We've got configure user accounts
during the setup it's going an create

82
00:03:30.680 --> 00:03:33.550
one user account for you that user
going and be a administrator,

83
00:03:33.550 --> 00:03:36.730
you may need to create other user
accounts if you share the computer and

84
00:03:36.730 --> 00:03:38.160
they might be administrators also.

85
00:03:38.160 --> 00:03:42.367
They might be regular users but
we need get those done and put in place.

86
00:03:42.367 --> 00:03:48.920
Then we got adjusting our general
setting preferences when MacOS fires up.

87
00:03:48.920 --> 00:03:54.030
Apple is configured it to what they think
is the base standard for most people.

88
00:03:54.030 --> 00:03:58.140
The settings that are appropriate,
and keep most people happy.

89
00:03:58.140 --> 00:04:00.270
But, different people
have different needs.

90
00:04:00.270 --> 00:04:05.270
There's people like me, where I really
hate the flashy bells and whistles and

91
00:04:05.270 --> 00:04:06.850
I turn a lot of stuff off, right?

92
00:04:06.850 --> 00:04:10.450
I'll turn off a lot of settings to make
things a little more streamlined but

93
00:04:10.450 --> 00:04:11.730
a little faster.

94
00:04:11.730 --> 00:04:14.610
And I am not afraid of
dropping to a terminal.

95
00:04:14.610 --> 00:04:16.670
There's other people
that hate the terminal.

96
00:04:16.670 --> 00:04:18.920
They want everything in the GUI and
they customize things and

97
00:04:18.920 --> 00:04:20.310
make it work in a certain way.

98
00:04:20.310 --> 00:04:22.120
Different people
are different preferences.

99
00:04:22.120 --> 00:04:25.210
And we need to be able to go in and
get those configured and setup, right.

100
00:04:25.210 --> 00:04:28.590
So we adjust things the way
that we want them to be.

101
00:04:28.590 --> 00:04:31.640
And then lastly,
we need to configure software updates.

102
00:04:31.640 --> 00:04:35.300
Mac OS is very stable and very secure.

103
00:04:35.300 --> 00:04:40.240
And the reason it is those two things
is that Apple very reliably pushes out

104
00:04:40.240 --> 00:04:44.690
updates on a regular basis,
if you're set up to receive them.

105
00:04:44.690 --> 00:04:45.630
If you don't set yourself up for

106
00:04:45.630 --> 00:04:50.070
that, then you could be running an older
version of Mac OS, and a virus or

107
00:04:50.070 --> 00:04:52.310
an attack or something like that
could be out there on the network.

108
00:04:52.310 --> 00:04:56.450
And you're not vulnerable to it, because
you haven't been doing updates, right?

109
00:04:56.450 --> 00:04:59.120
Interesting thing,
you hear a lot of people say, hey,

110
00:04:59.120 --> 00:05:01.890
you don't need antivirus
software on your Mac, right?

111
00:05:01.890 --> 00:05:06.060
And by in large,
that's true if you're doing your updates.

112
00:05:06.060 --> 00:05:09.340
Because anytime there's some
kinda exploit or a weakness or

113
00:05:09.340 --> 00:05:13.220
a whatever Apple will patch it and
push it out as part of their updates.

114
00:05:13.220 --> 00:05:15.890
So Apple acts as your antivirus.

115
00:05:15.890 --> 00:05:18.860
They are stopping these type
of exploits from working.

116
00:05:18.860 --> 00:05:21.640
But if you're not doing the updates,
then Apple's not helping you.

117
00:05:21.640 --> 00:05:24.720
And if they're not helping you,
you're not helping yourself.

118
00:05:24.720 --> 00:05:25.484
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

119
00:05:25.484 --> 00:05:26.418
>> Then you do need something

120
00:05:26.418 --> 00:05:26.970
like antivirus.

121
00:05:26.970 --> 00:05:28.666
And there are products out
there that you can get.

122
00:05:28.666 --> 00:05:30.746
But you shouldn't need them
if you're doing your updates.

123
00:05:30.746 --> 00:05:32.300
So getting your updates configured.

124
00:05:32.300 --> 00:05:34.080
It's kind of that fifth step.

125
00:05:34.080 --> 00:05:36.780
They're all very important,
you might do them all at once.

126
00:05:36.780 --> 00:05:40.280
Hey, I just got a new computer, let me run
through all five of these steps right now.

127
00:05:40.280 --> 00:05:43.780
Or you might do them slowly over a week or
two weeks as you get things set up.

128
00:05:43.780 --> 00:05:46.240
That's your option when
it's just your computer.

129
00:05:46.240 --> 00:05:49.920
But if you're at a business and
you just received 100 new MacBooks and

130
00:05:49.920 --> 00:05:52.310
you're suppose to be distributing
them out to the instruments agents,

131
00:05:52.310 --> 00:05:55.650
something like that You don't
wanna take weeks or months.

132
00:05:55.650 --> 00:05:57.740
You wanna get this done
as quickly as possible.

133
00:05:57.740 --> 00:06:00.650
So understanding the tools that
are available to speed this up

134
00:06:00.650 --> 00:06:03.600
will really help make this
an effective operation and work.

135
00:06:03.600 --> 00:06:06.900
>> All right Don real quickly, the process
that we're getting ready to go through.

136
00:06:06.900 --> 00:06:11.290
Is it the same if you have a new Mac
versus whether or not You reinstall it, or

137
00:06:11.290 --> 00:06:12.460
are they two different processes?

138
00:06:12.460 --> 00:06:15.130
>> Well, that's kinda the nice part
about it, is it is the same, right?

139
00:06:15.130 --> 00:06:17.250
Once you've reinstalled Mac OS,

140
00:06:17.250 --> 00:06:20.660
it's in the same state as if
you had just bought a new Mac.

141
00:06:20.660 --> 00:06:22.170
So what we're gonna see from here on out,

142
00:06:22.170 --> 00:06:26.470
the screen that I'm on right now, is what
you're greeted with regardless, right?

143
00:06:26.470 --> 00:06:27.280
So when I come in here,

144
00:06:27.280 --> 00:06:29.480
the first thing it's gonna ask me
is what country I'm in, right?

145
00:06:29.480 --> 00:06:32.850
So it needs to isolate a country, so it
can figure out the language and the other

146
00:06:32.850 --> 00:06:36.870
settings that go along with firing up
that new system and getting it in place.

147
00:06:36.870 --> 00:06:39.300
Now, it's defaulting to the United States
for me, which is convenient,

148
00:06:39.300 --> 00:06:40.490
cuz that's where I am.

149
00:06:40.490 --> 00:06:43.500
And I can move forward on that, and
now I get to select my keyboard.

150
00:06:43.500 --> 00:06:46.340
Now, you might be wondering why
these settings are important.

151
00:06:46.340 --> 00:06:49.060
If you've only lived in the US,
we get a little spoiled here,

152
00:06:49.060 --> 00:06:51.950
because a lot of computers,
especially the ones you purchase here,

153
00:06:51.950 --> 00:06:54.360
are all set up for us,
right out of the box.

154
00:06:54.360 --> 00:06:58.010
But if you travel to other countries,
you'll find that things are different.

155
00:06:58.010 --> 00:06:59.415
Well, I mean, they're other countries.

156
00:06:59.415 --> 00:07:01.410
>> [LAUGH]
>> But even the computers are different,

157
00:07:01.410 --> 00:07:03.990
especially when it comes
to keyboard layouts.

158
00:07:03.990 --> 00:07:06.230
So for example, on an English keyboard or

159
00:07:06.230 --> 00:07:10.730
a US English keyboard, the top row
of letters on your keyboard is,

160
00:07:10.730 --> 00:07:14.030
they call it a QWERTY keyboard,
cuz it's Q-W-E-R-T-Y, right, QWERTY.

161
00:07:14.030 --> 00:07:18.850
But if you go to France, that top row
of the The keyboard is different.

162
00:07:18.850 --> 00:07:20.200
It's an AZERTY.

163
00:07:20.200 --> 00:07:22.210
It's A-Z-E-R-T-Y.

164
00:07:22.210 --> 00:07:23.530
So different layout.

165
00:07:23.530 --> 00:07:26.350
So if you pick the wrong keyboard then
things aren't gonna work out so well for

166
00:07:26.350 --> 00:07:27.700
you and it's really gonna be a pain.

167
00:07:27.700 --> 00:07:30.960
So when I look at my keyboard layout here,
it's asking It's me to pick that,

168
00:07:30.960 --> 00:07:33.920
and, I'm just gonna go with US
cuz that's the city that I'm on.

169
00:07:33.920 --> 00:07:36.390
But if you choose show all,
you'll actually get a whole list and

170
00:07:36.390 --> 00:07:40.790
see we've got like AZ right there,
or, Q-W-E-R-T-Z, A QWERTZ.

171
00:07:40.790 --> 00:07:42.690
I don't know [INAUDIBLE]
>> [LAUGH]

172
00:07:42.690 --> 00:07:45.570
>> I would bet you the Dvorak is in

173
00:07:45.570 --> 00:07:46.360
here somewhere.

174
00:07:46.360 --> 00:07:49.350
Although, you never know,
cuz well, there they are, Dvorak.

175
00:07:49.350 --> 00:07:51.972
Yep, Apple doesn't actually
sell any Dvorak keyboards.

176
00:07:51.972 --> 00:07:55.071
But you can get one and

00:28:29.770 --> 00:28:33.910
And get that changed over to
the new entry, all right.

631
00:28:33.910 --> 00:28:35.280
When that's done, it's gonna log me in.

632
00:28:35.280 --> 00:28:37.860
And I should see that my information

633
00:28:37.860 --> 00:28:41.780
has been brought over to help me get this
Mac up and running that much faster.

634
00:28:41.780 --> 00:28:44.120
Now the things that I'm going to look for
are pretty minor.

635
00:28:44.120 --> 00:28:47.730
Some documents in my documents folder,
some bookmarks in Safari.

636
00:28:47.730 --> 00:28:49.870
But you may have many, many other things.

637
00:28:49.870 --> 00:28:52.060
There are some things
that don't come over.

638
00:28:52.060 --> 00:28:55.620
So for example, sorry,
I'm going to skip the iCloud sign-in.

639
00:28:55.620 --> 00:28:57.680
For example, my wallpaper, right?

640
00:28:57.680 --> 00:28:59.320
Wallpapers won't normally come over.

641
00:28:59.320 --> 00:29:03.370
There's a few reasons for that, but if
you're using a wallpaper that was included

642
00:29:03.370 --> 00:29:07.640
with Windows, well, your license for that
ties it to the Windows operating system so

643
00:29:07.640 --> 00:29:10.600
Apple doesn't bring it over and
I still end up with the mountains.

644
00:29:10.600 --> 00:29:13.010
If you do a custom wallpaper,
sometimes they do come over.

645
00:29:13.010 --> 00:29:13.640
Sometimes they don't.

646
00:29:13.640 --> 00:29:15.560
It's usually licensing
that's a problem there.

647
00:29:15.560 --> 00:29:18.850
But other things like my documents,
those should have come over just fine.

648
00:29:18.850 --> 00:29:23.490
If I fire up my finder and go into
My Documents, there's Don's Term Paper.

649
00:29:23.490 --> 00:29:25.200
It's sitting right there, ready to go.

650
00:29:25.200 --> 00:29:28.590
And if I fire up Safari,
now remember, on a Windows machine,

651
00:29:28.590 --> 00:29:30.360
we don't even have Safari.

652
00:29:30.360 --> 00:29:35.000
But here on the Mac, if I fire up Safari,
and I go into my bookmarks,

653
00:29:35.000 --> 00:29:39.160
I've got a folder here in my bookmarks
called Migrated from Internet Explorer.

654
00:29:39.160 --> 00:29:42.380
And there's Bing, CNN,
Fox News, and IT Pro TV.

655
00:29:42.380 --> 00:29:45.050
We can click on those,
browse right to them, and they're working.

656
00:29:45.050 --> 00:29:49.950
So now, I'm ready to go on
this new Mac in short order.

657
00:29:49.950 --> 00:29:53.620
I can get up and going because all
my data's been migrated over, and

658
00:29:53.620 --> 00:29:56.320
I turn off my old computer, but
I don't throw it away just yet.

659
00:29:56.320 --> 00:29:57.630
Hold on to it for a day or two, right?

660
00:29:57.630 --> 00:29:59.608
Make sure all your information is there,

661
00:29:59.608 --> 00:30:02.884
because if there's anything missing
you can go to the old computer,

662
00:30:02.884 --> 00:30:05.727
plug in a USB key, copy it over,
bring it over really easy.

663
00:30:05.727 --> 00:30:09.791
But if you've thrown it away, or
erased it or whatever, you can't do that.

664
00:30:09.791 --> 00:30:10.890
So wait a few days.

665
00:30:10.890 --> 00:30:12.530
Make sure you got all your information,
and

666
00:30:12.530 --> 00:30:14.240
then it's safe to get rid
of that old computer.

667
00:30:14.240 --> 00:30:17.170
>> Well it seems like the good people
over at the Apple Corporation have done

668
00:30:17.170 --> 00:30:21.430
a very good job of trying to
make this a very quick and

669
00:30:21.430 --> 00:30:25.900
even painless way to migrate from another
computer to something that they have.

670
00:30:25.900 --> 00:30:29.250
You know,
their new Mac OS is very nice and

671
00:30:29.250 --> 00:30:32.720
Don, I see not many flaws
in their logic here.

672
00:30:32.720 --> 00:30:33.910
I mean, it was super easy.

673
00:30:33.910 --> 00:30:35.240
It wasn't very difficult at all.

674
00:30:35.240 --> 00:30:39.363
I think just about anybody with any
kind of human acumen would be able to-

675
00:30:39.363 --> 00:30:40.475
>> [LAUGH]

676
00:30:40.475 --> 00:30:43.981
>> Do this procedure, it's not very hard.

677
00:30:43.981 --> 00:30:47.870
>> Yeah, the only real challenge is
it doesn't bring over applications.

678
00:30:47.870 --> 00:30:51.490
So maybe I had Microsoft Word
installed on my Windows machine.

679
00:30:51.490 --> 00:30:54.940
Well, it'll bring over my Word documents,
but it won't bring over Word,

680
00:30:54.940 --> 00:30:58.610
because I need to install the Mac version
of Microsoft Word to get that working.

681
00:30:58.610 --> 00:31:00.900
So you do still have the applications
that you gotta jump through.

682
00:31:00.900 --> 00:31:03.630
It's not a perfect transition.

683
00:31:03.630 --> 00:31:04.820
But it's a good start,

684
00:31:04.820 --> 00:31:08.190
and it saves you a lot of time
with getting things moved over.

685
00:31:08.190 --> 00:31:10.500
After that you throw on your applications
and then you're ready to rock.

686
00:31:10.500 --> 00:31:13.620
>> That's right,and then all the old
files that had those great extensions,

687
00:31:13.620 --> 00:31:15.320
they should be able to operate after that.

688
00:31:15.320 --> 00:31:18.040
So once you get that application
installed, it'll see those files and

689
00:31:18.040 --> 00:31:19.480
be able to run them very easily.

690
00:31:19.480 --> 00:31:21.975
Don, I know we actually have quite
a bit more to go through, but

691
00:31:21.975 --> 00:31:24.335
our clock has dwindled long ago.

692
00:31:24.335 --> 00:31:25.122
That time has expired.

693
00:31:25.122 --> 00:31:29.165
So we're gonna have to roll into
a Part Three, a Part Three, Part Two.

694
00:31:29.165 --> 00:31:29.845
Where am I at?

695
00:31:29.845 --> 00:31:31.125
My brain is all over the place today.

696
00:31:31.125 --> 00:31:32.505
>> You're ready to go Part Three?

697
00:31:32.505 --> 00:31:33.125
>> That's right.

698
00:31:33.125 --> 00:31:34.969
It felt like two parts.

699
00:31:34.969 --> 00:31:37.063
>> [LAUGH]
>> But thanks for joining us in this part.

700
00:31:37.063 --> 00:31:38.927
Looking forward to see you in Part Two.

701
00:31:38.927 --> 00:31:40.882
Hopefully, you good folks
will join us as well.

702
00:31:40.882 --> 00:31:43.640
But as for
this we're gonna go ahead and sign off.

703
00:31:43.640 --> 00:31:45.960
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

704
00:31:45.960 --> 00:31:46.900
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

705
00:31:46.900 --> 00:31:51.024
>> We'll see you next time.

706
00:31:51.024 --> 00:31:54.781
[MUSIC]

707
00:31:54.781 --> 00:31:56.665
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don take you through the initial setup configuration for a new or recently installed Mac OS system. Here they will explain and demo the 5 basic setup steps which includes migrating existing data, configure networking, configure user accounts, adjust system preferences, and configure software updates.
episodes.title: Initial Configuration Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.950 --> 00:00:01.492
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.492 --> 00:00:02.809
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.809 --> 00:00:05.893
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:05.893 --> 00:00:08.445
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.445 --> 00:00:12.102
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.102 --> 00:00:13.940
>> All right, greetings, everyone, and

7
00:00:13.940 --> 00:00:16.995
welcome back to another
exciting episode of ITProTV.

8
00:00:16.995 --> 00:00:19.785
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and
in today's episode, well,

9
00:00:19.785 --> 00:00:22.755
we're coming back with
more of the ACSP series.

10
00:00:22.755 --> 00:00:25.727
And joining us in the studio,
yet again continuing

11
00:00:25.727 --> 00:00:29.977
looking at additional configuration,
our good friend, Mr. Don Pezet.

12
00:00:29.977 --> 00:00:31.227
Don, glad to have you again, sir.

13
00:00:31.227 --> 00:00:32.057
How's it going today?

14
00:00:32.057 --> 00:00:34.952
>> Hey, ready to jump right back in and
keep configurating this thing.

15
00:00:34.952 --> 00:00:37.892
>> [LAUGH]
>> Configurating, that's right.

16
00:00:37.892 --> 00:00:41.579
>> So in the last episode we got a chance
to see the initial configuration of

17
00:00:41.579 --> 00:00:44.057
a new Mac, or
a Mac we've recently formatted.

18
00:00:44.057 --> 00:00:47.290
And we talked about migrating our
settings over from another computer.

19
00:00:47.290 --> 00:00:50.950
And at some point in the episode,
I threw out the flippant statement that

20
00:00:50.950 --> 00:00:53.120
there's really just one thing
that we can't migrate over, and

21
00:00:53.120 --> 00:00:55.290
those are our system preferences.

22
00:00:55.290 --> 00:00:58.900
So in this episode, I wanna talk
about those system preferences.

23
00:00:58.900 --> 00:01:02.310
And what you'll find is that most of them
are not really consequential to getting

24
00:01:02.310 --> 00:01:03.840
started on your new system.

25
00:01:03.840 --> 00:01:06.960
But they are things that, at least from a
quality of life perspective, we'll want to

26
00:01:06.960 --> 00:01:10.660
tweak and customize to get the computer
running the way that we're used to,

27
00:01:10.660 --> 00:01:13.450
which is gonna make us more productive and
be able to get things done faster.

28
00:01:13.450 --> 00:01:15.680
So in this episode that's our goal, right?

29
00:01:15.680 --> 00:01:19.910
We're gonna tackle system preferences and
some of the key important ones,

30
00:01:19.910 --> 00:01:21.280
especially like on the networking side.

31
00:01:21.280 --> 00:01:23.680
Those are really critical for
us to get configured properly.

32
00:01:23.680 --> 00:01:27.420
>> All right, well, since it's so
important, Don, well, for

33
00:01:27.420 --> 00:01:30.400
the uninitiated out there,
how the heck do you even

34
00:01:30.400 --> 00:01:31.315
get to your system-
>> [LAUGH]

35
00:01:31.315 --> 00:01:32.030
>> Preferences, so

36
00:01:32.030 --> 00:01:34.230
that you can tweak them
to the way you like?

37
00:01:34.230 --> 00:01:36.900
>> All right, so
this one's pretty easy because pretty much

38
00:01:36.900 --> 00:01:41.718
from any screen inside of macOS, you'll
always have your Apple menu up top, right?

39
00:01:41.718 --> 00:01:43.490
So when I look at the desktop here,

40
00:01:43.490 --> 00:01:47.520
up in my top corner, I've got this
little apple, whoops, there we go.

41
00:01:47.520 --> 00:01:49.200
There's a little apple
floating right up here.

42
00:01:49.200 --> 00:01:53.380
And if I click my apple, I'll see some
various things mainly About This Mac and

43
00:01:53.380 --> 00:01:55.110
then System Preferences, right?

44
00:01:55.110 --> 00:01:58.496
So I can quickly and easily jump into my
System Preferences right when I need it.

45
00:01:58.496 --> 00:02:01.430
So I'm gonna do that, just jump
right into System Preferences, and

46
00:02:01.430 --> 00:02:04.220
you'll see a screen that looks like this.

47
00:02:04.220 --> 00:02:08.810
Now we just completed a clean
install of macOS, and so this

48
00:02:08.810 --> 00:02:12.360
is the System Preference screen as you'll
see it on a new install of macOS Sierra.

49
00:02:13.390 --> 00:02:17.564
If you're looking your existing Mac,
things might look different, right?

50
00:02:17.564 --> 00:02:20.758
Over time, as you add more software,
things start to customize and change.

51
00:02:20.758 --> 00:02:23.622
You might add additional hardware and
things start to change.

52
00:02:23.622 --> 00:02:26.000
There's various thing that may appear or
may not appear.

53
00:02:26.000 --> 00:02:30.790
For example,
I see the CDs & DVDs system preference.

54
00:02:30.790 --> 00:02:33.032
What if you don't have a CD or DVD drive?

55
00:02:33.032 --> 00:02:34.508
Then that doesn't show up, and is missing.

56
00:02:34.508 --> 00:02:36.580
So it is little bit dynamic, right?

57
00:02:36.580 --> 00:02:38.248
It's also dynamic in screen size, right?

58
00:02:38.248 --> 00:02:42.060
So if I drag it, make it wider or
whatever, it'll kind of align differently.

59
00:02:42.060 --> 00:02:44.210
But as far as the icons themselves,

60
00:02:44.210 --> 00:02:47.150
they change based on the hardware
that you have, right?

61
00:02:47.150 --> 00:02:50.410
So your screen might look a little bit
different than mine, but for the most

62
00:02:50.410 --> 00:02:53.854
part, these are the icons that we expect
to see inside of System Preferences.

63
00:02:53.854 --> 00:02:57.070
>> Now Don, I'm also noticing
that they seem to be broken up.

64
00:02:57.070 --> 00:03:00.049
I don't see one continuous block of icons.

65
00:03:00.049 --> 00:03:02.220
They seem to be chunked together.

66
00:03:02.220 --> 00:03:04.470
>> Right, yeah, they're not alphabetized.

67
00:03:04.470 --> 00:03:05.754
First off,
that always kind off annoyed me.

68
00:03:05.754 --> 00:03:07.704
>> That's fun.
>> Here's General and there's Dock, so

69
00:03:07.704 --> 00:03:09.460
they're not really alphabetized.

70
00:03:09.460 --> 00:03:11.330
And they're arranged in
these odd categories and

71
00:03:11.330 --> 00:03:12.790
the categories are not labeled.

72
00:03:12.790 --> 00:03:15.000
So what's the real meaning here?

73
00:03:15.000 --> 00:03:18.220
Well, first off, let me just clarify
because this all sounds bad, right?

74
00:03:18.220 --> 00:03:18.982
Alphabetize it.

75
00:03:18.982 --> 00:03:20.365
>> This is horrible.
>> Weird categories,

76
00:03:20.365 --> 00:03:22.264
the main reason is they said look,

77
00:03:22.264 --> 00:03:25.825
users shouldn't have to
memorize where settings are.

78
00:03:25.825 --> 00:03:28.310
So if I wanna do something like
set my screen saver, well,

79
00:03:28.310 --> 00:03:31.895
I've got it right here, Desktop & Screen
Saver, if I know to look for it, right?

80
00:03:31.895 --> 00:03:34.755
But if you don't remember where
a setting is, you can just go

81
00:03:34.755 --> 00:03:39.495
right up to your search box and you can
type what it is you're looking to do.

82
00:03:39.495 --> 00:03:41.685
So when I start to type screen,

83
00:03:41.685 --> 00:03:45.900
see how some of the icons have
a little glow around them, right?

84
00:03:45.900 --> 00:03:48.580
Those are ones that have
something to do with screen.

85
00:03:48.580 --> 00:03:51.800
Now what does Keyboard
have to do with screen?

86
00:03:51.800 --> 00:03:55.150
Well, there's a screen reader
functionality that has a shortcut that's

87
00:03:55.150 --> 00:03:56.070
tied to the keyboards.

88
00:03:56.070 --> 00:03:58.730
You have a keyboard shortcut
to turn on the screen reader.

89
00:03:58.730 --> 00:04:01.780
I wouldn't necessarily know that
if I wasn't looking for it.

90
00:04:01.780 --> 00:04:03.890
But if I continue typing here, and

91
00:04:03.890 --> 00:04:07.350
type in screen saver, see how it
starts getting smaller and smaller?

92
00:04:07.350 --> 00:04:09.090
And finally, I got a direct hit.

93
00:04:09.090 --> 00:04:12.091
When you get a direct hit,
it's not just a little glow any more

94
00:04:12.091 --> 00:04:15.990
like under Security & Privacy where
there's a screensaver timeout setting.

95
00:04:15.990 --> 00:04:18.570
It says require a password
after the screensaver turns on.

96
00:04:18.570 --> 00:04:22.630
Here, I can actually set the screensaver,
so it's a nice well-defined circle.

97
00:04:22.630 --> 00:04:25.350
This is probably the one I want.

98
00:04:25.350 --> 00:04:27.920
So because of that search functionality,

99
00:04:27.920 --> 00:04:31.430
you don't really care what category
it's in, what order they're in.

100
00:04:31.430 --> 00:04:33.460
You can quickly and
easily find what you want.

101
00:04:33.460 --> 00:04:37.670
But just so you know, there is some
meaning to the madness, all right?

102
00:04:37.670 --> 00:04:41.770
Each of these little divisions
here represents a category, and

103
00:04:41.770 --> 00:04:45.420
the first category is
what's called Personal.

104
00:04:45.420 --> 00:04:49.300
These are personal settings that
apply just to your user account.

105
00:04:49.300 --> 00:04:52.890
If there's five different users on
the computer, when they log in,

106
00:04:52.890 --> 00:04:56.280
they each maintain their
own personal settings.

107
00:04:56.280 --> 00:04:58.130
Now there's a few exceptions to that rule.

108
00:04:58.130 --> 00:05:02.010
For example, when I go to Security and
Privacy, inside of Security and

109
00:05:02.010 --> 00:05:06.292
Privacy we have FileVault and FileVault
lets us encrypt the whole hard drive.

110
00:05:06.292 --> 00:05:08.210
Well, that's gonna encrypt it for
everybody,

111
00:05:08.210 --> 00:05:10.000
right, because it's the whole hard drive.

112
00:05:10.000 --> 00:05:11.790
So that one actually
does apply to everybody.

113
00:05:11.790 --> 00:05:16.100
But many of the other settings that
are in here really just apply to you.

114
00:05:16.100 --> 00:05:17.820
So for example, if I go under General,

115
00:05:17.820 --> 00:05:21.920
you'll see things like, what's my general
appearance for buttons and windows?

116
00:05:21.920 --> 00:05:24.610
See all these buttons,
these little drop down buttons are blue.

117
00:05:24.610 --> 00:05:27.030
Right, that's part of
the default theme in the system.

118
00:05:27.030 --> 00:05:29.950
I could change it to graphite and
now they'll turn gray.

119
00:05:29.950 --> 00:05:32.290
Right, so
if I hate blue I can switch to gray.

120
00:05:32.290 --> 00:05:34.710
Apple gives you the ability to hate color.

121
00:05:34.710 --> 00:05:36.902
[LAUGH] So you can choose that.

122
00:05:36.902 --> 00:05:38.250
People have preferences, I guess.

123
00:05:38.250 --> 00:05:41.080
They don't give you a whole lot of
options, right, blue and graphite.

124
00:05:41.080 --> 00:05:43.580
You can choose to Use a dark menu bar and
Dock.

125
00:05:43.580 --> 00:05:44.990
And sometimes that works out really well.

126
00:05:44.990 --> 00:05:47.619
See this menu bar up here how it's white,
or light gray, silver?

127
00:05:47.619 --> 00:05:48.847
>> It's like a light gray.

128
00:05:48.847 --> 00:05:49.780
>> Yeah, I don't know what it is.

129
00:05:49.780 --> 00:05:51.510
And then down here,
same thing in the Dock.

130
00:05:51.510 --> 00:05:54.320
I can come up here and choose to use
a dark one, and it becomes dark.

131
00:05:54.320 --> 00:05:56.082
It looks way more stylish, right?

132
00:05:56.082 --> 00:05:58.690
>> That's great for low lights,
if you're doing a low light area.

133
00:05:58.690 --> 00:05:59.380
>> That's a good point.

134
00:05:59.380 --> 00:06:00.860
>> I really like that in
a low light situation.

135
00:06:00.860 --> 00:06:03.070
>> Or if you just have a wallpaper
where it looks better,

136
00:06:03.070 --> 00:06:04.390
cuz it's aesthetics, right?

137
00:06:04.390 --> 00:06:08.050
But we can kinda tweak that, so that's
another option that we can customize.

138
00:06:08.050 --> 00:06:10.570
You can Automatically hide and
show the menu bar.

139
00:06:10.570 --> 00:06:13.590
The menu bar up top,
see how it's always up there, right?

140
00:06:13.590 --> 00:06:15.940
If I choose to automatically hide it,
it disappears.

141
00:06:15.940 --> 00:06:17.630
And if I move my mouse
up there it'll pop up.

142
00:06:17.630 --> 00:06:19.412
Now I'm in a virtual machine, so

143
00:06:19.412 --> 00:06:22.674
my virtual machine menu will
pop up also if I'm not careful.

144
00:06:22.674 --> 00:06:23.660
So you may not want that.

145
00:06:23.660 --> 00:06:25.950
Like for me, I don't want that
cuz it messes up my functionally.

146
00:06:25.950 --> 00:06:29.170
There went my virtual machine one,
but I'll turn that back off so

147
00:06:29.170 --> 00:06:30.630
the menu bar's always there.

148
00:06:30.630 --> 00:06:33.640
If I change these options,
they're being changed just for me.

149
00:06:33.640 --> 00:06:35.300

36
00:01:34.350 --> 00:01:37.490

37
00:01:37.490 --> 00:01:42.090

38
00:01:42.090 --> 00:01:45.540

00:01:45.540 --> 00:01:50.130

00:02:17.470 --> 00:02:20.520

00:02:45.620 --> 00:02:46.380

00:02:46.380 --> 00:02:50.930

00:02:50.930 --> 00:02:53.940

00:02:53.940 --> 00:02:57.390

00:05:18.440 --> 00:05:23.040

00:05:27.460 --> 00:05:29.800

00:05:42.040 --> 00:05:45.810

00:05:48.290 --> 00:05:51.680

117
00:05:51.680 --> 00:05:53.270
But once I reboot it'll turn that on.

118
00:05:53.270 --> 00:05:55.780
And we can just go right back into that

119
00:05:55.780 --> 00:05:58.158
So a firmware password
is easy to turn on and

ticks to another computer its

And where gonna see FileVault

00:19:00.860 --> 00:19:04.150

00:19:04.150 --> 00:19:06.250
It's pretty straight forward process, but

00:19:06.250 --> 00:19:09.450
this ensures that if somebody were

00:19:12.780 --> 00:19:16.120
Unless they have a password for

00:19:16.120 --> 00:19:17.194
So Filevault truly nice.

00:19:17.194 --> 00:19:20.661
One thing that might turn up on the exam

00:19:20.661 --> 00:19:21.800

00:19:21.800 --> 00:19:22.850
This is FileVault version two.

408
00:19:22.850 --> 00:19:25.407
I know it does [CROSSTALK] but

00:19:25.407 --> 00:19:28.461

00:19:30.210 --> 00:19:33.270

412
00:19:33.270 --> 00:19:35.630
So like slash users slash center or

413
00:19:35.630 --> 00:19:37.790
It would only encrypt your home directory.

414
00:19:37.790 --> 00:19:40.440
And the problem there was there

415
00:19:40.440 --> 00:19:42.240
That really wasn't good.

416
00:19:42.240 --> 00:19:45.800
So in FileVault version two,
it encrypts the entire hard drive.

417
00:19:45.800 --> 00:19:48.710
The only time you'll see
FileVault version one anymore is

418
00:19:48.710 --> 00:19:51.450
if you have a system that's been

419
00:19:51.450 --> 00:19:54.220
So maybe you were running snow leopard.

420
00:19:54.220 --> 00:19:56.380
I know a really old while back.

00:19:56.380 --> 00:19:59.950
>> And you've upgraded a few times and

And what Apple recommends you do is

427
00:20:17.960 --> 00:20:21.960

428
00:20:21.960 --> 00:20:23.250
That's the better way to go about it.

429
00:20:23.250 --> 00:20:26.920
So you really don't want to be running

00:20:26.920 --> 00:20:29.380
you really need to turn that off and

431

Now Don, we made a couple of jokes about

We do have concern about

>> Absolutely, yeah and that's really

And Location Services,

And that sounds like a bad thing, right?

There is a good side,

And that is, what happens if

00:21:28.490 --> 00:21:32.200
So that kinda in the other side, but you

So back under security and
privacy you can see or

we can choose who gets access

I want Safari or Siri or whoever that

Same thing with contacts,

You can dictate what's

The one you really wanna be

Applications that have accessibility

458

your keyboard right as well as record
what's going on on the screen and

459

So for example I use Flash Top.

Flash Top lets me remotely

468
00:22:22.430 --> 00:22:25.860
So any applications you
add under accessibility

episodes.description: In this episode, Don introduced us to the ways macOS handles disks and their associated data. He details the various file systems supported by macOS Sierra, demonstrates how to prepare a drive for use, and walks us through some troubleshooting procedures should the need arise.

WEBVTT

1

Welcome to ITPRO.TV,

2
00:00:01.981 --> 00:00:05.931

3

6
00:00:16.393 --> 00:00:20.710
certified support professional from
Mac OS Sierra I'm you host, Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:20.710 --> 00:00:22.717
And today, we're gonna be

8
00:00:22.717 --> 00:00:25.720
And helping us out is gonna be,

9

And this is a pretty neat topic because

14

But there are a lot of new
things some advanced features,

15
00:00:41.580 --> 00:00:44.720
some security concerns, and
other things that we need to be aware of.

16
00:00:44.720 --> 00:00:47.017
So in this episode, and really over

17
00:00:47.017 --> 00:00:50.503
We're gonna be talking about some of
the different file storage options,

18
00:00:50.503 --> 00:00:53.214
the way the files are handled

19
00:00:53.214 --> 00:00:56.450
some of the security procedures that

20
00:00:56.450 --> 00:00:59.414
So quite a bit of stuff, but
it is important, cuz it is foundational

21
00:00:59.414 --> 00:01:03.008
knowledge and it affects every single user
that makes use of an operating system.

22
00:01:03.008 --> 00:01:06.215
>> All right so, Don, what are some of
the different types of storage that we're

23
00:01:06.215 --> 00:01:08.410
really talking about when
we're working with this?

24
00:01:08.410 --> 00:01:11.700
>> okay so we've got two
primary categories of storage.

25
00:01:11.700 --> 00:01:13.870
There's internal and external.

26
00:01:13.870 --> 00:01:16.171
When you buy a Mac, well,
if you buy it today,

27
00:01:16.171 --> 00:01:19.786
you're gonna have internal storage
that's generally fixed storage.

28
00:01:19.786 --> 00:01:22.721
It's soldered onto the mother board
you really can't do anything about it.

29
00:01:22.721 --> 00:01:27.521
Some of the larger Macs like the Mac Pros
actually do have a changeable internal

30
00:01:27.521 --> 00:01:29.061
storage or expandable.

31
00:01:29.061 --> 00:01:32.299
We can add more or
get different configurations inside of it.

32
00:01:32.299 --> 00:01:38.910
But either way, that storage is designed
to always be inside the computer.

33
00:01:38.910 --> 00:01:40.890
It's not something you pop
out from time to time,

34
00:01:40.890 --> 00:01:43.640
it stays in the computer all the time.

35
00:01:43.640 --> 00:01:45.230
Versus external storage or

36
00:01:45.230 --> 00:01:48.600
removable storage, which is designed
to be there some of the time, right?

37
00:01:48.600 --> 00:01:52.071
We can add it when we need it, take it out
when we don't need it, it comes and goes.

38
00:01:52.071 --> 00:01:54.277
Now on the internal storage side,

39
00:01:54.277 --> 00:01:58.697
there's really only two types of
storage that we see on modern Macs.

40
00:01:58.697 --> 00:02:02.315
So when you go and publish one right now,
it's typically going to be a hard drive,

41
00:02:02.315 --> 00:02:03.312
and with hard drives,

42
00:02:03.312 --> 00:02:06.530
there's two types of hard drives
everything's gonna be in twos today.

43
00:02:06.530 --> 00:02:08.562
>> [LAUGH]
>> So we've got HDs,

44
00:02:08.562 --> 00:02:15.140
traditional spinning disks, and we've
got SSDs, or solid-state digital drives.

45
00:02:15.140 --> 00:02:18.130
And these two disks,
they show up the same for an end user.

46
00:02:18.130 --> 00:02:22.371
When an end user looks at their operating
system, they see Macintosh HD, and

47
00:02:22.371 --> 00:02:26.520
they don't necessarily know if it's SSD or
an older style HDD.

48
00:02:26.520 --> 00:02:30.086
And where they might notice
is simply in the speed.

49
00:02:30.086 --> 00:02:33.440
SSD is the newer technology it's very,
very fast.

50
00:02:33.440 --> 00:02:37.580
HDDs is the older technologies,
and they're not terribly fast.

51
00:02:37.580 --> 00:02:39.720
They were fast 20 years ago, but

52
00:02:39.720 --> 00:02:43.100
times have changed quite a bit and
they aren't fast anymore.

53
00:02:43.100 --> 00:02:44.982
So let's kinda cover what
the basics are on those.

54
00:02:44.982 --> 00:02:49.543
A HDD or a hard disk drive is
a traditional spinning disk.

55
00:02:49.543 --> 00:02:52.603
If you were to take one of these
things and crack them open,

56
00:02:52.603 --> 00:02:56.168
they've got these little platters,
these metal well, circles?

57
00:02:56.168 --> 00:02:56.996
>> Yeah, yeah.

58
00:02:56.996 --> 00:02:58.433
>> They spin, kind of,
kind of like a record in a record player,

59
00:02:58.433 --> 00:02:59.389
if you remember what a record player is.

60
00:02:59.389 --> 00:03:00.260
>> [LAUGH].

61
00:03:00.260 --> 00:03:01.370
>> And so they, they spin.

62
00:03:01.370 --> 00:03:04.150
And it reads the data right off
of there by using electricity.

63
00:03:04.150 --> 00:03:07.900
It's all, all stored with
magnetic pulses that are kind of

64
00:03:07.900 --> 00:03:10.620
written to the disk as ones and
zeros, it can be read back.

65
00:03:10.620 --> 00:03:13.210
The technology is sound,
it works very well.

66
00:03:13.210 --> 00:03:15.750
But it's not very fast,
because you have a spinning disk.

67
00:03:15.750 --> 00:03:18.956
And there's a mechanical arm that
has to move to read that disk and

68
00:03:18.956 --> 00:03:21.240
it takes time for
that mechanical arm to move.

69
00:03:21.240 --> 00:03:24.200
You've got a physical motor also.

70
00:03:24.200 --> 00:03:27.150
And that means that over time,
that disk is going to wear out.

71
00:03:27.150 --> 00:03:30.040
And it's rare that you get more than three
to four years of lifetime out of one

72
00:03:30.040 --> 00:03:31.048
of these spinning disks.

73
00:03:31.048 --> 00:03:33.580
There are some that will go much,
much longer.

74
00:03:33.580 --> 00:03:35.950
But it's really iffy beyond
three to four years.

75
00:03:37.160 --> 00:03:39.930
Solid state drives, on the other hand,
do away with the spinning disk.

76

00:26:19.210 --> 00:26:21.090
And that way you can identify that disk.

527
00:26:21.090 --> 00:26:25.990
GPT is supported by newer versions of
Windows and newer versions of Mac OS and

528
00:26:25.990 --> 00:26:30.050
this is usually what you're going
to want on your modern disks.

529
00:26:30.050 --> 00:26:32.560
Unless you're having to
integrate with older systems,

530
00:26:32.560 --> 00:26:34.440
they won't be able to read this, right?

531
00:26:34.440 --> 00:26:36.420
So we been joking around,

532
00:26:36.420 --> 00:26:41.170
in some of our intros Ronnie's
mentioned Mac OS 10.2 instead of 10.12.

533
00:26:41.170 --> 00:26:44.290
Well, Mac OS 10.2 didn't recognize GPT.

534
00:26:44.290 --> 00:26:47.170
And so if you plugged a dot drive
into that it wouldn't work, right?

535
00:26:47.170 --> 00:26:49.000
But if you have all monitor systems,
it's not a problem.

536
00:26:49.000 --> 00:26:51.660
GPT is the future,
that's usually what we're going to want.

537
00:26:51.660 --> 00:26:55.040
But if you know you're going to moving
an external drive between systems, and

538
00:26:55.040 --> 00:26:59.560
there's gonna be a lot of variation there,
then that can cause some problems.

539
00:26:59.560 --> 00:27:03.820
And then you might want to go ahead and
default back to the older MBR, all right.

540
00:27:03.820 --> 00:27:06.600
Now there's a third one, Apple Partition
Map, and you might be tempted and

541
00:27:06.600 --> 00:27:08.020
say, hey, I'm on a Mac.

542
00:27:08.020 --> 00:27:10.370
I like Apple,
I'm gonna go Apple Partition Map.

543
00:27:10.370 --> 00:27:11.615
Don't pick this one, right?

544
00:27:11.615 --> 00:27:14.110
>> [LAUGH]
>> This is ancient history.

545
00:27:14.110 --> 00:27:17.130
Apple, a long time ago,
before they did the Intel switch,

546
00:27:17.130 --> 00:27:20.760
was using the Apple Partition Map for
their systems back in the SCSI drive days.

547
00:27:20.760 --> 00:27:24.750
If you've got really old systems, you
might need to be able to connect to mount

548
00:27:24.750 --> 00:27:26.400
those, and
that's why that support is here.

549
00:27:26.400 --> 00:27:28.090
It's really there for
backwards compatibility.

550
00:27:28.090 --> 00:27:30.480
It's not intended to be used anymore.

551
00:27:30.480 --> 00:27:32.200
It is the older of the technology.

552
00:27:34.190 --> 00:27:36.080
Al right now,
when I pick one of these partition maps,

553
00:27:36.080 --> 00:27:39.920
right so If I pick GUID partition map,
and I'll call this my,

554
00:27:39.920 --> 00:27:44.860
Don's USB Storage or
whatever it is I want to call it.

555
00:27:44.860 --> 00:27:46.810
It's gonna automatically format that disk,

556
00:27:46.810 --> 00:27:50.890
it's gonna get it ready, and it's going
to fail on me, so what did it do?

557
00:27:50.890 --> 00:27:51.390
Let's see.

558
00:27:52.760 --> 00:27:54.910
So every now and then you might
get something like this, right?

559
00:27:54.910 --> 00:27:58.070
See how it says unmounting the disk
couldn't open the device, right.

560
00:27:58.070 --> 00:28:00.980
Well, that means that something on my
system was accessing the disk at the time.

561
00:28:00.980 --> 00:28:04.560
And so it wasn't able to release it and
it failed.

562
00:28:04.560 --> 00:28:08.210
Well, if it had just been patient,
then it probably would've succeeded.

563
00:28:08.210 --> 00:28:10.210
And in my case, it just wasn't patient.

564
00:28:10.210 --> 00:28:11.060
So I'm gonna hit Done.

565
00:28:11.060 --> 00:28:12.950
And I'm gonna try it again.

566
00:28:12.950 --> 00:28:16.610
And a lot of times, what you'll find is
that the second time you do it, it works.

567
00:28:16.610 --> 00:28:18.710
All right, and so we'll run it again.

568
00:28:18.710 --> 00:28:21.840
And this time, there we go,
and it works, right?

569
00:28:21.840 --> 00:28:23.770
If you just wait a moment, and

570
00:28:23.770 --> 00:28:27.510
make sure that whatever process is hitting
that disc releases, then it'll run.

571
00:28:27.510 --> 00:28:30.501
If it doesn't, right, if you run it
a second time and it still fails,

572
00:28:30.501 --> 00:28:33.293
then usually if you just reboot
your system that'll free it up and

573
00:28:33.293 --> 00:28:37.450
stop whatever it was accessing that disk,
and it'll let you get in there and do it.

574
00:28:37.450 --> 00:28:41.020
But now that's done, it's erased,
here's the drive I can see it.

575
00:28:41.020 --> 00:28:45.240
If I look down here the Partition Map is
showing is the GUID Partition Map, so

576
00:28:45.240 --> 00:28:47.700
that's good and it's up and it's going.

577
00:28:47.700 --> 00:28:50.250
And I'm now got this disk ready to use,
right.

578
00:28:50.250 --> 00:28:53.310
The partition is on it, but
the partition isn't enough.

579
00:28:53.310 --> 00:28:55.300
We actually have to take that
partition and format it, and

580
00:28:55.300 --> 00:28:56.340
put a file system on it.

581
00:28:56.340 --> 00:28:59.800
I'm gonna talk about file
systems in the next episode,

582
00:28:59.800 --> 00:29:02.460
cuz I'm kinda running out of time here.

583
00:29:02.460 --> 00:29:07.630
But basically, this disk is up and ready,
and we can start to make use of it.

584
00:29:07.630 --> 00:29:09.990
Now, I still can't partition it, right?

585
00:29:09.990 --> 00:29:11.090
Well, no, now I can.

586
00:29:11.090 --> 00:29:13.460
Now that I've formatted it and

587
00:29:13.460 --> 00:29:17.450
I've reset it over to GPT, there was
likely some older data on there cuz I had

588
00:29:17.450 --> 00:29:20.930
plugged it into a Windows machine that
was stopping me from partitioning it.

589
00:29:20.930 --> 00:29:24.480
So by erasing it, now I can come in and
I can partition this disk.

590
00:29:24.480 --> 00:29:26.870
And I can start to divide that up, right?

591
00:29:26.870 --> 00:29:30.710
So if you ever see where that partition
is blocked, the normal indicator, and

592
00:29:30.710 --> 00:29:33.430
you guys might not care about the
technical details, is that if you format

593
00:29:33.430 --> 00:29:37.350
a disk on Windows, a lot of times it
will create an EFI partition on there.

594
00:29:37.350 --> 00:29:41.430
And the disk utility hides
the EFI partitions by default.

595
00:29:41.430 --> 00:29:44.260
And that's what stops me from
being able to partition it.

596
00:29:44.260 --> 00:29:47.690
But when I erase the entire disk,
it got rid of that hidden partition.

597
00:29:47.690 --> 00:29:48.770
And now we can divide it up.

598
00:29:48.770 --> 00:29:53.190
So if you ever run into that in real life,
you can't see it through the GUI utility.

599
00:29:53.190 --> 00:29:55.350
If you go to the command
line drop the terminal,

600
00:29:55.350 --> 00:29:58.220
you can use the disk util command line and

601
00:29:58.220 --> 00:30:01.010
you actually see the DFI partition
in there and you can wipe it out.

602
00:30:01.010 --> 00:30:04.280
So just a little aside not on the exam but

603
00:30:04.280 --> 00:30:06.450
something you might run
into it in real life.

604
00:30:06.450 --> 00:30:08.920
All right so now it can come through
though and I can't take this.

605
00:30:08.920 --> 00:30:12.960
And I can say like maybe I'm gonna use
half this disk for Time Machine right?

606
00:30:12.960 --> 00:30:16.170
So this is gonna be 500 gigs
that I assign for Time Machine.

607
00:30:16.170 --> 00:30:17.990
And then the other half,
I want to come in and

608
00:30:17.990 --> 00:30:23.410
use for, I don't know,
temporary storage, right?

609
00:30:23.410 --> 00:30:26.720
So this is stuff that I might be sharing
with somebody else, or whatever.

610
00:30:26.720 --> 00:30:31.460
So I divide it in half, 500 and
500, or maybe 750 and 250,

611
00:30:31.460 --> 00:30:33.790
or however I want to divide it.

612
00:30:33.790 --> 00:30:37.122
I can apply that and it's gonna partition
that out and now I'll have that storage

613
00:30:37.122 --> 00:30:40.356
available, unless I get an error which
case, I'll just do it a second time and

614
00:30:40.356 --> 00:30:42.628
then [LAUGH] it'll partition
out a whole new business.

615
00:30:42.628 --> 00:30:46.059
But no, it's running through
just fine right there.

616
00:30:46.059 --> 00:30:48.390
Al right, so that is probably
a pretty good spot to stop.

617
00:30:48.390 --> 00:30:52.100
I do need to talk more about file systems,
but we'll need to do that in part two.

618
00:30:53.190 --> 00:30:57.160
>> All right, Don, well that's a great
reminder for us to think about the idea,

619
00:30:57.160 --> 00:31:00.270
here, of making sure that we understand
the storage that's available for

620
00:31:00.270 --> 00:31:03.250
us, when running,
of course, Mac OS Sierra.

621
00:31:03.250 --> 00:31:05.950
Making sure that we understand
difference between internal as well as

622
00:31:05.950 --> 00:31:07.050
external storage.

623
00:31:07.050 --> 00:31:11.860
And preparing that disk and disks so
that we can get ready to use downtime to

624
00:31:11.860 --> 00:31:15.320
be able to put operating systems as
well as our files on them as well.

625
00:31:15.320 --> 00:31:17.250
Thank you again, Don for
helping us out there.

626
00:31:17.250 --> 00:31:19.170
And thank you also for watching.

627
00:31:19.170 --> 00:31:22.790
Signing off from ITProTV,
I've been your host, Ronnie Wong.

628
00:31:22.790 --> 00:31:23.750
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

629
00:31:23.750 --> 00:31:27.711
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Apple Certified Support Professional.

630
00:31:27.711 --> 00:31:33.645
[MUSIC]

631
00:31:33.645 --> 00:31:37.077
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don introduced us to the ways macOS handles disks and their associated data. He details the various file systems supported by macOS Sierra, demonstrates how to prepare a drive for use, and walks us through some troubleshooting procedures should the need arise.
episodes.title: File Storage Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.250 --> 00:00:01.240
Welcome to IT PRO TV.

2
00:00:01.240 --> 00:00:03.210
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:03.210 --> 00:00:07.555
>> [CROSSTALK]
You're

4
00:00:07.555 --> 00:00:12.174
watching IT PRO TV.

5
00:00:12.174 --> 00:00:15.030
>> Welcome to another great
episode here IT PRO TV.

6
00:00:15.030 --> 00:00:19.580
You're watching the apple certified
support professional for Mac OS Sierra.

7
00:00:19.580 --> 00:00:23.456
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, today were
taking a look at a part II on file storage

8
00:00:23.456 --> 00:00:27.038
and here to help us to continue to
understand some more depth about this is

9
00:00:27.038 --> 00:00:29.940
gonna be Mr. Don Pezet,
Don welcome back to the studios.

10
00:00:29.940 --> 00:00:31.320
>> Thanks for having me back Ronnie, and

11
00:00:31.320 --> 00:00:32.970
yeah just kinda continuing
on with storage.

12
00:00:32.970 --> 00:00:35.974
In the last episode we talked about
some of the different types of storage

13
00:00:35.974 --> 00:00:37.300
that we find in Macs.

14
00:00:37.300 --> 00:00:40.867
And then I took a drive, we partitioned
it, and I just really quickly formatted it

15
00:00:40.867 --> 00:00:44.590
at the end of the show as we didn't have
enough time to talk about file systems.

16
00:00:44.590 --> 00:00:46.706
And so, in this episode,
that's where I want to start.

17
00:00:46.706 --> 00:00:49.260
I wanna start by talking
about file systems.

18
00:00:49.260 --> 00:00:53.130
When you partition a disk,
you're putting "walls" in the disk.

19
00:00:53.130 --> 00:00:56.765
Virtual walls, not real ones,
they can isolate and separate your data.

20
00:00:56.765 --> 00:00:58.980
Well, the nice part about
these walls is that,

21
00:00:58.980 --> 00:01:02.750
inside of them,
you can then apply a file system.

22
00:01:02.750 --> 00:01:06.040
And when you apply a file system,
now you can actually put files on it.

23
00:01:06.040 --> 00:01:08.870
Well, at that point,
it's not just a partition anymore.

24
00:01:08.870 --> 00:01:12.530
It now becomes a volume,
that terminology's important, right?

25
00:01:12.530 --> 00:01:14.660
When I divide up the disk and
I'm partitioning it.

26
00:01:14.660 --> 00:01:17.560
And then, when I put a file
system on that I create a volume.

27
00:01:17.560 --> 00:01:20.920
So if I create three partitions, and
then I format the three partitions,

28
00:01:20.920 --> 00:01:22.430
I now have three volumes.

29
00:01:22.430 --> 00:01:26.790
I can use a volume, I can't really use
a partition until it becomes a volume.

30
00:01:26.790 --> 00:01:30.457
Now when we format it, when we apply
the file system to that storage,

31
00:01:30.457 --> 00:01:33.700
there's actually a couple of
choices that we have, right?

32
00:01:33.700 --> 00:01:36.290
So for example,
let me go back into my disk utility here.

33
00:01:36.290 --> 00:01:38.530
This is what I did at
the very end of the show.

34
00:01:38.530 --> 00:01:42.170
I took my USB storage and
I divided it up into two drives, right.

35
00:01:42.170 --> 00:01:43.630
Well, I'm gonna divide it again.

36
00:01:43.630 --> 00:01:45.350
This time I'm gonna go to four drives.

37
00:01:45.350 --> 00:01:48.800
And I'm gonna divide that
up into four pieces, and

38
00:01:48.800 --> 00:01:51.460
each one I'm gonna format
a slightly different way.

39
00:01:51.460 --> 00:01:55.250
So I'm gonna take my first one here,
the one I labeled as time machine.

40
00:01:55.250 --> 00:01:59.150
And if you look at the options here
on my screen I've got the name,

41
00:01:59.150 --> 00:02:01.300
which you can call it whatever you want.

42
00:02:01.300 --> 00:02:07.712
And then the format, and the format is
defaulting to Mac OS Extended Journaled

43
00:02:07.712 --> 00:02:12.000
and I'm gonna type that as the name,
just so I can remember what it is, right.

44
00:02:12.000 --> 00:02:14.520
And that's kind of a long name,
but we'll run with it.

45
00:02:14.520 --> 00:02:16.350
So extended journal.

46
00:02:16.350 --> 00:02:19.820
And that is the file system
it's going to apply,

47
00:02:19.820 --> 00:02:21.850
that it's going to turn it into a volume.

48
00:02:21.850 --> 00:02:23.570
But I've got more choices.

49
00:02:23.570 --> 00:02:25.979
I've got Mac OS Extended Journal
encrypted,

50
00:02:25.979 --> 00:02:30.450
Mac OC Extended Case Sensitive Journal and
Case Sensitive Journal encrypted.

51
00:02:30.450 --> 00:02:33.427
I've also had an exFAT and
MS-DOS FAT, right.

52
00:02:33.427 --> 00:02:36.660
So what exactly is going on here?

53
00:02:36.660 --> 00:02:37.860
Which one should I pick?

54
00:02:37.860 --> 00:02:38.970
Which one serves what purpose?

55
00:02:38.970 --> 00:02:43.285
Well, if you're dealing in an all Apple
world and you're happy with your ecosystem

56
00:02:43.285 --> 00:02:46.400
then, you're normally just
gonna stick with the default.

57
00:02:46.400 --> 00:02:48.530
Mac OS Extended Journaled.

58
00:02:48.530 --> 00:02:52.520
The Mac OS Extended file system is one
created by Apple, so it's proprietary.

59
00:02:52.520 --> 00:02:54.020
It's only supported by Apple.

60
00:02:54.020 --> 00:02:56.080
It doesn't work on Linux,
it doesn't work on Windows,

61
00:02:56.080 --> 00:02:57.940
it just works in the Apple world.

62
00:02:57.940 --> 00:03:00.330
But let me tell you, it does a great job.

63
00:03:00.330 --> 00:03:03.890
You're gonna get the best performance and
the best stability by choosing this one.

64
00:03:03.890 --> 00:03:09.130
Mac OS Extended Journaled, that journaled
part is a key part of the stability there.

65
00:03:09.130 --> 00:03:11.380
Not every file system is journaled,
this is special.

66
00:03:11.380 --> 00:03:14.850
There actually is a Mac OS Extended
that isn't journaled, but

67
00:03:14.850 --> 00:03:16.230
I don't have that option.

68
00:03:16.230 --> 00:03:20.520
In older versions of Mac OS, you actually
had the option to do it non-journaled.

69
00:03:20.520 --> 00:03:22.841
What journaling does,
it says any time you write to the disk,

70
00:03:22.841 --> 00:03:27.090
i f it's a new file, you just write
it to the disk, that's it, right.

71
00:03:27.090 --> 00:03:30.890
But if a file already exists, let's say,
I'm making a change to a file, right.

72
00:03:30.890 --> 00:03:34.260
Imagine this,
imagine that I've got a picture, and

73
00:03:34.260 --> 00:03:36.960
the picture is 10 megs in size.

74
00:03:36.960 --> 00:03:40.360
And I go and change a few little dots
on that picture, then I go to save it.

75
00:03:40.360 --> 00:03:43.280
Well I only changed a little of it,
but I start writing to the disk,

76
00:03:43.280 --> 00:03:45.070
writing the 10 megs,
then all of a sudden I lose power.

77
00:03:46.220 --> 00:03:48.610
Well, what happened,
I was halfway through a write.

78
00:03:48.610 --> 00:03:50.720
And so when the system boots back up,

79
00:03:50.720 --> 00:03:54.630
that image is now corrupted,
it has half the data written to it.

80
00:03:54.630 --> 00:03:56.900
Half of it is new data,
half of it is old data.

81
00:03:56.900 --> 00:03:59.360
It's damaged, and
I can't recover that image, right.

82
00:03:59.360 --> 00:04:01.312
So losing data like
that is really painful,

83
00:04:01.312 --> 00:04:04.847
especially removable media where you
could disconnect the drive by accident,

84
00:04:04.847 --> 00:04:08.400
it happens very frequently, far more
frequently than power outages, right.

85
00:04:08.400 --> 00:04:12.116
But with journalling, it says, all right
if you're about to write a file and

86
00:04:12.116 --> 00:04:13.374
the file already exists,

87
00:04:13.374 --> 00:04:17.220
instead of overwriting the file we're
gonna write to an all new spot.

88
00:04:17.220 --> 00:04:18.947
We're gonna write it separate and

89
00:04:18.947 --> 00:04:22.350
we're gonna write it to the disk
until it gets to 100% written.

90
00:04:22.350 --> 00:04:27.190
When it's 100% done, then we just remove
the old file and you've got the new one.

91
00:04:27.190 --> 00:04:30.241
And now, if you were halfway through
the write and you lost power,

92
00:04:30.241 --> 00:04:34.056
the system would boot back up and it would
say, you were halfway through the write,

93
00:04:34.056 --> 00:04:37.680
so I'm just going to throw the write away,
and I still have the original file.

94
00:04:37.680 --> 00:04:41.090
And it puts it back, and we're able to
recover, and things work much better.

95
00:04:41.090 --> 00:04:44.020
So that journaled option right
there gives us a lot of stability.

96
00:04:44.020 --> 00:04:47.330
And so Apple doesn't even give us
the option to do non-journal any more.

97
00:04:47.330 --> 00:04:51.960
You'll notice all four versions of
Mac OS Extended support journaling now.

98
00:04:51.960 --> 00:04:55.646
So the only real choice that I have here
is whether I want it to be encrypted,

99
00:04:55.646 --> 00:04:58.500
case sensitive, or both.

100
00:04:58.500 --> 00:05:02.080
Case sensitive and encrypted, right,
that's that fourth option right there.

101
00:05:02.080 --> 00:05:04.260
So when would I pick these?

102
00:05:04.260 --> 00:05:08.220
Well, encrypted,
I could encrypt the disk itself.

103
00:05:08.220 --> 00:05:13.210
All right, well, that's cool, but be aware
that this is different than file vault.

104
00:05:13.210 --> 00:05:15.640
I talk about file vault
in another episode.

105
00:05:15.640 --> 00:05:20.230
With file vault, when I boot up my
system the key is stored as part

106
00:05:20.230 --> 00:05:22.890
of the TPM on the motherboard,
that trusted platform module.

107
00:05:22.890 --> 00:05:24.180
And it's able to boot up and

108
00:05:24.180 --> 00:05:27.410
load right in as long as I login
with my user account and password.

109
00:05:27.410 --> 00:05:30.510
It decrypts the disc and I'm able to
access it and everything works fine.

110
00:05:30.510 --> 00:05:33.840
When I choose this type of encryption,
though, this is really talking about for

111
00:05:33.840 --> 00:05:34.810
removable disks.

112
00:05:34.810 --> 00:05:39.190
When I plug a removable disk into my
