560
00:28:12.810 --> 00:28:15.800
If I just eject it, it's gonna break.

561
00:28:15.800 --> 00:28:18.550
But if I drop it here,
it will properly eject.

562
00:28:18.550 --> 00:28:19.680
Now when it does that,

563
00:28:19.680 --> 00:28:23.674
it's gonna recognize it as one partition
of a multi-partition disk, right?

564
00:28:23.674 --> 00:28:25.530
There's more than one volume on that disk.

565
00:28:25.530 --> 00:28:28.520
So do I want to eject them all,
or just this one?

566
00:28:28.520 --> 00:28:31.560
And I can choose eject all, and
that will knock them out and

567
00:28:31.560 --> 00:28:34.230
get them safely unmounted.

568
00:28:34.230 --> 00:28:38.805
Now it is possible a program could be
holding open one of these partitions,

569
00:28:38.805 --> 00:28:39.321
right?

570
00:28:39.321 --> 00:28:41.936
And if I try and inject one, so for

571
00:28:41.936 --> 00:28:47.463
example I'm gonna just unhook that
drive and plug it back in, right?

572
00:28:47.463 --> 00:28:50.400
And once it's plugged back in
it'll remount those disks.

573
00:28:50.400 --> 00:28:53.520
So I could have remounted
from the disk utility also.

574
00:28:53.520 --> 00:28:57.590
But what I'm gonna do is I'm
gonna go into my terminal and

575
00:28:57.590 --> 00:29:01.800
I'm gonna go into Volume/FAT, and

576
00:29:01.800 --> 00:29:06.142
maybe I'll start editing a file
here inside of that folder.

577
00:29:06.142 --> 00:29:10.029
All right, so
I'm now working inside of that volume,

578
00:29:10.029 --> 00:29:12.826
inside of the one that's labeled FAT.

579
00:29:12.826 --> 00:29:15.379
And if I take that FAT volume and
drag it, and

580
00:29:15.379 --> 00:29:18.790
I'm gonna drop it down here
onto my eject button, right?

581
00:29:18.790 --> 00:29:22.281
It's gonna warn me, well,
that it's just one of four, but

582
00:29:22.281 --> 00:29:24.342
I'll eject just this one, right?

583
00:29:24.342 --> 00:29:28.952
And when I eject it,
it's showing that it's in use, right?

584
00:29:28.952 --> 00:29:31.220
The terminal is holding it in use.

585
00:29:31.220 --> 00:29:34.720
I need to quit that application and
try to eject the disc again.

586
00:29:34.720 --> 00:29:36.120
Ok, now,

587
00:29:36.120 --> 00:29:40.190
the reason it's showing me this is because
macOS is aware of the terminal app.

588
00:29:40.190 --> 00:29:41.740
It knows that it's running and healthy and

589
00:29:41.740 --> 00:29:44.390
I just need to go and
end what I was doing before I eject.

590
00:29:44.390 --> 00:29:49.340
If I just eject right now I could have
damaged files, partially written files.

591
00:29:49.340 --> 00:29:53.210
Sometimes, macOS can't talk to
the application that's doing it.

592
00:29:53.210 --> 00:29:56.590
And if it can't,
it assumes the application is locked.

593
00:29:56.590 --> 00:30:00.170
And if that happens there'll be another
button that appears here that says

594
00:30:00.170 --> 00:30:01.650
force eject.

595
00:30:01.650 --> 00:30:04.150
Force eject, we say forget it.

596
00:30:04.150 --> 00:30:06.160
Just forget that application.

597
00:30:06.160 --> 00:30:07.830
Let's just eject the drive.

598
00:30:07.830 --> 00:30:10.970
And when that happens the odds of
you having damaged files goes up

599
00:30:10.970 --> 00:30:12.030
significantly.

600
00:30:12.030 --> 00:30:14.860
So you want to make sure that you
properly eject whenever you can.

601
00:30:14.860 --> 00:30:17.880
In this case I just need
to say okay to that and

602
00:30:17.880 --> 00:30:20.540
get out of my terminal application here.

603
00:30:21.980 --> 00:30:25.820
And once I'm out of that,
now I should be able to come over here and

604
00:30:25.820 --> 00:30:26.900
eject that FAT disk.

605
00:30:26.900 --> 00:30:29.530
I'll just drag it and
drop it back down here again.

606
00:30:29.530 --> 00:30:32.920
And eject it, and now it'll properly
eject and not complain, right?

607
00:30:32.920 --> 00:30:35.810
So you always wanna make
sure that you safely unmount

608
00:30:35.810 --> 00:30:37.640
disks when you're done with them.

609
00:30:37.640 --> 00:30:39.620
And that way your files
won't become corrupted.

610
00:30:41.260 --> 00:30:43.050
All right, well, I think that pretty
much wraps up everything that we

611
00:30:43.050 --> 00:30:44.270
need to talk about on file storage.

612
00:30:44.270 --> 00:30:45.370
We still have some security and

613
00:30:45.370 --> 00:30:46.640
permissions that we're
gonna talk about later.

614
00:30:46.640 --> 00:30:49.430
But for right now, this is a pretty
good stopping point on this one.

615
00:30:49.430 --> 00:30:52.030
And we had a great chance to
learn about the different

616
00:30:52.030 --> 00:30:53.930
file systems that we can drop on there.

617
00:30:53.930 --> 00:30:56.650
And even the target mode that we
can use to help troubleshoot and

618
00:30:56.650 --> 00:30:58.700
repair other Macs.

619
00:30:58.700 --> 00:31:01.880
>> All right Don, well,
thank you again for helping us to

620
00:31:01.880 --> 00:31:04.420
understand a little bit more about some
of those different file systems and

621
00:31:04.420 --> 00:31:06.000
the choices that are before us.

622
00:31:06.000 --> 00:31:08.920
As well as showing us
the ability to use disk utility

623
00:31:08.920 --> 00:31:10.900
to help us with issues that may arise.

624
00:31:10.900 --> 00:31:14.220
And of course even to see how
those volumes are broken up.

625
00:31:14.220 --> 00:31:16.440
But that's a great place for
us to sign off.

626
00:31:16.440 --> 00:31:19.660
For IT Pro TV I've been
your host Ronnie Wong.

627
00:31:19.660 --> 00:31:20.700
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

628
00:31:20.700 --> 00:31:25.208
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Apple Certified Support Professional.

629
00:31:25.208 --> 00:31:31.254
[MUSIC]

630
00:31:31.254 --> 00:31:34.597
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode Don demonstrates encrypting disks using FileVault v2. He also explains how to upgrade from the original FileVault. He ends the episode by discussing how to securely erase files from the hard drive.
episodes.title: Securing Data
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:01.289
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.289 --> 00:00:06.278
I'm your host Don Pezet.
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.278 --> 00:00:07.948
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:07.948 --> 00:00:12.465
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:12.465 --> 00:00:14.051
>> Welcome back to ITPRO.TV.

6
00:00:14.051 --> 00:00:18.564
You're watching Apple Certified Support
Professional for Mac OS Sierra.

7
00:00:18.564 --> 00:00:22.229
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and today
we'll be learning about securing data.

8
00:00:22.229 --> 00:00:24.924
And here to help us to understand
that better is gonna be Mr Don Pezet,

9
00:00:24.924 --> 00:00:26.400
Don welcome back to the studios.

10
00:00:26.400 --> 00:00:27.325
>> Thanks for having me back Ronnie,

11
00:00:27.325 --> 00:00:30.110
and we're gonna continue on
our storage conversations.

12
00:00:30.110 --> 00:00:33.230
And talk a little bit about ways that
we can secure our data on the drive.

13
00:00:33.230 --> 00:00:37.430
Now there are actually two main techniques
available for securing our data.

14
00:00:37.430 --> 00:00:39.590
One is encryption and one is permission.

15
00:00:39.590 --> 00:00:42.000
And we're gonna talk
permissions in a later episode.

16
00:00:42.000 --> 00:00:46.317
Right here, we're gonna be more focused
on encryption and data recovery.

17
00:00:46.317 --> 00:00:49.401
One of the big fears or problems
that you have with a mobile device,

18
00:00:49.401 --> 00:00:50.680
like my laptop right here.

19
00:00:50.680 --> 00:00:52.236
I could store a lot of personal and

20
00:00:52.236 --> 00:00:55.020
private information
right here in my laptop.

21
00:00:55.020 --> 00:00:59.145
And then I get in a cab and
I leave the laptop on the cab.

22
00:00:59.145 --> 00:00:59.730
>> [LAUGH]
>> And I forget, or

23
00:00:59.730 --> 00:01:02.910
I'm sitting in an airport and somebody
runs by and snatches my laptop and runs.

24
00:01:02.910 --> 00:01:05.840
Well, they got my laptop, right.

25
00:01:05.840 --> 00:01:08.540
Well, all right, at least I know
they don't have my password.

26
00:01:08.540 --> 00:01:11.157
They can't log in as me, or can they?

27
00:01:11.157 --> 00:01:14.490
Back in some of the earlier episodes
we talked about the firmware password.

28
00:01:14.490 --> 00:01:18.309
And how if there's no firmware password
set, they can boot to recovery, and

29
00:01:18.309 --> 00:01:20.160
they can reset my password.

30
00:01:20.160 --> 00:01:24.300
Now they can log into my computer as me,
and have access to all my stuff.

31
00:01:24.300 --> 00:01:25.950
My data is no longer safe.

32
00:01:25.950 --> 00:01:29.828
And so the way we protect from
that is by encrypting our data and

33
00:01:29.828 --> 00:01:32.760
the best way to do that
is through file vault.

34
00:01:32.760 --> 00:01:35.060
Now file vault is not a new technology,

35
00:01:35.060 --> 00:01:37.170
we talked about it in
an earlier episode also.

36
00:01:37.170 --> 00:01:39.408
It was introduced a long time ago,

37
00:01:39.408 --> 00:01:43.045
I think it was OS 10.4 that
actually introduced it.

38
00:01:43.045 --> 00:01:46.069
But it ran for several years.

39
00:01:46.069 --> 00:01:48.634
The way it worked is it would
encrypt your home directory.

40
00:01:48.634 --> 00:01:50.682
So it would take your home directory,
your files, and

41
00:01:50.682 --> 00:01:52.158
it would encrypt it with a private key.

42
00:01:52.158 --> 00:01:55.810
Now, if I had a shared computer,
maybe Ronnie and I shared a laptop.

43
00:01:55.810 --> 00:01:58.380
His home folder could be encrypted and
mine could be encrypted.

44
00:01:58.380 --> 00:02:00.490
Or I might encrypt mine and
he might not encrypt his.

45
00:02:00.490 --> 00:02:01.200
We would kind of pick.

46
00:02:01.200 --> 00:02:04.580
But it encrypts your home folder and
everybody's encrypted separately.

47
00:02:04.580 --> 00:02:07.781
On a positive side, it makes it so every
user has their own key, so that's nice.

48
00:02:07.781 --> 00:02:09.585
But on a negative side,

49
00:02:09.585 --> 00:02:15.010
if I save something outside of my
home folder then it's not encrypted.

50
00:02:15.010 --> 00:02:18.135
And if somebody gets my laptop
they could boot it in target mode.

51
00:02:18.135 --> 00:02:19.770
Hold T while we boot.

52
00:02:19.770 --> 00:02:22.550
Hook it up as external storage mode
in computer browse right in and

53
00:02:22.550 --> 00:02:23.740
access the data.

54
00:02:23.740 --> 00:02:25.886
They wouldn't be able to get
into my home directory, but

55
00:02:25.886 --> 00:02:27.726
they'd be able to get everything else,
right?

56
00:02:27.726 --> 00:02:32.918
So starting with OS 10.6,
Apple replaced the old File Vault.

57
00:02:32.918 --> 00:02:36.181
File Vault version 1 is now
called the Legacy File Vault, and

58
00:02:36.181 --> 00:02:38.770
it's been replaced with
File Vault version 2.

59
00:02:38.770 --> 00:02:44.810
File Vault version 2 encrypts your
entire disk, the whole thing.

60
00:02:44.810 --> 00:02:48.360
The operating system, your home directory,
the files that are in and

61
00:02:48.360 --> 00:02:51.190
out of your own directory;
it gets the whole thing.

62
00:02:51.190 --> 00:02:53.358
And that's the best level of protection.

63
00:02:53.358 --> 00:02:55.439
If somebody physically
steals your equipment.

64
00:02:55.439 --> 00:02:57.984
Even if they rip the hard drives out and
pop them in their own computer,

65
00:02:57.984 --> 00:02:59.900
they still aren't gonna be
able to access the data.

66
00:02:59.900 --> 00:03:02.360
The entire thing's encrypted.

67
00:03:02.360 --> 00:03:03.810
That is where you want to be.

68
00:03:03.810 --> 00:03:06.660
Now I mentioned that in
an earlier episode but

69
00:03:06.660 --> 00:03:08.710
what we didn't do is actually
implement file vault.

70
00:03:08.710 --> 00:03:12.380
So in this episode I want to show you
guys how we implement file vault and

71
00:03:12.380 --> 00:03:15.040
get our system protected and encrypt it.

72
00:03:15.040 --> 00:03:18.020
So I’ve got a new machine here,
it's up and it's running MacOS Sierra.

73
00:03:18.020 --> 00:03:20.866
I haven't really done anything to
mess with it, it’s just up and

74
00:03:20.866 --> 00:03:21.758
running and happy.

75
00:03:21.758 --> 00:03:26.027
And this is really one of the best
times to encrypt the system.

76
00:03:26.027 --> 00:03:30.297
Because when we encrypt it if you've got a
ton of data on your system it's gonna take

77
00:03:30.297 --> 00:03:31.528
a long time to encrypt.

78
00:03:31.528 --> 00:03:34.887
Right I just went through this with a
laptop the other day where it had an SSD.

79
00:03:34.887 --> 00:03:37.860
It was very fast and
it had a ton of data on it.

80
00:03:37.860 --> 00:03:39.628
It had probably 300 gigs of data.

81
00:03:39.628 --> 00:03:43.232
Well it took a solid eight hours to
encrypt that laptop, it took a while.

82
00:03:43.232 --> 00:03:46.820
But on a system that doesn't have a ton
of data it encrypts pretty quick.

83
00:03:46.820 --> 00:03:51.470
And the reason is where our data resides,
that obviously needs to be encrypted.

84
00:03:51.470 --> 00:03:53.190
But the empty space is empty.

85
00:03:53.190 --> 00:03:55.090
And so
it can write zero bytes out to those.

86
00:03:55.090 --> 00:03:56.610
And it does that pretty quickly.

87
00:03:56.610 --> 00:03:57.810
And now your disk is encrypted.

88
00:03:57.810 --> 00:04:00.070
We can actually choose to
encrypt the entire thing,

89
00:04:00.070 --> 00:04:02.340
even the empty space if you want.

90
00:04:02.340 --> 00:04:04.470
It's much more thorough,
but it does take longer.

91
00:04:04.470 --> 00:04:10.350
But encrypting the drive in the early days
is gonna make things go a little faster.

92
00:04:10.350 --> 00:04:13.350
Now even if you didn't though,
you can turn it on at any point,

93
00:04:13.350 --> 00:04:15.740
just make sure you set aside some time.

94
00:04:15.740 --> 00:04:17.660
You can use your device
while it's encrypting,

95
00:04:17.660 --> 00:04:19.380
it's just gonna be a little slow, right.

96
00:04:19.380 --> 00:04:20.030
Let me show you what I mean.

97
00:04:20.030 --> 00:04:23.620
So I'm gonna go into my system
preferences on this system.

98
00:04:23.620 --> 00:04:27.100
I'll go into my Apple menu and
System Preferences.

99
00:04:27.100 --> 00:04:30.480
And inside of System Preferences I'm
going to go to Security and Privacy.

100
00:04:31.660 --> 00:04:35.250
And inside Security and Privacy I'm
going to go to the File Vault tab.

101
00:04:35.250 --> 00:04:38.310
Now if your system was upgraded

102
00:04:38.310 --> 00:04:41.600
from 10.6 to earlier it upgraded
all the way up to Sierra.

103
00:04:41.600 --> 00:04:42.845
First off, that's amazing.

104
00:04:42.845 --> 00:04:45.430
[LAUGH] Not a lot of
hardware is gonna do that.

105
00:04:45.430 --> 00:04:49.200
But if you did you might actually
have the Legacy File Vault turned on,

106
00:04:49.200 --> 00:04:52.240
you would see another tab here
that says Legacy File Vault.

107
00:04:52.240 --> 00:04:54.242
If you see that, step one for

108
00:04:54.242 --> 00:04:58.679
you needs to be to go to
the Legacy File Vault tab and turn it off.

109
00:04:58.679 --> 00:05:00.909
Turn it off, that'll decrypt your data.

110
00:05:00.909 --> 00:05:04.220
And then you'll continue with these
steps just like everybody else.

111
00:05:04.220 --> 00:05:07.100
But you need to turn off legacy
FileVault if you already have it.

112
00:05:07.100 --> 00:05:11.560
Legacy FileVault is only supported under
Sierra if you already had it configured.

113
00:05:11.560 --> 00:05:14.750
You can't actually turn on
legacy FileVault in the newer

114
00:05:14.750 --> 00:05:16.390
versions of MacOS ever since template six.

115
00:05:17.980 --> 00:05:18.810
So I'm gonna go to FileVault.

116
00:05:18.810 --> 00:05:19.355
And here's it's just warning me.

117
00:05:19.355 --> 00:05:22.038
It's saying FileVault is turned off for
the disk Mac-HD.

118
00:05:22.038 --> 00:05:24.582
It's off by default.

119
00:05:24.582 --> 00:05:26.299
I need to turn it on.

120
00:05:26.299 --> 00:05:30.132
So I'm going to go ahead and
click the lock here to unlock this tool.

121
00:05:30.132 --> 00:05:34.690
And once it's unlocked, I'll be able
to click the Turn On File Vault button.

122
00:05:36.030 --> 00:05:39.369
Now there is another button down here
at the bottom that says Advanced.

123
00:05:39.369 --> 00:05:43.263
And if you click on Advanced,
it's just saying here.

124
00:05:43.263 --> 00:05:45.371
If you wanna log out after
a certain amount of inactivity,

125
00:05:45.371 --> 00:05:47.780
it's talking about
the administrative privileges here.

126
00:05:47.780 --> 00:05:51.790
We actually don't have a whole lot of
features here as far as File Vault itself.

127
00:05:51.790 --> 00:05:54.970
When you go to turn it on,
it's just the one button.

128
00:05:54.970 --> 00:05:57.180
And then it asks about where we
wanna store our recovery key.

129
00:05:57.180 --> 00:06:01.230
So it's a very simple process to get
that turned on, just one button.

130
00:06:01.230 --> 00:06:03.920
We hit that one button and
then we pick about the recovery key.

131
00:06:03.920 --> 00:06:05.980
Now the recovery key is important.

132
00:06:07.140 --> 00:06:11.770
Every time my computer boots up
it needs access to a private key.

133
00:06:11.770 --> 00:06:15.280
The private key is allowed
to decrypt the hard drive.

134
00:06:15.280 --> 00:06:17.340
I can't use the hard drive unless
I can decrypt what's on it.

135
00:06:17.340 --> 00:06:19.200
So I need the private key.

136
00:06:19.200 --> 00:06:23.250
Well the private key is actually stored in
what's called a trusted platform module or

137
00:06:23.250 --> 00:06:24.140
TPM.

138
00:06:24.140 --> 00:06:27.200
It's a chip that's located
on your motherboard.

139
00:06:27.200 --> 00:06:29.140
It's physically a part of your laptop.

140
00:06:29.140 --> 00:06:30.860
If somebody rips your hard drive out and

141
00:06:30.860 --> 00:06:33.210
plugs it into another computer,
it'll have your TPM.

142
00:06:33.210 --> 00:06:34.720
They can't decrypt it.

143
00:06:34.720 --> 00:06:38.520
But if they have your entire laptop,
they have the TPM also.

144
00:06:38.520 --> 00:06:41.110
So the TPM is locked.

145
00:06:41.110 --> 00:06:45.450
And the TPM gets unlocked when you
put in your username and password.

146
00:06:45.450 --> 00:06:49.585
When you log into your laptop, your
username and password unlocks the TPM,

147
00:06:49.585 --> 00:06:51.340
that Trusted Platform Module.

148
00:06:52.410 --> 00:06:57.310
Now, if I forget my password,
what happens?

149
00:06:57.310 --> 00:06:59.190
If I forget my password,
I can't unlock the TPM.

150
00:06:59.190 --> 00:07:01.780
If I can't unlock the TPM,
I can't get private key.

151
00:07:01.780 --> 00:07:05.610
And if I can't get the private key,
I can't decrypt the hard drive.

152
00:07:05.610 --> 00:07:07.225
I just lost all of my data, it's awesome.

153
00:07:07.225 --> 00:07:10.650
[LAUGH] And so, if we want to prevent
that, if you're worried about forgetting

154
00:07:10.650 --> 00:07:13.090
your password,
we need to have some kind of backup plan.

155
00:07:13.090 --> 00:07:15.130
And that's what this screen
is kind of telling me here.

156
00:07:15.130 --> 00:07:16.116
I can have a backup plan.

157
00:07:16.116 --> 00:07:18.768
I can link to my iCloud account.

158
00:07:18.768 --> 00:07:21.940
And if I do that, now if I forget
my password, I can just go and

159
00:07:21.940 --> 00:07:24.380
reset my password through iCloud.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don introduce us to File Permissions in macOS Sierra.  They show how permissions are set by default and how they follow the UNIX UGO model.  Don also explains the different types of permissions  and how Access Control Lists are different from the UGO permissions found on macOS Sierra.

00:13:44.450 --> 00:13:47.790
But he doesn't want me to have
access to the Private folder.

271
00:13:47.790 --> 00:13:49.499
So he could take that Private folder.

272
00:13:49.499 --> 00:13:52.331
Go down here to these permissions
that have now been inherited from

273
00:13:52.331 --> 00:13:53.480
the parent item.

274
00:13:53.480 --> 00:13:58.080
And they can take me and
bump me right out, and that's it, okay?

275
00:13:58.080 --> 00:14:02.005
So you still have control over
each individual item if you want.

276
00:14:02.005 --> 00:14:04.310
But by applying those permissions
to the enclosed item,

277
00:14:04.310 --> 00:14:06.480
we can roll out a set of
permissions across the board.

278
00:14:06.480 --> 00:14:09.956
>> Now Don, you just did something there
where you removed your own account.

279
00:14:09.956 --> 00:14:13.907
Is that gonna be anything different in
the result as If I had just put no access

280
00:14:13.907 --> 00:14:14.914
beside your name?

281
00:14:14.914 --> 00:14:16.960
Or should that be effectively the same?

282
00:14:16.960 --> 00:14:19.631
>> Well, you'll actually find where
you don't have that No Access option

283
00:14:19.631 --> 00:14:20.419
all the time.

284
00:14:20.419 --> 00:14:22.433
>> Okay.
>> So let's talk about that a little

285
00:14:22.433 --> 00:14:23.141
bit, right?

286
00:14:23.141 --> 00:14:25.549
So when I assign permissions,
right, when we add somebody in.

287
00:14:25.549 --> 00:14:27.752
So let's just add me back in here, right?

288
00:14:27.752 --> 00:14:28.897
We've put me on the list.

289
00:14:28.897 --> 00:14:33.017
There's several different
privileges that show up, okay?

290
00:14:33.017 --> 00:14:36.198
And looking at this list right here,
we see the three most common.

291
00:14:36.198 --> 00:14:41.036
Read & Write, Read only, and
No Access, those are my three, right?

292
00:14:41.036 --> 00:14:42.195
So what do those mean?

293
00:14:42.195 --> 00:14:45.010
Well Read & Write,
it's like the name implies.

294
00:14:45.010 --> 00:14:48.540
I can read, I can open the data
that's in there, right?

295
00:14:48.540 --> 00:14:51.680
If it's a folder, it means I can browse
into the folder and list its contents.

296
00:14:51.680 --> 00:14:55.670
If it's a file, it means I can open
the file and read it's contents.

297
00:14:55.670 --> 00:14:57.350
I might need a program to do that, right?

298
00:14:57.350 --> 00:15:00.420
Like Microsoft Word, or Pages,
or something like that.

299
00:15:00.420 --> 00:15:04.550
But otherwise I can at least open it,
but I can't change it.

300
00:15:04.550 --> 00:15:06.930
If I have Write, I can change it.

301
00:15:08.000 --> 00:15:11.780
I can modify the file, I can create new
files, I can delete old files, right?

302
00:15:11.780 --> 00:15:12.949
So you can do several things.

303
00:15:12.949 --> 00:15:18.350
The Write term actually encompasses many
different functions, I can rename files.

304
00:15:18.350 --> 00:15:22.440
So all of that stuff falls under Write,
it's a really big permission.

305
00:15:22.440 --> 00:15:24.600
And then No Access,
like it implies, I'm blocked.

306
00:15:24.600 --> 00:15:27.272
I have no access to the content
inside of this folder.

307
00:15:27.272 --> 00:15:30.500
Or if it's on a file, then I would
have no access to that file, right?

308
00:15:30.500 --> 00:15:32.274
I might see the file exists.

309
00:15:32.274 --> 00:15:36.123
But I can't open it, I can't change it,
I can't really manipulate it at all.

310
00:15:36.123 --> 00:15:38.302
Now for the everyone group,
when I drop that down,

311
00:15:38.302 --> 00:15:39.881
see how there's four permissions?

312
00:15:39.881 --> 00:15:43.650
Read & Write, Read only,
Write only, and No Access.

313
00:15:43.650 --> 00:15:49.860
If I do the same thing on staff, or
Ronnie, or me, I don't have four options.

314
00:15:49.860 --> 00:15:52.112
No Access is not in the list.

315
00:15:52.112 --> 00:15:54.564
Okay, why is No Access not on the list?

316
00:15:54.564 --> 00:15:57.061
If I wanna block access
to somebody like this,

317
00:15:57.061 --> 00:15:59.312
I just remove them from the list, right?

318
00:15:59.312 --> 00:16:02.137
So if Ronnie wants me to have no access,
he just takes me right out.

319
00:16:02.137 --> 00:16:03.924
And that's that, now I have no access.

320
00:16:03.924 --> 00:16:07.288
And then, Ronnie, you as the owner
can't give yourself no access,

321
00:16:07.288 --> 00:16:09.560
because that would
effectively lock you out.

322
00:16:09.560 --> 00:16:13.013
And, in fact, notice how when I choose
you, the- button is grayed out,

323
00:16:13.013 --> 00:16:15.170
like you can't even remove yourself.

324
00:16:15.170 --> 00:16:18.934
So you do get different behaviors,
depending on what you've selected,

325
00:16:18.934 --> 00:16:21.127
which item you've highlighted, right?

326
00:16:21.127 --> 00:16:26.517
Now also, I talked about Read,
Read & Write and No Access.

327
00:16:26.517 --> 00:16:29.686
There was that fourth one that
showed up under everyone.

328
00:16:29.686 --> 00:16:32.720
When I dropped it down it
was Write only (Drop Box).

329
00:16:32.720 --> 00:16:34.391
I think it only shows up for
everyone, right?

330
00:16:34.391 --> 00:16:36.787
No, it actually does show up for
group and you.

331
00:16:36.787 --> 00:16:38.072
I shows up for all three,
all right, so I'm completely wrong.

332
00:16:38.072 --> 00:16:39.424
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

333
00:16:39.424 --> 00:16:40.104
>> But basically

334
00:16:40.104 --> 00:16:42.680
you have this other option, Write only.

335
00:16:42.680 --> 00:16:45.202
Now Read only makes sense.

336
00:16:45.202 --> 00:16:48.070
I see a file,
I can open it I can look at it.

337
00:16:48.070 --> 00:16:49.670
I just can't change it and
delete it, right?

338
00:16:49.670 --> 00:16:50.850
That's stuff that I can't do.

339
00:16:50.850 --> 00:16:51.910
But I can access the file.

340
00:16:52.930 --> 00:16:56.950
Write only, when would I want someone
to be able to write to a file but

341
00:16:56.950 --> 00:16:57.770
not read it?

342
00:16:57.770 --> 00:17:00.250
You can't look at it,
but you can change it.

343
00:17:00.250 --> 00:17:02.400
That sounds really strange, doesn't it?

344
00:17:02.400 --> 00:17:08.290
Well this is a dropbox, not in terms of
like the DropBox Cloud storage service.

345
00:17:08.290 --> 00:17:12.203
Think more of like a bank
nighttime deposit box, right?

346
00:17:12.203 --> 00:17:15.292
You may or may not have done it in
this day and age of Internet banking,

347
00:17:15.292 --> 00:17:16.210
it's a lot easier.

348
00:17:16.210 --> 00:17:20.250
But in the olden days if you wanted
to make a deposit at a bank and

349
00:17:20.250 --> 00:17:24.330
it was after 5 PM, the bank had closed
its doors, the lights were out.

350
00:17:24.330 --> 00:17:27.062
So you would sign your checks or
endorse your checks.

351
00:17:27.062 --> 00:17:29.538
You'd stick them in an envelope,
you'd drive up to the bank.

352
00:17:29.538 --> 00:17:33.320
You'd pull open a little slot, and
you'd drop it down in there and close it.

353
00:17:33.320 --> 00:17:37.568
Okay, what you just did was
a write only operation.

354
00:17:40.032 --> 00:17:42.275
The big blue postal mailbox is
the same kind of thing, right?

355
00:17:42.275 --> 00:17:44.050
You drop a letter in there.

356
00:17:44.050 --> 00:17:49.160
You were able to write a letter, and
you were able to drop it in that mailbox.

357
00:17:49.160 --> 00:17:52.140
But once it was in there, it was gone.

358
00:17:52.140 --> 00:17:54.258
You couldn't see what was in the box,
right?

359
00:17:54.258 --> 00:17:57.310
So you couldn't read
the contents of that box.

360
00:17:57.310 --> 00:18:00.151
And you can't even
retrieve your own message.

361
00:18:00.151 --> 00:18:03.580
Your message that you dropped in
there is now effectively gone.

362
00:18:03.580 --> 00:18:06.376
It's been dropped off,
that's what a dropbox is.

363
00:18:06.376 --> 00:18:10.946
The Drop Box permission inside of
Mac OS is really used when you want

364
00:18:10.946 --> 00:18:13.569
somebody to be able to give you files.

365
00:18:13.569 --> 00:18:16.180
But not give them access to anything else.

366
00:18:16.180 --> 00:18:19.140
So maybe you're a school teacher,
right, or university professor.

367
00:18:19.140 --> 00:18:21.054
And you tell your students, hey,

368
00:18:21.054 --> 00:18:25.087
you've got until midnight on Friday
to turn in your term paper, right?

369
00:18:25.087 --> 00:18:26.031
>> [LAUGH]
>> But

370
00:18:26.031 --> 00:18:29.918
I don't wanna sit there at my desk
until midnight on Friday, waiting for

371
00:18:29.918 --> 00:18:33.756
deadbeat students to come in at 11:59 PM,
cuz you know they will.

372
00:18:33.756 --> 00:18:36.660
[LAUGH] And so
I don't I don't wanna do that.

373
00:18:36.660 --> 00:18:39.210
So instead I could create
a folder that's a dropbox.

374
00:18:39.210 --> 00:18:44.120
And I could say, look, all the way up
until 11:59 PM you can just drop your term

375
00:18:44.120 --> 00:18:46.410
paper in that folder, right?

376
00:18:46.410 --> 00:18:49.270
And when they do that they don't
see anybody else's term papers,

377
00:18:49.270 --> 00:18:51.190
because they can't read the folder.

378
00:18:51.190 --> 00:18:53.041
So they don't know anybody
else's stuff is in there.

379
00:18:53.041 --> 00:18:58.040
And they can drop their file in there,
and now they can't go and change it.

380
00:18:58.040 --> 00:18:59.550
They can't delete it,
they can't remove it.

381
00:18:59.550 --> 00:19:03.170
So I know the first paper they submitted.

382
00:19:03.170 --> 00:19:08.320
So if they come in and try to submit
a paper again at 2 AM or 5 AM, I'll know,

383
00:19:08.320 --> 00:19:11.520
because they're not allowed to overwrite
the file that's already existed.

384
00:19:11.520 --> 00:19:15.530
They dropped one in, and it's timestamped,
and you kinda know what goes on.

385
00:19:15.530 --> 00:19:17.350
So that's the way that
a dropbox gets used.

386
00:19:17.350 --> 00:19:21.220
It's a pretty specific use case scenario,
so most of us are never gonna use it.

387
00:19:21.220 --> 00:19:25.010
But we'll talk about home folder
structure a little bit later.

388
00:19:25.010 --> 00:19:29.620
And there is actually a default
dropbox created for every user.

389
00:19:29.620 --> 00:19:32.442
If you browse your home folder,
there's a folder called Public.

390
00:19:32.442 --> 00:19:35.340
And in the Public folder there's
another folder called Drop Box.

391
00:19:35.340 --> 00:19:36.859
And it's actually created,
it's there by default.

392
00:19:36.859 --> 00:19:39.070
And we'll look at it,
like I said, a little bit later.

393
00:19:40.330 --> 00:19:43.420
All right so let's see, we have
talked about Read & Write, Read only,

394
00:19:43.420 --> 00:19:46.010
Write only, No Access.

395
00:19:46.010 --> 00:19:48.830
There's a few other permissions
we're gonna learn about

396
00:19:48.830 --> 00:19:52.660
when we go into the Unix backend,
like the execute permission.

397
00:19:53.880 --> 00:19:57.030
Reading a file is just opening it and
looking at the contents.

398
00:19:57.030 --> 00:20:02.200
But executing means it's a program or
a script, and we actually want to run it.

399
00:20:02.200 --> 00:20:06.400
And that's an extra permission that
here in the GUI, we don't have.

400
00:20:06.400 --> 00:20:13.560
Even if I had a file, for example,
let me get to Ronnie's desktop here.

401
00:20:13.560 --> 00:20:20.909
And just real quick I'm going
to whip up a script.sh, right?

402
00:20:20.909 --> 00:20:22.790
So here's a script.

403
00:20:22.790 --> 00:20:27.030
And when I wanna run a script,
I need to be able to execute it.

404
00:20:27.030 --> 00:20:31.054
Well in Mac OS, when you create a script,
it recognizes that it's a script.

405
00:20:31.054 --> 00:20:34.451
So it shows up right here as script.sh,
right?

406
00:20:34.451 --> 00:20:38.700
And it even says SHELL, right,
so it knows that it's a script.

407
00:20:38.700 --> 00:20:44.260
But when I pull up its information, when I
pull up its permissions and other data and

408
00:20:44.260 --> 00:20:49.090
come in here and look at it,
I don't have execute as an option.

409
00:20:49.090 --> 00:20:53.780
In the GUI you actually can't manipulate
whether something's executable or not.

410
00:20:53.780 --> 00:20:55.480
It just recognizes it.

411
00:20:55.480 --> 00:20:59.312
And if it thinks that it should be
executable then it makes it executable.

412
00:20:59.312 --> 00:21:03.325
So that's kind of an automatic permission
that's hidden from us as part of the GUI,

413
00:21:03.325 --> 00:21:05.374
not one that we have
to really worry about.

414
00:21:05.374 --> 00:21:09.231
All right, the other thing that I
wanna mention here before we wrap up,

415
00:21:09.231 --> 00:21:13.618
I know I've only got a few minutes left,
is the default permissions that we see.

416
00:21:13.618 --> 00:21:17.650
So like looking at this one here where
it's got Ronnie, staff, and everyone.

417
00:21:17.650 --> 00:21:22.430
That's the UGO that I talked about, right,
the user, the group, and the other.

418
00:21:22.430 --> 00:21:27.329
Now those three are provided by
the default functionality in the Unix

419
00:21:27.329 --> 00:21:28.774
operating system.

420
00:21:28.774 --> 00:21:31.981
So under the hood,
under the nice little GUI that we have,

421
00:21:31.981 --> 00:21:33.820
is the Darwin operating system.

422
00:21:33.820 --> 00:21:36.700
And Darwin is technically
a BSD Unix operating system.

423
00:21:36.700 --> 00:21:40.550
So it uses BSD Unix style permissions,
U-G-O.

424
00:21:40.550 --> 00:21:43.068
But there's some limitations here, right?

425
00:21:43.068 --> 00:21:46.769
If I wanna give permissions to more
than one person or more than one group,

426
00:21:46.769 --> 00:21:48.631
Unix doesn't really support that.

427
00:21:48.631 --> 00:21:51.950
I have to set up nested groups and
things get really complex.

428
00:21:51.950 --> 00:21:55.150
So Unix permissions
are not terribly flexible.

429
00:21:55.150 --> 00:21:58.260
Apple wanted those
permissions to be flexible.

430
00:21:58.260 --> 00:22:01.600
So they created what were called ACLs,
or Access Control Lists.

431
00:22:01.600 --> 00:22:05.486
And the moment I deviate from this three
person model, see how each of these three

432
00:22:05.486 --> 00:22:08.300
when I choose them,
like I can choose staff and hit minus.

433
00:22:09.530 --> 00:22:13.180
And it's gonna try and take away the staff
permission, which Isn't letting me,

434
00:22:13.180 --> 00:22:14.320
because I don't have permissions, right?

435
00:22:14.320 --> 00:22:16.260
So I need to unlock this
before I can do it.

436
00:22:16.260 --> 00:22:19.360
But when I do that,
when I manipulate those permissions,

437
00:22:19.360 --> 00:22:23.410
I'm starting to move
away from the UGO model.

438
00:22:23.410 --> 00:22:27.350
And that is not something
that's allowed in Unix.

439
00:22:27.350 --> 00:22:32.480
So what Apple had to do was to find
a new way to store these permissions.

440
00:22:32.480 --> 00:22:36.901
So that when you come in and
you do crazy things like, here, we'll add,

441
00:22:36.901 --> 00:22:39.888
I've got a group like access.bpf or
Don Pezet.

442
00:22:39.888 --> 00:22:43.560
I can come in and
start adding these other entries.

443
00:22:43.560 --> 00:22:46.940
What I'm doing is I'm creating

444
00:22:46.940 --> 00:22:50.460
a list that It goes beyond
what Unix can normally track.

445
00:22:50.460 --> 00:22:54.110
And so this isn't stored the way Unix
permissions normally are stored.

446
00:22:54.110 --> 00:22:58.960
This is stored using an ACL,
an Access Control List that Mac OS tracks.

447
00:22:58.960 --> 00:23:03.050
This makes sense to Mac OS,
this doesn't make sense to Unix.

448
00:23:03.050 --> 00:23:06.280
So in the GUI I don't have to worry
about that, that's all hidden from me.

449
00:23:06.280 --> 00:23:08.050
I just set the permissions right here.

450
00:23:08.050 --> 00:23:13.520
I never know when I flip from
Unix-land To Mac OS ACL-land, right?

451
00:23:13.520 --> 00:23:16.340
It's all seamless,
it never prompted or warned.

452
00:23:16.340 --> 00:23:18.270
It just kind of happened.

453
00:23:18.270 --> 00:23:21.500
But in the next episode when we take
a look at the Unix side of things,

454
00:23:21.500 --> 00:23:22.580
we'll see where that happens.

455
00:23:22.580 --> 00:23:23.910
We'll see where we deviate and

456
00:23:23.910 --> 00:23:29.420
move away from the standard way of
handling permissions to the ACL method.

457
00:23:29.420 --> 00:23:32.260
But do know,
because it may turn up on the exam,

458
00:23:32.260 --> 00:23:37.017
that if you see permissions that go beyond
just a user, a group, and everyone,

459
00:23:37.017 --> 00:23:41.561
if it goes beyond that, then technically
you're dealing with with an ACL.

460
00:23:41.561 --> 00:23:44.900
And not standard permission, so
it is an Access Control List.

461
00:23:44.900 --> 00:23:47.870
But otherwise, as far as the end user's
concerned, they manipulate it the same,

462
00:23:47.870 --> 00:23:49.140
and those are our permissions.

463
00:23:50.302 --> 00:23:53.670
>> All right, Don, well thank you again
for helping to introduce us to this

464
00:23:53.670 --> 00:23:58.270
concept of the way that these permissions
are actually working for Mac OS Sierra.

465
00:23:58.270 --> 00:24:01.315
Remember that it really is based off that
Unix style of permissions where you have

466
00:24:01.315 --> 00:24:02.761
the user, the group, and the owner.

467
00:24:02.761 --> 00:24:05.866
Even though the names have changed,
it's still that underneath the hood.

468
00:24:05.866 --> 00:24:09.646
And that's some of the things that we'll
have to also be able to identify and

469
00:24:09.646 --> 00:24:10.365
understand.

470
00:24:10.365 --> 00:24:13.990
He also showed us about
permission inheritance, as well.

471
00:24:13.990 --> 00:24:18.770
And then lastly, talked a little bit
about ACLs, Access Control Lists,

472
00:24:18.770 --> 00:24:22.250
which we'll actually get
more into in a next episode.

473
00:24:22.250 --> 00:24:24.830
But that's a great place for
us to also sign off.

474
00:24:24.830 --> 00:24:27.820
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

475
00:24:27.820 --> 00:24:28.830
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

476
00:24:28.830 --> 00:24:33.930
>> Stay tuned for more Apple Certified
Support Professional for MacOS Sierra.

477
00:24:33.930 --> 00:24:39.727
[MUSIC]

478
00:24:39.727 --> 00:24:42.878
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

He demonstrates the use of chmod and chown and how to change the access control lists.  Also demonstrated is how the metadata is retained for files on macOS Sierra.

and then I can come in and

454
00:25:27.770 --> 00:25:31.950
this is where it gets a little less user
friendly, and I can say for example,

455
00:25:31.950 --> 00:25:39.160
"dpezet allow write", okay?

456
00:25:39.160 --> 00:25:41.430
And you have to put it in
quotes cuz of the spaces, and

457
00:25:41.430 --> 00:25:42.910
you could have more than one command.

458
00:25:42.910 --> 00:25:46.045
I could be allowing read,write.

459
00:25:47.080 --> 00:25:51.790
And then I specify the file, so
I'll do the Term Paper, okay?

460
00:25:51.790 --> 00:25:56.010
And when I do that,
it's gonna add those permissions, and

461
00:25:56.010 --> 00:26:01.860
if I do an ls-e, or I'm doing lae,
so I get the full output on it.

462
00:26:01.860 --> 00:26:05.668
Now I can come in and I can look, and
I can see that dpezet has read and

463
00:26:05.668 --> 00:26:07.320
write permissions.

464
00:26:07.320 --> 00:26:09.360
Now be careful when you do this,

465
00:26:09.360 --> 00:26:13.160
because you'll find that the GUI
assigns a little more than just write.

466
00:26:13.160 --> 00:26:15.640
Look at the group up here, it has write.

467
00:26:15.640 --> 00:26:18.570
But, it also has append, okay?

468
00:26:18.570 --> 00:26:21.190
In other words,
it can add on to the end of the file.

469
00:26:21.190 --> 00:26:22.590
I can't do that.

470
00:26:22.590 --> 00:26:26.480
I can replace the file by writing to it,
but I can't add on to the end of it.

471
00:26:26.480 --> 00:26:28.750
I also can't write an attribute.

472
00:26:29.900 --> 00:26:33.210
The group can, I can't,
because I didn't add those.

473
00:26:33.210 --> 00:26:35.460
I have to make sure that I add
all those little components or

474
00:26:35.460 --> 00:26:36.640
various things might not work.

475
00:26:36.640 --> 00:26:38.530
So the GUI knows to do that.

476
00:26:38.530 --> 00:26:39.410
From the command line,

477
00:26:39.410 --> 00:26:43.810
we have to remember to do those extra
things to make sure that we get

478
00:26:43.810 --> 00:26:48.470
all that extra functionality that we might
end up missing if we don't punch it in.

479
00:26:48.470 --> 00:26:51.240
All right, but those can be manipulated.

480
00:26:51.240 --> 00:26:56.070
Another place where you might see this,
and if you're in an all-Mac world,

481
00:26:56.070 --> 00:26:58.900
this is all transparent to you, so
most of us don't even think about it.

482
00:26:58.900 --> 00:27:01.910
But if you integrate with
Windows machines, and

483
00:27:01.910 --> 00:27:03.610
you go to share a file with somebody.

484
00:27:03.610 --> 00:27:05.930
Somebody says, hey,
can you give me a copy of that term paper?

485
00:27:05.930 --> 00:27:08.790
And you say, say,
here let me copy it to a thumb drive.

486
00:27:08.790 --> 00:27:11.570
And the thumb drive is formatted
with something like ExFAT, right?

487
00:27:11.570 --> 00:27:14.910
So I've got my ExFAT partition
from our file partition show.

488
00:27:14.910 --> 00:27:18.888
If I take that Term Paper and I'm gonna
just drop it right over there on ExFAT.

489
00:27:18.888 --> 00:27:24.294
When I do that it's going to copy it over,
and sometimes you'll get a warning and

490
00:27:24.294 --> 00:27:29.900
it'll say, are you sure you want to
copy this over with no metadata?

491
00:27:29.900 --> 00:27:32.467
Well that means the file system
that you're copying to just doesn't

492
00:27:32.467 --> 00:27:33.226
support metadata.

493
00:27:33.226 --> 00:27:37.295
Some of the older ones don't and they
get really kind of angry about it, and

494
00:27:37.295 --> 00:27:38.923
they'll lose the metadata.

495
00:27:38.923 --> 00:27:40.020
Well, you might be okay with that.

496
00:27:40.020 --> 00:27:42.500
Like, I don't care about the metadata,
just send it over.

497
00:27:42.500 --> 00:27:46.260
Because here for example,
ExFAT doesn't support file permissions.

498
00:27:46.260 --> 00:27:48.340
So what do I care if I
lose the file permissions?

499
00:27:48.340 --> 00:27:51.370
It's not that big of a deal, so
I might not worry about that.

500
00:27:51.370 --> 00:27:55.985
But what Apple tries to do, and what it
did do in my case, is it says I want to

501
00:27:55.985 --> 00:27:59.445
preserve the metadata, but
this file system doesn't support it.

502
00:27:59.445 --> 00:28:02.755
So instead we're gonna take the metadata
and store it in that second file.

503
00:28:02.755 --> 00:28:04.945
The file I mentioned that was hidden and
transparent.

504
00:28:04.945 --> 00:28:06.355
See how I don't see it here?

505
00:28:06.355 --> 00:28:08.135
But if you give this to a Windows user,
and

506
00:28:08.135 --> 00:28:12.565
they plug it into a Windows computer,
they'll actually see something else.

507
00:28:12.565 --> 00:28:15.421
What they'll see, let me see if I can
show you here, I'm pretty sure I can.

508
00:28:18.383 --> 00:28:22.192
So I'm just switching into this
/Volumes/ExFAT folder with that hard drive

509
00:28:22.192 --> 00:28:23.380
as mounted.

510
00:28:23.380 --> 00:28:28.620
And if I do an ls-la in there,
there it is.

511
00:28:28.620 --> 00:28:34.962
See I'll got Term Paper.rtf and
._Term Paper.rtf.

512
00:28:34.962 --> 00:28:39.770
If I were to just pull up an ls,
even a long listing, I don't see that.

513
00:28:39.770 --> 00:28:43.300
I have to tell it to show all files,
including hidden files.

514
00:28:43.300 --> 00:28:46.450
Files that start with a dot
are hidden by default.

515
00:28:46.450 --> 00:28:49.820
And there it is,
that's where the metadata is stored, so

516
00:28:49.820 --> 00:28:55.650
the extra ACL permissions, the tag that
I gave it, the comments I give it.

517
00:28:55.650 --> 00:28:58.690
They're all in that metadata file and
that's what that extra little bit is.

518
00:28:58.690 --> 00:29:01.630
So it ties into permissions because
these are extra values that've got to be

519
00:29:01.630 --> 00:29:05.670
stored some where, and on a Mac we
won't see it, but Windows users will.

520
00:29:05.670 --> 00:29:08.926
And sometimes Windows users will say what
are these extra garbage files let me just

521
00:29:08.926 --> 00:29:10.292
delete all those out of there, and

522
00:29:10.292 --> 00:29:14.320
they'll delete all the files that start
with ._ and it wont effect them one bit.

523
00:29:14.320 --> 00:29:18.250
But then when you bring it back to yours,
and you plug it into your Mac all your

524
00:29:18.250 --> 00:29:21.590
comments are gone, all your tags are gone,
and your permissions are messed up.

525
00:29:21.590 --> 00:29:24.110
And that's kind of the nature of
the beast there when you share with

526
00:29:24.110 --> 00:29:25.230
another system like that.

527
00:29:25.230 --> 00:29:29.985
What would have been better is to have
made a shared folder on your system.

528
00:29:29.985 --> 00:29:33.015
And they could have browsed over
the network and accessed your files,

529
00:29:33.015 --> 00:29:35.705
and they never would
have seen the metadata.

530
00:29:35.705 --> 00:29:38.345
And they could work with the files,
and your metadata would be preserved.

531
00:29:38.345 --> 00:29:42.297
That's always better than copying to some
file system that just doesn't have full

532
00:29:42.297 --> 00:29:43.127
support for what we do.

533
00:29:44.509 --> 00:29:48.089
All right, I think that's
probably a pretty good rundown.

534
00:29:48.089 --> 00:29:51.857
We're gonna talk a little bit more
about some of the other things,

535
00:29:51.857 --> 00:29:54.477
but one last thing,
this might turn up on the exam.

536
00:29:54.477 --> 00:29:58.000
That little metadata file,
that system that I just showed you.

537
00:29:58.000 --> 00:29:58.900
It has a name.

538
00:29:58.900 --> 00:30:01.860
It's actually called
the AppleDouble metadata, right?

539
00:30:01.860 --> 00:30:03.050
Apple double.

540
00:30:03.050 --> 00:30:07.360
That means that when you're on a normal
Apple Mac OS formatted file system,

541
00:30:07.360 --> 00:30:08.580
it's stored as part of file system.

542
00:30:08.580 --> 00:30:09.910
There's no second file.

543
00:30:09.910 --> 00:30:13.007
But we dump it to these other file
systems it creates that second file.

544
00:30:13.007 --> 00:30:14.460
They call that the AppleDouble.

545
00:30:14.460 --> 00:30:17.608
So on the exam you might actually
see it refered to as that,

546
00:30:17.608 --> 00:30:19.420
as AppleDouble, just be aware.

547
00:30:19.420 --> 00:30:22.522
>> All right Don, well thank you again for
helping us to get

548
00:30:22.522 --> 00:30:26.812
deeper dive on being able to take a look
at these different file permissions,

549
00:30:26.812 --> 00:30:30.772
not only the underlying Unix, but
also of course even how we can go in and

550
00:30:30.772 --> 00:30:33.947
see the access control list as well and
change those too.

551
00:30:33.947 --> 00:30:36.610
Make sure you pay attention to
some of those commands, right?

552
00:30:36.610 --> 00:30:40.910
Such as the chmon and
chown that we also saw here,

553
00:30:40.910 --> 00:30:44.010
that will help you out as
you do more support as well.

554
00:30:44.010 --> 00:30:46.540
Well, that's a great place for
us to also sign off.

555
00:30:46.540 --> 00:30:49.430
For IT Pro TV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

556
00:30:49.430 --> 00:30:50.660
>> And I'm Don Presset.

>> Stay tuned right here for
more Apple Certified Support Professional.

permissions drwxr-xr-x,

Well that means that it's a directory,

00:03:49.150 --> 00:03:50.440
just like all the others.

But then staff,
everybody on their laptop or desktop,

or Mac, Mini, whatever it is that

other, in other words the everyone grou,

If Ronnie has a folder that he wants to

00:04:36.020 --> 00:04:39.558

c to copy that one and

00:04:46.660 --> 00:04:49.490

Now I'm an administrator, I could change

This is where people have write only,

00:08:43.020 --> 00:08:46.700

00:09:47.750 --> 00:09:49.720
So far, it sound it sounds like an alias.

00:09:49.720 --> 00:09:50.793
It's harder to do, right?

[LAUGH] But am alias,

00:09:53.560 --> 00:09:55.682
Here, I've gotta use this

00:09:55.682 --> 00:09:58.830

age if I'm trying to script and

00:10:24.806 --> 00:10:27.200

00:10:29.220 --> 00:10:33.470

00:10:33.470 --> 00:10:36.380

00:10:36.380 --> 00:10:38.050

00:10:38.050 --> 00:10:40.990
A symbolic link is similar to

00:10:40.990 --> 00:10:43.830

00:10:43.830 --> 00:10:47.640
So, we define a path to a source, where
we're gonna be getting our information

00:10:47.640 --> 00:10:50.260
from, and it creates a link for that.

00:10:50.260 --> 00:10:54.040

00:10:57.470 --> 00:10:58.650

So, I'm gonna get into my desktop.

So I am in /users/dpezet/Desktop.

00:11:03.870 --> 00:11:06.100
And I'll do ln -s.

where it's gonna go, and I choose Install.

00:22:39.790 --> 00:22:42.280
As soon as I do that, there it goes.

442
00:22:42.280 --> 00:22:46.400
It's gonna prompt me, cuz it needs to have
administrative privileges to write it.

443
00:22:46.400 --> 00:22:48.940
And then once it writes those files,
it needs to reboot for

444
00:22:48.940 --> 00:22:50.790
them to be recognized by
the operating system.

445
00:22:50.790 --> 00:22:54.090
And now my hardware would be supported,
I can hook up my USB monitor, and

446
00:22:54.090 --> 00:22:55.570
now I'm in business.

447
00:22:55.570 --> 00:22:57.020
So these are special,

448
00:22:57.020 --> 00:23:00.510
there's a different type of
application than what we're used to.

449
00:23:00.510 --> 00:23:05.280
But at the end of the day it is still an
application, an installation application.

450
00:23:05.280 --> 00:23:06.720
It installs something.

451
00:23:06.720 --> 00:23:10.730
And usually programs that we install
this way don't show up in Applications,

452
00:23:10.730 --> 00:23:13.810
instead they show up in
our System Preferences.

453
00:23:13.810 --> 00:23:15.680
So when you go into
the System Preferences,

454
00:23:15.680 --> 00:23:18.130
those things will typically
show up down here.

455
00:23:18.130 --> 00:23:20.360
You'll see some other programs
that I've installed like that.

456
00:23:20.360 --> 00:23:24.889
Like FUSE, which gives me
different file system support.

457
00:23:25.970 --> 00:23:30.170
GPGPreferences, which lets me
do file encryption or Java.

458
00:23:30.170 --> 00:23:32.900
These were all installed with pkgs,
with packages, and

459
00:23:32.900 --> 00:23:34.540
each one created a preference here.

460
00:23:34.540 --> 00:23:37.838
Now you'll notice that I
don't have a DisplayLink one.

461
00:23:37.838 --> 00:23:41.410
And that's because the DisplayLink one
just installed a driver and that's it.

462
00:23:41.410 --> 00:23:44.750
So I put a driver in and
I don't have any options to configure.

463
00:23:44.750 --> 00:23:47.000
I just hook that other monitor up and
the monitor works.

464
00:23:47.000 --> 00:23:49.460
That's basically how that one goes.

465
00:23:49.460 --> 00:23:52.400
But just recognize that there are some
variations of applications that

466
00:23:52.400 --> 00:23:55.590
are out there, but otherwise
everything else that you work with,

467
00:23:55.590 --> 00:23:58.360
you can create aliases, you can create
links on and they're gonna work just fine.

468
00:23:59.520 --> 00:24:00.244
>> All right, Don,

469
00:24:00.244 --> 00:24:03.636
well, that's a lot of good information on
taking a look at managing file systems.

470
00:24:03.636 --> 00:24:06.964
One other thing that we took
at in this episode, of course,

471
00:24:06.964 --> 00:24:11.025
is the idea of being able to create
aliases and why we would also use them as

472
00:24:11.025 --> 00:24:15.753
well as the different links, the symbolic
links and hard links showing that that's

473
00:24:15.753 --> 00:24:20.640
what is underlying the operating system
itself and we can also use those too.

474
00:24:20.640 --> 00:24:23.200
Then Don helped us to
differentiate between apps,

475
00:24:23.200 --> 00:24:26.090
as well as some of the different
packages that are out there.

476
00:24:26.090 --> 00:24:28.890
That's a great place for
us to also sign off then.

477
00:24:28.890 --> 00:24:32.100
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Ronnie Wong.

478
00:24:32.100 --> 00:24:33.150
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

479
00:24:33.150 --> 00:24:37.603
>> Stay tuned right here for more
Apple Certified Support Professional for

480
00:24:37.603 --> 00:24:38.553
MacOS Sierra.

481
00:24:38.553 --> 00:24:44.132
[MUSIC]

482
00:24:44.132 --> 00:24:47.771
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don take a look at hidden system folders.  Don shows how to view the hidden system folders and emphasizes some of the places in which the folders appear to be redundant.  This redundancy is really about the scope of what is effected that is File Domains, according to Don. He also takes the time to point out special folders and what their importance is to the OS.
episodes.title: Managing Files Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:05.996
Welcome to ITPRO.TV, I'm your host-
>> [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:05.996 --> 00:00:08.387
>> [MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.387 --> 00:00:12.212
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

4
00:00:12.212 --> 00:00:15.204
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:15.204 --> 00:00:19.590
You're watching the Apple Certified
Support Professional for Mac OS Sierra.

6
00:00:19.590 --> 00:00:24.000
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and today we're
going into a part two on managing files

7
00:00:24.000 --> 00:00:27.240
which means we're digging a little
bit deeper into the subject.

8
00:00:27.240 --> 00:00:29.200
And here to help us out is Mr. Don Pezet.

9
00:00:29.200 --> 00:00:30.660
Don, welcome back to the studios.

10
00:00:30.660 --> 00:00:31.650
>> Thanks for having me, Ronnie.

11
00:00:31.650 --> 00:00:33.160
And yep, in the episode,

12
00:00:33.160 --> 00:00:36.600
we got a couple of really
interesting things to talk about.

13
00:00:36.600 --> 00:00:39.248
The more important topic that I want
to hit in this episode is I want to

14
00:00:39.248 --> 00:00:41.235
talk about files and
folders that you can't see.

15
00:00:41.235 --> 00:00:42.520
>> [LAUGH]
>> That are invisible

16
00:00:42.520 --> 00:00:44.450
ones that are hidden away.

17
00:00:44.450 --> 00:00:46.840
When you look at the Mac OS GUIs.

18
00:00:46.840 --> 00:00:49.541
We browse around on the finder,
you see a lot of folders,

19
00:00:49.541 --> 00:00:51.130
you see a lot of easy to use icons.

20
00:00:51.130 --> 00:00:53.410
It's all designed to be easy to use.

21
00:00:53.410 --> 00:00:57.470
And part of the way they made it easy is
by hiding the stuff that wasn't easy,

22
00:00:57.470 --> 00:01:00.110
right which is not
necessarily a bad thing.

23
00:01:00.110 --> 00:01:03.250
There's a lot more going on under
the hood though if you know it's there.

24
00:01:03.250 --> 00:01:07.360
And sometimes we do need to interact
with it your end users typically won't.

25
00:01:07.360 --> 00:01:11.570
Your average end user, their world kind
of rotates around their Home folder.

26
00:01:11.570 --> 00:01:14.460
They usually don't go very far
away from their Home folder.

27
00:01:14.460 --> 00:01:16.000
But as a System Administrator,

28
00:01:16.000 --> 00:01:18.288
you oftentimes will have
to go outside of that.

29
00:01:18.288 --> 00:01:21.424
And look at these other areas where
there might be a hidden folder or

30
00:01:21.424 --> 00:01:24.180
something that you need
to get into to work with.

31
00:01:24.180 --> 00:01:27.770
So just as a quick example here to
show you what I'm talking about.

32
00:01:27.770 --> 00:01:30.820
If I browse into my hard drive,
what do I see?

33
00:01:30.820 --> 00:01:35.020
Well, I just see five little folders here,
and in fact, I have messed with mine, so

34
00:01:35.020 --> 00:01:35.850
I have this extra folder.

35
00:01:35.850 --> 00:01:37.360
Normally, you'll only see four.

36
00:01:37.360 --> 00:01:41.090
Applications, libraries,
system, and user, but

37
00:01:41.090 --> 00:01:44.690
there's actually a lot more
than these that show up.

38
00:01:44.690 --> 00:01:48.890
If I were to drop into a terminal and
go into my root folder and

39
00:01:48.890 --> 00:01:53.682
take a look, I'll see that there's
actually about twice as many.

40
00:01:53.682 --> 00:01:57.558
We've got applications, library, network,
system, users, volume, bin, cores,

41
00:01:57.558 --> 00:01:58.078
dev, etc.

42
00:01:58.078 --> 00:02:01.395
Home, installer.failurerequests.

43
00:02:01.395 --> 00:02:02.215
>> [LAUGH]
>> Clearly,

44
00:02:02.215 --> 00:02:03.600
I have screwed something up somewhere.

45
00:02:03.600 --> 00:02:08.050
net, opt, private, sbin,
tmp, usr and var various.

46
00:02:08.050 --> 00:02:12.766
So, all these different folders but,
I didn't see those a minute ago.

47
00:02:12.766 --> 00:02:15.770
And that's because most people never
have to mess with these other folders.

48
00:02:15.770 --> 00:02:18.504
A lot of these are tied to
the UNIX Operating System that is running

49
00:02:18.504 --> 00:02:19.209
under the hood.

50
00:02:19.209 --> 00:02:21.220
And so, we don't need to mess with that.

51
00:02:21.220 --> 00:02:23.930
But some of these aren't
necessarily tied to Unix,

52
00:02:23.930 --> 00:02:26.030
they're just being hidden
to keep people out of them.

53
00:02:26.030 --> 00:02:28.980
For example, /volumes.

54
00:02:28.980 --> 00:02:31.660
Whenever I plug in a USB drive,
it gets mounted, and

55
00:02:31.660 --> 00:02:34.410
it gets mounted under that volumes folder,
that's where it is.

56
00:02:34.410 --> 00:02:39.860
But when I come in here,
I don't see volumes in the list.

57
00:02:39.860 --> 00:02:42.070
Even though I can browse through
the USB drive or whatever,

58
00:02:42.070 --> 00:02:45.260
I won't see the volumes folder itself.

59
00:02:45.260 --> 00:02:49.220
So when something is hidden like that,
it's really just hidden to make life easy.

60
00:02:49.220 --> 00:02:51.020
It's not hidden to stop
you from going there.

61
00:02:51.020 --> 00:02:53.490
You can still browse to
these hidden folders.

62
00:02:53.490 --> 00:02:54.423
So for example,

63
00:02:54.423 --> 00:02:58.771
/volumes if I wanna browse to it I can go
up top to my menu here where it says Go.

64
00:02:58.771 --> 00:03:04.008
And under the Go menu I'll see
where I can choose go to folder.

65
00:03:04.008 --> 00:03:10.430
And under Go to Folder, I can choose that,
and I can type in whatever folder I want.

66
00:03:10.430 --> 00:03:13.603
And you can even use tab auto complete
in this which is kind of nice.

67
00:03:13.603 --> 00:03:16.510
But I can punch in /volumes.

68
00:03:16.510 --> 00:03:19.611
And when I hit go, it browse's to it.

69
00:03:19.611 --> 00:03:22.296
There's my hard drive and
my mobile time machine backups, right.

70
00:03:22.296 --> 00:03:25.490
Or if I plug in a USB drive,
it would show up here too.

71
00:03:25.490 --> 00:03:26.470
I can get to it.

72
00:03:26.470 --> 00:03:27.765
It's not forbidden.

73
00:03:27.765 --> 00:03:29.970
It's not block off with permissions.

74
00:03:29.970 --> 00:03:32.970
It's just hidden to
make life easier on us.

75
00:03:32.970 --> 00:03:34.760
Now, if we wanna hide something,

76
00:03:34.760 --> 00:03:38.300
there's actually two different ways
that you can hide things in Mac OS.

77
00:03:38.300 --> 00:03:40.490
There's the standard Unix way and

78
00:03:40.490 --> 00:03:43.210
then there's the Apple way as with most
of the things we've learned about here.

79
00:03:43.210 --> 00:03:44.880
There's always two ways of doing things.

80
00:03:44.880 --> 00:03:48.110
The standard Unix way is if
you want to hide something,

81
00:03:48.110 --> 00:03:49.890
you just stick a dot before it.

82
00:03:49.890 --> 00:03:54.480
If the file name starts with a dot,
a period then it hides it.

83
00:03:54.480 --> 00:03:56.070
Simple as that, right?

84
00:03:56.070 --> 00:03:59.750
So for example,
if I'm sitting here on my desktop and

85
00:03:59.750 --> 00:04:02.810
I create a folder called Secrets, right?

86
00:04:02.810 --> 00:04:06.680
So this is gonna be where
I store all of my secrets.

87
00:04:06.680 --> 00:04:11.510
And if I take that folder and I just take
a dot at the beginning of it, right?

88
00:04:11.510 --> 00:04:15.350
When I do that,
the GUI says you can't do that,

89
00:04:15.350 --> 00:04:17.510
you can't start a folder with a dot,
because that name,

90
00:04:17.510 --> 00:04:21.320
this name is a reserved for the system,
please choose another name, right?

91
00:04:21.320 --> 00:04:25.500
It's telling me I can't do it, because the
folder would effectively disappear, and

92
00:04:25.500 --> 00:04:27.030
I would lose it, right?

93
00:04:27.030 --> 00:04:32.250
But from the terminal,
if I get into my terminal, and

94
00:04:32.250 --> 00:04:34.980
go into my desktop, and take a look.

95
00:04:34.980 --> 00:04:37.080
There's my secrets folder.

96
00:04:37.080 --> 00:04:40.540
And I can rename it, and
stick a dot before it, right?

97
00:04:40.540 --> 00:04:44.350
I can actually say, mv,
which is the move command.

98
00:04:44.350 --> 00:04:51.595
And I can move secrets to be .Secrets,
like that, okay?

99
00:04:51.595 --> 00:04:55.506
And I don't know, I should have pointed
it out, but that folder just disappeared,

100
00:04:55.506 --> 00:04:57.330
right here in the background.

101
00:04:57.330 --> 00:05:01.840
It disappeared, because now it has
a dot at the beginning of its name, and

102
00:05:01.840 --> 00:05:02.920
so it's hidden.

103
00:05:02.920 --> 00:05:06.660
It is still there, but
even when I do the Unix ls command,

104
00:05:06.660 --> 00:05:09.660
the list command,
I don't see it there either.

105
00:05:09.660 --> 00:05:11.840
It's disappeared,
I just lost all my secrets.

106
00:05:11.840 --> 00:05:13.630
This is a tragedy, right?

107
00:05:13.630 --> 00:05:15.700
Well, I didn't lose them.

108
00:05:15.700 --> 00:05:20.070
I just need to do an ls -a,
to say show me all files,

109
00:05:20.070 --> 00:05:23.690
not just the ones that
are normally visible.

110
00:05:23.690 --> 00:05:28.520
And when I do that,
I should find .Secrets is right back.

111
00:05:28.520 --> 00:05:31.340
And you'll see there's some other ones
that I didn't highlight, like .localized.

112
00:05:31.340 --> 00:05:32.060
I didn't make that.

113
00:05:32.060 --> 00:05:33.770
That was part of my default user profile.

114
00:05:33.770 --> 00:05:37.220
Or .DS_Store, I'm seeing these
other ones that are hidden

115
00:05:37.220 --> 00:05:39.010
with a dot at the beginning of them.

116
00:05:39.010 --> 00:05:42.040
And it could be a file or
it could be a folder, right?

117
00:05:42.040 --> 00:05:44.350
In this case,
I think these are all folders.

118
00:05:44.350 --> 00:05:46.952
Let me add a -held just to be sure.

119
00:05:46.952 --> 00:05:49.250
No not .localize this are file.

120
00:05:49.250 --> 00:05:51.900
So it's just a regular file that
has a dot on the beginning of it so

121
00:05:51.900 --> 00:05:54.970
it's hiding it from the user interface,
right?

122
00:05:54.970 --> 00:06:00.154
And if I go into .Secrets for
example, I could start creating

123
00:06:00.154 --> 00:06:04.752
files like secret1.txt or
secret2.txt and so on.

124
00:06:04.752 --> 00:06:09.480
I could start creating files and
in the GUI, I don't see that.

125
00:06:09.480 --> 00:06:14.770
If I browse into my Finder and
I go into my user, my Home folder and

126
00:06:14.770 --> 00:06:18.830
I go into my Desktop,
I don't see that .Secrets.

127
00:06:18.830 --> 00:06:22.420
But if I choose Go and Go to Folder,

128
00:06:22.420 --> 00:06:26.180
I can type in my Home folder
which there's a UNIX alias.

129
00:06:26.180 --> 00:06:28.940
When you wanna go to your home
folder you can type slash.

130
00:06:28.940 --> 00:06:33.592
But if I wanted to do the full one
I could just say /Users/DonPezet

131
00:06:33.592 --> 00:06:36.926
which it doesn't want to autocomplete for
me.

132
00:06:36.926 --> 00:06:39.280
dpezet, sorry I have my Unix name.

133
00:06:39.280 --> 00:06:43.550
And then Desktop and then .Secrets.

134
00:06:43.550 --> 00:06:46.590
And see how I was even able
to tab autocomplete cuz it's

135
00:06:46.590 --> 00:06:47.250
just visually hidden.

136
00:06:47.250 --> 00:06:49.750
And when I choose Go.

137
00:06:49.750 --> 00:06:52.979
There is secret one, there is secret two,
and I can work with them.

138
00:06:52.979 --> 00:06:53.830
You'll find that a lot.

139
00:06:53.830 --> 00:06:54.710
There's things that are hidden.

140
00:06:54.710 --> 00:06:57.260
There's like secrets in the GUI sometimes.

141
00:06:57.260 --> 00:07:01.233
For example, in every home folder,
there is a folder called Library.

142
00:07:01.233 --> 00:07:03.180
And we're gonna talk more about
the Library folder in a minute.

143
00:07:03.180 --> 00:07:04.590
It's a really important one.

144
00:07:04.590 --> 00:07:08.920
But when I go to my Home folder
I don't see the Library.

145
00:07:08.920 --> 00:07:12.300
And when I use the Go menu up here,
and I see all this stuff,

146
00:07:12.300 --> 00:07:14.230
I don't see the Library in there either.

147
00:07:14.230 --> 00:07:19.920
But if I hold the Option key down on
my keyboard, see how the menu changes?

148
00:07:19.920 --> 00:07:22.010
And it makes Library show up.

149
00:07:22.010 --> 00:07:26.460
Library's hidden from the GUI by default,
but if I hold the Option key down,

150
00:07:26.460 --> 00:07:30.060
it gives me a shortcut, so I can jump and
browse right into that Library folder.

151
00:07:30.060 --> 00:07:33.900
So this is some kind of secret things
that are hidden away in the GUI.

152
00:07:33.900 --> 00:07:36.918
Now the example I gave you a minute
ago was hiding something the Unix way.

153
00:07:36.918 --> 00:07:39.240
You stick a dot before the name.

154
00:07:39.240 --> 00:07:42.580
But you can hide things without
putting a dot before its name.

155
00:07:42.580 --> 00:07:45.635
The Library folder I just showed you.

156
00:07:45.635 --> 00:07:48.435
If I take a look at my home folders,
it's right here.

157
00:07:48.435 --> 00:07:50.205
It doesn't have a dot, right.

158
00:07:50.205 --> 00:07:52.689
That's because it was
hidden the Apple way.

159
00:07:52.689 --> 00:07:57.395
And Apple actually has a file flag that
they use that flags a file that was hidden

160
00:07:57.395 --> 00:08:02.168
without having a dot at the beginning of
it's name So, for example, if I go back

161
00:08:02.168 --> 00:08:06.760
to my desktop, I'm gonna take my .Secrets
folder that I made a minute ago.

162
00:08:06.760 --> 00:08:08.070
I'm gonna get rid of that dot.

163
00:08:09.110 --> 00:08:17.733
So I'm gonna move .Secrets to
just regular old Secrets, there.

164
00:08:17.733 --> 00:08:22.721
And so now it shows up, and I should
actually see it in the background here.

165
00:08:22.721 --> 00:08:23.547
Yep, there it is.

166
00:08:23.547 --> 00:08:26.940
My Secrets folder is now
showing up in the GUI.

167
00:08:28.400 --> 00:08:31.880
Now I'm gonna use
the change flags command.

168
00:08:31.880 --> 00:08:33.460
There's a setting,

169
00:08:33.460 --> 00:08:38.480
which is a flag, that's gonna indicate
that I want this file to be hidden.

170
00:08:39.650 --> 00:08:42.634
And let me just shrink this up a little
bit so we can kinda watch what happens.

171
00:08:42.634 --> 00:08:47.260
My Secrets folder is right
here on the screen, and

172
00:08:47.260 --> 00:08:52.229
the command that I'm gonna
issue is chflags hidden.

173
00:08:52.229 --> 00:08:54.528
And then I'll specify who
it is that I'm changing.

174
00:08:54.528 --> 00:08:56.208
I'm changing the Secrets folder.

175
00:08:56.208 --> 00:09:00.702
So I'm gonna change the hidden flag
to turn it on, and when I do that,

176
00:09:00.702 --> 00:09:02.187
you see it disappear?

177
00:09:02.187 --> 00:09:03.271
And now it's gone.

178
00:09:03.271 --> 00:09:06.734
It doesn't have a dot at the beginning of
its name, it just has a flag activated

179
00:09:06.734 --> 00:09:10.650
that says hide this from the GUI, and
so now it's hidden, and that's that.

180
00:09:10.650 --> 00:09:15.449
Right, if I do a chflags nohidden, right,

181
00:09:15.449 --> 00:09:19.355
it reappears, and now it's back.

182
00:09:19.355 --> 00:09:21.887
So I can quickly and
easily change it that way, and

183
00:09:21.887 --> 00:09:24.530
that is how the library folder is hidden.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don show two of the different file types that are important:  Archive Files and File Images.   Archive file type ZIP are natively supported in the OS.  This allows us to combine multiple files into a single file and compress them too.  This is great when operability is needed when moving data between systems running different Operating System.  File Images are also natively supported (dmg) this is great if working between macOS machines.  These files are mountable and seen by the macOS as another disk drive.  Don also talks about and demonstrates how to create them.
