00:25:08.161 --> 00:25:09.812
all the way April 28th.

523
00:25:09.812 --> 00:25:11.340
Let's see what it looked like back then.

524
00:25:11.340 --> 00:25:13.010
Actually I have no idea.

525
00:25:13.010 --> 00:25:16.230
So we can jump back there, and
it looks pretty much the same actually.

526
00:25:16.230 --> 00:25:20.380
I had an examples folder that was not
there, but I can look at the files and

527
00:25:20.380 --> 00:25:22.490
things that were on my desktop
as they were back then.

528
00:25:22.490 --> 00:25:25.843
I can choose them, and
restore them, and off we go, right?

529
00:25:25.843 --> 00:25:29.106
All right, so what we've just saw,

530
00:25:29.106 --> 00:25:34.492
that is an example of a Time Machine
backup to a disk, right?

531
00:25:34.492 --> 00:25:38.460
But I mentioned there were other place
that we could back up to a server, right?

532
00:25:38.460 --> 00:25:41.070
In a server, let me just jump over here.

533
00:25:41.070 --> 00:25:44.140
This is a machine that's
running macOS Sierra and

534
00:25:44.140 --> 00:25:47.010
I've installed the OS 10 server app.

535
00:25:47.010 --> 00:25:48.568
The server app is available
right in the app store.

536
00:25:48.568 --> 00:25:51.194
You just go in there, you download it,
install it, you got it, right?

537
00:25:51.194 --> 00:25:52.807
It cost $20.

538
00:25:52.807 --> 00:25:54.300
Pay $20, now you got a server.

539
00:25:54.300 --> 00:25:56.700
So, it's actually really reasonable.

540
00:25:56.700 --> 00:25:58.750
In the server app though,
if you look down the left side,

541
00:25:58.750 --> 00:26:01.110
you'll find where there is
a Time Machine service.

542
00:26:02.120 --> 00:26:04.500
And if you choose that
Time Machine service,

543
00:26:04.500 --> 00:26:07.230
there's not a whole lot of
options you've got to specify.

544
00:26:07.230 --> 00:26:09.740
First off, you need to add a backup disk.

545
00:26:09.740 --> 00:26:13.090
So if you've got a storage area network,
or multiple disks, or whatever,

546
00:26:13.090 --> 00:26:13.760
you'll add them in.

547
00:26:13.760 --> 00:26:17.970
So I've added in a backup disk right
here as one of my backup destinations.

548
00:26:17.970 --> 00:26:23.010
And once you've done that,
you then hit this big On button, up here.

549
00:26:23.010 --> 00:26:23.740
And it's done.

550
00:26:23.740 --> 00:26:25.010
You just set up a Time Machine server.

551
00:26:25.010 --> 00:26:25.678
It's that easy.

552
00:26:25.678 --> 00:26:28.981
You might wanna tweak who's allowed
to connect to it, and so on.

553
00:26:28.981 --> 00:26:32.730
But otherwise, this is a Time Machine
server now that is up and running.

554
00:26:32.730 --> 00:26:34.710
And if I take a look at the backups tab,

555
00:26:34.710 --> 00:26:36.640
I can look at all the backups
that have been deposited here.

556
00:26:36.640 --> 00:26:39.910
Well, nobody's backed up to it yet,
so I don't see anything.

557
00:26:39.910 --> 00:26:43.250
If I wanna get somebody set up for that,
I just need to go into their Time Machine

558
00:26:43.250 --> 00:26:46.320
options and instead of choosing a disk,
I need to choose this server.

559
00:26:46.320 --> 00:26:48.220
And the same thing would be true for

560
00:26:48.220 --> 00:26:53.060
the time capsule devices,
if we wanna back up to one of those.

561
00:26:53.060 --> 00:26:54.656
So we go through and get them set up,

562
00:26:54.656 --> 00:26:57.332
we'll jump in and
we'll see this server as a destination.

563
00:26:57.332 --> 00:27:00.663
You'll see your local disks,
you'll see the time capsule option,

564
00:27:00.663 --> 00:27:04.180
and you'll see this server showing up
in the list and we can back up to it.

565
00:27:04.180 --> 00:27:06.979
Now Daniel, I've got a handful of other
things that I wanna talk about here.

566
00:27:06.979 --> 00:27:12.038
I wanna show connecting a client to
this server, I wanna show the local

567
00:27:12.038 --> 00:27:16.520
cached Time Machine,
I haven't even talked about that yet.

568
00:27:16.520 --> 00:27:19.503
But my client is stuck encrypting
that disk right now, or

569
00:27:19.503 --> 00:27:23.730
actually I guess it finally got past
that encryption, but he's got 31 minutes

570
00:27:23.730 --> 00:27:28.163
remaining on its backup, and I'm not a
giant patient man, or something like this.

571
00:27:28.163 --> 00:27:28.872
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

572
00:27:28.872 --> 00:27:31.027
why don't we do this,
why don't we break off in to a part 2.

573
00:27:31.027 --> 00:27:32.615
>> Okay.
>> And that way I can wait for

574
00:27:32.615 --> 00:27:36.222
this backup to finish, and in part 2,
we'll take this client and instead of

575
00:27:36.222 --> 00:27:40.217
backing him up to the disk, we'll get them
to back up against the network server, and

576
00:27:40.217 --> 00:27:42.970
that will be a lot more of
an enterprise type solution.

577
00:27:42.970 --> 00:27:44.667
>> Excellent.
And that's actual and

578
00:27:44.667 --> 00:27:48.129
natural stopping spot,
great segue into going from home,

579
00:27:48.129 --> 00:27:51.300
personal use into more
enterprise type of solution.

580
00:27:51.300 --> 00:27:52.780
So definitely do that.

581
00:27:52.780 --> 00:27:56.200
We did thank you go getting us this far to
figure out how we can use Time Machine.

582
00:27:56.200 --> 00:27:59.370
As you've seen super easy,
great product, works really,

583
00:27:59.370 --> 00:28:01.560
really well, not too difficult.

584
00:28:01.560 --> 00:28:04.890
So, definitely, check out the next episode
we're about to do about doing that

585
00:28:04.890 --> 00:28:06.310
enterprise side solution.

586
00:28:06.310 --> 00:28:08.853
That being said, as Don said,
we're out of time for this episode.

587
00:28:08.853 --> 00:28:10.600
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, we're gonna go ahead and

588
00:28:10.600 --> 00:28:11.470
call it a day.

589
00:28:11.470 --> 00:28:13.850
For ITProTV, I've been your host,
Daniel Lowrie.

590
00:28:13.850 --> 00:28:15.279
>> And I'm Don Pezet.
>> And we'll see you next time.

591
00:28:15.279 --> 00:28:22.360
[MUSIC]

592
00:28:22.360 --> 00:28:24.950
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explain the function and use of Time Machine as the Mac OS built-in backup solution. Here they will show you how to set up Time Machine to take backups, configuration settings to fine tune with, and restoring in the event of a failure.
episodes.title: Time Machine Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.230 --> 00:00:02.568
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet-

2
00:00:02.568 --> 00:00:06.952
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.952 --> 00:00:08.214
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.214 --> 00:00:10.560
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.330 --> 00:00:13.810
>> All right, greetings everyone and

6
00:00:13.810 --> 00:00:17.370
welcome back to another
exciting episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:17.370 --> 00:00:19.690
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and
in today's episode well,

8
00:00:19.690 --> 00:00:22.330
we're back with more of the ACSP series.

9
00:00:22.330 --> 00:00:26.895
And, of course, joining us back yet
again, continuing our Time Machine backup

10
00:00:26.895 --> 00:00:29.520
plus series here is our good friend,
Mr. Don Pezet.

11
00:00:29.520 --> 00:00:31.336
Don, you're back in time [LAUGH].

12
00:00:31.336 --> 00:00:32.110
>> That's right.

13
00:00:32.110 --> 00:00:35.930
We are back and basically just waited for
that initial backup to complete so

14
00:00:35.930 --> 00:00:38.380
that we could jump in and
see how it works.

15
00:00:38.380 --> 00:00:40.240
Now that the backup is done,

16
00:00:40.240 --> 00:00:42.640
we need to look at how it
stored the files on the disk.

17
00:00:42.640 --> 00:00:45.540
How that worked, and
we've kind of already seen recoverings,

18
00:00:45.540 --> 00:00:46.350
we don't need to tackle that.

19
00:00:46.350 --> 00:00:48.420
But I wanted to show you guys
how that folder structure works,

20
00:00:48.420 --> 00:00:49.570
cuz it's kind of important.

21
00:00:49.570 --> 00:00:51.890
I wanna show you connecting
this client to a server,

22
00:00:51.890 --> 00:00:53.650
instead of just backing up to a disk.

23
00:00:53.650 --> 00:00:57.353
And show you a couple other little tweaks
that we have inside of Time Machine.

24
00:00:57.353 --> 00:01:00.345
And so that's what we've got
before us right here in part two.

25
00:01:00.345 --> 00:01:03.055
>> All right Don, well,
let's pick up where we left off and

26
00:01:03.055 --> 00:01:04.085
continue down the road.

27
00:01:04.085 --> 00:01:07.265
>> All right, so we did a backup and
the backup has completed.

28
00:01:07.265 --> 00:01:09.745
I know it's completed
cuz if I look up here I

29
00:01:09.745 --> 00:01:13.135
can click on that Time Machine menu
item we added in the last episode.

30
00:01:13.135 --> 00:01:16.195
And I can see the last backup
was today at 10:55 AM.

31
00:01:16.195 --> 00:01:17.245
Right now it's 11:07,

32
00:01:17.245 --> 00:01:21.660
so about 12 minutes ago it finished
the backup and now we're ready to rock.

33
00:01:21.660 --> 00:01:22.820
>> It's a beautiful thing.

34
00:01:22.820 --> 00:01:24.852
>> And now that doesn't tell
me how many backups I had.

35
00:01:24.852 --> 00:01:28.120
I could've had 50 backups, 100 backups,
or I could just have one backup, but

36
00:01:28.120 --> 00:01:29.390
it just shows me the latest one.

37
00:01:29.390 --> 00:01:33.150
I know that it's done as opposed to
seeing that it's backing up right now.

38
00:01:33.150 --> 00:01:35.520
I would be waiting, and
there would be a little progress bar.

39
00:01:35.520 --> 00:01:36.580
All right, so it backed up.

40
00:01:36.580 --> 00:01:38.690
What does a backup look like?

41
00:01:38.690 --> 00:01:41.710
Well, if I go to my Time Machine disk,
and I open it up,

42
00:01:41.710 --> 00:01:45.970
what you'll see is a folder
called Backups.backupdb.

43
00:01:45.970 --> 00:01:49.770
Backupdb is backup database, it's not
really a database, it's just a folder.

44
00:01:49.770 --> 00:01:53.890
And if you browse into the folder, what
you're going to see is a computer name.

45
00:01:53.890 --> 00:01:55.310
Now, why a computer name?

46
00:01:55.310 --> 00:02:00.360
Because I might be using a backup
disk on more than one computer.

47
00:02:00.360 --> 00:02:03.470
I might have a Time Machine disk and
Daniel and I share it.

48
00:02:03.470 --> 00:02:05.320
I give him the disk and
he backs up his laptop.

49
00:02:05.320 --> 00:02:07.040
Then I come over here and I backup mine.

50
00:02:07.040 --> 00:02:10.090
So we would have separate folders for
each computer.

51
00:02:10.090 --> 00:02:12.860
Now on removable storage like this
that doesn't normally happen.

52
00:02:12.860 --> 00:02:15.410
But on a server, it does.

53
00:02:15.410 --> 00:02:16.700
If we're backing up to a server,

54
00:02:16.700 --> 00:02:20.390
you can have hundreds of clients all
backing themselves up to one server.

55
00:02:20.390 --> 00:02:22.360
So it's gotta maintain
separate folders for

56
00:02:22.360 --> 00:02:25.020
each one based on the name of that client.

57
00:02:25.020 --> 00:02:27.380
And remember,
if you don't know the name of your client,

58
00:02:27.380 --> 00:02:29.990
it's usually something silly
like Don's Mac Book Pro.

59
00:02:29.990 --> 00:02:33.050
But if you go into your
system preferences and

60
00:02:33.050 --> 00:02:35.900
go into sharing,
that's where the name comes from.

61
00:02:35.900 --> 00:02:40.635
So if I go into system preferences and
sharing, whatever's up here,

62
00:02:40.635 --> 00:02:42.892
that's the name of your client.

63
00:02:42.892 --> 00:02:45.705
And so on the time machine server
that's where that name of the folder

64
00:02:45.705 --> 00:02:46.440
would come from.

65
00:02:47.670 --> 00:02:51.610
All right, now if I go inside of that
folder, here's where the backup is.

66
00:02:51.610 --> 00:02:55.020
And I can see that I actually
have two backups, not one.

67
00:02:55.020 --> 00:02:56.160
I don't know why I have two but

68
00:02:56.160 --> 00:02:59.650
I do, so if you wait long
enough you'll have plenty more.

69
00:02:59.650 --> 00:03:02.180
In fact if we go and
take a look at my laptop here, right, and

70
00:03:02.180 --> 00:03:04.370
I'll take a look at my actual laptop.

71
00:03:04.370 --> 00:03:08.443
And remember on my actual laptop you
can see my folder is Don's MacBook Pro,

72
00:03:08.443 --> 00:03:09.533
something simple.

73
00:03:09.533 --> 00:03:15.080
And if I go in there, I've got tons of
backups all the way back up to April 28th.

74
00:03:15.080 --> 00:03:18.820
And what you're seeing is one folder for
each backup.

75
00:03:18.820 --> 00:03:20.420
Now, the original backup,

76
00:03:20.420 --> 00:03:24.920
the very first one that's taken is a full
backup of my entire laptop, all the data.

77
00:03:24.920 --> 00:03:30.180
And then every other backup that's
made is just what's changed.

78
00:03:30.180 --> 00:03:34.304
So if I look at this one,
this 4-28, that's the full backup.

79
00:03:34.304 --> 00:03:40.470
And then 4-29, 4-30, each of these
are just what changed since then.

80
00:03:40.470 --> 00:03:44.690
Okay, but if my disk gets full its gotta
delete the old and make room for the new.

81
00:03:44.690 --> 00:03:46.950
So what happens when it deletes 4-28?

82
00:03:46.950 --> 00:03:49.720
Doesn't that delete my full backup?

83
00:03:49.720 --> 00:03:51.780
Well it actually doesn't.

84
00:03:51.780 --> 00:03:56.460
When you look in these folders,
you're not actually seeing real files.

85
00:03:56.460 --> 00:03:59.990
What you're seeing are a ton of aliases.

86
00:03:59.990 --> 00:04:04.930
So when I browse into this folder for
example, I can see Macintosh HD and

87
00:04:04.930 --> 00:04:08.540
then I see Applications,
Library, opt, System, Users.

88
00:04:08.540 --> 00:04:10.740
I'm seeing a full back up.

89
00:04:10.740 --> 00:04:12.810
And I can see user accounts
that I've got on my system.

90
00:04:12.810 --> 00:04:14.710
I can browse into my user account.

91
00:04:14.710 --> 00:04:18.830
And I can browse into desktop and
I'm seeing everything.

92
00:04:18.830 --> 00:04:20.460
Everything that would be in here.

93
00:04:20.460 --> 00:04:23.680
Okay, well if I go back and
I pick another folder.

94
00:04:23.680 --> 00:04:28.030
Let me pick one from like May 17th,
a lot of backups on May 17th.

95
00:04:28.030 --> 00:04:31.623
So if I go into May 17th,
I browse into Macintosh HD.

96
00:04:31.623 --> 00:04:35.497
I see all the folders I can come in and
I see dpezet.

97
00:04:35.497 --> 00:04:38.868
And I come in here and I can see my
desktop, and I browse in here and

98
00:04:38.868 --> 00:04:40.160
I see my desktop.

99
00:04:40.160 --> 00:04:43.500
Now notice I've got these
podcast files sitting here.

100
00:04:43.500 --> 00:04:47.450
Those podcast files are sitting
in the other backup also.

101
00:04:47.450 --> 00:04:49.080
Are they stored twice?

102
00:04:49.080 --> 00:04:52.960
Well if they didn't change,
no, they're only stored once.

103
00:04:52.960 --> 00:04:56.282
There's an alias in every
one of these backups.

104
00:04:56.282 --> 00:04:59.470
>> So it's just kinda like showing you
a representation of the actual file?

105
00:04:59.470 --> 00:05:02.230
>> Yes, and that's what makes it so
nice and easy.

106
00:05:02.230 --> 00:05:04.890
Is that if I wanna go and restore
things how they looked on April 28th,

107
00:05:04.890 --> 00:05:07.460
I don't have to go to just one folder.

108
00:05:07.460 --> 00:05:08.891
Well, I guess April 28th's a bad example.

109
00:05:08.891 --> 00:05:13.755
If I wanna restore from May 17th,
I don't have to access May 17th and

110
00:05:13.755 --> 00:05:17.080
every folder before it to get everything.

111
00:05:17.080 --> 00:05:19.180
And that's how the old style
incremental backups would work.

112
00:05:19.180 --> 00:05:22.490
Because you would restore your full
backup and then every incremental,

113
00:05:22.490 --> 00:05:25.420
all the way up until the point
where you were current.

114
00:05:25.420 --> 00:05:26.280
We don't have to do that.

115
00:05:26.280 --> 00:05:28.500
Thanks to the aliases
that are put in place.

116
00:05:28.500 --> 00:05:30.760
And the only time a real file
is in there is if it changed.

117
00:05:30.760 --> 00:05:33.330
If it changed, the real files there and
it's not an alias, but

118
00:05:33.330 --> 00:05:37.630
then every backup afterwards would
have an alias to points that change.

119
00:05:37.630 --> 00:05:41.300
So that keeps the size really
optimized and nice and small.

120
00:05:41.300 --> 00:05:45.620
When you browse into a folder,
it looks like a full set of your data.

121
00:05:45.620 --> 00:05:49.851
But it's using the macOS extended general
file systems alias functions to be able to

122
00:05:49.851 --> 00:05:51.165
shrink all that down.

123
00:05:51.165 --> 00:05:53.480
So it's kind of neat to see
how that's stored in there and

124
00:05:53.480 --> 00:05:56.459
really design which is convenient and
easy work with.

125
00:05:57.890 --> 00:06:02.370
Now this is not the only place
that my backups are being stored.

126
00:06:02.370 --> 00:06:05.530
If I've got my removable media plugged in
or I'm connected to my network server and

127
00:06:05.530 --> 00:06:08.030
I'm backing up to it,
these backups are gonna get located here.

128
00:06:08.030 --> 00:06:12.950
But what about times when I'm not
connected to my removable media?

129
00:06:12.950 --> 00:06:15.390
So maybe I'm traveling,
I'm at a hotel somewhere.

130
00:06:15.390 --> 00:06:18.550
I leave my Time Machine
drive back at the office.

131
00:06:18.550 --> 00:06:22.640
Well, the time machine backup happen, they
just don't backup to the external disk,

132
00:06:22.640 --> 00:06:24.300
because the external disk isn't there.

133
00:06:24.300 --> 00:06:26.620
Instead they backup to a local cache.

134
00:06:26.620 --> 00:06:29.380
So there's another place I wanna
show you here on the disk.

135
00:06:29.380 --> 00:06:30.930
I'm gonna fire up a terminal.

136
00:06:30.930 --> 00:06:32.940
Actually, let me use my
virtual machine for this.

137
00:06:32.940 --> 00:06:39.600
So I'm gonna fire up a terminal and
on the disk,

138
00:06:39.600 --> 00:06:44.190
if I browse to the volumes folder,
so I'm gonna go to /volumes.

139
00:06:44.190 --> 00:06:49.770
And we take a look in there, what you'll
see are a couple of different folders.

140
00:06:49.770 --> 00:06:53.780
I can see a link Macintosh HD,
cuz that's a mounted disk that I've got.

141
00:06:53.780 --> 00:06:55.840
And I can see a link to Time Machine.

142
00:06:57.280 --> 00:07:00.260
And the Time Machine,
that's my USB drive that's attached.

143
00:07:00.260 --> 00:07:05.560
Now if I unplug that Time Machine disk,
I can't back up to it anymore.

144
00:07:05.560 --> 00:07:07.500
And so Time Machine can't work.

145
00:07:07.500 --> 00:07:11.290
Well, what it'll do is it'll
create another folder, and

146
00:07:11.290 --> 00:07:12.720
that folder will be called Mobile Backups.

147
00:07:12.720 --> 00:07:14.220
And the Mobile Backups,

148
00:07:14.220 --> 00:07:18.410
basically a Time Machine backup location
that's stored right here on the same disk.

149
00:07:18.410 --> 00:07:23.470
Now if my disk fails I lose that backup,
so it doesn't save me from disk failure.

150
00:07:23.470 --> 00:07:27.420
But if I accidentally delete something,
when I enter Time Machine it's gonna look

151
00:07:27.420 --> 00:07:31.230
not only at my Time Machine
disk if I've got it.

152
00:07:31.230 --> 00:07:34.770
But it'll also look at the mobile backup.

1

7

00:00:43.870 --> 00:00:46.580
it, you just upgrade it and

00:00:46.580 --> 00:00:51.810

18
00:00:51.810 --> 00:00:56.130

edit utility is just part of the OS,

19
00:00:56.130 --> 00:00:59.080
it's there, it's not very fancy, it's not

numbers, GarageBand,

00:01:03.590 --> 00:01:07.180
iMovie, those little projects,

00:01:07.180 --> 00:01:09.920
people love them, and they're

23
00:01:09.920 --> 00:01:15.030

24
00:01:15.030 --> 00:01:18.430

25

00:01:46.020 --> 00:01:48.490

So, if I want to have a fully

I mean they've got

00:02:18.170 --> 00:02:19.540
And Apple says hey, that's great.

00:02:19.540 --> 00:02:20.300

00:02:21.360 --> 00:02:23.130
They specialize in that software.

00:02:28.170 --> 00:02:28.990

00:02:33.110 --> 00:02:37.810

00:02:40.740 --> 00:02:42.230

00:02:44.740 --> 00:02:51.160
And it gives you a very stable,

57
00:02:51.160 --> 00:02:54.140
But when we start loading on
these third party applications,

58
00:02:54.140 --> 00:02:57.350

59
00:02:57.350 --> 00:03:00.110
And that causes some problems, right?

60
00:03:00.110 --> 00:03:01.460
And it puts us at risk.

61
00:03:01.460 --> 00:03:04.980

applications work, where we can get them

Those are the ones that are global.

519
00:24:50.940 --> 00:24:54.940
These are installed for
all users and they end in wdgt.

520
00:24:54.940 --> 00:24:58.640
They don't end in .app, they end in .wdgt.

521
00:24:58.640 --> 00:25:02.307
So, these are the widgets that
are effectively applications.

522
00:25:04.225 --> 00:25:06.820
All right,
one last thing that I wanna point out.

523
00:25:06.820 --> 00:25:08.961
And I don't think this will show
up on the exam, but just so

524
00:25:08.961 --> 00:25:09.985
you know in real life land.

525
00:25:09.985 --> 00:25:14.256
When we install applications,
if they're installed from the App Store,

526
00:25:14.256 --> 00:25:16.240
the applications get sandboxed.

527
00:25:16.240 --> 00:25:17.349
I mentioned that, right?

528
00:25:17.349 --> 00:25:20.713
Well, one area where that's
important to know is

529
00:25:20.713 --> 00:25:25.213
that it changes the permissions
on the applications themselves.

530
00:25:25.213 --> 00:25:29.565
So when you install an application from a
third-party it has one set of permissions

531
00:25:29.565 --> 00:25:31.628
cuz it can access way more than normal.

532
00:25:31.628 --> 00:25:35.920
But when you install an application
from the App Store it has much more

533
00:25:35.920 --> 00:25:38.440
restricted permissions on that.

534
00:25:38.440 --> 00:25:42.336
And most users aren't gonna see that, but
if I go into the applications folder and

535
00:25:42.336 --> 00:25:43.873
take a look at my applications.

536
00:25:43.873 --> 00:25:48.056
I can find an application that I installed
from outside, like ForkLift, right?

537
00:25:48.056 --> 00:25:51.604
So ForkLift I installed from the outside,
it's right here.

538
00:25:51.604 --> 00:25:58.039
And if I do a, ls -la, fork*,
[LAUGH] We can find it,

539
00:25:58.039 --> 00:26:02.413
and oops, You know what?

540
00:26:02.413 --> 00:26:04.190
It's a directory, so
it's going inside of it.

541
00:26:04.190 --> 00:26:06.018
Let me just do a full
directory listing here.

542
00:26:06.018 --> 00:26:10.203
And we can find ForkLift, and here it is.

543
00:26:10.203 --> 00:26:13.136
And if you look at the permissions,
look at the permissions on it.

544
00:26:13.136 --> 00:26:16.572
It's owned by depezet, it's owned by me.

545
00:26:16.572 --> 00:26:19.140
And the group is set to admin.

546
00:26:19.140 --> 00:26:23.480
I'm the one who installed it and
I was the administrator who authorized it,

547
00:26:23.480 --> 00:26:26.380
prompted for administrative credentials,
I provided it and they installed.

548
00:26:26.380 --> 00:26:28.582
All right so there it is, I installed it.

549
00:26:28.582 --> 00:26:32.732
But look at some of the other
applications that are in here,

550
00:26:32.732 --> 00:26:36.510
things like the Font Book or
Firefox or whatever.

551
00:26:36.510 --> 00:26:42.515
See how some of them are owned by root and
wheel and others are owned by me, okay?

552
00:26:42.515 --> 00:26:45.315
When you look at these,
the ones that are owned by a user,

553
00:26:45.315 --> 00:26:48.415
those are generally ones that we've
installed from a website, right?

554
00:26:48.415 --> 00:26:51.835
We went to a website, downloaded them,
and installed them, right?

555
00:26:51.835 --> 00:26:53.604
But, Jump Desktop.

556
00:26:53.604 --> 00:26:56.363
You guys saw where I had purchased that,
it's in my App Store.

557
00:26:56.363 --> 00:27:00.284
And I can see it's owned by root and
admin, or root and wheel,

558
00:27:00.284 --> 00:27:03.990
not exactly sure why those
are owned by a different group.

559
00:27:03.990 --> 00:27:05.990
But the user's the important part here.

560
00:27:05.990 --> 00:27:10.510
The root,
because the system is controlling them.

561
00:27:10.510 --> 00:27:15.050
By default the regular user can
install apps from the App Store

562
00:27:15.050 --> 00:27:17.300
because the system is doing it for them.

563
00:27:17.300 --> 00:27:20.354
But they can't install apps from a third
party they'll be prompted to provide

564
00:27:20.354 --> 00:27:22.343
administrative credentials to do it,
right, and

565
00:27:22.343 --> 00:27:23.655
it is because of this ownership.

566
00:27:23.655 --> 00:27:25.752
So if you're ever poking around
in your applications and

567
00:27:25.752 --> 00:27:28.090
you notice these different permissions.

568
00:27:28.090 --> 00:27:31.560
It's because of where these things
are being installed from, and

569
00:27:31.560 --> 00:27:34.690
they end up with different settings like
these based on how they're installed.

570
00:27:34.690 --> 00:27:36.081
Here is FileZilla, right?

571
00:27:36.081 --> 00:27:39.341
I downloaded that from
the FileZilla project website,

572
00:27:39.341 --> 00:27:41.690
it's owned by me the group is staff.

573
00:27:41.690 --> 00:27:44.339
So now we've seen staff, admin,
we owe a couple of different groups.

574
00:27:44.339 --> 00:27:46.920
These programs can assign
permissions incorrectly sometimes.

575
00:27:46.920 --> 00:27:50.970
So yeah, that's not supposed to be owned
by staff, but it is, you can notice none

576
00:27:50.970 --> 00:27:55.428
of the other ones are owned by staff, it's
not, well, it's just inventory access.

577
00:27:55.428 --> 00:27:58.570
You'll see that I have a lot of
applications from third-party vendors.

578
00:27:58.570 --> 00:28:02.510
But there's plenty that were pulled
either part of the default install or

579
00:28:02.510 --> 00:28:03.760
from the App Store.

580
00:28:03.760 --> 00:28:07.600
So the serial was one of the ones
I showed from the App Store.

581
00:28:07.600 --> 00:28:08.330
So I can find it right here.

582
00:28:08.330 --> 00:28:12.060
And you see it's owned by root and
wheel, okay?

583
00:28:12.060 --> 00:28:16.303
So just be aware that there are different
permissions from the App Store apps versus

584
00:28:16.303 --> 00:28:17.222
the third party.

585
00:28:17.222 --> 00:28:20.483
>> Well Don, that's a lot of great
information when we start taking a look,

586
00:28:20.483 --> 00:28:23.023
of course,
at managing these different applications.

587
00:28:23.023 --> 00:28:27.483
Remember in terms of installing, we have,
of course, the App Store itself, and

588
00:28:27.483 --> 00:28:31.940
the website that is normally going
to be identified by Apple, as well.

589
00:28:31.940 --> 00:28:35.284
You do, well no you don't,
anymore, have a chance to

590
00:28:35.284 --> 00:28:39.384
be able to get an app from
an unidentified Apple provider, right?

591
00:28:39.384 --> 00:28:42.409
>> You can get it, it's just it's gonna
prompt you and you've got to authorize it.

592
00:28:42.409 --> 00:28:42.983
>> That's right.

593
00:28:42.983 --> 00:28:44.306
>> And you really shouldn't do it.

594
00:28:44.306 --> 00:28:45.610
>> Yeah, so don't do that.

595
00:28:45.610 --> 00:28:46.471
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

596
00:28:46.471 --> 00:28:50.610
then remember that Gatekeeper is what
helps us to make sure that we can take

597
00:28:50.610 --> 00:28:55.441
advantage of the security that's there for

598
00:28:55.441 --> 00:29:01.120
As well as, lastly, Don's favorite feature

00:29:03.370 --> 00:29:05.395
>> I actually just turned it off on

00:29:05.395 --> 00:29:06.759
>> [LAUGH]
>> So,

00:29:06.759 --> 00:29:08.755
there's a lot of fun features there too.

00:29:08.755 --> 00:29:10.498
But make sure you do
pay attention to that.

00:29:10.498 --> 00:29:14.355
Well that's a great place for

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don dive into the Application Data.  They show where applications are not just a single standalone file but they require additional files to make them function the way users need to them.  Don demonstrates where to find the preference files that help with settings that will allow the user to customize how the product works with the user.  Also He shows the ability lock the files to prevent modifications and lastly how to use the launch services to choose what opens a file instead of allow the OS to choose for us.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.063 --> 00:00:03.665
Welcome to ITPRO TV,

2
00:00:03.665 --> 00:00:08.274
I'm your host [CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:08.274 --> 00:00:12.027
>> You're watching ITPRO TV.

4
00:00:12.027 --> 00:00:14.834
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITPRO TV.

5
00:00:14.834 --> 00:00:19.310
You're watching the Apple Certified
Support Professional for macOS Sierra.

6
00:00:19.310 --> 00:00:20.850
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:20.850 --> 00:00:24.510
Today we're diving into
the realm of application data.

8
00:00:24.510 --> 00:00:27.800
Taking look at that with us,
deeply, is gonna be Mr. Don Pezet.

9
00:00:27.800 --> 00:00:29.136
Don, welcome back to the studios.

10
00:00:29.136 --> 00:00:32.260
>> Wow, being described as deep is not
something that happens to me a lot, but

11
00:00:32.260 --> 00:00:33.013
[LAUGH] all right.

12
00:00:33.013 --> 00:00:36.269
So, in this episode we're gonna
be diving back into applications.

13
00:00:36.269 --> 00:00:38.242
And if you've watched
the last few episodes,

14
00:00:38.242 --> 00:00:41.387
we've got a chance to learn a little
bit about how the applications work.

15
00:00:41.387 --> 00:00:46.315
And I highlighted, in one episode,
how an application is really a bundle of

16
00:00:46.315 --> 00:00:49.397
files that are all combined together,
right?

17
00:00:49.397 --> 00:00:53.427
But the application doesn't full
exist inside of that one file.

18
00:00:53.427 --> 00:00:54.678
There's other settings and

19
00:00:54.678 --> 00:00:58.283
supporting files that it'll create in the
file system that we need to be aware of.

20
00:00:58.283 --> 00:01:01.369
And so in this episode we're gonna take
a look at some of those supporting files

21
00:01:01.369 --> 00:01:02.745
that go along with it, all right?

22
00:01:02.745 --> 00:01:04.617
But before I get too far,
let me just recap for

23
00:01:04.617 --> 00:01:06.593
anybody who didn't catch
the other episodes.

24
00:01:06.593 --> 00:01:10.532
When we browse into our hard-drives,
I'll take my laptop here for example,

25
00:01:10.532 --> 00:01:12.390
and go in to my Applications folder.

26
00:01:12.390 --> 00:01:16.170
I can find an application like, we'll
use ForkLift as our example here in this

27
00:01:16.170 --> 00:01:18.760
episode, I think that's
the one I was using before.

28
00:01:18.760 --> 00:01:21.512
So, I've got this ForkLift application,
right, and

29
00:01:21.512 --> 00:01:23.158
it just shows up as a single icon.

30
00:01:23.158 --> 00:01:25.903
And when I installed it,
all I did was drag this icon and

31
00:01:25.903 --> 00:01:30.400
drop it right here into my applications
folder, and then, pow, I had ForkLift.

32
00:01:30.400 --> 00:01:34.360
Great, wonderful, that's it,
right, it's one file.

33
00:01:34.360 --> 00:01:37.655
Well, the application itself is
actually made up of a number of files.

34
00:01:37.655 --> 00:01:40.138
And if you right-click, or ctrl-click, or

35
00:01:40.138 --> 00:01:43.775
whatever secret is it you have to do
to get your [LAUGH] menu to come up.

36
00:01:43.775 --> 00:01:46.651
You'll see we've got Open,
which would launch the application, or

37
00:01:46.651 --> 00:01:47.682
Show Package Contents.

38
00:01:47.682 --> 00:01:52.975
And when you choose Show Package Contents,
you actually browse inside of the app.

39
00:01:52.975 --> 00:01:56.655
And inside of the app you'll
find quite a few files

40
00:01:56.655 --> 00:01:58.335
that make up the actual application.

41
00:01:58.335 --> 00:02:00.440
Here's the actual application,
right here, but

42
00:02:00.440 --> 00:02:05.190
if I browse back and
look at some of these other folders.

43
00:02:05.190 --> 00:02:09.520
Like when I go into Resources, for
example, here's a lot of the icons and

44
00:02:09.520 --> 00:02:11.870
other resources that
make up this application.

45
00:02:11.870 --> 00:02:14.780
It's all part of that program, right?

46
00:02:14.780 --> 00:02:16.250
So, programs are actually kind of complex.

47
00:02:17.620 --> 00:02:22.180
However, once this application file is
written like it is, for the most part,

48
00:02:22.180 --> 00:02:22.700
it's read only.

49
00:02:22.700 --> 00:02:25.507
We don't tamper with what's inside of it,
a lot of these are digitally signed.

50
00:02:25.507 --> 00:02:28.475
So if you do tamper with it,
like if I were to rename this icon file,

51
00:02:28.475 --> 00:02:29.968
it would break the application.

52
00:02:29.968 --> 00:02:34.146
And macOS wouldn't allow it to run because
the digital signature would fail at

53
00:02:34.146 --> 00:02:35.220
that point.

54
00:02:35.220 --> 00:02:38.970
So if the application has to store
settings and other information,

55
00:02:38.970 --> 00:02:40.640
it's not allowed to store it here.

56
00:02:40.640 --> 00:02:43.430
It's gotta store it somewhere else, right?

57
00:02:43.430 --> 00:02:45.713
And what am I talking about here
when I talk about settings?

58
00:02:45.713 --> 00:02:49.639
Well, if I launch the ForkLift
application, so here I am.

59
00:02:49.639 --> 00:02:52.080
And when I installed it,
it went into the Applications folder.

60
00:02:52.080 --> 00:02:54.080
So, I might have five other
users on this computer,

61
00:02:54.080 --> 00:02:56.850
all five of us could run
the ForkLift application.

62
00:02:56.850 --> 00:02:59.870
But maybe I wanna change
the way that it looks.

63
00:02:59.870 --> 00:03:00.520
So, for example,

64
00:03:00.520 --> 00:03:05.160
I might wanna go up here to my
ForkLift menu, and go to Preferences.

65
00:03:05.160 --> 00:03:08.810
Every application has preferences
that it keeps track off, and

66
00:03:08.810 --> 00:03:11.700
you can change the way that
different things work.

67
00:03:11.700 --> 00:03:14.095
Whether you wanna restore
Windows on tabs startup,

68
00:03:14.095 --> 00:03:16.060
what this default starting directory is?

69
00:03:16.060 --> 00:03:19.569
Right, maybe I want this one to start
in my desktop instead of in my Home

70
00:03:19.569 --> 00:03:20.870
folder, right?

71
00:03:20.870 --> 00:03:23.730
You can specify what terminal
application you used and so on.

72
00:03:23.730 --> 00:03:27.350
This is all gonna vary based on
whatever application you're using.

73
00:03:27.350 --> 00:03:30.090
But the key thing here is
that these preferences,

74
00:03:30.090 --> 00:03:32.330
they have to get stored somewhere.

75
00:03:32.330 --> 00:03:36.520
And they are, they're stored in preference
files that are called plist files.

76
00:03:36.520 --> 00:03:38.950
Plist is just short for
a preference list, or

77
00:03:38.950 --> 00:03:41.850
a list of all these settings,
what value we put them at.

78
00:03:41.850 --> 00:03:45.080
Now, there's two different
levels of preferences.

79
00:03:45.080 --> 00:03:48.930
There's global preferences that
apply to everybody on the computer.

80
00:03:48.930 --> 00:03:52.820
And then there's user preferences
that just apply to that user.

81
00:03:52.820 --> 00:03:55.419
The settings that I'm showing you here,
these are user preferences,

82
00:03:55.419 --> 00:03:56.295
these just apply to me.

83
00:03:56.295 --> 00:04:00.703
If I change it so that it launches and
goes right to my hard drive, well,

84
00:04:00.703 --> 00:04:02.102
that would affect me.

85
00:04:02.102 --> 00:04:05.465
Another user that launches this
application would be at the default,

86
00:04:05.465 --> 00:04:08.894
which I think is your home directory,
so it would default to wherever.

87
00:04:08.894 --> 00:04:11.162
Those settings have to be
stored separately otherwise,

88
00:04:11.162 --> 00:04:13.584
when I made a change,
it would overwrite somebody else's.

89
00:04:13.584 --> 00:04:16.264
So like if Ronnie had a different
preference on his application,

90
00:04:16.264 --> 00:04:18.910
I would be overwriting his if they
were stored in the same place.

91
00:04:18.910 --> 00:04:21.000
So instead, they're stored separate.

92
00:04:21.000 --> 00:04:24.150
And where you can find those,
is in the Library folder.

93
00:04:24.150 --> 00:04:31.967
If I fire up a terminal,
if I go into /Library/Preferences, okay?

94
00:04:33.410 --> 00:04:36.320
When you browse into /Library/Preferences,

95
00:04:36.320 --> 00:04:39.550
these are the global preferences for
your system.

96
00:04:39.550 --> 00:04:44.800
And if we pull up a listing in here,
I'll find plist files for

97
00:04:44.800 --> 00:04:49.320
maybe not every application, but
for many applications, right?

98
00:04:49.320 --> 00:04:52.851
Some applications don't have
a global preference, right?

99
00:04:52.851 --> 00:04:55.325
And so
I might not find them here in my list, and

100
00:04:55.325 --> 00:04:58.315
that's because they track
everything on a user basis.

101
00:04:58.315 --> 00:04:59.710
It's actually pretty common.

102
00:04:59.710 --> 00:05:02.396
So, looking at this list here,
there's really not all that much, maybe,

103
00:05:02.396 --> 00:05:04.860
50, 50 entries.

104
00:05:04.860 --> 00:05:08.720
I definitely have over 100 apps,
so I'm missing quite a bit here.

105
00:05:08.720 --> 00:05:11.890
And I was using ForkLift as my example,
let's find them in the list.

106
00:05:11.890 --> 00:05:17.864
Well, notice the names of these files,
it's kinda weird, com.apple and so on.

107
00:05:17.864 --> 00:05:21.587
According to the Apple design guidelines,
if the developers follow the guidelines,

108
00:05:21.587 --> 00:05:22.866
which they don't have to do.

109
00:05:22.866 --> 00:05:25.520
If I downloaded it from a third party
site, they could break the guidelines.

110
00:05:25.520 --> 00:05:29.241
But if it's from the app store, or
a developer who's worth their salt,

111
00:05:29.241 --> 00:05:31.322
they're gonna follow the guidelines.

112
00:05:31.322 --> 00:05:35.700
And what they do for naming their
application files is they basically take

113
00:05:35.700 --> 00:05:38.050
their domain name and reverse it.

114
00:05:38.050 --> 00:05:40.694
So apple.com becomes com.apple, and

115
00:05:40.694 --> 00:05:44.515
then they follow that with
the application name, right?

116
00:05:44.515 --> 00:05:48.384
So if I'm looking for ForkLift,
it's by a company called BinaryNights.

117
00:05:48.384 --> 00:05:52.901
And so I would look for
com.binarynights, or net., or org.,

118
00:05:52.901 --> 00:05:55.464
whatever it is that their domain is.

119
00:05:55.464 --> 00:05:57.282
And I would try and find it in here, so

120
00:05:57.282 --> 00:06:00.173
this one should be com.binarynights
which I don't see.

121
00:06:00.173 --> 00:06:02.535
I see some of the other ones
like com.blackmagic-design,

122
00:06:02.535 --> 00:06:04.440
they make my little video recorder.

123
00:06:04.440 --> 00:06:07.190
They have some global settings, and
that's what it's got right here,

124
00:06:07.190 --> 00:06:09.090
the preference panel.plist.

125
00:06:09.090 --> 00:06:12.000
Here's the global settings,
these would effect every user.

126
00:06:13.080 --> 00:06:15.750
All right, if I don't find
my application here though,

127
00:06:15.750 --> 00:06:17.920
then it must be in my User folder.

128
00:06:17.920 --> 00:06:20.971
So if I switch back to my User folder,
which you can just type cd and

129
00:06:20.971 --> 00:06:22.703
it'll take you to your User folder.

130
00:06:22.703 --> 00:06:27.420
And I go into Library and
Preferences, right, so

131
00:06:27.420 --> 00:06:33.165
now my path is
/user/username/library/preferences.

132
00:06:33.165 --> 00:06:36.694
And I take a look in here,

When I installed Sublime Text,
it did a launch service for

359
00:18:07.990 --> 00:18:12.010
a number of other file extensions
including Markdown and took it over.

360
00:18:12.010 --> 00:18:13.860
So we might need to get
involved with that,

361
00:18:13.860 --> 00:18:18.230
we might need to influence that process to
dictate which application opens our file.

362
00:18:18.230 --> 00:18:24.320
Now the launch services themselves,
you don't ever really mess with, right?

363
00:18:24.320 --> 00:18:27.860
But let me just show you where
they're stored, just so you know.

364
00:18:27.860 --> 00:18:29.870
But in real life,
you really wouldn't mess with these.

365
00:18:29.870 --> 00:18:33.939
If I go into /Library/Preferences,

366
00:18:33.939 --> 00:18:37.638
inside of the Preferences folder,

367
00:18:37.638 --> 00:18:42.954
there is a com.apple
.launchservices.plist.

368
00:18:42.954 --> 00:18:49.620
So if we look around here,
and, do I not have it?

369
00:18:49.620 --> 00:18:51.760
I am not seeing it.

370
00:18:51.760 --> 00:18:53.820
So let me, let me just check.

371
00:18:55.269 --> 00:18:59.185
If it's not here, then it will be under my
own, that's a long schema but it's not it.

372
00:18:59.185 --> 00:19:03.425
All right, so if I go into my own user
folder, and I'll go into my library and

373
00:19:03.425 --> 00:19:05.405
my preferences there.

374
00:19:05.405 --> 00:19:07.535
Apparently I don't have any global ones,
which is possible,

375
00:19:07.535 --> 00:19:10.015
this can be tracked separately per user.

376
00:19:10.015 --> 00:19:12.330
And I kinda figured I have
my global one at least.

377
00:19:12.330 --> 00:19:16.360
But let me look here for, there it is.

378
00:19:16.360 --> 00:19:20.330
So under my user I've got
com.apple.LaunchServices, right there.

379
00:19:20.330 --> 00:19:24.890
And that preference file is
actually keeping track of

380
00:19:24.890 --> 00:19:28.070
which programs are able to
open up which documents.

381
00:19:28.070 --> 00:19:30.900
Now, I don't normally have to mess with
that because we can easily do it from

382
00:19:30.900 --> 00:19:32.280
the GUI.

383
00:19:32.280 --> 00:19:36.020
If I wanna open up this Markdown file and
I wanna open it in Sublime Text, well,

384
00:19:36.020 --> 00:19:36.610
that's the default.

385
00:19:36.610 --> 00:19:39.870
I just double click on it, and
there it is in Sublime Text, great.

386
00:19:39.870 --> 00:19:41.540
But if I wanna open it up in Haroopad and

387
00:19:41.540 --> 00:19:47.100
I just wanna do it one time,
I can Ctrl + click and choose Open With.

388
00:19:47.100 --> 00:19:49.390
And then as a one time thing,
I can come in here and

389
00:19:49.390 --> 00:19:52.200
choose one of my other programs,
like Haroopad.

390
00:19:52.200 --> 00:19:54.100
And then it can open up
over in Haroopad and

391
00:19:54.100 --> 00:19:56.830
it will pop open in that one, eventually.

392
00:19:56.830 --> 00:19:58.570
It's probably gonna take its time.

393
00:19:58.570 --> 00:20:00.910
So maybe I'll open it with Marked instead.

394
00:20:00.910 --> 00:20:02.400
A program that will run a little faster.

395
00:20:02.400 --> 00:20:05.850
And so I opened it up, and
there it opens up in Marked.

396
00:20:05.850 --> 00:20:08.140
So easy enough for
me to do as a one time thing.

397
00:20:08.140 --> 00:20:12.170
But if I wanted to open up in
another program all the time, right?

398
00:20:12.170 --> 00:20:14.770
Maybe I always wanted
to open up in Marked.

399
00:20:14.770 --> 00:20:19.650
Well, if you take a file and
do a get info on it, or Ctrl + click and

400
00:20:19.650 --> 00:20:21.030
choose get info.

401
00:20:21.030 --> 00:20:23.650
You'll see right here, it's got Open with.

402
00:20:23.650 --> 00:20:28.780
And you can change the default program
that just this one file opens with.

403
00:20:28.780 --> 00:20:31.730
Now, all my other Markdown stuff
will still go to Sublime Text, but

404
00:20:31.730 --> 00:20:33.420
this one will open with Marked.

405
00:20:33.420 --> 00:20:36.190
And you can do that, or
you can hit Change All.

406
00:20:36.190 --> 00:20:40.740
And now all of my Markdown files
are going to open up with Marked.

407
00:20:40.740 --> 00:20:44.680
And so from now on, any time I
wanna open up one of these things,

408
00:20:44.680 --> 00:20:46.115
I can just double click on it.

409
00:20:46.115 --> 00:20:48.665
And it opens in Marked,
instead of opening in Sublime Text.

410
00:20:48.665 --> 00:20:52.551
So there's never really a need to go and
modify the plist file itself, I can show

411
00:20:52.551 --> 00:20:56.553
you right here from the GUI and change who
that default application is going to be,

412
00:20:56.553 --> 00:20:58.410
pretty straight forward on that one.

413
00:21:00.347 --> 00:21:02.197
That pretty much wraps up that.

414
00:21:02.197 --> 00:21:05.307
I mean, we do have some other
files you'll find like just,

415
00:21:05.307 --> 00:21:07.027
I don't want the episode
to be ten hours long.

416
00:21:07.027 --> 00:21:10.087
But if you were to browse
into your library,

417
00:21:10.087 --> 00:21:15.057
let me go into my library real quick,
and take a look at the files that you've

418
00:21:15.057 --> 00:21:18.990
got in there, you've got application
scripts and application support.

419
00:21:18.990 --> 00:21:22.500
You'll find that some applications put
files in the application support folder.

420
00:21:22.500 --> 00:21:24.640
And so, you'll find things in here,
like here's ForkLift,

421
00:21:24.640 --> 00:21:28.780
where it's storing my favorites,
right here, inside of application support.

422
00:21:28.780 --> 00:21:32.800
So you may have other files that go along
with applications that are stored there.

423
00:21:32.800 --> 00:21:34.400
They can start to get spread out.

424
00:21:34.400 --> 00:21:37.000
The key thing to remember here
is that applications are not

425
00:21:37.000 --> 00:21:40.540
completely self-contained to that one
little icon in your applications folder.

426
00:21:40.540 --> 00:21:42.540
We do have data that's
stored in other places and

427
00:21:42.540 --> 00:21:45.040
that data does influence
the application every time it runs.

428
00:21:45.040 --> 00:21:47.360
>> All right, Don, well,
thank you again for

429
00:21:47.360 --> 00:21:50.350
helping to understand a little bit
more about the application data.

430
00:21:50.350 --> 00:21:54.010
We did take a look at those plists,
remember, don't modify them directly.

431
00:21:54.010 --> 00:21:55.840
Go into the applications themselves and

432
00:21:55.840 --> 00:21:58.300
look in the preferences,
modify them there.

433
00:21:58.300 --> 00:22:00.185
Also, if we need to build the log files,

434
00:22:00.185 --> 00:22:02.700
Don showed us how to be
able to do that as well.

435
00:22:02.700 --> 00:22:06.960
And then, of course, the launch services
where we can choose what particular

436
00:22:06.960 --> 00:22:11.530
application that we want to be able
to open whatever file that we're

437
00:22:11.530 --> 00:22:15.800
using at that point too, instead of just
whatever the default one that is there.

438
00:22:15.800 --> 00:22:18.530
Make sure you take a look at that
again as you go in for the exam.

439
00:22:18.530 --> 00:22:22.070
All right, well, that's a great place for
us to sign off as well.

440
00:22:22.070 --> 00:22:24.820
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

441
00:22:24.820 --> 00:22:25.900
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

442
00:22:25.900 --> 00:22:29.792
>> Stay tuned right here for more
Apple Certified Support Professional for

443
00:22:29.792 --> 00:22:30.629
macOS Sierra.

444
00:22:30.629 --> 00:22:36.585
[MUSIC]

445
00:22:36.585 --> 00:22:40.065
Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don continue with Application Data.  Here they take look at two built in features to make working with application data easier: The Quick Look and the Auto Save.  These two combined make it much easier to see the available data without having to open the data in a full blown applications with Quick Look.  Also we see how to setup and use the auto save feature as well.
episodes.title: Application Data Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.250 --> 00:00:01.349
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.349 --> 00:00:02.141
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.141 --> 00:00:06.414
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.414 --> 00:00:08.295
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.295 --> 00:00:10.059
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:10.059 --> 00:00:12.138
[MUSIC]

7
00:00:12.138 --> 00:00:14.196
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

8
00:00:14.196 --> 00:00:19.254
You're watching the Apple Certified
Support Professional for macOS Sierra.

9
00:00:19.254 --> 00:00:21.118
And I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

10
00:00:21.118 --> 00:00:24.820
Today, we're gonna be taking a look
at a part two on application data.

11
00:00:24.820 --> 00:00:27.550
Diving right back into it is gonna be Mr.
Don Pezet.

12
00:00:27.550 --> 00:00:28.501
Don, welcome back to the studios.

13
00:00:28.501 --> 00:00:29.682
>> And thanks for having me back, Ronnie.

14
00:00:29.682 --> 00:00:32.760
Ready to continue on with our
adventure on application data.

15
00:00:32.760 --> 00:00:37.430
In the last episode, we focused more
on the files that kind of support

16
00:00:37.430 --> 00:00:39.340
an application and
help an application run.

17
00:00:39.340 --> 00:00:42.868
In this episode, I wanna focus on
the documents that we create, or

18
00:00:42.868 --> 00:00:47.156
the files that we create, inside the
application that we actually use, right?

19
00:00:47.156 --> 00:00:47.972
Like Microsoft Word.

20
00:00:47.972 --> 00:00:50.620
I don't really care about Microsoft Word.

21
00:00:50.620 --> 00:00:54.060
What I care about is creating
a document that's in a format that

22
00:00:54.060 --> 00:00:55.330
other people can read.

23
00:00:55.330 --> 00:00:59.120
So it creates those .DOC documents and
most people can open those up.

24
00:00:59.120 --> 00:01:06.330
Or if I use Pixelmator or Adobe Photoshop,
I can create PNGs and GIF images.

25
00:01:06.330 --> 00:01:09.365
And I know those image formats can
be opened up wherever they are.

26
00:01:09.365 --> 00:01:12.076
So those files,
that's the actual product of our work and

27
00:01:12.076 --> 00:01:15.698
that's what's more important than
the program that we used to create them.

28
00:01:15.698 --> 00:01:18.265
So I wanna take a look at those files and

29
00:01:18.265 --> 00:01:21.490
have the operating system supports
those and works with them.

30
00:01:21.490 --> 00:01:24.250
And we'll see some interesting things
as we kinda mess around with it.

31
00:01:24.250 --> 00:01:27.200
What I wanna start with is
a feature called Quick Look.

32
00:01:28.480 --> 00:01:30.495
A lot of times, we get to sent documents.

33
00:01:30.495 --> 00:01:33.740
We get to sent files,
as an email attachment or whatever, and

34
00:01:33.740 --> 00:01:37.230
we might not necessarily have
the application that goes along with it.

35
00:01:37.230 --> 00:01:38.777
A great example of that are PDFs, right?

36
00:01:38.777 --> 00:01:41.544
Adobe portable document format, a PDF,

37
00:01:41.544 --> 00:01:46.930
is a file format that's supposed to be
a document that anybody can open, right?

38
00:01:46.930 --> 00:01:48.937
That is very easily supported.

39
00:01:48.937 --> 00:01:52.339
But if you don't have the Adobe Acrobat
Reader installed or a web browser that

40
00:01:52.339 --> 00:01:55.800
supports displaying it online,
then you might not be able to open those.

41
00:01:55.800 --> 00:01:59.130
So if somebody sends you that document,
what do you have to do?

42
00:01:59.130 --> 00:02:01.553
Well, you gotta go and
download a program to view it.

43
00:02:01.553 --> 00:02:05.150
Or if they send you a, well,
I'll use Pixelmator as an example.

44
00:02:05.150 --> 00:02:07.320
Pixelmator is a graphics editor.

45
00:02:07.320 --> 00:02:08.200
It's a great program.

46
00:02:08.200 --> 00:02:12.020
It takes forever to load even on the
fastest of computers, it has to load so

47
00:02:12.020 --> 00:02:14.490
many extensions and everything that
it just takes forever to load.

48
00:02:14.490 --> 00:02:16.700
So if I just wanna look at
a picture somebody sent me,

49
00:02:16.700 --> 00:02:20.050
I don't wanna open that in Pixelmator,
it'll take too long, right?

50
00:02:20.050 --> 00:02:22.780
So instead, I might just wanna
quickly view the document.

51
00:02:22.780 --> 00:02:25.762
Well, in Mac OS,
we have a feature called Quick Look.

52
00:02:25.762 --> 00:02:29.100
And Quick Look is designed to,
well, give you a quick look.

53
00:02:29.100 --> 00:02:31.980
I can look at something fast without
having to go into a full application.

54
00:02:31.980 --> 00:02:35.990
And two, it lets me look at files that I
don't necessarily have the application

55
00:02:35.990 --> 00:02:37.640
available for, right?

56
00:02:37.640 --> 00:02:40.882
So for example here, I'll go into my
little examples folder on my desktop.

57
00:02:40.882 --> 00:02:44.900
I've got a PDF in here somewhere,
it is right here.

58
00:02:44.900 --> 00:02:49.031
So this is the macOS Support Essentials
10.12 Exam Preparation Guide right off of

59
00:02:49.031 --> 00:02:50.400
Apple's website.

60
00:02:50.400 --> 00:02:52.020
So this is a PDF.

61
00:02:52.020 --> 00:02:55.419
And if I have Adobe Acrobat Reader
installed, I can open it up in there and

62
00:02:55.419 --> 00:02:56.605
I can view the document.

63
00:02:56.605 --> 00:02:58.893
But the reality is most web
browsers can open it too.

64
00:02:58.893 --> 00:03:03.110
So I should be able to open it up in
Google Chrome or Safari or whatever, and

65
00:03:03.110 --> 00:03:04.590
read it that way.

66
00:03:04.590 --> 00:03:08.400
But if I don't wanna go into one
of those full-blown programs,

67
00:03:08.400 --> 00:03:11.700
what I can do is just hit the space bar.

68
00:03:11.700 --> 00:03:16.040
If I hit the space bar,
it'll open that up in Quick Look.

69
00:03:16.040 --> 00:03:19.692
Quick Look, which some people call Preview
but the official title is Quick Look.

70
00:03:19.692 --> 00:03:24.100
People call it Preview, cuz a lot of times
you'll see like Open with Preview up here.

71
00:03:24.100 --> 00:03:26.320
Preview is technically a separate program.

72
00:03:26.320 --> 00:03:30.640
In Quick Look,
I'm getting a quick snapshot of that file.

73
00:03:30.640 --> 00:03:33.010
And I'm actually seeing the file.

74
00:03:33.010 --> 00:03:33.950
I see each page.

75
00:03:33.950 --> 00:03:35.230
I can navigate through.

76
00:03:35.230 --> 00:03:38.330
And likely,
this is everything I need, right?

77
00:03:38.330 --> 00:03:41.270
I'm able to look in here and
get the information that I want.

78
00:03:41.270 --> 00:03:44.008
I can even zoom in a little bit,
cuz really tiny.

79
00:03:44.008 --> 00:03:47.648
So I can look in here and
find the information that I'm looking for

80
00:03:47.648 --> 00:03:50.790
all without having to
launch some crazy program.

81
00:03:50.790 --> 00:03:53.372
And because it's part of the operating
system, it was very fast.

82
00:03:53.372 --> 00:03:56.710
I pressed space bar and I'm viewing it.

83
00:03:56.710 --> 00:04:00.390
Even just launching Acrobat Reader,
it takes longer than that, better yet

84
00:04:00.390 --> 00:04:02.440
opening the document that's inside of it.

85
00:04:02.440 --> 00:04:04.360
And you'll see that carries
over to other files.

86
00:04:04.360 --> 00:04:06.680
So for example, I've got Don's Term Paper,

87
00:04:06.680 --> 00:04:09.440
that was a text file we made in
one of the earlier episodes.

88
00:04:09.440 --> 00:04:11.640
If I just hit the space bar on that,
there it is.

89
00:04:11.640 --> 00:04:13.900
There's my preview that I can see and

90
00:04:13.900 --> 00:04:18.820
take a quick look at the contents of
that file and read what's inside of it.

91
00:04:18.820 --> 00:04:23.230
Now, Quick Look works thanks to a series
of extensions that are a part of macOS.

92
00:04:23.230 --> 00:04:25.870
And the operating system actually
ships with a handful of them, but

93
00:04:25.870 --> 00:04:27.610
you can get third party ones.

94
00:04:27.610 --> 00:04:29.830
When you install things
like Microsoft Office.

95
00:04:29.830 --> 00:04:33.030
Well, Microsoft Office will install
Quick Look extensions for it, so

96
00:04:33.030 --> 00:04:36.130
that you can look at PowerPoint slides and
Word documents and so

97
00:04:36.130 --> 00:04:37.610
on and actually view those.

98
00:04:37.610 --> 00:04:41.330
A lot of third parties have started
adopting these but not everyone.

99
00:04:41.330 --> 00:04:43.130
For example, I've got Markdown files.

100
00:04:43.130 --> 00:04:45.530
I do all my show notes in Markdown and

101
00:04:45.530 --> 00:04:48.550
I've got three different
Markdown programs on here.

102
00:04:48.550 --> 00:04:52.350
If I choose Open With,
I've got Sublime Text, Haroopad, Marked,

103
00:04:52.350 --> 00:04:53.866
and I use all three of them.

104
00:04:53.866 --> 00:04:57.780
None of them installed
the Quick Look extension.

105
00:04:57.780 --> 00:04:58.810
They just haven't written it.

106
00:04:58.810 --> 00:05:03.130
So if I choose my Markdown file and I hit
the space bar, I just get this, right?

107
00:05:03.130 --> 00:05:07.760
I get a big version of the icon,
which is useless, and then the file name.

108
00:05:07.760 --> 00:05:09.400
I don't get a preview of it.

109
00:05:09.400 --> 00:05:13.380
So you don't have Quick Look support for
every file format.

110
00:05:13.380 --> 00:05:14.312
But for the big ones, right?

111
00:05:14.312 --> 00:05:16.971
The PDFs, PNG, JPG, GIF, all those guys.

112
00:05:16.971 --> 00:05:20.710
You're gonna have support for those.

113
00:05:20.710 --> 00:05:21.473
A lot of them are baked in.

114
00:05:21.473 --> 00:05:24.223
Now, if you wanna get an idea
of what I'll support and

115
00:05:24.223 --> 00:05:27.586
you can take a look at where
the Quick Look extensions are stored,

116
00:05:27.586 --> 00:05:31.220
if you drop to your terminal,
there's a few different places.

117
00:05:31.220 --> 00:05:33.540
You could have Quick Look
extensions just for your user.

118
00:05:33.540 --> 00:05:34.593
We normally don't but you might.

119
00:05:34.593 --> 00:05:37.740
If you do,
they'll be in your own library folder.

120
00:05:37.740 --> 00:05:39.431
So I'm inside of my library.

121
00:05:39.431 --> 00:05:45.786
So /Users/dpezet/Library and you may have
a folder in there called Quick Look.

122
00:05:45.786 --> 00:05:46.540
I don't.

123
00:05:46.540 --> 00:05:49.400
That means, I don't have any third-party
extensions that have been added just for

124
00:05:49.400 --> 00:05:50.280
my account.

125
00:05:50.280 --> 00:05:52.680
But I probably have them for the system.

126
00:05:52.680 --> 00:05:54.820
So if I go to /Library, right?

127
00:05:54.820 --> 00:05:58.322
The global library,
not the one that's talking about user.

128
00:05:58.322 --> 00:06:03.280
If I go into /Library/QuickLook,
there we go.

129
00:06:03.280 --> 00:06:04.072
So now I'm in the QuickLook folder.

130
00:06:04.072 --> 00:06:05.430
And if I take a look, I can see.

131
00:06:05.430 --> 00:06:07.328
I've got iBooks and iWork.

132
00:06:07.328 --> 00:06:11.394
All right, well, iWork will actually let
me preview most Microsoft Office documents

133
00:06:11.394 --> 00:06:13.297
as well as the ones from the iWork suite.

134
00:06:13.297 --> 00:06:16.050
And iBooks will let me take
a look at a lot of EPUB and

135
00:06:16.050 --> 00:06:20.300
other type of documents that
we generate as part of iBooks.

136
00:06:20.300 --> 00:06:21.410
But that's it.

137
00:06:21.410 --> 00:06:23.225
I opened a PDF a minute ago.

138
00:06:23.225 --> 00:06:25.190
