00:17:13.890 --> 00:17:15.970
Don's Term Paper might have
a previous version, let's see.

371
00:17:16.980 --> 00:17:19.943
And so if I go to Revert To, shoot.

372
00:17:19.943 --> 00:17:22.260
Actually it does, yes.

373
00:17:22.260 --> 00:17:23.930
So if I choose that Revert To,
there it goes, and

374
00:17:23.930 --> 00:17:25.390
it's showing me my previous versions.

375
00:17:25.390 --> 00:17:27.750
See how it's really just
a Time Machine interface.

376
00:17:27.750 --> 00:17:30.970
And I can see where it's only got one
paragraph versus the three that I have now

377
00:17:31.980 --> 00:17:34.060
from the Quick Books stop.

378
00:17:34.060 --> 00:17:37.260
So that's how I know
auto-save is supported.

379
00:17:37.260 --> 00:17:41.420
The other thing is, remember when
I closed this application and

380
00:17:41.420 --> 00:17:43.860
it asked if I wanted to save and
I told it to save?

381
00:17:43.860 --> 00:17:46.810
It never did ask me for
file names, did it?

382
00:17:46.810 --> 00:17:49.080
It didn't actually save them
anywhere on the hard drive.

383
00:17:49.080 --> 00:17:51.920
It saved them as part of auto-save.

384
00:17:51.920 --> 00:17:54.650
So if I take this document here,
Document 3 and go to close it,

385
00:17:54.650 --> 00:17:57.130
see how it's asking me for a file name?

386
00:17:57.130 --> 00:17:58.560
But it did save it, right?

387
00:17:58.560 --> 00:18:04.452
Because when I quit out of TextEdit, all
of them went away, those files are gone.

388
00:18:04.452 --> 00:18:07.400
And then I launch TextEdit again,
and there they are.

389
00:18:07.400 --> 00:18:09.500
They have to be saved somewhere.

390
00:18:09.500 --> 00:18:11.360
That's auto-save, that's it doing it.

391
00:18:11.360 --> 00:18:14.900
So, it's a great feature to have, and
it's, just built right in, just have to

392
00:18:14.900 --> 00:18:17.990
get it turned on and configured properly,
and then it will work.

393
00:18:17.990 --> 00:18:19.350
That's a nice feature.

394
00:18:19.350 --> 00:18:20.710
This is what Apple Extra,

395
00:18:20.710 --> 00:18:24.690
call, Resume that you can resume
working right where you left off.

396
00:18:24.690 --> 00:18:28.170
Everything pops right back up and
there you go.

397
00:18:28.170 --> 00:18:30.220
Between auto-save and

398
00:18:30.220 --> 00:18:33.870
resuming these two little features
we have in our system configuration,

399
00:18:33.870 --> 00:18:37.930
we can really protect our information,
but not every application has it.

400
00:18:37.930 --> 00:18:40.119
For example, I use Sublime Text for
a lot of my stuff.

401
00:18:40.119 --> 00:18:44.300
And if I go into the File menu here,
notice how I don't have Rename.

402
00:18:44.300 --> 00:18:45.670
I don't have Duplicate.

403
00:18:45.670 --> 00:18:48.660
I don't have Previous Versions.

404
00:18:48.660 --> 00:18:49.700
All this stuff's missing.

405
00:18:49.700 --> 00:18:53.900
That's because the author of Sublime Text
has not added that functionality yet.

406
00:18:53.900 --> 00:18:54.900
So be aware that,

407
00:18:54.900 --> 00:18:58.180
and there's actually probably a number of
programs that I use that don't have it.

408
00:18:58.180 --> 00:19:01.884
Let me try good old Haroopad here.

409
00:19:01.884 --> 00:19:03.770
Yeah, Haroopad doesn't have it.

410
00:19:03.770 --> 00:19:07.210
So if your applications don't have it,
you don't get that protection.

411
00:19:07.210 --> 00:19:08.990
But they might have their
own built in thing, and

412
00:19:08.990 --> 00:19:10.478
there's several vendors that do that.

413
00:19:10.478 --> 00:19:13.680
So Sublime Text, it actually
does have its own built in one.

414
00:19:13.680 --> 00:19:19.356
So if I come in here and create a new
document and say this is a new document.

415
00:19:19.356 --> 00:19:21.280
And then I'm not gonna save it,
I'm just gonna quit.

416
00:19:22.350 --> 00:19:24.140
See how it didn't ask me to save or
anything?

417
00:19:24.140 --> 00:19:26.760
And then I can launch Sublime Text and
it takes me right back to it.

418
00:19:26.760 --> 00:19:30.230
They've written their own way
of preserving my documents.

419
00:19:30.230 --> 00:19:32.300
But it means I'm not
integrated with Time Machine.

420
00:19:32.300 --> 00:19:36.120
I can't quickly revert back to a previous
version, I'm missing that functionality.

421
00:19:36.120 --> 00:19:38.870
But this is a multi platform application,
so

422
00:19:38.870 --> 00:19:42.410
they support Windows and
Linux as well as Mac.

423
00:19:42.410 --> 00:19:46.900
And so
the auto-save feature is only in Mac OS.

424
00:19:46.900 --> 00:19:49.390
If they supported it, it wouldn't
work on the other platforms, so

425
00:19:49.390 --> 00:19:50.650
they wrote their own.

426
00:19:50.650 --> 00:19:54.740
But if you're using an application
that's specifically designed for Mac OS,

427
00:19:54.740 --> 00:19:57.240
it'll typically support it and
you'll have it.

428
00:19:57.240 --> 00:20:00.890
But just be aware there's two different
ways that vendors handle this.

429
00:20:00.890 --> 00:20:03.400
And you'd be surprised sometimes,
even the big shops, like Word,

430
00:20:03.400 --> 00:20:05.710
I don't think Microsoft supports it,
let's find out.

431
00:20:05.710 --> 00:20:08.870
So if I fire up Microsoft Word and
create a new document here.

432
00:20:10.300 --> 00:20:15.280
And I go up to my File Menu,
I can see up here, I do have a restore but

433
00:20:15.280 --> 00:20:17.820
see how it's View Version History Online?

434
00:20:17.820 --> 00:20:21.530
That's tied into Office365,
not tied into auto-save.

435
00:20:21.530 --> 00:20:24.240
And I don't have the Rename and Duplicate.

436
00:20:24.240 --> 00:20:29.964
First, if I fired up Pages, actually
I don't have Pages installed, do I?

437
00:20:29.964 --> 00:20:32.600
But if I were to fire up one of
the native Mac applications they have,

438
00:20:32.600 --> 00:20:35.110
cuz obviously Apple's kind of
bakes it into their own product.

439
00:20:35.110 --> 00:20:36.450
So definitely take a look.

440
00:20:36.450 --> 00:20:38.793
You might not have the support in
the applications that you use.

441
00:20:40.163 --> 00:20:43.070
All right, let's see,
what else did I have on my list?

442
00:20:43.070 --> 00:20:45.010
I feel like I'm forgetting something.

443
00:20:45.010 --> 00:20:48.790
But, running down the list,
looks like we've got it.

444
00:20:48.790 --> 00:20:51.060
Do be aware that sometimes,

445
00:20:51.060 --> 00:20:55.880
you'll be surprised how many
applications have QuickLook enabled.

446
00:20:55.880 --> 00:20:59.000
But sometimes, you'll be surprised,
there are application that don't have it.

447
00:20:59.000 --> 00:21:02.135
Sometimes there can be features inside of
a document that are more complex than what

448
00:21:02.135 --> 00:21:04.580
QuickLook can handle and
it render improperly.

449
00:21:04.580 --> 00:21:06.820
I see this with slide shows all the time.

450
00:21:06.820 --> 00:21:10.680
That in the preview for the slide show
it might be missing pie charts or

451
00:21:10.680 --> 00:21:11.630
other components.

452
00:21:11.630 --> 00:21:15.360
But then when you open
it up in PowerPoint or

453
00:21:15.360 --> 00:21:19.820
one of your presentation applications
that everything looks fine.

454
00:21:19.820 --> 00:21:22.010
So, don't always trust the QuickLook.

455
00:21:22.010 --> 00:21:24.290
It is designed for
just a quick glance to look and

456
00:21:24.290 --> 00:21:27.340
see what's in there, without the risk of
opening it in a full blown application.

457
00:21:28.580 --> 00:21:31.897
>> All right Don, well those
are very interesting features that

458
00:21:31.897 --> 00:21:34.785
are automatically there
inside of the OS by default.

459
00:21:34.785 --> 00:21:38.340
Remember to take a look at QuickLook,
it really is very interesting.

460
00:21:38.340 --> 00:21:38.940
Don, believe it or

461
00:21:38.940 --> 00:21:41.920
not, I've never actually used QuickLook
in the way that you showed me.

462
00:21:41.920 --> 00:21:43.310
All these years of using Mac.

463
00:21:43.310 --> 00:21:45.981
And it's weird,
I've always used the preview,

464
00:21:45.981 --> 00:21:48.343
the full-blown preview that they showed.

465
00:21:48.343 --> 00:21:51.803
But I never thought about using QuickLook,
cuz it wasn't really that important to me

466
00:21:51.803 --> 00:21:54.580
when I said, previews,
that's perfectly fine that'll work.

467
00:21:54.580 --> 00:21:56.955
>> That' super intuitive cuz you don't,
>> Hit the space bar.

468
00:21:56.955 --> 00:21:59.285
>> Right and usually the space bar,

469
00:21:59.285 --> 00:22:01.995
I was doing something that
would launch the actual finder.

470
00:22:01.995 --> 00:22:05.125
>> But overall though remember
to take a very neat feature,

471
00:22:05.125 --> 00:22:08.275
especially when you start going hey,
I don't have that program on.

472
00:22:08.275 --> 00:22:10.289
Try it.
See if it actually does work for you.

473
00:22:10.289 --> 00:22:13.085
It's a feature that users
will be interested in.

474
00:22:13.085 --> 00:22:14.545
And also the auto-save.

475
00:22:14.545 --> 00:22:17.530
>> Remember,
not as intuitive as it seems try it out,

476
00:22:17.530 --> 00:22:20.650
see some of the different features there,
verify that your apps can,

477
00:22:20.650 --> 00:22:24.300
either support it, or not, and then make
your decision based on that as well.

478
00:22:24.300 --> 00:22:28.155
But, that's a great place, also, for
us to sign off, then, for ITProTV.

479
00:22:28.155 --> 00:22:29.970
I've been your host, Ronnie Wong.

480
00:22:29.970 --> 00:22:30.920
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

481
00:22:30.920 --> 00:22:34.799
>> Stay tuned, right here, for more
Apple Certified Support Professional for

482
00:22:34.799 --> 00:22:35.462
Mac OS Sierra

483
00:22:35.462 --> 00:22:41.157
[MUSIC]

484
00:22:41.157 --> 00:22:43.180
Thank you for watching ITPro TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don take a look at application support in Mac OS 10.12 Sierra. They start by looking support for Java (both Apple's version and Oracle's version), and then address iCloud as an application framework.
episodes.title: Application Support
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:01.200 --> 00:00:04.060
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:04.060 --> 00:00:05.285
I'm your host.

3
00:00:05.285 --> 00:00:12.030
[CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.030 --> 00:00:12.718
>> All right.

5
00:00:12.718 --> 00:00:16.340
Greetings everyone and welcome to
another exciting episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:16.340 --> 00:00:17.955
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

7
00:00:17.955 --> 00:00:22.223
And in today's episode, we are coming back
at you with more on our ASP, right, ACSP,

8
00:00:22.223 --> 00:00:23.583
that's right, not ASPC.

9
00:00:23.583 --> 00:00:24.209
>> ASPCA?

10
00:00:24.209 --> 00:00:24.944
>> Yeah, ASCPA, that's right.

11
00:00:24.944 --> 00:00:26.780
>> [LAUGH]
>> With the eyes of an angel, right,

12
00:00:26.780 --> 00:00:29.330
we gotta take care of
our animals out there.

13
00:00:29.330 --> 00:00:32.990
But, no, this is the ACSP,
the Apple Certified Support Professional.

14
00:00:32.990 --> 00:00:35.711
And joining us in the studio again
to lend us expertise on the topic,

15
00:00:35.711 --> 00:00:37.330
our good friend Mr. Don Pezet.

16
00:00:37.330 --> 00:00:38.520
Don, welcome back man, how's it going?

17
00:00:38.520 --> 00:00:39.410
>> Thanks for having me back Daniel.

18
00:00:39.410 --> 00:00:41.770
Ready to dive right back
into application support.

19
00:00:41.770 --> 00:00:44.750
In the last couple of episodes,
we've been talking about installing apps,

20
00:00:44.750 --> 00:00:46.470
and where apps store their data.

21
00:00:46.470 --> 00:00:49.815
And, in this episode, we're gonna
talk about the stuff that didn't

22
00:00:49.815 --> 00:00:51.725
really quite fit in to the other episodes.

23
00:00:51.725 --> 00:00:53.775
>> [LAUGH]
>> The things that we need to know as

24
00:00:53.775 --> 00:00:56.515
support professionals to keep
applications up and running smooth.

25
00:00:56.515 --> 00:00:59.425
So it's kind of a mixed bag of
things we're gonna cover and

26
00:00:59.425 --> 00:01:01.115
it'll be more than what I
can fit in one episode.

27
00:01:01.115 --> 00:01:03.995
So we'll do a two parter or
three or four, who knows.

28
00:01:03.995 --> 00:01:06.655
We'll run the whole thing to make
sure we cover all the little odds and

29
00:01:06.655 --> 00:01:10.065
ends we need to keep our applications
up and running, happy and healthy.

30
00:01:10.065 --> 00:01:12.305
So that's what's on our
agenda right here today.

31
00:01:12.305 --> 00:01:16.030
>> All right Don, well when it comes
to application support, what better,

32
00:01:16.030 --> 00:01:18.830
where to start, right,
than good old Java, right?

33
00:01:18.830 --> 00:01:20.990
The Java.
[LAUGH] It's everywhere.

34
00:01:20.990 --> 00:01:22.360
It's very ubiquitous.

35
00:01:22.360 --> 00:01:23.900
I assume Apple also supports this.

36
00:01:23.900 --> 00:01:25.570
>> All right, let's talk about Java.

37
00:01:25.570 --> 00:01:29.870
So Java is unfortunately a necessary evil
on most computers that are out there.

38
00:01:29.870 --> 00:01:32.650
If you guys have watched my shows
in the past, it doesn't take

39
00:01:32.650 --> 00:01:35.690
too many of my episodes for
you to hear me despair Java at least once.

40
00:01:35.690 --> 00:01:38.100
>> [LAUGH] This is going to be like
a fifteen minute flogging, right?

41
00:01:38.100 --> 00:01:41.190
>> I know, I'm not a fan of
the product for a few reasons.

42
00:01:41.190 --> 00:01:45.110
But it actually does serve
a very important purpose and

43
00:01:45.110 --> 00:01:48.660
we actually can credit a lot
of the rise of Apple and

44
00:01:48.660 --> 00:01:50.950
the desktop space to having
things like Java available.

45
00:01:50.950 --> 00:01:53.730
See one of the challenges with
having a different operating system

46
00:01:53.730 --> 00:01:55.340
is getting applications to work, right?

47
00:01:55.340 --> 00:01:58.360
So if I'm a developer, and
I wanna write an application,

48
00:01:58.360 --> 00:02:00.330
I'm gonna look at where
the biggest market share is.

49
00:02:00.330 --> 00:02:02.100
And who's got the biggest market share?

50
00:02:02.100 --> 00:02:02.810
Microsoft.

51
00:02:02.810 --> 00:02:06.510
So I'll write a Windows app first, because
I know I can make a bunch of money.

52
00:02:06.510 --> 00:02:09.160
And I might not write
a Mac app until later.

53
00:02:09.160 --> 00:02:10.660
I might not write it at all, and

54
00:02:10.660 --> 00:02:13.790
that's very common to see applications
that are only available on Windows.

55
00:02:13.790 --> 00:02:15.560
And not available on Mac.

56
00:02:15.560 --> 00:02:19.560
And the challenge there is, for
an application to run natively on Mac OS,

57
00:02:19.560 --> 00:02:22.700
it has to support certain libraries,
it has to support the architecture.

58
00:02:22.700 --> 00:02:26.670
It's a different kernel that's
controlling everything under the hood

59
00:02:26.670 --> 00:02:29.000
than what you have in Windows,
so it takes a lot of work.

60
00:02:29.000 --> 00:02:32.750
And a lot of developers either don't have
the monetary resources, or just don't have

61
00:02:32.750 --> 00:02:35.890
the desire to put in that work to
create a Mac version of the product.

62
00:02:35.890 --> 00:02:37.980
Now that's not a generalization.

63
00:02:37.980 --> 00:02:41.060
There's plenty of developers out
there that create great products.

64
00:02:41.060 --> 00:02:45.730
Adobe is a great example of that where
Adobe makes Photoshop for macOS and

65
00:02:45.730 --> 00:02:46.480
Photoshop for Windows.

66
00:02:46.480 --> 00:02:49.520
And they're both great products
that work very well on their own.

67
00:02:49.520 --> 00:02:51.150
But if you're a smaller developer or

68
00:02:51.150 --> 00:02:54.030
you're developing a line of business
application, you might not wanna

69
00:02:54.030 --> 00:02:57.970
dedicate the resources developing on
macOS, so that's where Java fits in.

70
00:02:57.970 --> 00:03:00.990
What happened in a long
time twenty years ago now

71
00:03:00.990 --> 00:03:04.360
a company called Sun Microsystems
created the Java development language.

72
00:03:04.360 --> 00:03:07.910
And the way it works, is you have
what's called the Java engine and

73
00:03:07.910 --> 00:03:11.590
the Java Runtime Engine or
JRE, it runs on your computer.

74
00:03:11.590 --> 00:03:14.455
And they wrote a Java runtime
engine that would run on macOS,

75
00:03:14.455 --> 00:03:18.030
that would run on Windows, that would run
on Linux, that would run on darn, your

76
00:03:18.030 --> 00:03:23.440
every mobile phone on the planet that is
very, very versatile, there's one engine.

77
00:03:23.440 --> 00:03:25.270
So Sun Microsystems,

78
00:03:25.270 --> 00:03:28.980
they put in the work to make their engine
run on all these different platforms.

79
00:03:28.980 --> 00:03:35.210
And then all a developer has to do is if
they write their application in Java,

80
00:03:35.210 --> 00:03:37.530
It can run on the Java Runtime Engine.

81
00:03:37.530 --> 00:03:41.270
So the developer just
writes their app once, and

82
00:03:41.270 --> 00:03:44.860
then it can run on this engine that
runs on a number of different platforms.

83
00:03:44.860 --> 00:03:48.820
And that brought a lot of applications
over to macOS that didn't exist there

84
00:03:48.820 --> 00:03:51.950
before, applications that might
just be a Windows only thing.

85
00:03:51.950 --> 00:03:57.190
A developer can now write once,
run anywhere, that was the slogan of Java.

86
00:03:57.190 --> 00:04:00.985
Well, it sounds great but
I mentioned I don't like it.

87
00:04:00.985 --> 00:04:02.310
And one of the main
reasons I don't like it,

88
00:04:02.310 --> 00:04:06.300
is that,
after a long run where it ran really well.

89
00:04:06.300 --> 00:04:10.620
And almost every computer had Java
installed just as a de facto standard,

90
00:04:11.890 --> 00:04:13.610
a company called Oracle purchased them.

91
00:04:13.610 --> 00:04:16.640
And Oracle has not done a great
job of maintaining Java,

92
00:04:16.640 --> 00:04:18.410
and keeping it secure, and updated.

93
00:04:18.410 --> 00:04:19.570
And so it's a challenge.

94
00:04:19.570 --> 00:04:21.040
This is an attack vector.

95
00:04:21.040 --> 00:04:24.170
If somebody wants to write a virus,
or a Trojan, or

96
00:04:24.170 --> 00:04:28.140
whatever, they're usually gonna target
Windows, cuz it's the larger market share.

97
00:04:28.140 --> 00:04:31.910
But if they can target Java,
now they can hit Windows, Mac, Linux,

98
00:04:31.910 --> 00:04:33.070
they can hit all that other stuff, right?

99
00:04:33.070 --> 00:04:35.330
They can use that versatility against us.

100
00:04:35.330 --> 00:04:37.490
And it happens, it happens a lot.

101
00:04:37.490 --> 00:04:40.970
There are a lot of Java exploits
that are out there in the wild.

102
00:04:40.970 --> 00:04:42.800
So, we've gotta keep it up to date.

103
00:04:42.800 --> 00:04:46.900
Now, why am I bringing all of
this up in a Mac show, and

104
00:04:46.900 --> 00:04:48.590
in a applications support show?

105
00:04:48.590 --> 00:04:50.440
The reason is when you're
out there in the field, and

106
00:04:50.440 --> 00:04:55.160
you're deploying applications on Macs,
you may have some that require Java,

107
00:04:55.160 --> 00:04:56.810
that you need to have Java on your system.

108
00:04:56.810 --> 00:04:58.240
I've got some on my laptop right now.

109
00:04:58.240 --> 00:04:59.420
I don't like Java, but

110
00:04:59.420 --> 00:05:02.820
I've got it installed because I have
to have it to run certain applications.

111
00:05:02.820 --> 00:05:07.320
So in that scenario you've got
to install the Java framework.

112
00:05:07.320 --> 00:05:11.180
And you've got to get it put on

only other options we really have are to

501
00:22:27.161 --> 00:22:30.710
enable her and to show her in the menu
bar, which are both on by default.

502
00:22:30.710 --> 00:22:34.750
Well, let me clarify that, when you
initially install Mac OS it actually

503
00:22:34.750 --> 00:22:36.930
does give you a screen where
she is enabled by default.

504
00:22:36.930 --> 00:22:39.520
You have the option to turn
her off during the install.

505
00:22:39.520 --> 00:22:42.100
And you can always come back in here
turn her back on if you want, or

506
00:22:42.100 --> 00:22:45.060
if you don't want Siri on,
you can turn it off and there we go.

507
00:22:45.060 --> 00:22:48.160
There are some people out there
who are super paranoid and

508
00:22:48.160 --> 00:22:49.610
say I don't want my
computer listening to me.

509
00:22:49.610 --> 00:22:50.990
I want to turn that off.

510
00:22:50.990 --> 00:22:54.490
Well, if somebody is gonna go to
the trouble listening on your microphone,

511
00:22:54.490 --> 00:22:56.450
it's not gonna matter if you
check enable here, or not.

512
00:22:56.450 --> 00:22:57.710
>> Yeah.
>> Right, cuz they can turn that on.

513
00:22:57.710 --> 00:22:59.160
So, don't be paranoid,
if you're gonna use it,

514
00:22:59.160 --> 00:23:00.490
turn it on, if you're not gonna use it,
turn it off.

515
00:23:00.490 --> 00:23:02.460
But that's really about it.

516
00:23:02.460 --> 00:23:04.709
The paranoia shouldn't really
enter into that decision.

517
00:23:04.709 --> 00:23:07.919
But once it's there,
it's pretty easy to use and

518
00:23:07.919 --> 00:23:10.755
you can get some pretty interesting stuff.

519
00:23:10.755 --> 00:23:14.970
It depends on what you
consider interesting,

520
00:23:14.970 --> 00:23:18.868
you can say, Siri, what's the weather?

521
00:23:18.868 --> 00:23:21.010
>> I don't know where you are but
you can help me find out.

522
00:23:22.200 --> 00:23:26.050
In security and privacy settings,
choose the privacy tab.

523
00:23:26.050 --> 00:23:29.850
Under location services, check enable
location services and Siri and dictation.

524
00:23:31.320 --> 00:23:35.390
>> All right, so here's an example of
a Siri configuration I need to do.

525
00:23:35.390 --> 00:23:36.930
I asked her what the weather was.

526
00:23:36.930 --> 00:23:38.150
She doesn't know where I am, right?

527
00:23:38.150 --> 00:23:41.340
I don't have a GPS in the laptop,
so she can't find where I am.

528
00:23:41.340 --> 00:23:43.980
So I need to get that set up, so
she gave me the instructions.

529
00:23:43.980 --> 00:23:45.610
Here's where you need to go and
get that set up.

530
00:23:45.610 --> 00:23:46.400
Now notice.

531
00:23:46.400 --> 00:23:47.620
She didn't offer to set it up for me.

532
00:23:47.620 --> 00:23:48.877
She didn't say, hey Don,
what's your zip code?

533
00:23:48.877 --> 00:23:49.844
>> Yeah [LAUGH].

534
00:23:49.844 --> 00:23:52.560
>> She can't do that,
she's not that powerful yet.

535
00:23:52.560 --> 00:23:53.917
>> If you were more specific.

536
00:23:53.917 --> 00:23:56.220
You said what is the weather
in Gainesville, Florida,

537
00:23:56.220 --> 00:23:57.596
would she be able to answer that?

538
00:23:57.596 --> 00:24:00.116
>> I would hope so [LAUGH].

539
00:24:00.116 --> 00:24:02.028
What is the weather in Gainesville,
Florida?

540
00:24:03.480 --> 00:24:07.040
Okay, here's the weather for
Gainesville, Florida for today.

541
00:24:07.040 --> 00:24:07.944
>> There we go.

542
00:24:07.944 --> 00:24:12.767
And so not only do I get a auditory
response, I get that voice feedback, but

543
00:24:12.767 --> 00:24:15.613
I also get a visual
response of the weather.

544
00:24:15.613 --> 00:24:18.631
And it's important because she didn't
actually tell me what the weather

545
00:24:18.631 --> 00:24:19.740
was, did she?

546
00:24:19.740 --> 00:24:20.530
>> No she did not.

547
00:24:20.530 --> 00:24:22.352
>> No, I got the voice feedback,
and that's it.

548
00:24:22.352 --> 00:24:24.280
And then I get the visual response.

549
00:24:24.280 --> 00:24:28.700
So that's another example of where Siri
is not a replacement for accessibility,

550
00:24:28.700 --> 00:24:29.970
at least not yet.

551
00:24:29.970 --> 00:24:30.829
She's getting there.

552
00:24:30.829 --> 00:24:33.156
They're adding new stuff
to her all the time.

553
00:24:33.156 --> 00:24:34.720
Eventually, she will be there.

554
00:24:34.720 --> 00:24:37.010
But right now,
it's still two separate systems.

555
00:24:37.010 --> 00:24:40.920
So if you're wondering, why do we have
these two completely separate entities?

556
00:24:40.920 --> 00:24:44.060
It's because they really
do fit a different purpose.

557
00:24:44.060 --> 00:24:48.750
Siri is more of a novelty,
ease of use, type thing.

558
00:24:48.750 --> 00:24:50.530
I hate to call it a novelty,

559
00:24:50.530 --> 00:24:51.538
that's what it is, but-
>> [LAUGH]

560
00:24:51.538 --> 00:24:52.320
>> I hate to call it that because

561
00:24:52.320 --> 00:24:54.460
I know that one day it will
be extremely powerful, right?

562
00:24:54.460 --> 00:24:55.020
>> Right.
>> But

563
00:24:55.020 --> 00:24:58.278
right now it is mostly just
a convenience utility.

564
00:24:58.278 --> 00:25:02.950
Versus voice over and voice dictation,
where that's a necessity for

565
00:25:02.950 --> 00:25:03.690
a lot of people.

566
00:25:03.690 --> 00:25:06.910
So that tool's not messing around,
that's important stuff.

567
00:25:06.910 --> 00:25:11.720
So if you're having to support anyone
that needs voice functionality like this,

568
00:25:11.720 --> 00:25:15.900
anybody with a visual impairment or
just finds it easier to use this way,

569
00:25:15.900 --> 00:25:17.530
you need to familiarize
yourself with these tools.

570
00:25:17.530 --> 00:25:19.762
You will encounter them out
there in the real world and

571
00:25:19.762 --> 00:25:22.110
they are very important to people.

572
00:25:22.110 --> 00:25:25.160
So whether you think it's useful or
not doesn't matter.

573
00:25:25.160 --> 00:25:28.790
If they think it's useful you should do
whatever you can to make sure they get

574
00:25:28.790 --> 00:25:31.920
the best computer experience possible
when working with the computer.

575
00:25:31.920 --> 00:25:33.080
That's really what it's all about.

576
00:25:33.080 --> 00:25:35.520
>> Now Don going back to
issuing commands with Siri,

577
00:25:35.520 --> 00:25:39.350
am I able to say to Siri you know open
Finder and she'll open the Finder?

578
00:25:39.350 --> 00:25:41.570
Cuz like you asked her about the weather,
she said,

579
00:25:41.570 --> 00:25:44.060
here are some steps you can go through
if you let me know where you're at so

580
00:25:44.060 --> 00:25:46.420
that I can make sure that you get
the weather that you're looking for

581
00:25:46.420 --> 00:25:48.280
when you ask a more generalized question.

582
00:25:48.280 --> 00:25:51.250
But if I say, open Finder,
can she do that?

583
00:25:51.250 --> 00:25:52.710
>> It's a mixed bag what she can do and

584
00:25:52.710 --> 00:25:54.660
can't do, and sometimes you have
to experiment around with it.

585
00:25:54.660 --> 00:25:58.230
Apple has a posted list on their website
of the various commands she supports.

586
00:25:58.230 --> 00:26:02.231
Let me just try like [NOISE]
Launch activity monitor.

587
00:26:02.231 --> 00:26:04.911
[SOUND] There we go, right?

588
00:26:04.911 --> 00:26:07.165
So I told her to launch an application.

589
00:26:07.165 --> 00:26:09.324
She fired it up, and there we go.

590
00:26:09.324 --> 00:26:09.936
As your commands get more and

591
00:26:09.936 --> 00:26:11.170
more complex you run the risk
of starting to lose things.

592
00:26:11.170 --> 00:26:13.950
>> Right.

593
00:26:13.950 --> 00:26:20.434
>> [SOUND] Search for word documents.

594
00:26:20.434 --> 00:26:23.186
>> [SOUND] I found these documents.

595
00:26:23.186 --> 00:26:26.136
>> So here she returned some documents
that she found on the computer, and

596
00:26:26.136 --> 00:26:27.970
we can jump in, we can start to see these.

597
00:26:27.970 --> 00:26:30.260
That's the kind of functionality
that we have now, and

598
00:26:30.260 --> 00:26:32.800
over time we'll start to see
that increase and become better.

599
00:26:32.800 --> 00:26:35.870
But if I had told her to launch
the activity monitor, and then told her to

600
00:26:35.870 --> 00:26:39.790
change to the memory tab, well, she can't
actually interact with the application.

601
00:26:39.790 --> 00:26:42.034
She can launch it for me, but
then she can't interact with it.

602
00:26:42.034 --> 00:26:44.095
Not yet.
One day we'll see that, but

603
00:26:44.095 --> 00:26:45.820
that day is not today.

604
00:26:45.820 --> 00:26:50.190
>> All right, well Don, again, I know
that we have a bit more to go but, again,

605
00:26:50.190 --> 00:26:53.680
the time is not on our side for
this episode.

606
00:26:53.680 --> 00:26:55.765
So we'll have to come back for
a part three.

607
00:26:55.765 --> 00:26:57.480
>> [LAUGH]
>> And continue with more

608
00:26:57.480 --> 00:27:01.320
what can we do with the application
support inside of Sierra.

609
00:27:01.320 --> 00:27:03.232
So Don, I look forward to
seeing you in that episode.

610
00:27:03.232 --> 00:27:07.560
I look forward to seeing our lovely
guests as well, but as for this episode,

611
00:27:07.560 --> 00:27:09.242
looks like its time for us to sign off.

612
00:27:09.242 --> 00:27:11.560
For ITPRO.TV,
I have been your host Daniel Lowrie.

613
00:27:11.560 --> 00:27:12.480
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

614
00:27:12.480 --> 00:27:13.793
>> We'll see you next time.

615
00:27:13.793 --> 00:27:19.684
[MUSIC]

616
00:27:19.684 --> 00:27:23.125
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don continue to explore application support in Mac OS 10.12 Sierra. Here they discuss application improvements in Sierra, application sandboxing, application monitoring, and Diagnostic reporting and logging.
episodes.title: Application Support Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.290 --> 00:00:06.794
Welcome to ITPro.TV,
I'm your host Don [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.794 --> 00:00:08.485
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.485 --> 00:00:11.994
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

4
00:00:11.994 --> 00:00:12.654
>> All right,

5
00:00:12.654 --> 00:00:16.949
greetings everyone and welcome back
to another great episode of ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:16.949 --> 00:00:19.433
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and
in today's episode,

7
00:00:19.433 --> 00:00:22.620
we're back with more
Apple Certified Support Professional.

8
00:00:22.620 --> 00:00:27.009
And joining us in the studio, yet again,
for a part three on application support.

9
00:00:27.009 --> 00:00:28.730
Mr. Don Pezet, Don, welcome back, man.

10
00:00:28.730 --> 00:00:29.400
How's it going today?

11
00:00:29.400 --> 00:00:32.222
>> Thanks for having me, and who knew, how
difficult it was to support applications.

12
00:00:32.222 --> 00:00:33.374
>> [LAUGH]
>> Turns out-

13
00:00:33.374 --> 00:00:33.955
>> That's all you do.

14
00:00:33.955 --> 00:00:35.380
[LAUGH]
>> That's a lot of stuff,right,

15
00:00:35.380 --> 00:00:37.897
there's a lot of things to get
involved when running applications.

16
00:00:37.897 --> 00:00:40.188
So we're gonna continue looking
at here in this episode,

17
00:00:40.188 --> 00:00:42.680
it's not necessarily
the applications themselves.

18
00:00:42.680 --> 00:00:45.390
But all the stuff that we have to
do around them, to keep them up and

19
00:00:45.390 --> 00:00:47.600
running and happy and so on,

20
00:00:47.600 --> 00:00:50.140
which does include some interesting
things that we need to be aware of.

21
00:00:50.140 --> 00:00:52.710
So, we're going to continue running
with that school of thought.

22
00:00:52.710 --> 00:00:53.240
In this episode,

23
00:00:53.240 --> 00:00:57.442
we are going to take a look at 64-bit
applications which are pretty important.

24
00:00:57.442 --> 00:01:00.858
We're gonna talk a little bit about what
to do when applications go wrong, and

25
00:01:00.858 --> 00:01:02.795
we'll see how to force quit applications.

26
00:01:02.795 --> 00:01:04.942
And look at our diagnostic logs
to figure out what happened, and

27
00:01:04.942 --> 00:01:07.029
kinda troubleshoot problems
that we have with application.

28
00:01:07.029 --> 00:01:10.595
So all in all, pretty run of the mill for
a day in the life of an IT worker,

29
00:01:10.595 --> 00:01:12.979
right, if you're doing
Mac desktop support.

30
00:01:12.979 --> 00:01:16.265
>> Yeah, it is true, now,
Don we are talking about the latest and

31
00:01:16.265 --> 00:01:18.480
greatest of Mac operating systems.

32
00:01:18.480 --> 00:01:21.480
And usually, when a new operating
system comes out, they do that for

33
00:01:21.480 --> 00:01:22.130
reasons, right?

34
00:01:22.130 --> 00:01:26.420
They make a new OS for reasons, because
they've increased it's abilities, right?

35
00:01:26.420 --> 00:01:28.850
I would assume that's
with application support,

36
00:01:28.850 --> 00:01:32.460
that is no separate issue,
that there is new functionality there.

37
00:01:32.460 --> 00:01:36.550
>> Absolutely, about six years ago,
maybe seven years ago.

38
00:01:36.550 --> 00:01:39.820
Apple made the switch to being
a 64-bit operating system, so

39
00:01:39.820 --> 00:01:42.930
MacOS previously to that,
was a 32-bit operating system.

40
00:01:42.930 --> 00:01:46.930
And they switched to 64-bit, now,
what the heck does that mean?

41
00:01:46.930 --> 00:01:49.420
Well, when a computer addresses memory,
right?

42
00:01:49.420 --> 00:01:51.572
You've got RAM, inside of your computer,

43
00:01:51.572 --> 00:01:55.430
and, each little bit that gets stored
in RAM has to have an address.

44
00:01:55.430 --> 00:01:58.414
It's just like an address on a house,
and so, if I say,

45
00:01:58.414 --> 00:02:03.066
this is building number 7525, I know
that's different than building 7526.

46
00:02:03.066 --> 00:02:05.080
So, the number is how we identify it.

47
00:02:05.080 --> 00:02:10.044
And, in a 32-bit operating system,
you have 32-bits available for

48
00:02:10.044 --> 00:02:12.020
referencing memory.

49
00:02:12.020 --> 00:02:17.120
Well, a 32-bit number can only go
up to a certain amount, right?

50
00:02:17.120 --> 00:02:19.979
If we were to convert that
binary number into decimal,

51
00:02:19.979 --> 00:02:22.850
it's somewhere around 4.3 billion or
so, right?

52
00:02:22.850 --> 00:02:26.300
So, that's the maximum number
you can have on a 32-bit system.

53
00:02:26.300 --> 00:02:30.030
Well, when you're addressing your memory
that way, that means the maximum amount of

54
00:02:30.030 --> 00:02:35.680
memory you can address is four gigabytes,
sorry, so four gigabytes of memory.

55
00:02:35.680 --> 00:02:39.250
Well, we've had Macs with more than
four gigabytes for a long time,

56
00:02:39.250 --> 00:02:42.770
you can get some Mac Pros back in the day,
that eight or 16 gigabytes.

57
00:02:42.770 --> 00:02:47.198
So if the operating system can
handle more than 16 gigabytes,

58
00:02:47.198 --> 00:02:49.911
why do I care if it's 32-bit or not?

59
00:02:49.911 --> 00:02:52.130
Well, the problem came
with the applications.

60
00:02:52.130 --> 00:02:54.980
If your application was
a 32-bit application,

61
00:02:54.980 --> 00:02:58.780
it could only address
up to four gigs of RAM.

62
00:02:58.780 --> 00:03:02.821
Now for most people, that's way more
than they need, if you're firing up

63
00:03:02.821 --> 00:03:07.135
a web browser and in pages, iMovies and
you do a couple simple things like that.

64
00:03:07.135 --> 00:03:08.081
>> Or chrome, maybe.

65
00:03:08.081 --> 00:03:11.234
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, well, even chrome though,

66
00:03:11.234 --> 00:03:13.730
if you look at google chrome
which is a memory hog, right?

67
00:03:13.730 --> 00:03:16.378
Every tab runs it's own process, well,

68
00:03:16.378 --> 00:03:20.570
chrome as a whole might be
eating two gigs of RAM.

69
00:03:20.570 --> 00:03:23.990
Each tab is really eating
about 200 megs of RAM, and so,

70
00:03:23.990 --> 00:03:25.520
it can go really big because of that.

71
00:03:25.520 --> 00:03:28.910
Google did that on purpose,
it still eats way too much memory.

72
00:03:28.910 --> 00:03:32.778
But that's a challenge you can't
overcome in some applications, Google,

73
00:03:32.778 --> 00:03:34.095
they found a way, right?

74
00:03:34.095 --> 00:03:35.455
But I mentioned iMovie,

75
00:03:35.455 --> 00:03:39.225
iMovie's not the best example cuz
it relies on disc pretty heavily.

76
00:03:39.225 --> 00:03:41.295
Adobe Premiere is a great example.

77
00:03:41.295 --> 00:03:45.921
Where if I open up a two gigabyte
movie clip inside of Adobe Premier,

78
00:03:45.921 --> 00:03:47.633
do you know what it does?

79
00:03:47.633 --> 00:03:49.972
It caches it to ram, so it'll try and

80
00:03:49.972 --> 00:03:53.232
get as much of that video
clip into ram as possible.

81
00:03:53.232 --> 00:03:58.230
And if it's only two gigs, it can do that,
what if it's an eight gig video clip?

82
00:03:58.230 --> 00:04:00.837
It can't cache it in a RAM,
if it's a 32-bit application.

83
00:04:00.837 --> 00:04:04.470
It can cache 4 gigs of it into RAM,
the rest of it?

84
00:04:04.470 --> 00:04:08.540
It just can't cache it, it's got to read
from disk which means it's gonna be slow.

85
00:04:08.540 --> 00:04:11.700
So if you want an application
to be able to take advantage

86
00:04:11.700 --> 00:04:15.500
of more than four gigs of RAM,
it's got to be a 64-bit application.

87
00:04:15.500 --> 00:04:18.890
Now, back in the day, seven years ago.

88
00:04:18.890 --> 00:04:21.710
This was a big deal,
Apple release support for it,

89
00:04:21.710 --> 00:04:23.950
and then the developers had to catch up.

90
00:04:23.950 --> 00:04:27.150
The developers had to convert their apps
over to 64-bit, which believe it or not,

91
00:04:27.150 --> 00:04:28.539
it's actually not that hard at all.

92
00:04:28.539 --> 00:04:30.398
>> [LAUGH]
>> If you really, just go and

93
00:04:30.398 --> 00:04:33.486
recompile it, but you would be shock
that how many developers took years and

94
00:04:33.486 --> 00:04:35.940
years to finally make that
switch over to being 64-bit.

95
00:04:35.940 --> 00:04:39.180
And there's a reason for that,
but it's happened, right?

96
00:04:39.180 --> 00:04:42.351
It's happened a lot more quickly
in recent years, so that now,

97
00:04:42.351 --> 00:04:46.243
it's pretty uncommon that you find
an application that's still 32-bit.

98
00:04:46.243 --> 00:04:48.114
Most of them flipped over to 64-bit and

99
00:04:48.114 --> 00:04:51.020
they're able to address way
more than four gigs of RAM.

100
00:04:51.020 --> 00:04:55.160
And that's great because most
of your MacBooks this days,

101
00:04:55.160 --> 00:04:57.320
comes with 16 gigs of RAM.

102
00:04:57.320 --> 00:04:59.820
Well, if you're running five or
six different applications,

103
00:04:59.820 --> 00:05:02.030
they can all splice that up and
it's not a big deal.

104
00:05:02.030 --> 00:05:05.580
But if you have one app that you wanna
consume as much memory as possible,

105
00:05:05.580 --> 00:05:07.950
you'll want that application to be 64-bit.

106
00:05:07.950 --> 00:05:11.660
Now Adobe, they updated their
entire creative suite to 64-bit, so

107
00:05:11.660 --> 00:05:12.980
they all run that way.

108
00:05:12.980 --> 00:05:17.240
Apple updated all their applications,

our Internet connection is 200 megabit.

565
00:26:53.280 --> 00:26:57.810
So I might be able to handle 500
megabit of traffic here no problem, but

566
00:26:57.810 --> 00:26:58.480
not to the Internet.

567
00:26:58.480 --> 00:27:00.680
So I have a bottleneck,
the bottleneck is usually somewhere else.

568
00:27:00.680 --> 00:27:02.720
But if the bottleneck were here,
I could usually see it and

569
00:27:02.720 --> 00:27:06.020
figure out who it is that's
consuming most of the resources.

570
00:27:06.020 --> 00:27:10.120
I can see that I've got my network file
system manager here it's consuming

571
00:27:10.120 --> 00:27:11.310
a good bit.

572
00:27:11.310 --> 00:27:14.830
I've got a postgres database,
which I can't remember starting.

573
00:27:14.830 --> 00:27:16.410
So I need to find out
why I'm running that.,

574
00:27:16.410 --> 00:27:17.230
>> That's that malware

575
00:27:17.230 --> 00:27:17.963
running in the background.

576
00:27:17.963 --> 00:27:19.610
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] I have started some

577
00:27:19.610 --> 00:27:20.390
various things.

578
00:27:20.390 --> 00:27:24.560
I'm running the OS 10 server on my laptop,
and it has a postgres database in it.

579
00:27:24.560 --> 00:27:26.660
So I probably fired it up in
open directory or something and

580
00:27:26.660 --> 00:27:28.740
it's got kind of going
running in the background.

581
00:27:28.740 --> 00:27:32.990
But I can see it there and it's consuming
a very small amount of network you have.

582
00:27:32.990 --> 00:27:35.070
But it is consuming
the network resources and

583
00:27:35.070 --> 00:27:37.360
that there maybe something
that I need to look into.

584
00:27:37.360 --> 00:27:40.060
And the you'll see the other
things that are all consuming

585
00:27:40.060 --> 00:27:41.370
network resources as well.

586
00:27:41.370 --> 00:27:45.330
All right, now the activity
manner is not just for show.

587
00:27:45.330 --> 00:27:48.290
Right, I mean it certainly does the show
part pretty well like down here at

588
00:27:48.290 --> 00:27:49.750
the bottom you get some nice old grasp and

589
00:27:49.750 --> 00:27:53.250
you kind of see how your system is
doing at any given time and so on.

590
00:27:53.250 --> 00:27:54.980
That's nice right?

591
00:27:54.980 --> 00:27:57.580
But you can also take actions here.

592
00:27:57.580 --> 00:28:02.140
So say I get mad at Firefox, firefox is
frozen and it's just not responding, but

593
00:28:02.140 --> 00:28:04.860
here it is consuming all these
resources and now I'm frustrated.

594
00:28:04.860 --> 00:28:07.460
Well you can highlight any
application in here, and

595
00:28:07.460 --> 00:28:11.020
up top you'll see where you've
got this--- Stop sign with an X.

596
00:28:11.020 --> 00:28:13.230
You owe me to get the information
button too which is nice,

597
00:28:13.230 --> 00:28:15.510
you see some information
about that process.

598
00:28:15.510 --> 00:28:19.660
It shows you like files of that process
is holding open, apparently there's none.

599
00:28:19.660 --> 00:28:22.250
You get some other statistics and
memory, that's all cool but

600
00:28:22.250 --> 00:28:23.810
that really is just for show.

601
00:28:23.810 --> 00:28:27.350
But then I can choose the application and
I can hit the stop button.

602
00:28:27.350 --> 00:28:30.980
And that will do is called force quitting,
I force quit the application and

603
00:28:30.980 --> 00:28:31.510
terminate it.

604
00:28:31.510 --> 00:28:36.130
So that's kind of knock that out and let
me recover the memory and CPU and so on,

605
00:28:36.130 --> 00:28:37.170
that's consuming.

606
00:28:37.170 --> 00:28:40.560
Now, be careful, because sometimes
one application is linked to another.

607
00:28:40.560 --> 00:28:43.120
Like here,
the web content is linked to Firefox.

608
00:28:43.120 --> 00:28:46.400
So, when you kill one application,
it might kill others along with it.

609
00:28:46.400 --> 00:28:48.060
So, you always want to make
sure you're careful about that.

610
00:28:48.060 --> 00:28:51.760
If you kill something really critical,
it could break other things and

611
00:28:51.760 --> 00:28:54.390
now you need to reboot your computer
before you get it all straight again,

612
00:28:54.390 --> 00:28:55.958
which we usually want to avoid.

613
00:28:55.958 --> 00:28:59.350
All right, and if you highlight
something like Firefox and

614
00:28:59.350 --> 00:29:02.170
hit the Stop button,
it's just gonna say hey do you wanna Quit,

615
00:29:02.170 --> 00:29:05.770
which is a graceful quit, that would be
the same thing as if I went to Firefox,

616
00:29:05.770 --> 00:29:09.530
and went to the Firefox menu and
hit Quit, or clicked the little x.

617
00:29:09.530 --> 00:29:13.790
Or I could force quit, if it's frozen,
it's not gonna respond to a Quit, so

618
00:29:13.790 --> 00:29:14.820
I need to force quit it.

619
00:29:14.820 --> 00:29:18.040
This uses the Unix side of
things to kill the process.

620
00:29:18.040 --> 00:29:21.490
And when it kills it, it's gonna kill
that process and anything tied to it.

621
00:29:21.490 --> 00:29:23.360
So see how I killed Firefox?

622
00:29:23.360 --> 00:29:26.610
But the Firefox web content went with it,
right, they were tied together.

623
00:29:26.610 --> 00:29:31.040
It's gone and I just recovered the memory
and other resources that it was eating.

624
00:29:31.040 --> 00:29:33.390
And if you watch my little
CPU chart down here,

625
00:29:33.390 --> 00:29:37.900
you'll see it takes that dip
Which was me freeing up Firefox.

626
00:29:37.900 --> 00:29:40.400
Memory should have shown a bigger dip

627
00:29:40.400 --> 00:29:43.840
because Firefox was
consuming a gig of memory.

628
00:29:43.840 --> 00:29:46.720
It is kind of hard to see there,
the green line does dip

629
00:29:46.720 --> 00:29:49.920
down a bit there where it was terminated
and I freed up that giga memory.

630
00:29:51.530 --> 00:29:53.830
So, that's something we can do
from writing to false credit.

631
00:29:53.830 --> 00:29:57.910
There's other ways to force quit things
for example if it has a dark icon down

632
00:29:57.910 --> 00:30:00.620
here and it's running so
maybe I've got a clued iPad up and going.

633
00:30:02.730 --> 00:30:08.790
When you control click on an icon
here in the doc you'll see quit and

634
00:30:08.790 --> 00:30:10.240
gracefully quit out of it.

635
00:30:10.240 --> 00:30:14.430
And if you hold your option key see how
it changes from quit to force quit?

636
00:30:14.430 --> 00:30:20.220
So I can right click or control click on
the dock icon, hold option and choose

637
00:30:20.220 --> 00:30:23.280
force quit and that will do the same thing
as well I did for the activity monitors.

638
00:30:23.280 --> 00:30:26.450
That's another way to kind
of achieve the same goal.

639
00:30:26.450 --> 00:30:29.220
>> Now Don, I've worked on helpdesk for
many many years.

640
00:30:29.220 --> 00:30:31.850
One of my favorite things is
when a user calls and says.

641
00:30:31.850 --> 00:30:35.410
I had an error pop up and I clicked OK.

642
00:30:35.410 --> 00:30:36.290
Well, what did the error say?

643
00:30:36.290 --> 00:30:36.880
I don't know.
>> [LAUGH]

644
00:30:36.880 --> 00:30:38.200
>> But there's something wrong with

645
00:30:38.200 --> 00:30:39.170
my computer now.

646
00:30:39.170 --> 00:30:41.770
And then I have to go look at the logs.

647
00:30:41.770 --> 00:30:45.020
I assumed that MacBook also has
some sort of logging and reporting.

648
00:30:45.020 --> 00:30:47.980
Have to send this information to
Apple sometimes to try to get to

649
00:30:47.980 --> 00:30:48.635
the bottom of the issue.

650
00:30:48.635 --> 00:30:53.470
>> Absolutely, typically when
an application crashes, it tries to

651
00:30:53.470 --> 00:30:55.790
log some information to let you know what
happened because otherwise it crashes and

652
00:30:55.790 --> 00:30:57.335
you launch it back up and
everything's fine.

653
00:30:57.335 --> 00:30:59.000
>> Yeah.
>> How do you fix the problem?

654
00:30:59.000 --> 00:31:02.340
It's gone or maybe a problem happened over
night or maybe there's a problem happening

655
00:31:02.340 --> 00:31:04.650
right now and
you just don't even know about it, right?

656
00:31:04.650 --> 00:31:06.395
When you need to access
the logs in the system.

657
00:31:06.395 --> 00:31:09.600
And there's another utility which you
can get to by going to applications,

658
00:31:09.600 --> 00:31:12.140
and utilities, but
It's called the console.

659
00:31:12.140 --> 00:31:16.080
I usually launch it through the spotlight,
so if I launch Spotlight and

660
00:31:16.080 --> 00:31:19.410
type console,
it will launch the console application.

661
00:31:19.410 --> 00:31:24.400
What the console application lets us do,
is view the logs of our system and so

662
00:31:24.400 --> 00:31:27.730
when I click on the default is that
it's bring me up the full logs, but

663
00:31:27.730 --> 00:31:30.370
you see over here we can actually
kind of filter things a bit.

664
00:31:30.370 --> 00:31:33.920
You can look at the logs for your user
account, you can look at the logs for

665
00:31:33.920 --> 00:31:37.370
the system and you can look at
the logs for Unix under the hood.

666
00:31:37.370 --> 00:31:41.560
What I'm looking at here we have devices
chosen is actually all three of them in

667
00:31:41.560 --> 00:31:45.740
one place, I'm seeing the full logs which
can be a little overwhelming sometimes

668
00:31:45.740 --> 00:31:49.940
even just while I'm talking you'll see
log messages popping up here, right?

669
00:31:49.940 --> 00:31:53.530
Some kind of connections canceling and
being destroyed and whatever.

670
00:31:53.530 --> 00:31:58.004
Sounds really bad, but it isn't, it's just
normal stuff that's kinda running and

671
00:31:58.004 --> 00:31:58.947
doing its thing.

672
00:31:58.947 --> 00:32:02.879
This is parsecd, which is part
of a network service that I use.

673
00:32:02.879 --> 00:32:05.893
And it's just trying to connect to
a server and failing, right, and so

674
00:32:05.893 --> 00:32:07.714
it's just not Getting out to that server.

675
00:32:07.714 --> 00:32:10.351
You'll see other things,
though that might actually be serious.

676
00:32:10.351 --> 00:32:12.570
There might be problems
that we need to deal with.

677
00:32:12.570 --> 00:32:16.750
We've got some kind of security exception
here, but it's not telling me what it is.

678
00:32:16.750 --> 00:32:18.670
Sometimes, it's not terribly helpful,
right?

679
00:32:18.670 --> 00:32:20.990
And you can choose details, and maybe
you'll get a little more information, but

680
00:32:20.990 --> 00:32:24.410
here it's telling me I've got some kind
of security exception, which is more than

681
00:32:24.410 --> 00:32:27.820
likely an application tried to do
something it wasn't allowed to do.

682
00:32:27.820 --> 00:32:32.000
Like an application tried to access
something outside of its sandbox, and

683
00:32:32.000 --> 00:32:32.680
it was blocked, right?

684
00:32:32.680 --> 00:32:33.850
It was good that it was blocked, but

685
00:32:33.850 --> 00:32:35.910
it's not really giving me
any information to act on.

686
00:32:35.910 --> 00:32:39.120
So sometimes you can't act on this stuff,
but sometimes you can.

687
00:32:39.120 --> 00:32:42.585
If I'm having problems with Forklift,
I can come in here and

688
00:32:42.585 --> 00:32:46.315
I can search the logs and
I can just look for Forklift.

689
00:32:46.315 --> 00:32:49.945
And it'll scan through and show me any
logs that have the keyword forklift in it.

690
00:32:49.945 --> 00:32:51.575
And, well, apparently I don't have any.

691
00:32:51.575 --> 00:32:52.339
So maybe not a good example.

692
00:32:52.339 --> 00:32:53.635
>> Maybe Firefox.

693
00:32:53.635 --> 00:32:56.285
>> Yeah, you know, Firefox,
we did just crash that one.

694
00:32:56.285 --> 00:32:58.908
It's not turning up.

695
00:32:58.908 --> 00:32:59.605
It's not under Mozilla either.

696
00:32:59.605 --> 00:33:01.545
Sometimes the hardest part is-
>> What it is, yeah.

697
00:33:01.545 --> 00:33:02.825
>> Figuring out what
you need to search for.

698
00:33:02.825 --> 00:33:04.871
Yeah, so we can come through and
look for that.

699
00:33:04.871 --> 00:33:07.521
There's other things that you
can pull up in here too, though,

700
00:33:07.521 --> 00:33:10.480
like this straight up system log where
you see it kind of in a raw format.

701
00:33:10.480 --> 00:33:13.400
And if I don't know what I'm looking for,
this is where I normally come.

702
00:33:13.400 --> 00:33:16.397
You can go into the system log and
now you can kind of browse through and

703
00:33:16.397 --> 00:33:18.220
you see how you get
the giant wall of text.

704
00:33:18.220 --> 00:33:22.658
But it kind of helps you to spot what
you're looking for and a lot of times you

705
00:33:22.658 --> 00:33:27.382
can find things that have crashed or
generated an error message of some sought,

706
00:33:27.382 --> 00:33:30.630
and you can sort of figure
out what's going on.

707
00:33:30.630 --> 00:33:31.470
Looking through here,

708
00:33:31.470 --> 00:33:35.380
actually I see my Splashtop streamer
is throwing a bunch of messages.

709
00:33:35.380 --> 00:33:39.760
These aren't errors, they're just
messages that certain events happened

710
00:33:39.760 --> 00:33:42.820
that it took some action and
something happened.

711
00:33:42.820 --> 00:33:47.230
Here it's saying this end point has been
activated through Legacy Launch APIs.

712
00:33:47.230 --> 00:33:51.240
So the developments application has
imported something over to a newer API.

713
00:33:51.240 --> 00:33:54.466
The old API still works, this isn't
an error, but it's a message telling me,

714
00:33:54.466 --> 00:33:56.168
hey the future of this isn't gonna work.

715
00:33:56.168 --> 00:33:59.714
So if I'm the developer, I know, hey,
I need to go in, and update this,

716
00:33:59.714 --> 00:34:00.690
and fix it.

717
00:34:00.690 --> 00:34:03.710
So you can find things like that as
you dig through these reports, and

718
00:34:03.710 --> 00:34:05.710
each one is kind of filtered
in a different way.

719
00:34:05.710 --> 00:34:09.853
On the left side, if you look at
system reports or user reports,

720
00:34:09.853 --> 00:34:13.480
it's breaking things down
based on certain criteria.

721
00:34:13.480 --> 00:34:16.069
And so here it looks like I've had
a crash log under my user reports,

722
00:34:16.069 --> 00:34:18.030
something crashed,
let's figure out what it is.

723
00:34:19.830 --> 00:34:22.730
It says, it just says a plug in container.

724
00:34:22.730 --> 00:34:25.350
It's actually not telling me which
application it is that crashed,

725
00:34:25.350 --> 00:34:26.310
which is useful.

726
00:34:26.310 --> 00:34:28.820
If it doesn't tell you the application
a lot of times that means

727
00:34:28.820 --> 00:34:29.870
it's the operating system.

728
00:34:29.870 --> 00:34:33.020
But, no,
in this case it's a Firefox plugin.

729
00:34:33.020 --> 00:34:36.180
I can see right here I've got a path and
in the path it's

730
00:34:36.180 --> 00:34:40.324
/application/Firefox.app/Content MacOS
plugin-conatiner.

731
00:34:40.324 --> 00:34:44.707
And so if I keep drilling down here
I can figure out that it's the actual

732
00:34:44.707 --> 00:34:49.120
plugin container, the plugin
subsystem of Firefox is what crashed.

733
00:34:49.120 --> 00:34:52.280
Well, remember I booted it
in 32-bit mode a minute ago?

734
00:34:52.280 --> 00:34:56.490
This is probably when it started up in
32-bit mode and it didn't have a plugin,

735
00:34:56.490 --> 00:34:57.260
so it had to download them.

736
00:34:57.260 --> 00:35:00.230
So, it probably crashed, downloaded
then re-launched, but if it didn't,

737
00:35:00.230 --> 00:35:04.265
I could use this to start troubleshooting
and finding out what's going on.

738
00:35:04.265 --> 00:35:07.535
And actually it's telling me here
the code type is X86-64 (Native) so

739
00:35:07.535 --> 00:35:11.145
that means it was when I was running
64 bit mode that it crashed.

740
00:35:11.145 --> 00:35:15.035
So maybe this was after I launched it
back into 64 bit mode, after 32 bit mode.

741
00:35:15.035 --> 00:35:18.415
But you can find information here,
identify what crashed,

742
00:35:18.415 --> 00:35:20.445
what it was accessing when it crashed.

743
00:35:20.445 --> 00:35:23.380
And some of this information might not
mean anything to you, but if you're on

744
00:35:23.380 --> 00:35:26.820
the phone with Apple tech support they
might ask you to send them this log.

745
00:35:26.820 --> 00:35:28.790
And so you can send it over to them,
you can just copy and

746
00:35:28.790 --> 00:35:30.250
paste right here into an email.

747
00:35:30.250 --> 00:35:33.390
And send it over to them and it's
a great way to share that with them so

748
00:35:33.390 --> 00:35:36.890
they can view it and
get access to that information.

749
00:35:36.890 --> 00:35:40.620
>> Well Don, if you're working on any kind
of support capacity this is definitely

750
00:35:40.620 --> 00:35:44.410
some of the best information you can have
because you're probably gonna spend a lot

751
00:35:44.410 --> 00:35:47.440
of time in this area troubleshooting
issues with applications.

752
00:35:47.440 --> 00:35:49.568
Like we said, things that get hung up,
they're not working,

753
00:35:49.568 --> 00:35:50.930
you need to be able to quit them.

754
00:35:50.930 --> 00:35:52.470
What is it that is hung up?

755
00:35:52.470 --> 00:35:55.290
How much memory and
resources are being utilized?

756
00:35:55.290 --> 00:35:57.110
Maybe they're being over
utilized by something,

757
00:35:57.110 --> 00:35:59.060
we need to address those things.

758
00:35:59.060 --> 00:36:02.750
And then ultimately, if there's an error,
we can look into log system and

759
00:36:02.750 --> 00:36:05.510
get that information to
the correct person to help

760
00:36:05.510 --> 00:36:08.780
fix whatever is ailing
your poor Mac machine.

761
00:36:08.780 --> 00:36:09.420
Don, that make sense?

762
00:36:09.420 --> 00:36:12.236
Is there anything else we can add to
this episode before we close it down

763
00:36:12.236 --> 00:36:12.770
for the day?

764
00:36:12.770 --> 00:36:15.410
>> The only thing I can think of
is that there are a lot of filters

765
00:36:15.410 --> 00:36:16.640
in the console application.

766
00:36:16.640 --> 00:36:20.170
So do know that, if you navigate
in the menus there's a few things,

767
00:36:20.170 --> 00:36:23.340
one of my favorites is command to, that
if you hit that, it just shows errors and

768
00:36:23.340 --> 00:36:25.050
it takes out all
the informational messages.

769
00:36:25.050 --> 00:36:27.708
So there's ways you can filter,
to narrow that information down, and

770
00:36:27.708 --> 00:36:29.438
that's usually where it's gonna be useful,

771
00:36:29.438 --> 00:36:32.475
otherwise you just get overwhelmed by
the logs and then they become less useful.

772
00:36:32.475 --> 00:36:35.322
>> Yeah,
that's never a good time had by anyone.

773
00:36:35.322 --> 00:36:39.928
All right, Don, well thanks for helping us
get through application support inside of

774
00:36:39.928 --> 00:36:43.150
MAC OS Sierra or 10.1.2,
however you like it.

775
00:36:43.150 --> 00:36:45.120
But it does look like we
are out of time for today.

776
00:36:45.120 --> 00:36:47.990
We do appreciate our audience for
joining us as well.

777
00:36:47.990 --> 00:36:51.210
Hopefully you've learned a lot and
it's gonna enrich your lives and

778
00:36:51.210 --> 00:36:52.630
maybe even pass an exam.

779
00:36:52.630 --> 00:36:54.960
That being said, it is time for
us to sign out for ITPro.tv.

780
00:36:54.960 --> 00:36:57.000
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

781
00:36:57.000 --> 00:36:57.640
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

782
00:36:57.640 --> 00:36:59.321
>> And we'll see you next time.

783
00:36:59.321 --> 00:37:05.220

00:37:05.220 --> 00:37:08.734
Thank you for watching ITPRO TV.

463
00:21:05.482 --> 00:21:08.986
Instead of 4.3 billion,
we have this crazy,

464
00:21:08.986 --> 00:21:12.836
insane number that's actually
going off my screen.

465
00:21:12.836 --> 00:21:14.941
I can't even zoom out to get that.

466
00:21:14.941 --> 00:21:16.490
It just continues on.

467
00:21:16.490 --> 00:21:20.172
[LAUGH] It's a big, big number.

468
00:21:20.172 --> 00:21:25.586
And what it is is so many IP addresses.

469
00:21:25.586 --> 00:21:27.483
Basically, they said,
we're gonna pick addresses, so

470
00:21:27.483 --> 00:21:28.498
we never have to do this again.

471
00:21:28.498 --> 00:21:29.081
>> Yeah.

472
00:21:29.081 --> 00:21:32.503
[LAUGH]
>> We don't ever want to run out again.

473
00:21:32.503 --> 00:21:34.876
This number, it's actually got a name.

474
00:21:34.876 --> 00:21:36.538
It's 340 undecillion,

475
00:21:36.538 --> 00:21:40.215
which is some crazy number that
is meaningless to us as humans.

476
00:21:40.215 --> 00:21:43.806
So let's try and put this into
a format that we can understand.

477
00:21:43.806 --> 00:21:47.225
The Earth's population today
is a hair over six billion.

478
00:21:47.225 --> 00:21:49.526
So there's over six billion
people on the planet.

479
00:21:49.526 --> 00:21:55.413
Well remember, on our IPv4,
there were 4.3 billion addresses, right?

480
00:21:55.413 --> 00:21:56.160
So not enough.

481
00:21:56.160 --> 00:22:00.871
Under IPv6,
I could take the 6 billion people,

482
00:22:00.871 --> 00:22:04.133
and I could give every one of them.

483
00:22:04.133 --> 00:22:09.040
4.3 billion addresses and
we'd still have plenty left over.

484
00:22:09.040 --> 00:22:12.631
That's how big this address base is,
it's massive.

485
00:22:12.631 --> 00:22:14.800
That's what IPv6 gives us.

486
00:22:14.800 --> 00:22:16.418
That's the reason they're
moving towards it.

487
00:22:16.418 --> 00:22:20.209
Now IPv6 has a lot of other features
that are great that you'll want to take

488
00:22:20.209 --> 00:22:21.001
advantage of.

489
00:22:21.001 --> 00:22:25.400
But at the heart of it is addressing
IPv6 uses more addresses.

490
00:22:25.400 --> 00:22:26.531
>> It's actually 7 billion now.

491
00:22:26.531 --> 00:22:27.389
>> 7 billion?

492
00:22:27.389 --> 00:22:28.179
>> 7 billion.

493
00:22:28.179 --> 00:22:28.884
>> Very busy.

494
00:22:28.884 --> 00:22:33.913
[LAUGH] So a lot of people it's
not getting smaller right.

495
00:22:33.913 --> 00:22:40.124
We wanna launch people in the space yet,
so it is a problem and it solves it right.

496
00:22:40.124 --> 00:22:43.494
The only challenge that it creates for us
is that the addresses get really big and

497
00:22:43.494 --> 00:22:45.471
we can't even write them
in decimal anymore.

498
00:22:45.471 --> 00:22:47.161
Most of them are gonna be
written in hexadecimals.

499
00:22:47.161 --> 00:22:50.301
So here's an example this is the IPv6
address that my laptop has and

500
00:22:50.301 --> 00:22:54.396
you'll see where it's got letters in the
address It's usually hexadecimal, right?

501
00:22:54.396 --> 00:22:59.785
Normally, we use decimal, which is
every digit is a value 0-9, right?

502
00:22:59.785 --> 00:23:05.730
So I have like 1-9 and
then I have 10-99 and

503
00:23:05.730 --> 00:23:08.995
100-999, right?

504
00:23:08.995 --> 00:23:13.209
Each digit represents ten possible values,
zero to nine, yeah.

505
00:23:13.209 --> 00:23:17.833
In hexadecimal though,
it's zero through nine and

506
00:23:17.833 --> 00:23:22.360
then A through F for
a total of 16 values, right?

507
00:23:22.360 --> 00:23:26.923
So when I look at F,
That's actually the 16th value, right.

508
00:23:26.923 --> 00:23:30.915
But it starts at 0, so
it's zero through 15 really, so

509
00:23:30.915 --> 00:23:34.264
F would represent 15, 0 would represent 0.

510
00:23:34.264 --> 00:23:39.082
When I see something like A,
A represents 10 and B represents 11 and

511
00:23:39.082 --> 00:23:43.109
C represents 12 and
then it just goes up until you get to F.

512
00:23:43.109 --> 00:23:44.617
So they represent 16 values.

513
00:23:44.617 --> 00:23:49.484
and that means we can represent a much
larger address in a smaller space.

514
00:23:49.484 --> 00:23:51.259
So IPv6 addresses look funny, and

515
00:23:51.259 --> 00:23:55.296
that's kind of the way they're arranged
right there, as letters and numbers.

516
00:23:55.296 --> 00:23:59.930
They separate them with colons to indicate
the separations there to make it a little

517
00:23:59.930 --> 00:24:01.463
more human readable to us.

518
00:24:01.463 --> 00:24:05.003
Meanwhile in the background the computer
just converts it to binary,

519
00:24:05.003 --> 00:24:08.480
it's 128 1s and 0s which really
doesn't roll of the tongue.

520
00:24:08.480 --> 00:24:10.080
If 32 didn't, 128 absolutely doesn't.

521
00:24:10.080 --> 00:24:13.450
That's how the computer see's it though,
that's what's going on in the background.

522
00:24:14.765 --> 00:24:17.895
Now when I look at my network
configuration here, I just see IPv4.

523
00:24:17.895 --> 00:24:22.945
And that's because Apple knows most
of us are only using IPv4 right now.

524
00:24:22.945 --> 00:24:28.165
But IPv6 is enabled, if I go into my
Advanced settings here, and take a look,

525
00:24:28.165 --> 00:24:32.445
I can come in here and see IPv4,
and right beneath it I see IPv6.

526
00:24:32.445 --> 00:24:35.505
And it's set to Automatic,
I can change it to Manually, and

527
00:24:35.505 --> 00:24:39.820
I can punch in an IPv6 address and
router and so on to connect to.

528
00:24:39.820 --> 00:24:42.884
So we've got that IPv6 support,
it's turned on.

529
00:24:42.884 --> 00:24:48.552
If I, you can't really see it here,
but if I drop to my terminal and

530
00:24:48.552 --> 00:24:53.715
let me fire up a good old Unix
command here a little ifconfig,

531
00:24:53.715 --> 00:24:59.300
and take a look at my physical
interface which is en0, this guy.

532
00:24:59.300 --> 00:25:04.340
All right, so
here is my physical interface, and if take

533
00:25:04.340 --> 00:25:11.500
a look inside of it I'll see where I've
got a inet address and an inet6 address.

534
00:25:11.500 --> 00:25:19.030
inet that's the old IPv4 and then inet6
that's my IPv6 address right there.

535
00:25:19.030 --> 00:25:21.690
So I've actually got both, by default.

536
00:25:21.690 --> 00:25:22.530
So you are using both.

537
00:25:22.530 --> 00:25:24.970
And on the exam you need to be
familiar with both types of addresses.

538
00:25:24.970 --> 00:25:27.360
They're not going to ask you to
do anything crazy with them but

539
00:25:27.360 --> 00:25:30.170
just to understand the difference between
the two and know that when you're setting

540
00:25:30.170 --> 00:25:33.830
up a network connection, you'll need
to be aware of both network types.

541
00:25:33.830 --> 00:25:37.084
>> Now, Don, I'm looking at your
screen there, you also have another,

542
00:25:37.084 --> 00:25:39.703
what looks to be,
hex type of addressing going on there.

543
00:25:39.703 --> 00:25:40.295
What's going on there?

544
00:25:40.295 --> 00:25:43.747
>> Okay, so this one,
it's labeled here as an ether address, or

545
00:25:43.747 --> 00:25:46.140
ether depending on how you want to say it.

546
00:25:46.140 --> 00:25:47.810
But it's actually called a MAC address.

547
00:25:47.810 --> 00:25:52.425
And not Mac like Macintosh,
it stands for media access control.

548
00:25:52.425 --> 00:25:54.220
Every physical network adapter and

549
00:25:54.220 --> 00:25:56.770
every wireless network
adapter has a MAC address.

550
00:25:56.770 --> 00:26:01.000
And a MAC address will uniquely identify
your computer on a local network.

551
00:26:01.000 --> 00:26:02.010
It doesn't work on the Internet.

552
00:26:02.010 --> 00:26:03.560
It's not routable address.

553
00:26:03.560 --> 00:26:05.690
It's only on the local side.

554
00:26:05.690 --> 00:26:08.920
And it's a 48-bit hexadecimal number.

555
00:26:08.920 --> 00:26:13.160
So it's kinda like IPv6 except much
smaller, 48 bits instead of 128.

556
00:26:13.160 --> 00:26:17.190
And when they manufacturer your laptop or
desktop, when they manufacture the dongle

557
00:26:17.190 --> 00:26:22.010
that is your network adapter, they
will burn in this MAC address into it.

558
00:26:22.010 --> 00:26:23.540
And that identifies that adapter.

559
00:26:23.540 --> 00:26:25.850
If I were to pop this adapter off and
stick it onto your laptop,

560
00:26:25.850 --> 00:26:28.300
Daniel, you would have that same MAC.

561
00:26:28.300 --> 00:26:30.940
That media access control address
would follow over to your laptop.

562
00:26:30.940 --> 00:26:33.100
It is tied to the adapter.

563
00:26:33.100 --> 00:26:37.555
And that's how you find systems on your
own network, when you communicate.

564
00:26:37.555 --> 00:26:41.120
There's actually a whole process that
occurs, called address resolution, and

565
00:26:41.120 --> 00:26:43.610
you have
the Address Resolution Protocol or ARP.

566
00:26:43.610 --> 00:26:44.990
That when you ping somebody or

567
00:26:44.990 --> 00:26:48.260
talk to them, the first thing you
do is send out this broadcast to

568
00:26:48.260 --> 00:26:52.170
find out what their MAC address is and
you learn it and you talk to them,.

569
00:26:52.170 --> 00:26:54.410
Because it's broadcast driven,
it doesn't work in the Internet,

570
00:26:54.410 --> 00:26:57.540
it only works on a local network,
and that's what third address is.

571
00:26:57.540 --> 00:27:00.660
So, if you want to learn more about
this you don't necessarily need it for

572
00:27:00.660 --> 00:27:01.270
this exam.

573
00:27:01.270 --> 00:27:05.420
But just for your own use it
is really good stuff to learn.

574
00:27:05.420 --> 00:27:08.430
Take a look at our
CompTIA Network+ training.

575
00:27:08.430 --> 00:27:09.720
It's part of the ITProTV library.

576
00:27:09.720 --> 00:27:10.756
It's part of your subscription.

577
00:27:10.756 --> 00:27:11.407
Jump over and check it out.

578
00:27:11.407 --> 00:27:15.566
Because we go in-depth on how these MAC
addresses work, how IP addresses work,

579
00:27:15.566 --> 00:27:16.620
how they interact.

580
00:27:16.620 --> 00:27:18.150
You can learn all that
you want about them.

581
00:27:18.150 --> 00:27:20.195
There's a ton of information behind there.

582
00:27:20.195 --> 00:27:20.887
But on this exam,

583
00:27:20.887 --> 00:27:23.945
they really just want you to be able
to differentiate between IPv4 and IPv6.

584
00:27:23.945 --> 00:27:27.704
>> Alright, Don, a lot of interesting
things going on when it come to

585
00:27:27.704 --> 00:27:31.410
networks and networking,
how our computers talk to each other.

586
00:27:31.410 --> 00:27:34.610
And you've given us a great rundown
of how that is working inside of our

587
00:27:34.610 --> 00:27:37.990
Mac computers running Sierra
as the operating system.

588
00:27:37.990 --> 00:27:41.320
And, like Don said, if that has
whet your appetite on networking,

589
00:27:41.320 --> 00:27:45.090
man that's super interesting, definitely
jump over in our course library and

590
00:27:45.090 --> 00:27:47.980
check out that
CompTIA Network Plus series.

591
00:27:47.980 --> 00:27:49.090
Very, very good stuff there.

592
00:27:49.090 --> 00:27:51.370
That being said, Don, looks like
we're out of time in this episode.

593
00:27:51.370 --> 00:27:55.190
We do thank you for joining us and
lending your knowledge to us as well.

594
00:27:55.190 --> 00:27:57.100
We do thank our audience for watching.

595
00:27:57.100 --> 00:28:00.080
Again, I always hope that you
guys get a lot out of these

596
00:28:00.080 --> 00:28:01.815
series that we create for you guys.

597
00:28:01.815 --> 00:28:03.150
But we are out of time for today.

598
00:28:03.150 --> 00:28:04.700
We do thank you for joining us, again.

599
00:28:04.700 --> 00:28:07.810
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

600
00:28:07.810 --> 00:28:08.610
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

601
00:28:08.610 --> 00:28:09.600
>> We'll see you next time.

602

>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:02.677
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don- [CROSSTALK]

2

>> You're watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:11.376 --> 00:00:13.735
>> All right, greetings everyone, and

4
00:00:13.735 --> 00:00:16.618
welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:16.618 --> 00:00:19.547
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode, well,

6
00:00:19.547 --> 00:00:22.216
we are continuing on with more
of our ACSP series, right.

7
00:00:22.216 --> 00:00:25.965
The Apple Certified Support Professional,
that's right, hey, I got it right.

8
00:00:25.965 --> 00:00:27.322
>> [LAUGH]
>> Joining us in the studio,

9
00:00:27.322 --> 00:00:28.900
our good friend, Mr. Don Pezet.

10
00:00:28.900 --> 00:00:30.720
Don, welcome back, man,
how's it going today?

11
00:00:30.720 --> 00:00:34.260
>> It is going swell, ready to continue
on with configuring networking.

12
00:00:34.260 --> 00:00:36.330
In the last episode we
talked about networking and

13
00:00:36.330 --> 00:00:40.140
how a Mac interacts with the network,
which is pretty important to us.

14
00:00:40.140 --> 00:00:43.590
And we ran through some basic settings,
we really didn't configure a whole lot.

15
00:00:43.590 --> 00:00:46.330
In fact, we really kind of
focused on the preference

16
00:00:46.330 --> 00:00:48.550
order of the interfaces
that are on the system.

17
00:00:48.550 --> 00:00:50.440
So in this episode I
want to double back and

18
00:00:50.440 --> 00:00:54.210
take a look a bit at the configuration,
actually getting ourselves set up.

19
00:00:54.210 --> 00:00:58.015
And what we'll find is that a lot of
networks these days are configured to make

20
00:00:58.015 --> 00:01:02.620
this as easy as possible where
we plug in and it just works.

21
00:01:02.620 --> 00:01:03.690
Old Mac slogan, right.

22
00:01:03.690 --> 00:01:08.050
But there are times where we can't go
automatic, where we actually do need to

23
00:01:08.050 --> 00:01:10.092
get involved in the configuration
that connects us to the network.

24
00:01:10.092 --> 00:01:12.610
And so that's what we're gonna
be taking a look at as we rattle

25
00:01:12.610 --> 00:01:13.830
through our topics today.

26
00:01:13.830 --> 00:01:14.440
>> All right, well, Don,

27
00:01:14.440 --> 00:01:18.560
we kind of touched on IP communications
in our previous episode.

28
00:01:18.560 --> 00:01:21.840
Maybe we can give a little bit
of a refresher on that and

29
00:01:21.840 --> 00:01:23.430
maybe even a little more
depth to it as well.

30
00:01:23.430 --> 00:01:27.360
>> Absolutely, so one of the things that I
mentioned very briefly in the last episode

31
00:01:27.360 --> 00:01:31.300
was static IP addressing and
dynamic IP addressing.

32
00:01:31.300 --> 00:01:34.680
But I didn't really go into detail, so
let's revisit that and take a look at it.

33
00:01:34.680 --> 00:01:37.362
I'm gonna show you guys
here on my laptop before,

34
00:01:37.362 --> 00:01:39.410
it'll be easier to kinda see as we work.

35
00:01:39.410 --> 00:01:43.940
But if I go into my System Preferences,
and I go into my network and

36
00:01:43.940 --> 00:01:45.570
I pull up one of my network interfaces.

37
00:01:45.570 --> 00:01:49.020
Now I've got two but
you usually have at least one.

38
00:01:49.020 --> 00:01:50.530
So I'm gonna pull up one
of my interfaces and

39
00:01:50.530 --> 00:01:54.510
I'll stick with my physical Ethernet
connection just for right now.

40
00:01:54.510 --> 00:01:57.810
Because on wi-fi we bring in a whole
second layer of complexity with

41
00:01:57.810 --> 00:01:59.310
the wireless network itself.

42
00:01:59.310 --> 00:02:02.400
With a physical connection, we just
plug in and we're ready to go, right?

43
00:02:02.400 --> 00:02:06.476
So on the physical side, you'll see
right here on the main screen where it's

44
00:02:06.476 --> 00:02:08.682
asking me to configure my IPv4 address.

45
00:02:08.682 --> 00:02:12.401
Which I said before is the most
common type of addressing used in

46
00:02:12.401 --> 00:02:14.240
the entire world.

47
00:02:14.240 --> 00:02:17.240
Now mine is set to be manual.

48
00:02:17.240 --> 00:02:20.020
I have manually assigned an address.

49
00:02:20.020 --> 00:02:24.560
Now in the official IP terminology,
that's called a static assignment.

50
00:02:24.560 --> 00:02:29.540
Static means I've manually bound
a particular IP address to this laptop.

51
00:02:29.540 --> 00:02:33.700
The reason I did that Is because I wanted
my laptop to have the same address

52
00:02:33.700 --> 00:02:35.020
every single day.

53
00:02:35.020 --> 00:02:36.580
Every day that I come into this office,

54
00:02:36.580 --> 00:02:40.490
every day that I work on my computers,
I want them to have the same address.

55
00:02:40.490 --> 00:02:42.790
If you're running any kind of server,

56
00:02:42.790 --> 00:02:45.050
you don't want your
server's address to change.

57
00:02:45.050 --> 00:02:46.280
You want it to always be the same, and

58
00:02:46.280 --> 00:02:49.350
you'll normally manually assign them,
all right?

59
00:02:49.350 --> 00:02:53.180
But manual assignment is not
always the best thing, right?

60
00:02:53.180 --> 00:02:54.920
Because of two main problems.

61
00:02:54.920 --> 00:02:58.180
Problem number one, every time a new
computer comes to your network,

62
00:02:58.180 --> 00:03:00.290
you've got to go and
manually assign an address to it.

63
00:03:00.290 --> 00:03:03.780
So anytime somebody brings an iPad,
or an iPhone, a new laptop,

64
00:03:03.780 --> 00:03:07.900
a computer, a printer, you've got to
go and manually assign an address.

65
00:03:07.900 --> 00:03:08.980
It's frustrating.

66
00:03:08.980 --> 00:03:12.090
And then two,
it opens you up to human error.

67
00:03:12.090 --> 00:03:14.710
When you type in an address,
when you type in a subnet mask,

68
00:03:14.710 --> 00:03:18.660
when you type in these things you can make
a typo and put something in incorrectly.

69
00:03:18.660 --> 00:03:21.590
And when you do that,
now it's not going to work, right.

70
00:03:21.590 --> 00:03:25.800
Worse, you could even pick an IP address
that's already in use by somebody else,

71
00:03:25.800 --> 00:03:29.410
and now you've got a duplicate address,
and that causes a lot of problems.

72
00:03:29.410 --> 00:03:32.540
What really happens is one of those
two devices is not gonna be able to

73
00:03:32.540 --> 00:03:33.520
communicate right.

74
00:03:33.520 --> 00:03:37.010
And the other device is gonna be receiving
information it shouldn't be receiving.

75
00:03:37.010 --> 00:03:38.380
Either scenario is bad, right?

76
00:03:38.380 --> 00:03:40.240
Neither one is something that we want.

77
00:03:40.240 --> 00:03:42.680
So those are challenges
with manual assignment.

78
00:03:42.680 --> 00:03:46.590
It's still the best option
when you've got a server.

79
00:03:46.590 --> 00:03:51.470
But on a mobile device, on a laptop, on
a desktop, even on devices where we don't

80
00:03:51.470 --> 00:03:54.760
really care about what address they have,
there's another option.

81
00:03:54.760 --> 00:04:00.000
And if we drop that list down, you'll see
where we can choose, Use DHCP, all right.

82
00:04:00.000 --> 00:04:04.910
DHCP is
the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol.

83
00:04:04.910 --> 00:04:09.710
And what it's designed is so
that when a new phone or tablet or

84
00:04:09.710 --> 00:04:13.090
laptop comes in on your network
it talks to the network.

Well, anybody who's on the same network as
