it's still there too.

534
00:26:14.310 --> 00:26:16.189
And so I can do a lookup for itpro.tv, but

535
00:26:16.189 --> 00:26:18.411
you'll see it shows
a little less information.

536
00:26:18.411 --> 00:26:23.002
There's a way to increase its robusity and
see more, but dig does it automatically,

537
00:26:23.002 --> 00:26:25.891
so I normally use dig for
doing these kind of lookups.

538
00:26:25.891 --> 00:26:28.090
All right, let's see what else to know.

539
00:26:28.090 --> 00:26:30.420
I wanna mention here before
we wrap this one up.

540
00:26:30.420 --> 00:26:35.010
A couple of other things that we need to
be aware of is there are advanced settings

541
00:26:35.010 --> 00:26:36.970
tied to a lot of these network adaptors?

542
00:26:36.970 --> 00:26:41.210
If I go back into my System Preferences,
and I go back into Network,

543
00:26:41.210 --> 00:26:44.870
when we take a look at something
like an Ethernet connection, right?

544
00:26:44.870 --> 00:26:48.910
I saw where I had router,
gateway, and so on.

545
00:26:48.910 --> 00:26:51.860
But if we go back into advanced,
there was a lot more in here.

546
00:26:51.860 --> 00:26:54.740
Right, I have been talking about DNS,
but what are these other tabs?

547
00:26:54.740 --> 00:26:56.644
So let's run through these real quick,

548
00:26:56.644 --> 00:27:00.120
I didn't get to wireless we will have
to do that in part three, I guess.

549
00:27:00.120 --> 00:27:03.110
Let me at least hit these here,
and we will wrap this episode up.

550
00:27:03.110 --> 00:27:05.967
The first tab was setting the address,
IPv4 and

551
00:27:05.967 --> 00:27:09.600
IPv6, the second tab is setting DNS,
so we talked about those.

552
00:27:09.600 --> 00:27:12.705
The third tab is 802.1x.

553
00:27:12.705 --> 00:27:15.909
And 802.1x is a network
authentication mechanism, right?

554
00:27:15.909 --> 00:27:20.454
If I have a secure facility, and maybe one
day we move somebody's desk to a different

555
00:27:20.454 --> 00:27:25.630
location in their office, and now there's
an exposed network jack on the wall.

556
00:27:25.630 --> 00:27:27.580
Anybody could come along with a laptop and

557
00:27:27.580 --> 00:27:30.690
plug into that network jack in the wall
and now they're on my network, right?

558
00:27:30.690 --> 00:27:32.064
Not if we use Ava 2.1X.

559
00:27:32.064 --> 00:27:37.441
With Ava 2.1X, you issue a certificate to
every approved device on your network.

560
00:27:37.441 --> 00:27:40.439
And the certificate resides as
part of the Operating System.

561
00:27:40.439 --> 00:27:44.300
And if an unauthorized laptop comes in and
they plug into a wall jack,

562
00:27:44.300 --> 00:27:48.910
if they don't have a certificate, it
doesn't even let them talk on the network.

563
00:27:48.910 --> 00:27:51.810
They can't get DHCP address,
they can't communicate, they're

564
00:27:51.810 --> 00:27:56.030
completely blocked off from the network,
it's a great way of securing things.

565
00:27:56.030 --> 00:27:58.334
Most networks don't do this at home,
you definitely don't do this.

566
00:27:58.334 --> 00:28:01.331
But if you work for
the government, the military,

567
00:28:01.331 --> 00:28:05.460
anywhere that handles sensitive data,
they may well leverage this.

568
00:28:05.460 --> 00:28:07.688
And if they do,
you'll need to come in here and

569
00:28:07.688 --> 00:28:10.558
load an 802.1x certificate
to be used by the network.

570
00:28:10.558 --> 00:28:12.865
Once it's installed,
you'll see the certificates over here, and

571
00:28:12.865 --> 00:28:14.430
you can choose them.

572
00:28:14.430 --> 00:28:16.320
And that's what's going to
authenticate your laptop or

573
00:28:16.320 --> 00:28:18.290
desktop to be able to
communicate on the network.

574
00:28:19.330 --> 00:28:20.840
We have proxys.

575
00:28:20.840 --> 00:28:24.260
Not every network allows you
direct access to the internet.

576
00:28:24.260 --> 00:28:26.780
Instead, you might be required
to talk to a proxy sever.

577
00:28:26.780 --> 00:28:29.250
A proxy server is like a middle man.

578
00:28:29.250 --> 00:28:32.614
Instead of going to a router you go
to this proxy server, and you say,

579
00:28:32.614 --> 00:28:35.878
can you give me a copy of CNN.com,
or give me a copy of apple.com?

580
00:28:35.878 --> 00:28:38.808
And instead if letting
you go to apple.com,

581
00:28:38.808 --> 00:28:40.975
the proxy server does it for you.

582
00:28:40.975 --> 00:28:43.988
It reaches out to Apple, gets a copy of
the web page and then presents it to you,

583
00:28:43.988 --> 00:28:45.400
it says, here it is.

584
00:28:45.400 --> 00:28:48.220
You never actually went on the Internet.

585
00:28:48.220 --> 00:28:51.120
Now there's two nice benefits for that.

586
00:28:51.120 --> 00:28:53.890
One, you can protect people from attacks,
right?

587
00:28:53.890 --> 00:28:58.220
Their computers are not actually exposed
to the Internet, only the proxy is.

588
00:28:58.220 --> 00:29:01.870
So if I secure the proxy, I don't have
to worry about attackers coming in and

589
00:29:01.870 --> 00:29:03.160
getting into the internal systems.

590
00:29:03.160 --> 00:29:05.210
I just have one place to protect,
that's a good thing.

591
00:29:05.210 --> 00:29:08.677
The other thing is, we can enforce
draconian content filtering, right?

592
00:29:08.677 --> 00:29:11.083
We can say, I don't want you to go to CNN.

593
00:29:11.083 --> 00:29:15.771
We can control that, or you can even
manipulate content before you deliver it.

594
00:29:15.771 --> 00:29:19.735
So you have a big presidential election or
something you could actually have fake

595
00:29:19.735 --> 00:29:22.778
results, or there's [ [INAUDIBLE]
pranks you can do with it.

596
00:29:22.778 --> 00:29:26.310
But on a serious note, you can use it for
things like content filtering.

597
00:29:26.310 --> 00:29:29.810
Like blocking adult websites,
gambling and other things.

598
00:29:29.810 --> 00:29:33.200
So you can define different proxies
right here if your laptop or

599
00:29:33.200 --> 00:29:36.890
desktop needs to go through a proxy
to gain access to the internet.

600
00:29:36.890 --> 00:29:38.050
You configure that, right here.

601
00:29:38.050 --> 00:29:39.820
>> Don't forget the caching feature,
that's always nice for

602
00:29:39.820 --> 00:29:41.450
people with slower networks.

603
00:29:41.450 --> 00:29:44.820
>> Yeah, if there's 50 people all
trying to go to CNN's webpage.

604
00:29:44.820 --> 00:29:47.200
The proxy server can cache it
the first time that it gets it,

605
00:29:47.200 --> 00:29:49.830
and the other 49 people all
get a local copy super fast.

606
00:29:49.830 --> 00:29:51.370
>> Yeah.
>> Right, so that's pretty handy.

607
00:29:51.370 --> 00:29:52.860
Not so good on dynamic webpages.

608
00:29:52.860 --> 00:29:54.620
You know if you're watching
a sports scoreboard,

609
00:29:54.620 --> 00:29:56.095
you don't wanna cache the scoreboard.

610
00:29:56.095 --> 00:29:56.790
>> [LAUGH]
>> But for

611
00:29:56.790 --> 00:29:58.270
a lot of things it works out really well.

612
00:29:58.270 --> 00:30:00.598
And then the last tab is the hardware tab.

613
00:30:00.598 --> 00:30:03.250
You're not typically going
to change things here.

614
00:30:03.250 --> 00:30:06.620
But this is where we can see our media
access control address, our MAC address,

615
00:30:06.620 --> 00:30:08.800
that's burned in so we can't modify that.

616
00:30:08.800 --> 00:30:13.970
And then you see a few other things,
like your speed, duplex and MTU.

617
00:30:13.970 --> 00:30:17.410
Speed is how fast your network adapter's
able to go, what its bandwidth is, right?

618
00:30:17.410 --> 00:30:19.290
Most networks these days are gigabit, but

619
00:30:19.290 --> 00:30:22.870
there are 100 megabit and 10 megabit
networks that are still out there.

620
00:30:22.870 --> 00:30:24.670
There are 10 gigabit networks, and so

621
00:30:24.670 --> 00:30:27.820
you'll see your options right
here as far as what you support.

622
00:30:27.820 --> 00:30:31.600
By default, you usually want this to
be automatic, it'll autoselect, and

623
00:30:31.600 --> 00:30:33.750
it'll go as fast as the network supports.

624
00:30:33.750 --> 00:30:35.240
That's typically what we want.

625
00:30:35.240 --> 00:30:36.650
Then you got duplex.

626
00:30:36.650 --> 00:30:42.420
Duplex is whether you can send, and
receive data at the same time, or not.

627
00:30:42.420 --> 00:30:45.240
If you're full duplex, you can send and
receive at the same time.

628
00:30:45.240 --> 00:30:48.005
If you're half duplex,
you could only send or receive.

629
00:30:48.005 --> 00:30:51.063
Well, a gigabit adaptor
requires full-duplex.

630
00:30:51.063 --> 00:30:53.311
But if I drop this down to 100 megabit,

631
00:30:53.311 --> 00:30:57.330
now I'll start to see where I've
got half-duplex as an option.

632
00:30:57.330 --> 00:31:00.760
Where I can only send or receive, which is
slow, that's the old way of doings things.

633
00:31:00.760 --> 00:31:02.910
So again,
we don't necessarily wanna do that.

634
00:31:02.910 --> 00:31:05.280
And then you'll see
the Maximum Transmission Unit, or MTU.

635
00:31:05.280 --> 00:31:08.610
When you send data on the network
it gets broken up into frames.

636
00:31:08.610 --> 00:31:10.014
And there's a maximum size of that frame,

637
00:31:10.014 --> 00:31:12.006
because if a frame get's
corrupted we gotta retransmit it.

638
00:31:12.006 --> 00:31:15.920
See you don't want to be too big,
and so the typical average is 1500.

639
00:31:15.920 --> 00:31:18.750
And that's what Apple sets to,
that's what Microsoft sets to and

640
00:31:18.750 --> 00:31:19.800
several of the other vendors.

641
00:31:19.800 --> 00:31:21.630
But you can tweak it if you need to,
there's custom ones.

642
00:31:21.630 --> 00:31:23.551
You'll see jumbo frames,
which are great for

643
00:31:23.551 --> 00:31:25.480
ISCSI networks you can go up to 9,000,.

644
00:31:25.480 --> 00:31:29.170
You can actually go even higher than that,
but your switches need to support it.

645
00:31:29.170 --> 00:31:30.790
Your network adaptors needs to support it,
and

646
00:31:30.790 --> 00:31:32.160
your Operating System needs to support it.

647
00:31:32.160 --> 00:31:35.140
>> I think you just inadvertently
made a Dragon Ball Z reference.

648
00:31:35.140 --> 00:31:37.040
>> It goes up to 9,000, or
it's over 9,000 [INAUDIBLE].

649
00:31:37.040 --> 00:31:39.140
>> Never seen Dragon Ball Z,
so I don't know.

650
00:31:39.140 --> 00:31:41.497
>> DBZ fans out there-
>> [LAUGH] Are cracking up right now,

651
00:31:41.497 --> 00:31:43.269
they're going he just
said it's over 9,000.

652
00:31:43.269 --> 00:31:44.450
>> [LAUGH] It's over 9,000.

653
00:31:44.450 --> 00:31:45.160
>> There you go.

654
00:31:45.160 --> 00:31:45.850
Sweet.

655
00:31:45.850 --> 00:31:47.265
I know it makes your hair spiky.

656
00:31:47.265 --> 00:31:47.950
>> It does do that.

657
00:31:47.950 --> 00:31:49.380
>> So there we go [LAUGH].

658
00:31:49.380 --> 00:31:51.372
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right, okay, so

659
00:31:51.372 --> 00:31:54.170
that's basically the advanced options for
a network adapter.

660
00:31:54.170 --> 00:31:56.720
I didn't get to wireless but
we'll get to that in the next episode.

661
00:31:56.720 --> 00:31:59.670
It's definitely an important thing we
see wireless more and more these days.

662
00:31:59.670 --> 00:32:02.820
But hopefully you have a good idea of
the configuration options right there for

663
00:32:02.820 --> 00:32:04.410
a standard network adapter.

664
00:32:04.410 --> 00:32:05.850
>> Excellent stuff Don, thanks for

665
00:32:05.850 --> 00:32:09.718
getting us thus far on our network
configurations inside of Mac OS.

666
00:32:09.718 --> 00:32:13.160
Very multifaceted, there's a lot of
different areas in which we have to be

667
00:32:13.160 --> 00:32:17.260
aware of to make networking efficient, and
working, and doing things we need to do.

668
00:32:17.260 --> 00:32:20.140
And if trouble shooting ever comes
into play, well now you have

669
00:32:20.140 --> 00:32:24.750
a better idea where you might need to go,
depending on the issue that you're having.

670
00:32:24.750 --> 00:32:27.840
So Don, we do look forward to finishing
this up, hopefully in part three.

671
00:32:27.840 --> 00:32:29.930
We got a little wireless to go through.

672
00:32:29.930 --> 00:32:30.830
>> [LAUGH]
>> Hopefully we'll see you

673
00:32:30.830 --> 00:32:32.250
guys there on that one as well.

674
00:32:32.250 --> 00:32:34.570
But as for this episode,
looks like we've come to the end.

675
00:32:34.570 --> 00:32:35.660
Thanks for joining us.

676
00:32:35.660 --> 00:32:38.320
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie.

677
00:32:38.320 --> 00:32:39.220
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

678
00:32:39.220 --> 00:32:39.921
>> We'll see you next time.

00:32:46.247 --> 00:32:49.234
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

14

15

>> It is going swell.

16
00:00:36.065 --> 00:00:38.015
Ready to dive right back into networking,
and

17
00:00:38.015 --> 00:00:40.965
we're actually gonna focus in on
something that's really important

18
00:00:40.965 --> 00:00:44.323
because in the first two episodes I've
been using a physical network adapter.

19
00:00:44.323 --> 00:00:47.600
But that is becoming less and less common.

20
00:00:47.600 --> 00:00:51.980
Wireless networks have really
significantly improved from what they

21
00:00:51.980 --> 00:00:57.380
originally were back in 1999 and

22
00:00:57.380 --> 00:01:00.730
that we've had 17 years of

23
00:01:00.730 --> 00:01:02.470
And, boy, has it come a long way.

24
00:01:02.470 --> 00:01:07.645
So much so, that many networks have

25
00:01:07.645 --> 00:01:09.280
And for a home network,

26
00:01:09.280 --> 00:01:11.580
we used to run cable through
the walls all the time at home.

27
00:01:11.580 --> 00:01:13.940
Now, wireless is suitable for most people.

28
00:01:13.940 --> 00:01:15.570
So, it's really come a long way.

29
00:01:15.570 --> 00:01:16.475
For mobile devices,

30
00:01:16.475 --> 00:01:19.810
it's a necessity because you don't have
the physical network jacks on them.

31
00:01:19.810 --> 00:01:22.780
So we need to understand how to get
a wireless network configured, and some of

32
00:01:22.780 --> 00:01:25.180
the different options that are available
that we might need to tweak with.

33
00:01:25.180 --> 00:01:25.750
>> That's right, and

34
00:01:25.750 --> 00:01:29.050
wireless is super convenient,
that's why we like it so much, right?

35
00:01:29.050 --> 00:01:30.460
We're not tethered to one spot.

36
00:01:30.460 --> 00:01:33.290
Like Don said, we used to have to run
wires through the walls in our house.

37
00:01:33.290 --> 00:01:38.000
And if you've ever worked a fishtape to do
that, you know the hell of which I speak.

38
00:01:38.000 --> 00:01:39.870
That's not a fun, fun time.

39
00:01:39.870 --> 00:01:43.365
So wireless has us at convenience,
but it's interesting.

40
00:01:43.365 --> 00:01:45.360
Sometimes you get people and
they call you up and

41
00:01:45.360 --> 00:01:49.380
say I can't connect to the wireless,
what the heck is going on?

42
00:01:49.380 --> 00:01:50.830
This is supposed to just work for
me, right?

43
00:01:50.830 --> 00:01:52.134
It's a Mac product, too, though.

44
00:01:52.134 --> 00:01:55.178
Everything just works,
why is this just not working?

45
00:01:55.178 --> 00:01:57.330
So, we have to understand
how it does work so

46
00:01:57.330 --> 00:01:58.500
we can troubleshoot those issues, right?

47
00:01:58.500 --> 00:02:00.735
>> Absolutely.
>> So, Don, where do we begin with that?

48
00:02:00.735 --> 00:02:05.315
All right, well, first off, every Mac
sold today has a wireless card in it.

49
00:02:05.315 --> 00:02:08.865
Every iMac, Macpro,
Macbookpro, it doesn't matter.

50
00:02:08.865 --> 00:02:12.485
Even if it's a desktop like the iMac Pro,
they have wireless built into them.

51
00:02:12.485 --> 00:02:14.395
The Mac mini has wireless built into it.

52
00:02:14.395 --> 00:02:15.025
So they've all got it.

53
00:02:16.255 --> 00:02:19.365
We might turn it off and not use it,
but they do have it, all right?

54
00:02:19.365 --> 00:02:22.495
And it's easy to see if you do because
you'll have right here in your menu bar up

55
00:02:22.495 --> 00:02:25.550
at the top of your screen,
you'll have a little wireless symbol.

56
00:02:25.550 --> 00:02:28.375
And you may not be connected to anything,
but it will be there, right?

57
00:02:28.375 --> 00:02:30.930
And so, when I clicked on mine,
while it was looking for

58
00:02:30.930 --> 00:02:33.710
a network for a brief moment
there to populate the list, but

59
00:02:33.710 --> 00:02:37.860
otherwise it shows that I am
connected to the ITProTV network.

60
00:02:37.860 --> 00:02:41.004
And I can turn wireless off if I
don't want to use it, all right?

61
00:02:41.004 --> 00:02:42.836
If I turn it off, well, it just drops.

62
00:02:42.836 --> 00:02:45.490
The network should turn the antennas off,
right?

63
00:02:45.490 --> 00:02:47.330
There are antennas for
your wireless adapter.

64
00:02:47.330 --> 00:02:49.940
Here on my laptop,
if you ever disassemble one of these,

65
00:02:49.940 --> 00:02:54.930
it's kinda neat because the wireless
antennas actually run through the display,

66
00:02:54.930 --> 00:02:56.700
they run up the sides of the display.

67
00:02:56.700 --> 00:02:58.540
Cuz that's a big,
nice open area they can get.

68
00:02:58.540 --> 00:03:00.240
And they know the display
will be pointing straight up,

69
00:03:00.240 --> 00:03:01.850
which is perfect for an antenna.

70
00:03:01.850 --> 00:03:02.800
So they'll run them that way.

71
00:03:02.800 --> 00:03:07.570
Same thing in the iMacs where the antennas
run along the edge of the monitors.

72
00:03:07.570 --> 00:03:10.320
The Mac Pro, I actually don't know
where their stuck in the trash can,

73
00:03:10.320 --> 00:03:12.670
you know that round cylindrical Mac Pro.

74
00:03:12.670 --> 00:03:14.830
I'm not sure where its antennas are.

75
00:03:14.830 --> 00:03:18.430
But basically, it's turning antennas on or
turning them off.

76
00:03:18.430 --> 00:03:20.460
When you turn the antennas off,

00:27:41.591 --> 00:27:46.149
So when I go in here and

00:27:46.149 --> 00:27:48.620

00:28:02.760 --> 00:28:05.320

So it's reaching out over the Internet and

00:28:09.580 --> 00:28:13.340

Now, technically I'm about to connect

00:28:17.290 --> 00:28:19.473
>> It's going to be an interesting day.

00:28:19.473 --> 00:28:21.953
>> Yeah, I think it's actually
gonna disconnect me, but

00:28:21.953 --> 00:28:24.077
we'll give it a shot and
see what happens here.

00:28:24.077 --> 00:28:29.044
So let me go ahead and connect,

00:28:29.044 --> 00:28:32.170
I put in my iCloud credentials.

I actually have a different

00:28:45.460 --> 00:28:46.920
I've just put in the wrong thing.

00:28:46.920 --> 00:28:47.950

00:28:53.240 --> 00:28:58.420

>> Yeah,

I don't see that.

00:29:20.180 --> 00:29:23.490

00:29:23.490 --> 00:29:27.150

00:29:27.150 --> 00:29:31.870

00:29:31.870 --> 00:29:33.885
So, it's like help me to help you, right?

00:29:33.885 --> 00:29:37.920
[LAUGH] Don, is there anything

00:29:37.920 --> 00:29:40.040

00:29:40.040 --> 00:29:42.280

00:29:42.280 --> 00:29:46.000

00:29:47.510 --> 00:29:51.650
>> So if you only own one Mac, Back to

>> Not really, yeah.
So it's really designed for

00:29:56.009 --> 00:29:58.957
Find my Mac, on the other hand, that's

00:30:01.922 --> 00:30:02.882

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don cover Shared Resources in Mac OS 10.12. Watch as they demonstrate using Apple Remote Desktop(ARD) to remotely manage and update Sierra client on the network. They also show how ARD can be used to replace screen sharing for centralized management. Finally, they describe troubleshooting shared resources.

24

35

00:01:48.570 --> 00:01:50.680

00:01:50.680 --> 00:01:52.760

gonna use on a regular basis.

48
00:01:52.760 --> 00:01:54.690
>> All right Don we're
following you with this,

definitely where you think of sharing, we

00:02:18.706 --> 00:02:20.490

00:02:44.080 --> 00:02:45.970
These are all different
things that we can share.

00:02:45.970 --> 00:02:50.200
And there is even some others that

now

00:21:51.850 --> 00:21:55.290
I'm going out my wireless instead
of going out my physical adapter.

461
00:21:55.290 --> 00:21:57.360
And you can figure out
how that's communicating.

462
00:21:57.360 --> 00:21:59.330
Discovery might not be working properly,
but

463
00:21:59.330 --> 00:22:01.350
it turns out your using the wrong network.

464
00:22:01.350 --> 00:22:03.250
It makes sense you wouldn't be
able to do the discovery, right?

465
00:22:03.250 --> 00:22:05.640
So some of the other tools
are things like Ping.

466
00:22:05.640 --> 00:22:10.220
Ping is an incredibly useful
tool because you can use it to,

467
00:22:10.220 --> 00:22:12.670
I call it troubleshooting
from the inside out.

468
00:22:12.670 --> 00:22:16.562
If there's a problem between me and
Daniel's laptop, all right?

469
00:22:16.562 --> 00:22:18.430
Well, I need to figure out
where that problem is.

470
00:22:18.430 --> 00:22:19.470
It could be his laptop.

471
00:22:19.470 --> 00:22:20.370
It could be my laptop.

472
00:22:20.370 --> 00:22:22.540
It could be the network in between us,
right?

473
00:22:22.540 --> 00:22:24.320
So what I'll usually do
is I'll ask Daniel, hey,

474
00:22:24.320 --> 00:22:26.420
Daniel can you tell me
what your IP address is?

475
00:22:26.420 --> 00:22:29.680
And he can go into the network utility and
it'll tell him the IP address.

476
00:22:29.680 --> 00:22:31.527
I'll just use the IP address
to one of my servers here.

477
00:22:31.527 --> 00:22:35.822
So I'm on this machine,
which is 192.168.0.129, and

478
00:22:35.822 --> 00:22:41.850
if I'm trying to talk to a server at
192.168.0.11, why can't I get there?

479
00:22:41.850 --> 00:22:43.920
Well, let's figure out
where the problem is.

480
00:22:43.920 --> 00:22:44.940
I'll start by pinging myself.

481
00:22:44.940 --> 00:22:47.470
Now when you ping yourself,
there's two ways to do it.

482
00:22:47.470 --> 00:22:52.060
You can use the loopback,
which is a virtual address, 127.0.0.1.

483
00:22:52.060 --> 00:22:54.460
That's testing the software.

484
00:22:54.460 --> 00:22:56.770
Is my TCP/IP stack working?

485
00:22:56.770 --> 00:23:01.100
And so if I do that and I ping,
you should always get responses here.

486
00:23:01.100 --> 00:23:03.775
If you don't, it means your
operating system is damaged and

487
00:23:03.775 --> 00:23:06.980
you'll need to go into recovery and
reinstall MacOS.

488
00:23:06.980 --> 00:23:10.090
So it's a lot of hassle,
you don't want to do that.

489
00:23:10.090 --> 00:23:11.320
So hopefully that will work.

490
00:23:11.320 --> 00:23:14.320
Then, you can try to ping your own IP,
right?

491
00:23:14.320 --> 00:23:18.590
So this one is 192.168.0.129,
so I'll go in and ping that.

492
00:23:18.590 --> 00:23:23.160
And when I do that, if this fails, that
usually means either I've got to duplicate

493
00:23:23.160 --> 00:23:25.700
IP address or
there's something wrong with my link.

494
00:23:25.700 --> 00:23:28.970
I might not have a link light on my
Network Adapter, that kind of a problem.

495
00:23:30.000 --> 00:23:34.010
After that, if I'm going through a router,
I can ping the router.

496
00:23:34.010 --> 00:23:36.920
And if I can ping the router, then I
know I'm at least getting to it, and

497
00:23:36.920 --> 00:23:39.540
the next I can ping all
the way to my destination.

498
00:23:39.540 --> 00:23:43.330
And in my case, the destination is .11,
and I can ping it.

499
00:23:43.330 --> 00:23:46.136
What's nice here is you keep
trying each of these, and

500
00:23:46.136 --> 00:23:49.492
the one that fails is usually
the one that is the problem, right?

501
00:23:49.492 --> 00:23:53.764
Now, to make it easier, cuz there might
be a number of devices between you and

502
00:23:53.764 --> 00:23:56.985
the destination,
you can jump over here to trace route And

503
00:23:56.985 --> 00:23:59.176
trace route will do all of that for you.

504
00:23:59.176 --> 00:24:03.630
You type in who it is you wanna ping so
maybe I want to ping Google's DNS servers.

505
00:24:03.630 --> 00:24:05.870
I can't get to Google's DNS servers for
some reason.

506
00:24:05.870 --> 00:24:08.973
And when you do a trace route,
it doesn't just ping out to Google.

507
00:24:08.973 --> 00:24:12.919
It pings Google and
everything in between you and there.

508
00:24:12.919 --> 00:24:15.620
And so, when I trace that here it goes.

509
00:24:15.620 --> 00:24:18.490
It's hitting my router and
then it's taking the next step,

510
00:24:18.490 --> 00:24:20.690
which should be hitting
the firewall here in our building.

511
00:24:20.690 --> 00:24:23.430
And then the next step out on
to the Internet and beyond.

512
00:24:23.430 --> 00:24:26.100
And it looks like I'm
dying out right there,

513
00:24:26.100 --> 00:24:27.710
after my first little virtual router.

514
00:24:27.710 --> 00:24:29.470
So, I've got a network issue.

515
00:24:29.470 --> 00:24:30.620
Well, I kind of already knew that.

516
00:24:30.620 --> 00:24:32.300
My laptop's not responding right.

517
00:24:32.300 --> 00:24:36.810
So, if I were to go and
tweak this and try and fix it.

518
00:24:36.810 --> 00:24:38.560
I'm apparently not able to
get to the Internet, and

519
00:24:38.560 --> 00:24:41.700
I get an idea of where that
breaks down right there.

520
00:24:41.700 --> 00:24:44.500
Let me show you and
example where it doesn't break down.

521
00:24:44.500 --> 00:24:46.260
Actually, my router's finally came up.

522
00:24:46.260 --> 00:24:50.232
So here's our routing table; we completely
break our continuity in the episode.

523
00:24:50.232 --> 00:24:51.890
>> [LAUGH]
>> But here's our routing table.

524
00:24:51.890 --> 00:24:55.560
Where we can see the interfaces like
ethernet 3, ethernet 0 and the networks

525
00:24:55.560 --> 00:24:58.510
that are attached to them so we can
figure out who is being routed where.

526
00:24:58.510 --> 00:25:03.710
But what I wanted to show you is a trace
route out to like Google for example.

527
00:25:03.710 --> 00:25:05.030
>> There we go.
>> And there we go.

528
00:25:05.030 --> 00:25:07.070
So now, when that one reaches out,
I can see,

529
00:25:07.070 --> 00:25:09.260
I didn't have to pass through
all that many host to get there.

530
00:25:09.260 --> 00:25:13.840
I hit our router which is in
the racks behind me there.

531
00:25:13.840 --> 00:25:16.660
And then I jumped over to our
service provider, GRU and

532
00:25:16.660 --> 00:25:21.000
then they sent me up to Atlanta where it
turns out they're paired with Google.

533
00:25:21.000 --> 00:25:23.150
So I immediately hit Google's network.

534
00:25:23.150 --> 00:25:25.990
And then from Google's network,
they routed me around some servers and

535
00:25:25.990 --> 00:25:28.520
I finally got to wherever
it was I was going.

536
00:25:28.520 --> 00:25:30.660
If I had a problem I could
spot that problem in here.

537
00:25:30.660 --> 00:25:31.900
Now notice these stars?

538
00:25:31.900 --> 00:25:33.390
That usually means you hit a firewall and

539
00:25:33.390 --> 00:25:36.719
the firewall stopping you from doing
any further research in there.

540
00:25:36.719 --> 00:25:39.510
That happens when a lot of networks
are tightening up their security.

541
00:25:39.510 --> 00:25:43.490
But at a minimum, I was able to see that
I made it all the way to Google network.

542
00:25:43.490 --> 00:25:46.720
So if I'm having a problem connecting
to them right now then it's a problem

543
00:25:46.720 --> 00:25:47.750
on Google's network.

544
00:25:47.750 --> 00:25:49.420
>> Yeah.
>> Cuz I got that far, right?

545
00:25:49.420 --> 00:25:52.120
That's where this type
of tool can really help.

546
00:25:52.120 --> 00:25:55.070
All right, the other two tools
that I wanna mention is lookup.

547
00:25:55.070 --> 00:25:58.260
If you're doing a DNS lookup are you
actually getting an address so

548
00:25:58.260 --> 00:25:58.990
you can do that.

549
00:25:58.990 --> 00:26:02.510
I covered this in one of the earlier
shows so we can do a lookup and

550
00:26:02.510 --> 00:26:04.080
I'll give you a name to IP.

551
00:26:04.080 --> 00:26:05.200
And lastly, the port scans.

552
00:26:05.200 --> 00:26:09.940
So Daniel mentioned how do we know
what a particular system is running?

553
00:26:09.940 --> 00:26:12.357
How do I know if it's running FTP or

554
00:26:12.357 --> 00:26:16.440
whatever that you can do
a port scan of a server.

555
00:26:18.120 --> 00:26:21.580
And it will try and
find what protocols it's running.

556
00:26:21.580 --> 00:26:24.220
And so when I scan my server I
can see that it's running SSH,

557
00:26:24.220 --> 00:26:27.770
I can see it's running HTTP,
it's running HTTPs.

558
00:26:27.770 --> 00:26:31.330
I can get an idea of some of
the different things that it's running.

559
00:26:31.330 --> 00:26:32.360
Now be careful with this.

560
00:26:32.360 --> 00:26:34.660
On your network use the heck out of it,
right?

561
00:26:34.660 --> 00:26:37.510
But on the Internet doing a port
sweep like this is usually

562
00:26:37.510 --> 00:26:39.040
considered a reconnoissance attack.

563
00:26:39.040 --> 00:26:42.850
And so you'll usually get red-flagged and
your communications can get blocked.

564
00:26:42.850 --> 00:26:44.720
So, you don't wanna use
it out on the Internet.

565
00:26:44.720 --> 00:26:48.130
But on your local network it's a great way
of discovering what services, something is

566
00:26:48.130 --> 00:26:52.200
running and you'll only discover
a lot more than what you think right?

567
00:26:52.200 --> 00:26:54.470
So I mean, some of these like afpovertcp.

568
00:26:54.470 --> 00:26:59.200
All right, we know it's running Apple
file protocol cuz I got shared folders.

569
00:26:59.200 --> 00:27:03.410
But it's also running,
ldaps, and Kerberos, right?

570
00:27:03.410 --> 00:27:06.670
That's part of Apple's Open Directory,
so I know it's running that.

571
00:27:06.670 --> 00:27:08.610
But it's running 3com-tsmux.

572
00:27:09.850 --> 00:27:12.030
What's that?

573
00:27:12.030 --> 00:27:13.450
I actually have no idea.

574
00:27:13.450 --> 00:27:13.975
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

575
00:27:13.975 --> 00:27:14.605
>> So

576
00:27:14.605 --> 00:27:17.475
it's a multiplexor of some sort.
>> Yeah it's networking

577
00:27:17.475 --> 00:27:18.485
right?
>> So

578
00:27:18.485 --> 00:27:20.425
you know it's apparently being used for
something,

579
00:27:20.425 --> 00:27:23.075
I have to go and research that.
We might find that there's a service

580
00:27:23.075 --> 00:27:25.170
that's running that we don't want running.

581
00:27:25.170 --> 00:27:26.910
Or it might be mislabeled, right?

582
00:27:26.910 --> 00:27:29.630
Like this port might actually
be registered to 3com, but

583
00:27:29.630 --> 00:27:31.240
Apple might be using it for
something else.

584
00:27:31.240 --> 00:27:33.850
But we can go and research and
find out what that is and figure it out.

585
00:27:33.850 --> 00:27:35.340
And I'll to research that one,-
>> Yeah.

586
00:27:35.340 --> 00:27:36.370
>> I actually don't know what that one is.

587
00:27:36.370 --> 00:27:39.000
>> Yeah, at the very least,
if you realize you're not even using it,

588
00:27:39.000 --> 00:27:42.500
even if it's not causing you any problems
>> You don't want to just leave open

589
00:27:42.500 --> 00:27:43.340
ports on your system.

590
00:27:43.340 --> 00:27:45.440
So for security sake,
you can shut it down.

591
00:27:45.440 --> 00:27:46.860
>> Yeah, absolutely, yeah.

592
00:27:46.860 --> 00:27:50.070
So that's kind of how we go about
our trouble shooting to find out

593
00:27:50.070 --> 00:27:50.760
what's going on.

594
00:27:50.760 --> 00:27:55.070
Beyond that, you really, have to kind
of deal with your customized networks.

595
00:27:55.070 --> 00:27:58.820
So in my case, where I'm plugging in my
adapter and not getting an IP address.

596
00:27:58.820 --> 00:27:59.950
What I would do,

597
00:27:59.950 --> 00:28:03.700
just to give you an example of what
I'm going to do after the show.

598
00:28:03.700 --> 00:28:05.043
>> Yeah, [LAUGH].
>> Is I would go into my

599
00:28:05.043 --> 00:28:07.978
System Preferences and
I would go into Network.

600
00:28:07.978 --> 00:28:10.621
And I would pull up that
ethernet adaptor and

601
00:28:10.621 --> 00:28:14.058
see, all right,
I have a manually assigned IP address.

602
00:28:14.058 --> 00:28:15.890
But it wasn't showing up
in the Network Utility.

603
00:28:15.890 --> 00:28:17.960
So that means that I'm
probably getting a duplicate.

604
00:28:17.960 --> 00:28:20.040
This IP's probably in use somewhere else.

605
00:28:20.040 --> 00:28:24.850
So I can switch over to DHTP and
see if I get a dynamic address.

606
00:28:24.850 --> 00:28:27.060
Right, and
that may solve my problem right there.

607
00:28:27.060 --> 00:28:30.140
And now that adapter might start working,
so I got a dynamic address.

608
00:28:30.140 --> 00:28:33.945
And if I go back into
the Network Utility and go to Info, and

609
00:28:33.945 --> 00:28:38.305
I might have to close it and
open it again before it refreshes this.

610
00:28:38.305 --> 00:28:40.340
But still not showing the address there.

611
00:28:40.340 --> 00:28:43.260
So I'll probably have to close out of it,
but now I'm getting that address.

612
00:28:43.260 --> 00:28:46.120
And so
that connection should be working again.

613
00:28:46.120 --> 00:28:50.620
If that hadn't worked, my next stop
would have been the console, right?

614
00:28:50.620 --> 00:28:53.440
So if you launch the console application,
you can go in to your logs.

615
00:28:53.440 --> 00:28:55.765
And I can look into my logs and try and

616
00:28:55.765 --> 00:28:59.280
find what's going on with that network
connection, why it's not working.

617
00:28:59.280 --> 00:29:02.580
And look for errors in here that
are related to the network's hub system.

618
00:29:02.580 --> 00:29:05.030
That would be the next
step in troubleshooting.

619
00:29:05.030 --> 00:29:05.690
>> All right, Don.

620
00:29:05.690 --> 00:29:09.465
Well, we've covered a lot of resource
sharing in these three episodes.

621
00:29:09.465 --> 00:29:10.690
>> [LAUGH]
>> We didn't think it was gonna

622
00:29:10.690 --> 00:29:11.858
go that long ladies and gentlemen.

623
00:29:11.858 --> 00:29:15.228
[LAUGH] But it's a lot of great
information in there for you to figure out

624
00:29:15.228 --> 00:29:18.556
how to get people to be able to use
things that are from your computer.

625
00:29:18.556 --> 00:29:21.820
And to utilize resources
from their computer as well.

626
00:29:21.820 --> 00:29:24.680
And then, worse comes to worse,
a little troubleshooting thrown on for

627
00:29:24.680 --> 00:29:25.420
good measure.

628
00:29:25.420 --> 00:29:28.410
Don, we do thank you for
your insight on these topics.

629
00:29:28.410 --> 00:29:31.440
We thank our audience for watching but
looking at that clock, yeah,

630
00:29:31.440 --> 00:29:32.500
it's run out yet again.

631
00:29:32.500 --> 00:29:33.580
Thanks for watching everyone.

632
00:29:33.580 --> 00:29:36.590
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

633
00:29:36.590 --> 00:29:37.500
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

634
00:29:37.500 --> 00:29:38.838
>> We'll see you next time.

635
00:29:38.838 --> 00:29:44.875
[MUSIC]

636
00:29:44.875 --> 00:29:46.880
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explore expanding your Mac's capabilities through peripheral devices. They go over the different types of common peripheral devices like storage, input/output devices, and communications. They also cover driver support for 3rd party devices.
episodes.title: Peripheral Devices

00:01:03.150 --> 00:01:05.430
Different ways in which

00:01:05.430 --> 00:01:07.170
It's a laundry list, a litany,

00:01:07.170 --> 00:01:11.040
if you would, of different things that

And apparently you can't just jam one

So Don, you're here today to help us

But you can also flush the queue
from the System Preferences.

557
00:26:57.560 --> 00:27:00.692
When you go in your System Preferences,
and then the Printers.

558
00:27:00.692 --> 00:27:04.960
If there's a queue that's building up, you
have that option because you can choose

559
00:27:04.960 --> 00:27:08.320
the printer and you get this nice
button right here, Open Print Queue.

560
00:27:08.320 --> 00:27:12.260
And you can go in here and see the
graphical representation of that queue.

561
00:27:12.260 --> 00:27:15.679
And you can even pause the printer from
here, which is nice for testing, right?

562
00:27:15.679 --> 00:27:20.009
Because now, I can go,
I shouldn't let this menu go, in Print.

563
00:27:20.009 --> 00:27:24.366
And when I print to that printer, the job
is going to get sent to the printer and

564
00:27:24.366 --> 00:27:27.700
is gonna sit there,
stuck in the queue, right?

565
00:27:27.700 --> 00:27:30.975
And as administrator, I can come and
hit the X and get it out the queue.

566
00:27:30.975 --> 00:27:35.530
Or if I'm in the command line, like I am
here on the background, I can pull it up.

567
00:27:35.530 --> 00:27:40.420
And I can see these jobs getting deposited
in the queue and waiting for me to work.

568
00:27:40.420 --> 00:27:45.270
So see how that d00066-001 reappeared,
right?

569
00:27:45.270 --> 00:27:48.020
And so that's that print job waiting.

570
00:27:48.020 --> 00:27:51.810
And as I continue to send more print jobs,
right, so I'll just print again,

571
00:27:51.810 --> 00:27:55.926
and we'll send that one out.

572
00:27:55.926 --> 00:27:58.621
Right, so now,
there's a second job in the print queue.

573
00:27:58.621 --> 00:28:01.170
And if I come down here and look, now,

574
00:28:01.170 --> 00:28:05.800
I can see another one of those
d00 files that's been created.

575
00:28:05.800 --> 00:28:07.458
And you know what?
I thought it incremented the second

576
00:28:07.458 --> 00:28:10.890
number, but it has incremented that one,
so I had that a little bit backwards.

577
00:28:10.890 --> 00:28:11.493
That might be the page count.

578
00:28:11.493 --> 00:28:13.550
Let me, we will experiment here.

579
00:28:13.550 --> 00:28:14.139
I'm curious now.

580
00:28:14.139 --> 00:28:15.041
>> [LAUGH]
>> If I take it and

581
00:28:15.041 --> 00:28:19.871
tell it to send like more than one copy,
I'm gonna send four copies of this job and

582
00:28:19.871 --> 00:28:21.520
we start to send it.

583
00:28:21.520 --> 00:28:24.860
I'm not sure Apple's filename and
convention here, so I'm just curious.

584
00:28:24.860 --> 00:28:28.210
And take a look at that, and no.

585
00:28:28.210 --> 00:28:31.475
I have no idea what increment
that second part of the number.

586
00:28:31.475 --> 00:28:31.979
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

587
00:28:31.979 --> 00:28:32.479
>> It's increment in this part.

588
00:28:32.479 --> 00:28:34.079
>> That's what makes you wonder why they

589
00:28:34.079 --> 00:28:35.645
even have the other part.

590
00:28:35.645 --> 00:28:37.455
>> But there we go, so
that's the print queue.

591
00:28:37.455 --> 00:28:39.905
We don't normally have to interact
with it in the file system.

592
00:28:39.905 --> 00:28:43.465
Unless there was some job that was like
truly stuck in the print queue that you

593
00:28:43.465 --> 00:28:45.465
couldn't remove out from the printer.

594
00:28:45.465 --> 00:28:47.765
Usually, it's easier to just
delete the printer and re-add it.

595
00:28:47.765 --> 00:28:49.625
But if you've got a ton of
permissions configured and stuff,

596
00:28:49.625 --> 00:28:50.725
that would be a hassle.

597
00:28:50.725 --> 00:28:53.761
So instead, you can boot to recovery,
drop to a shell, and go and

598
00:28:53.761 --> 00:28:55.264
knock these files out of there.

599
00:28:55.264 --> 00:28:58.250
And then when you reboot, the queue will
be empty and you'll be back in business.

600
00:28:58.250 --> 00:28:59.450
And it's hard to do any
damage in the queue.

601
00:28:59.450 --> 00:29:01.983
Like if you will completely
delete the cups folder, right,

602
00:29:01.983 --> 00:29:03.334
just blow the whole thing away.

603
00:29:03.334 --> 00:29:06.990
When the system comes back up,
it'll recreate it and that would be fine.

604
00:29:06.990 --> 00:29:09.425
A little bit different if you blow away
where the PPDs are, that will be bad,

605
00:29:09.425 --> 00:29:10.003
>> [LAUGH]

606
00:29:10.003 --> 00:29:11.389
>> But blowing this folder away

607
00:29:11.389 --> 00:29:13.210
is really not a big of a deal.

608
00:29:13.210 --> 00:29:16.538
>> All right, Don, printers obviously
they're a part of our lives.

609
00:29:16.538 --> 00:29:20.037
It's like we said in the beginning of
the show, in a business environment,

610
00:29:20.037 --> 00:29:23.770
printers are gonna be a lifeblood thing
that people will really take seriously.

611
00:29:23.770 --> 00:29:25.690
So make sure that you understand
how to work with printers.

612
00:29:25.690 --> 00:29:28.791
Now, Don, I think you've done
a fantastic job of explaining each,

613
00:29:28.791 --> 00:29:32.428
every little facets that you're probably
going to have to deal with when it comes

614
00:29:32.428 --> 00:29:33.780
to printers inside of Mac OS.

615
00:29:33.780 --> 00:29:36.200
So hopefully,
you guys got a lot out of this episode.

616
00:29:36.200 --> 00:29:37.870
But as I look at our clock,
>> [LAUGH]

617
00:29:37.870 --> 00:29:39.650
>> We are well out of time for today.

618
00:29:39.650 --> 00:29:40.898
We do thank you for joining us,

619
00:29:40.898 --> 00:29:43.257
but it looks like it's time for
us to sign off for ITProTV.

620
00:29:43.257 --> 00:29:48.002
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie
>> and I'm Don Pezet.

621
00:29:48.002 --> 00:29:51.752
>> And we'll see you next time.

622
00:29:51.752 --> 00:29:53.920
[MUSIC].

623
00:29:53.920 --> 00:29:56.840
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don take on the task of troubleshooting issues with Mac OS Sierra if/when they arise. Here they will explore the process of troubleshooting starting with the boot process through to the loading of the operating system, login, finishing with logout. They also cover system recovery options and "hidden" system shortcuts and diagnostics.
episodes.title: System Troubleshooting
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.290 --> 00:00:01.234
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.234 --> 00:00:06.355
I'm your host, Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.355 --> 00:00:08.075
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.075 --> 00:00:12.057
>> You're watching ITPro TV.

5
00:00:12.057 --> 00:00:13.870
>> All right, greetings everyone.

6
00:00:13.870 --> 00:00:16.756
Welcome to another exciting
episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:16.756 --> 00:00:19.540
I'm your Daniel Lowrie and
in today's episode,

8
00:00:19.540 --> 00:00:22.270
well, we are continuing
on our ACSP series.

9
00:00:22.270 --> 00:00:25.890
So hopefully that's exactly what you're
looking for and you have found it.

10
00:00:25.890 --> 00:00:28.950
Joining us in the studio, yet
again, our good friend Don Pezet.

11
00:00:28.950 --> 00:00:31.491
Don is good to have you yet
again man, how is it going on today?

12
00:00:31.491 --> 00:00:34.101
>> I'm glad you're back and
I'm actually excited about this show and

13
00:00:34.101 --> 00:00:35.714
what we're ultimately be a second part.

14
00:00:35.714 --> 00:00:37.977
>> [LAUGH]
>> He's calling his shot.

15
00:00:37.977 --> 00:00:40.680
[LAUGH]
>> Because we're gonna go into some neat

16
00:00:40.680 --> 00:00:41.225
stuff here.

17
00:00:41.225 --> 00:00:45.832
And this is kinda where we separate,
what is it, the wheat from the chaff?

18
00:00:45.832 --> 00:00:46.981
>> Yes.

19
00:00:46.981 --> 00:00:48.740
>> The cream of the crop.

20
00:00:48.740 --> 00:00:52.000
Basically when you buy a Mac,
a lot of home users and

21
00:00:52.000 --> 00:00:54.420
individuals buy Macs because
they're very easy, right?

22
00:00:54.420 --> 00:00:55.780
And they just work, right?

23
00:00:55.780 --> 00:00:57.820
That was the motto for many, many years.

24
00:00:57.820 --> 00:01:01.060
But things do go wrong,
things don't always just work and

25
00:01:01.060 --> 00:01:03.598
sometimes we got to just get in and
troubleshoot and figure out what happened.

26
00:01:03.598 --> 00:01:08.050
Well Apple's kinda direction over the last
few years has really been to say,

27
00:01:08.050 --> 00:01:10.730
hey if something goes wrong,
just take it down to the Apple Store.

28
00:01:10.730 --> 00:01:12.180
Take it down to local Genius Bar,

29
00:01:12.180 --> 00:01:15.623
some high school zombie kid
will help you with the problem.

30
00:01:15.623 --> 00:01:18.612
And try and get it fixed up or
usually just erase it for you.

31
00:01:18.612 --> 00:01:19.749
And then off you go.

32
00:01:19.749 --> 00:01:20.840
That's kinda the plan.

33
00:01:20.840 --> 00:01:24.370
And that's fine for individuals,
but for businesses, for

34
00:01:24.370 --> 00:01:25.900
enterprises, that doesn't work out so
well.

35
00:01:25.900 --> 00:01:30.200
And you don't want to be carting machines
down to the Apple Store every other day.

36
00:01:30.200 --> 00:01:31.500
It becomes a bit of a challenge.

37
00:01:31.500 --> 00:01:35.710
So, we need to be able to troubleshoot and
resolve issues ourselves.

38
00:01:35.710 --> 00:01:39.190
And in this episode,
which is too much to fit in one episode,

39
00:01:39.190 --> 00:01:41.080
we're going to take a look at
some of the different tools and

40
00:01:41.080 --> 00:01:43.510
techniques that are available for
troubleshooting a Mac.

41
00:01:43.510 --> 00:01:46.924
And finding out what's going wrong and
getting things back in order.

42
00:01:46.924 --> 00:01:50.237
So we're going to pull back
the veil on some of the hidden

43
00:01:50.237 --> 00:01:54.979
behind the scenes stuff in macOS to get
a chance to see the underlying workings.

44
00:01:54.979 --> 00:01:58.029
And to see the things that we can do to
avoid having to make that trip down to

45
00:01:58.029 --> 00:01:59.410
the Apple Store.

46
00:01:59.410 --> 00:02:03.170
>> All right, well, Don, I guess the best
place to start would be in the beginning,

47
00:02:03.170 --> 00:02:08.840
Steve Jobs created Mac, and
we are going to start at the beginning.

48
00:02:08.840 --> 00:02:13.810
I open my Mac Book or
I hit the power button on my Mac, and

49
00:02:13.810 --> 00:02:16.650
it starts up and a process begins.

50
00:02:16.650 --> 00:02:18.880
I think that's probably the best place for
us to kick this off.

51
00:02:18.880 --> 00:02:19.920
>> Yeah, absolutely.

52
00:02:19.920 --> 00:02:23.450
And let me just show you here,
I'm going to take this Mac.

53
00:02:23.450 --> 00:02:28.429
And this is the Mac Mini,
we used way back in Episode 2 or

54
00:02:28.429 --> 00:02:31.160
something, when we were
showing how to install macOS.

55
00:02:31.160 --> 00:02:32.337
So this is running macOS Sierra.

56
00:02:32.337 --> 00:02:34.279
It's a clean install that really,

57
00:02:34.279 --> 00:02:37.720
I don't think I've installed
even a single app on this thing.

58
00:02:37.720 --> 00:02:38.848
So it's just a straight up one.

59
00:02:38.848 --> 00:02:41.712
I just cleared the little dialog boxes up
asking me to turn on auto update which is

60
00:02:41.712 --> 00:02:43.650
the first thing you see when
you login the first time.

61
00:02:43.650 --> 00:02:46.140
So this is pretty much a fresh and
clean system.

62
00:02:46.140 --> 00:02:50.526
And when you get a new Mac, and
you press that power button for

63
00:02:50.526 --> 00:02:54.411
the first time, and it boots up,
what all do you see?

64
00:02:54.411 --> 00:02:55.475
So I'm going to reboot this one here.

65
00:02:55.475 --> 00:02:58.529
I'm going to lose my signal, and then
it'll come up, and we're going to see,

66
00:02:58.529 --> 00:03:00.049
well first off, we're going to hear.

67
00:03:00.049 --> 00:03:03.295
When you turn on a Mac,
it makes that iconic Mac tone,

68
00:03:03.295 --> 00:03:06.670
that boom noise that
they call the Mac bong.

69
00:03:06.670 --> 00:03:09.967
>> It is a C major chord.

70
00:03:09.967 --> 00:03:10.921
>> A C major chord?

71
00:03:10.921 --> 00:03:11.527
>> Yes it is.

72
00:03:11.527 --> 00:03:12.208
>> Where did you learn that?

73
00:03:12.208 --> 00:03:14.770
>> I watched a documentary on Macs.

74
00:03:14.770 --> 00:03:16.690
>> All right, I call it the Wall-E sound.

75
00:03:16.690 --> 00:03:20.980
But when it turns on,
we see the little Apple logo and

76
00:03:20.980 --> 00:03:22.880
you see a little bar going across, right?

77
00:03:22.880 --> 00:03:26.350
Well, the bar is just telling you, hey,
the Mac is booting, wait a second.

78
00:03:26.350 --> 00:03:30.130
But in reality, in the background, there's
a lot that's going on behind the scenes.

79
00:03:30.130 --> 00:03:35.250
Actually five steps, five distinct steps,
that are going on during the boot process.

80
00:03:35.250 --> 00:03:37.470
And we're actually on step 3 already.

81
00:03:37.470 --> 00:03:41.615
And all I did was push a power button and
here's this Apple going.

82
00:03:41.615 --> 00:03:43.947
And in a moment it's gonna
progress a little further and

83
00:03:43.947 --> 00:03:45.095
we'll see a login screen.

84
00:03:45.095 --> 00:03:48.055
By the time we get to login screen,
that's step five.

85
00:03:48.055 --> 00:03:50.435
That it's actually completed
the boot process and

86
00:03:50.435 --> 00:03:53.705
gone through five distinct
phases to get us right to here.

87
00:03:53.705 --> 00:03:59.660
Now, the thing is something can go wrong
at any one of these five steps and

88
00:03:59.660 --> 00:04:02.880
cause things not to work
the way we expect them to.

89
00:04:02.880 --> 00:04:06.790
And if we can identify which of
those five steps it is that failed,

90
00:04:06.790 --> 00:04:11.710
we have different troubleshooting tools
available to us to try and resolve that.

91
00:04:11.710 --> 00:04:16.907
Now I will tell you that there does come a
time where it's not worth troubleshooting,

92
00:04:16.907 --> 00:04:17.430
right?

93
00:04:17.430 --> 00:04:23.290
And if it takes me an hour to figure
out which phase was failing, how

94
00:04:23.290 --> 00:04:26.455
long would it have taking me to just boot
to recovery and restore from time machine?

95
00:04:26.455 --> 00:04:27.220
>> [LAUGH]
>> Right?

96
00:04:27.220 --> 00:04:28.260
>> Five minutes?

97
00:04:28.260 --> 00:04:32.000
>> We laugh about it, but if you've
got a current time machine back up and

98
00:04:32.000 --> 00:04:34.400
you could boot to,
like Daniel said, five minutes.

99
00:04:34.400 --> 00:04:37.380
You kick off the restore,
the restore might take 20 minutes, so

100
00:04:37.380 --> 00:04:40.520
in 25 minutes you can have
the computer completely refreshed.

101
00:04:40.520 --> 00:04:44.170
If it was a software failure,
that's gonna fix it and

102
00:04:44.170 --> 00:04:45.490
you saved yourself a bunch of time.

103
00:04:45.490 --> 00:04:48.566
If it was a software failure, with
a hardware failure you've got a different

104
00:04:48.566 --> 00:04:51.160
problem and time machine's
not going to help you there.

105
00:04:51.160 --> 00:04:53.910
So what we'll talk a little
bit about hardware issues

106
00:04:53.910 --> 00:04:55.220
here later in this episode.

107
00:04:55.220 --> 00:05:00.840
But on the software side, if you got
a current time machine backup, nine

108
00:05:00.840 --> 00:05:04.480
times out of ten it's faster to restore
the time machine backup, if you got it.

109
00:05:04.480 --> 00:05:06.622
If you don't, if the time machine
backup is out of date and

110
00:05:06.622 --> 00:05:08.123
the user never even setup time machine.

111
00:05:08.123 --> 00:05:10.155
Like I never setup time
machine on this computer.

112
00:05:10.155 --> 00:05:12.563
Then that's not an option for me.

113
00:05:12.563 --> 00:05:17.306
And my only real options are to format and
reinstall macOS and

114
00:05:17.306 --> 00:05:22.250
lose all my data or
possibly I could boot into target mode.

115
00:05:22.250 --> 00:05:24.980
If I boot into target mode,
which we did into early episode, but

116
00:05:24.980 --> 00:05:27.100
you boot while holding
the letter T on the keyboard.

117
00:05:27.100 --> 00:05:30.805
And when you boot into target mode,
now it becomes an external hard drive.

118
00:05:30.805 --> 00:05:33.956
I could hook it up to another computer and
get my documents off of there, and

119
00:05:33.956 --> 00:05:36.819
then format it, and then re-install macOS,
and put my data back.

120
00:05:36.819 --> 00:05:38.240
So there's that option.

121
00:05:38.240 --> 00:05:40.924
But if we've got time machine or
even iCloud set up,

122
00:05:40.924 --> 00:05:43.059
a lot of time is just
wiping the machine and

123
00:05:43.059 --> 00:05:46.419
restoring can be a lot faster than
trying to troubleshoot it out.

124
00:05:46.419 --> 00:05:49.527
But, I'm kind of poo
pooing this whole episode.

125
00:05:49.527 --> 00:05:51.089
Don't watch the rest of this episode,
just restore and that's it.

126
00:05:51.089 --> 00:05:52.220
>> Just go to time machine.

127
00:05:52.220 --> 00:05:53.560
>> But it is a reality.

128
00:05:53.560 --> 00:05:55.520
That is an option and I do it myself.

129
00:05:55.520 --> 00:06:00.330
I work with computers every single day and
when I go home at the end of the day,

130
00:06:00.330 --> 00:06:01.140
I want to relax.

131
00:06:01.140 --> 00:06:03.930
I might want to use a computer, but
I don't want to troubleshoot a computer.

132
00:06:03.930 --> 00:06:05.880
I don't want to work on it,
just make it work.

133
00:06:05.880 --> 00:06:09.357
So I'll restore it at the drop of the hat,
if I think something's wrong.

134
00:06:09.357 --> 00:06:11.900
>> I might not be keeping
time machine backups.

135
00:06:11.900 --> 00:06:14.392
Maybe I'm living life in the fast lane.

136
00:06:14.392 --> 00:06:18.500
I said, time machine that's not for
me, so I might not have that option.

137
00:06:18.500 --> 00:06:20.960
>> Yeah, and that is a reality.

138
00:06:20.960 --> 00:06:23.360
So, let's talk about the boot process and

139
00:06:23.360 --> 00:06:25.920
what's going on at each of these
stages and see what we can do.

140
00:06:27.050 --> 00:06:29.444
When you push the power button,
on your Mac,

141
00:06:29.444 --> 00:06:32.349
you're entering the first
phase of the boot process.

142
00:06:32.349 --> 00:06:36.820
Now, first phase is just called
the firmware, or boot ROM.

143
00:06:36.820 --> 00:06:38.480
Apple just calls it the firmware.

144
00:06:38.480 --> 00:06:41.560
Basically inside your Mac is
a motherboard, and on the motherboard,

145
00:06:41.560 --> 00:06:45.130
there is a chip somewhere which
is usually called a BIOS chip,

146
00:06:45.130 --> 00:06:47.380
a Basic Input/Output Operating System.

147
00:06:47.380 --> 00:06:52.220
And what that BIOS chip is responsible for
doing is enabling all your hardware.

148
00:06:52.220 --> 00:06:54.060
So when you push the power button,

149
00:06:54.060 --> 00:06:56.530
you're telling the power supply
to send power to the motherboard.

150
00:06:56.530 --> 00:06:57.970
The motherboard wakes up.

151
00:06:57.970 --> 00:07:02.900
Then the motherboard wakes up the CPU and
BIOS chip.

152
00:07:02.900 --> 00:07:06.900
And the BIOS chip then reads itself
into RAM, so the RAM wakes up also.

153
00:07:06.900 --> 00:07:08.710
And then once it's in RAM,

154
00:07:08.710 --> 00:07:11.560
it's able to start initializing
the rest of the hardware.

155
00:07:11.560 --> 00:07:15.900
And to start the quest to find an
operating system on your computer, right?

on your Mac, you get your Apple logo.

605
00:28:43.240 --> 00:28:46.919
The little bar starts to go across and
then you don't get to a login screen.

606
00:28:48.140 --> 00:28:51.790
I saw the Apple logo, so that means that
the booter was doing its job, right?

607
00:28:51.790 --> 00:28:54.170
And that it was looking to the hard drive.

608
00:28:54.170 --> 00:28:57.120
And if it didn't find boot.efi, it would
have got the question mark on the screen.

609
00:28:57.120 --> 00:29:01.220
But I got the Apple logo, it started
to load, and then it freezes, or

610
00:29:01.220 --> 00:29:03.890
it dies before we get to a login screen.

611
00:29:03.890 --> 00:29:05.170
That's important, right?

612
00:29:05.170 --> 00:29:07.470
If you don't get to a login screen,

613
00:29:07.470 --> 00:29:12.320
then it's likely a failure right here
in phase four, because it's launchd.

614
00:29:12.320 --> 00:29:14.510
Launchd is supposed to run phase five.

615
00:29:14.510 --> 00:29:16.700
Phase five is the login phase.

616
00:29:16.700 --> 00:29:21.290
And the login phase runs
a service called login window.

617
00:29:21.290 --> 00:29:25.090
And so if we look here,
in my list of processes,

618
00:29:25.090 --> 00:29:27.790
I should find that in here somewhere,
the login window.

619
00:29:27.790 --> 00:29:31.010
Even afer you log in,
it's still running in the background.

620
00:29:31.010 --> 00:29:32.960
Because you might have things
like fast user switching,

621
00:29:32.960 --> 00:29:34.390
where you need to go
back to the login window.

622
00:29:34.390 --> 00:29:37.060
And so here it is, I can find it,
loginwindow, right?

623
00:29:37.060 --> 00:29:40.660
That's the actual login window that
let me log into this stinkin' thing.

624
00:29:40.660 --> 00:29:43.420
And if I look, it's process id 123.

625
00:29:43.420 --> 00:29:48.411
So the kernel and ultimately launchd

626
00:29:48.411 --> 00:29:53.340
had to run 122 other programs.

627
00:29:53.340 --> 00:29:55.273
Well, I guess launchd counts as one, so

628
00:29:55.273 --> 00:29:58.680
121 other programs and
any one of those could have failed and

629
00:29:58.680 --> 00:30:02.730
stopped me from getting the login and
that would have been in phase four.

630
00:30:02.730 --> 00:30:08.450
But once the login window runs, now I'm
ready to login and that's phase five.

631
00:30:08.450 --> 00:30:12.200
And we troubleshoot problems in phase four
differently than we troubleshoot problems

632
00:30:12.200 --> 00:30:13.150
in phase five.

633
00:30:13.150 --> 00:30:15.170
So, I wanna show the different
techniques that we've got.

634
00:30:15.170 --> 00:30:18.280
That we've got what's called Safe Boot and
Safe Mode.

635
00:30:18.280 --> 00:30:19.370
And they're easy to confuse.

636
00:30:19.370 --> 00:30:21.480
They're both on the exam and
they're both in real life.

637
00:30:21.480 --> 00:30:22.726
So we need to learn how they work.

638
00:30:22.726 --> 00:30:26.910
So, I wanna talk a bit about those to see
how we would troubleshoot phase three and

639
00:30:26.910 --> 00:30:28.500
Phase four and phase five.

640
00:30:28.500 --> 00:30:31.430
But I know we're low on time, so
that I think is gonna have to wait for

641
00:30:31.430 --> 00:30:32.360
good old part two.

642
00:30:32.360 --> 00:30:35.040
>> All right, well, part two's
gonna be action-packed, definitely.

643
00:30:35.040 --> 00:30:37.900
Don, it's interesting stuff thus far,
I can't wait to see what else you have

644
00:30:37.900 --> 00:30:40.940
in store for us when it comes
to troubleshooting our Macs.

645
00:30:40.940 --> 00:30:44.440
Definitely join us back for that part two,
and see how that works out.

646
00:30:44.440 --> 00:30:46.960
Well, like Don said, we're kind
of out of time for this episode.

647
00:30:46.960 --> 00:30:49.142
So we're gonna go ahead and
call it a day, thanks for watching.

648
00:30:49.142 --> 00:30:50.522
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

649
00:30:50.522 --> 00:30:51.539
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

650
00:30:51.539 --> 00:30:53.084
>> And we'll see you next time.

651
00:30:53.084 --> 00:30:58.996
[MUSIC]

652
00:30:58.996 --> 00:31:02.515
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don take on the task of troubleshooting issues with Mac OS Sierra if/when they arise. Here they will explore the process of troubleshooting starting with the boot process through to the loading of the operating system, login, finishing with logout. They also cover system recovery options and "hidden" system shortcuts and diagnostics.
episodes.title: System Troubleshooting Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:06.050
Welcome to ITPro.TV,
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.050 --> 00:00:08.401
>> [MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.401 --> 00:00:12.291
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

4
00:00:12.291 --> 00:00:12.934
>> All right,

5
00:00:12.934 --> 00:00:17.124
greetings everyone and welcome back
to another great episode of ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:17.124 --> 00:00:21.482
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie, and
in today's episode, well, we're continuing

7
00:00:21.482 --> 00:00:25.312
with more on that ASP series,
specifically looking at troubleshooting.

8
00:00:25.312 --> 00:00:27.995
Joining us back in the studio yet
again, our good friend Mr.

9
00:00:27.995 --> 00:00:29.530
Don Pezet to help us out with that.

10
00:00:29.530 --> 00:00:30.340
Don, welcome back, sir.

11
00:00:30.340 --> 00:00:30.840
How's it going today?

12
00:00:30.840 --> 00:00:32.317
>> Hey, thanks for having me back, Daniel.

13
00:00:32.317 --> 00:00:33.140
In the last episode,

14
00:00:33.140 --> 00:00:35.850
we were talking about the boot
process that Mac goes through, right?

15
00:00:35.850 --> 00:00:39.100
We went through the five step boot process
that I'm sure we've all committed to

16
00:00:39.100 --> 00:00:40.186
memory at this point.

17
00:00:40.186 --> 00:00:43.930
But just to kinda recap,
when you press that power button,

18
00:00:43.930 --> 00:00:46.730
you go through five different
steps of things happening.

19
00:00:46.730 --> 00:00:49.940
And we go from the bootrom or the
firmware, that's kinda that first step.

20
00:00:49.940 --> 00:00:53.050
And then that takes us to our second
step which is the booter, right?

21
00:00:53.050 --> 00:00:56.410
Once it finds the EFI firmware on
the hard drive and it fires that up.

22
00:00:56.410 --> 00:00:57.610
That moves us to the third step,

23
00:00:57.610 --> 00:01:01.300
which is the kernel, the actual
operating system beginning to launch.

24
00:01:01.300 --> 00:01:04.910
Then that takes us to the two steps that
I wanna focus on here in this episode.

25
00:01:04.910 --> 00:01:08.980
Which is launchd, right, the launcher
kicks in and starts running programs.

26
00:01:08.980 --> 00:01:12.850
And then the final step, which is
the login window, is presented and

27
00:01:12.850 --> 00:01:14.280
we're able to log in.

28
00:01:14.280 --> 00:01:17.070
Now, in the earlier steps
troubleshooting is really challenging

29
00:01:17.070 --> 00:01:18.950
because the operating system is broken.

30
00:01:18.950 --> 00:01:23.000
But when you have issues with launchd, or
you have issues with the login window,

31
00:01:23.000 --> 00:01:25.320
by that point technically your
operating system is not broken.

32
00:01:25.320 --> 00:01:28.990
It is running, but
something is going wrong, and stopping it.

33
00:01:28.990 --> 00:01:32.960
And nine times out of ten that something
is going wrong is not Apple's fault.

34
00:01:32.960 --> 00:01:35.810
It's normally third party software,right?

35
00:01:35.810 --> 00:01:40.047
When you have launchd running, part of
what it does is launches all the drivers

36
00:01:40.047 --> 00:01:43.141
and things that are a part of
what a third party presents.

37
00:01:43.141 --> 00:01:45.800
All the kernel extensions and
all that other good stuff.

38
00:01:45.800 --> 00:01:50.790
And if there is a bad kernel extension
written, it can freeze the system.

39
00:01:50.790 --> 00:01:53.460
And you'll know it's
a launchd program if you

40
00:01:53.460 --> 00:01:55.800
don't even get to a login window, right.

41
00:01:55.800 --> 00:01:57.540
If you don't get to the login window,

42
00:01:57.540 --> 00:02:00.480
then there's something going
on on the launchd side.

43
00:02:00.480 --> 00:02:03.360
But if you get to the login window,
and you type in your password, and

44
00:02:03.360 --> 00:02:06.510
you hit the button to log in,
and then something goes wrong

45
00:02:06.510 --> 00:02:10.130
before you get to your desktop,
then you know it's a login window problem.

46
00:02:10.130 --> 00:02:11.652
Now, why does that matter?

47
00:02:11.652 --> 00:02:13.160
Well launchd and

48
00:02:13.160 --> 00:02:18.155
login window both are responsible for
launching other applications.

49
00:02:18.155 --> 00:02:22.140
Launchd is launching all the applications
that run in the background, the daemons.

50
00:02:22.140 --> 00:02:25.270
The Unix Services that run in
the background on your system.

51
00:02:25.270 --> 00:02:28.172
The login window is running the
applications that are tied to your user

52
00:02:28.172 --> 00:02:28.967
account, right?

53
00:02:28.967 --> 00:02:31.504
Every user account has startup
items that can launch, and

54
00:02:31.504 --> 00:02:33.640
any one of those can cause a problem.

55
00:02:33.640 --> 00:02:36.250
And so on this episode I wanna show
you guys how to troubleshoot that.

56
00:02:36.250 --> 00:02:37.377
How to figure out and

57
00:02:37.377 --> 00:02:41.685
fix launchd as well as the login window
to make it where you're able to get in,

58
00:02:41.685 --> 00:02:46.158
login, and work on the system again even
though it isn't quite working right.

59
00:02:46.158 --> 00:02:47.175
So That's what we got before us.

60
00:02:47.175 --> 00:02:50.980
>> All right Don well, that being said,
which one of these should we tackle first?

61
00:02:50.980 --> 00:02:52.230
Probably launchd right?

62
00:02:52.230 --> 00:02:53.310
>> Yeah, well, let's start with launchd.

63
00:02:53.310 --> 00:02:55.570
So, remember the scenario,
that's what's important here.

64
00:02:55.570 --> 00:02:56.700
You push the power button,

65
00:02:56.700 --> 00:03:00.160
the apple logo comes up,
the little bar starts scrolling across.

66
00:03:00.160 --> 00:03:02.730
And then, something happens.

67
00:03:02.730 --> 00:03:03.700
It just sits there.

68
00:03:03.700 --> 00:03:07.310
It sits there and you never actually
get to a login window, right.

69
00:03:07.310 --> 00:03:08.360
That's our indicator.

70
00:03:08.360 --> 00:03:10.030
We don't get a question
mark on the screen,

71
00:03:10.030 --> 00:03:12.780
that would indicate a problem with
the boot process or the hard drive.

72
00:03:12.780 --> 00:03:14.500
But we actually see the Apple logo.

73
00:03:14.500 --> 00:03:16.690
We see the bar progressing and
then it stops, but

74
00:03:16.690 --> 00:03:18.380
we don't get anywhere, all right.

75
00:03:18.380 --> 00:03:21.770
Well, what you can do
is one of two things.

76
00:03:21.770 --> 00:03:24.290
The first thing is you can try and
get an idea of where it stopped.

77
00:03:24.290 --> 00:03:27.600
The problem with figuring out where it
stopped is you don't really get to see.

78
00:03:27.600 --> 00:03:31.460
You see an apple and a little bar going
across the bottom, right, it's all hidden.

79
00:03:31.460 --> 00:03:35.320
When you boot your Mac, you can actually
boot into what's called verbose mode,

80
00:03:35.320 --> 00:03:37.060
where it doesn't show the apple,

81
00:03:37.060 --> 00:03:40.500
where it actually shows stuff
scrolling across on the screen.

82
00:03:40.500 --> 00:03:44.490
Let me show you on my Mac here, which
is just at a black a screen right now.

83
00:03:44.490 --> 00:03:46.240
But I'm gonna power on my Mac,

84
00:03:46.240 --> 00:03:51.380
and when I do it I'm gonna hold
command V on my keyboard, all right.

85
00:03:51.380 --> 00:03:55.890
So I'm gonna push the power button and
hit command V.

86
00:03:55.890 --> 00:03:57.500
Now while I'm holding command V,

87
00:03:57.500 --> 00:04:01.380
the system is gonna recognize that,
and when it boots,

88
00:04:01.380 --> 00:04:04.890
it's gonna boot into verbose mode,
unless I missed it which apparently I did.

89
00:04:04.890 --> 00:04:07.460
So see how we got the little bar?

90
00:04:07.460 --> 00:04:09.710
That bar is not terribly informative,
is it?

91
00:04:09.710 --> 00:04:12.640
It's not really telling me a whole a lot
about what's going on in the system.

92
00:04:12.640 --> 00:04:17.156
So what I'm gonna have to do is well,
I'll have to power back off and try again.

93
00:04:17.156 --> 00:04:18.874
I must have turned my keyboard off,
there we go.

94
00:04:18.874 --> 00:04:20.810
All right, so let's try this again,
we'll go ahead and power that off.

95
00:04:22.130 --> 00:04:25.320
And we'll power it back on again,
holding that command V.

96
00:04:25.320 --> 00:04:29.360
And command V doesn't change
the boot process one single bit.

97
00:04:29.360 --> 00:04:33.664
All it does, [SOUND] is it
says don't show me that apple.

98
00:04:33.664 --> 00:04:36.230
Instead, show me what's really going on,
all right?

99
00:04:36.230 --> 00:04:39.500
And that's nice because if
the boot process freezes, right,

100
00:04:39.500 --> 00:04:41.460
there goes that text rattling by.

101
00:04:41.460 --> 00:04:45.978
If the boot process freezes, I can at
least see what it was doing when it froze,

102
00:04:45.978 --> 00:04:46.673
all right?

103
00:04:46.673 --> 00:04:48.313
Now, all of this text,

104
00:04:48.313 --> 00:04:53.650
a lot of it is just kind of information
that doesn't necessarily benefit us.

105
00:04:53.650 --> 00:04:55.380
You know,
it's just rattling by as it does things.

106
00:04:55.380 --> 00:04:59.020
Sometimes there's errors in here that
are okay, right, that it expects to have.

107
00:04:59.020 --> 00:05:02.470
But if it freezes we get an idea of
the last step that it went through, and

108
00:05:02.470 --> 00:05:04.630
then we can try and
trouble shoot from there.

109
00:05:04.630 --> 00:05:07.990
But if everything goes correct,
it gets through it and

110
00:05:07.990 --> 00:05:12.000
then it goes into the boot and
we get our login window, all right.

111
00:05:12.000 --> 00:05:16.840
So verbose mode helps us
to see where we were at.

112
00:05:16.840 --> 00:05:18.930
I don't normally mess around with
verbose mode because most of

113
00:05:18.930 --> 00:05:21.960
the time the information you get there is
really just useful to Apple tech support.

114
00:05:21.960 --> 00:05:23.596
So we're trying to fix it on our own.

115
00:05:23.596 --> 00:05:26.770
The verbose mode is not gonna
quite get us there, all right.

116
00:05:26.770 --> 00:05:30.460
But what I like to do is to boot
without all the third party stuff.

117
00:05:30.460 --> 00:05:32.780
Cuz the third party stuff is
usually what our problem is.

118
00:05:32.780 --> 00:05:36.688
And so that's another thing that we
can do when we boot this system up,

119
00:05:36.688 --> 00:05:38.957
is you can do what's called a safe boot.

120
00:05:38.957 --> 00:05:40.860
I'm gonna shut this back down.

121
00:05:40.860 --> 00:05:43.850
And when you do a normal boot,
it's gonna boot up and

122
00:05:43.850 --> 00:05:46.920
it's gonna load all the third
party drivers and other things.

123
00:05:46.920 --> 00:05:50.300
But if you do a safe boot,
safe boot will not.

124
00:05:50.300 --> 00:05:55.330
Safe boot will load the official Apple
software and not any third party software.

125
00:05:55.330 --> 00:05:58.700
And more importantly, it will clear
the cache of any third party stuff.

126
00:05:58.700 --> 00:06:00.980
So any temporary files and
other things that have been generated,

127
00:06:00.980 --> 00:06:05.900
it will flush that out and
give you a good, clean, safe boot.

128
00:06:05.900 --> 00:06:07.444
>> So it's all about minimalistic,

129
00:06:07.444 --> 00:06:10.808
trying to just keep only what you need
to get the operating system running.

130
00:06:10.808 --> 00:06:13.920
And therefore if it's a operating system
problem you'll know because it won't boot

131
00:06:13.920 --> 00:06:15.381
>> Right, if we do a safe boot and

132
00:06:15.381 --> 00:06:19.130
we get to a login window, we know the
problem is with the third party driver.

133
00:06:19.130 --> 00:06:20.163
And you can boot to recovery and

134
00:06:20.163 --> 00:06:22.166
you can delete the third party
kernel extensions, right?

135
00:06:22.166 --> 00:06:25.585
They're in /library/extensions, you can
go in there and you can delete them out.

136
00:06:25.585 --> 00:06:29.305
But if you do a safe boot and it still
won't log in, then you know you've got

137
00:06:29.305 --> 00:06:32.405
a problem with the operating system and
you need to go in and do a repair.

138
00:06:32.405 --> 00:06:37.345
So, if I press power and hold the Shift
key on my keyboard this time,

139
00:06:38.795 --> 00:06:41.178
[SOUND] All right, so
I'm just gonna hold the Shift key.

140
00:06:41.178 --> 00:06:42.970
The Shift key is the secret, right?

141
00:06:42.970 --> 00:06:46.276
So as soon as you hear that tone,
you hold that Shift key and

142
00:06:46.276 --> 00:06:48.246
now it's booting into safe mode.

143
00:06:48.246 --> 00:06:49.903
It looks very different, doesn't it?

144
00:06:49.903 --> 00:06:51.260
>> [LAUGH]
>> It doesn't.

145
00:06:51.260 --> 00:06:52.790
>> It doesn't look different at all.

146
00:06:52.790 --> 00:06:54.970
It's just leaving things off.

147
00:06:54.970 --> 00:06:55.660
So when you boot,

148
00:06:55.660 --> 00:06:58.478
sometimes it can be difficult to tell
if you booted into safe mode or not.

149
00:06:58.478 --> 00:07:01.379
But it's leaving off the third
party drivers, the third party

150
00:07:01.379 --> 00:07:04.860
kernel extensions in the software,
so it's just booting the Apple side.

151
00:07:04.860 --> 00:07:08.790
And if I do this and I get to a login
window, well, I may have already fixed

152
00:07:08.790 --> 00:07:11.450
the problem by flushing the caches
of that third party software.

153
00:07:11.450 --> 00:07:12.670
But it may still not have.

154
00:07:12.670 --> 00:07:14.811
I might need to boot to recovery and
delete the third party stuff.

155
00:07:14.811 --> 00:07:19.360
We're holding shift key after
the tone does safe boot.

156
00:07:19.360 --> 00:07:22.170
Now there's another
technology called safe mode.

157
00:07:22.170 --> 00:07:25.010
Safe mode sounds a lot like safe boot.

158
00:07:25.010 --> 00:07:29.610
The difference is safe boot is
designed for launchd, right?

159
00:07:29.610 --> 00:07:31.310
For before we log in.

160
00:07:31.310 --> 00:07:34.650
Safe mode is designed for after we log in.

161
00:07:34.650 --> 00:07:38.160
When you log in, you've got startup
items that are tied to your user, right?

162
00:07:38.160 --> 00:07:39.830
If we look at my laptop, for example.

163
00:07:39.830 --> 00:07:41.730
Let me go pull up my user account.

164
00:07:41.730 --> 00:07:44.700
If I go into System Preferences and
Users and Groups, and

165
00:07:44.700 --> 00:07:48.030
I take my user account here and
I look at login items.

166
00:07:48.030 --> 00:07:50.900
When I login,
look at all the stuff that runs, right?

167
00:07:50.900 --> 00:07:54.690
Viscosity, it's a VPN client, Moon,
that's a window manager that I use.

168
00:07:54.690 --> 00:07:56.833
VMware Fusion Start Menu,
which I never use.

169
00:07:56.833 --> 00:08:00.172
Dropbox, Undock,
these are all programs I have that run.

170
00:08:00.172 --> 00:08:03.732
Some of which I've uninstalled, I don't
have Odrive anymore But it's got a little,

171
00:08:03.732 --> 00:08:06.392
yellow triangle over here telling
me it can't find it, right?

172
00:08:06.392 --> 00:08:08.740
So I really shouldn't have that
in there cuz I don't have it.

173
00:08:08.740 --> 00:08:11.666
And this one that's got a GYD or
something, I don't even know what that is,

174
00:08:11.666 --> 00:08:13.972
but it doesn't exist because
